paraphrased: For patients with HCM, TEE may be beneficial when TTE does not provide sufficient information for clinical decisions about medical treatment, and in cases such as planning myectomy, ruling out a subaortic membrane or MR due to structural issues with the mitral valve apparatus, or evaluating the suitability for alcohol septal ablation.

original: For frozen and thawed tissue and between the toes and fingers, bulky, clean, dry gauze or sterile cotton dressings should be applied. Circumfer- ential dressings should be wrapped loosely to allow for swelling without placing pressure on the underlying tissue.
paraphrased: For tissue that has been frozen and thawed, as well as areas between the toes and fingers, apply thick, clean, dry gauze or sterile cotton dressings. Wrap these dressings loosely around the area to accommodate swelling without exerting pressure on the tissue beneath.

original: It may be reasonable to give ibuprofen to a person with frostbite to prevent further tissue damage and to treat pain.
paraphrased: Administering ibuprofen to an individual with frostbite might be advisable to alleviate pain and prevent additional tissue damage.

original: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnosis of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhancing agent is reason- able, particularly if other imaging modalities such as CMR are not readily available or are contraindi- cated.44,45
paraphrased: For patients with HCM where the diagnosis of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or unusual hypertrophy patterns is uncertain on TTE, it is reasonable to use an intravenous ultrasound contrast agent, especially if other imaging methods like CMR are unavailable or contraindicated.

original: In adults who do not tolerate statin therapy and who have LDL-C >100 mg/dL and elevated car- diovascular risk, treatment with bempedoic acid to reduce the risk of a first stroke is not well estab- lished.246
paraphrased: For adults unable to tolerate statins, with LDL-C levels exceeding 100 mg/dL and increased cardiovascular risk, the use of bempedoic acid to lower the risk of an initial stroke is not well supported.

original: In adults without CVD who qualify for treatment with lipid-lowering therapy, according to the 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of CVD (eg, 20–75 years of age with LDL-C level >190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], 10-year ASCVD risk ≥20%, or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%–<20% plus ≥1 risk enhancers), who cannot reach goals or cannot tolerate other therapies such as statins, the benefit of treatment with alirocumab or evo- locumab compared with other active lipid-lowering therapy for the reduction of the risk of a first stroke is uncertain.245
paraphrased: For adults without cardiovascular disease who meet the criteria for lipid-lowering therapy per the 2019 ACC/AHA guidelines on primary prevention of CVD (such as those aged 20–75 with LDL-C levels over 190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], a 10-year ASCVD risk of 20% or higher, or a 10-year ASCVD risk between 7.5% and 20% with at least one risk enhancer), and who are unable to achieve targets or tolerate other treatments like statins, the advantage of using alirocumab or evolocumab over other active lipid-lowering therapies for reducing the risk of a first stroke remains uncertain.

original: In adults with moderate or low intake of long-chain omega-3 fatty acid, supplementation is not recom- mended to reduce the risk of a first stroke.92
paraphrased: For adults with moderate or low consumption of long-chain omega-3 fatty acids, taking supplements is not advised to lower the risk of an initial stroke.

original: When discussing treatment and prevention with patients who have CCD, it is recommended that the health care team discuss out-of-pocket costs for medications at the time of initiating a new med- ication and at least annually thereafter to preempt cost-related nonadherence.1–6
paraphrased: For patients with CCD, it is advised that healthcare providers address the out-of-pocket expenses for medications when starting a new medication and at least once a year thereafter to prevent nonadherence due to cost.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and symptomatic extracranial carotid stenosis who are scheduled for carotid artery stent- ing (CAS) or CEA, procedures should be performed by operators with established periprocedural stroke and mortality rates of <6% to reduce the risk of surgical adverse events.370
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke or TIA with symptomatic extracranial carotid stenosis who are planned for carotid artery stenting (CAS) or carotid endarterectomy (CEA), it is recommended that these procedures be conducted by operators whose periprocedural stroke and mortality rates are below 6% to minimize the risk of surgical complications.

original: In patients with carotid artery stenosis and a TIA or stroke, intensive medical therapy, with antiplatelet therapy, lipid-lowering therapy, and treatment of hypertension, is recom- mended to reduce stroke risk.210
paraphrased: For patients with carotid artery stenosis who have experienced a TIA or stroke, it is advised to implement intensive medical treatment, including antiplatelet therapy, lipid-lowering therapy, and hypertension management, to decrease the risk of stroke.

original: In patients with rheumatic MS and a discrepancy between resting echocardiographic findings and clinical symptoms, exercise testing with Doppler or invasive hemodynamic assessment is recommended to evaluate symptomatic response, exercise capacity, and the response of the mean mitral gradient and pulmonary artery pressure.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis who exhibit a mismatch between resting echocardiographic results and clinical symptoms, it is advised to perform exercise testing with Doppler or invasive hemodynamic evaluation to assess symptomatic response, exercise capacity, and changes in the mean mitral gradient and pulmonary artery pressure.

original: It is not recommended for first aid providers to debride blisters associated with frostbite. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: First aid providers are advised against debriding blisters caused by frostbite.

original: In patients with known CVD being considered for NCS, a validated risk-prediction tool can be useful to estimate the risk of perioperative MACE.1–4
paraphrased: For patients with established cardiovascular disease undergoing evaluation for non-cardiac surgery, employing a validated risk-prediction tool can help assess the likelihood of perioperative major adverse cardiac events.

original: In all patients, screening for cigarette smoking, use of other forms of tobacco, use of electronic nicotine delivery systems such as electronic ciga- rettes (e-cigarettes) and vapes, and environmental tobacco smoke exposure (secondhand smoke exposure) is effective to inform stroke risk and target cessation interventions.254–270 Prevention intervention
paraphrased: Screening for cigarette smoking, other tobacco use, electronic nicotine delivery systems like e-cigarettes and vapes, and exposure to secondhand smoke is effective in assessing stroke risk and guiding cessation efforts in all patients.

original: In patients with rheumatic MS and 1) AF, 2) a prior embolic event, or 3) an LA thrombus, anticoagulation with a VKA is indicated.1–7
paraphrased: For patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis who have atrial fibrillation, a history of embolic events, or a left atrial thrombus, anticoagulation with a vitamin K antagonist is recommended.

original: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.15,19,20,22–25
paraphrased: In asymptomatic patients with HCM lacking a resting or inducible outflow tract peak gradient of ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, it is reasonable to use exercise TTE to detect and measure dynamic LVOTO.

original: For patients suspected of having HCM in whom echocardiography is inconclusive, CMR imaging is indicated for diagnostic clarification.1–7
paraphrased: If echocardiography results are inconclusive in patients suspected of having HCM, CMR imaging should be used for further diagnostic clarity.

original: For people with exertional hyperthermia or heatstroke, first aid providers should move the individual from the hot environment, remove excess clothing, limit exertion, and provide cool liquids if the person is able to swallow.
paraphrased: For individuals experiencing exertional hyperthermia or heatstroke, first aid responders should relocate them to a cooler area, remove unnecessary clothing, reduce physical activity, and offer cool fluids if they can swallow.

original: In patients ≥70 years of age with stroke or TIA in whom carotid revascularization is being considered, it is reasonable to select CEA over CAS to reduce the periprocedural stroke rate.371
paraphrased: For patients aged 70 and older with stroke or TIA who are candidates for carotid revascularization, choosing CEA instead of CAS is advisable to lower the risk of stroke during the procedure.

original: In patients with rheumatic MS and AF with a rapid ventricular response, heart rate control can be beneficial.8
paraphrased: For patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation with a fast ventricular rate, controlling the heart rate may be advantageous.

original: In patients undergoing elevated-risk NCS, a structured assessment of functional capac­ ity (such as the Duke Activity Status Index [DASI]) is reasonable to stratify the risk of perioperative adverse cardiovascular events.1–8
paraphrased: For patients facing high-risk non-cardiac surgery, it is advisable to evaluate functional capacity using tools like the Duke Activity Status Index (DASI) to assess the risk of adverse cardiovascular events during the perioperative period.

original: For people with heatstroke (heat illness with altered mental status), first aid providers should activate emergency services.
paraphrased: First aid responders should contact emergency services for individuals experiencing heatstroke, characterized by changes in mental status.

original: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and ipsilateral moderate (50%–69%) carotid steno- sis as documented by catheter-based imaging or noninvasive imaging, CEA is recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, depending on patient-specific factors such as age, sex, and comorbidities, if the perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.369
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a recent TIA or ischemic stroke and have ipsilateral carotid stenosis of 50%–69% confirmed by catheter-based or noninvasive imaging, carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is advised to lower the risk of subsequent strokes, taking into account individual factors like age, sex, and existing health conditions, provided the estimated risk of perioperative complications and death is below 6%.

original: For patients with LVH in whom there is a suspicion of alternative diagnoses, including infiltrative or stor- age disease as well as athlete’s heart, CMR imaging is useful (Figure 1).1–7
paraphrased: CMR imaging is beneficial for patients with LVH when alternative diagnoses, such as infiltrative or storage diseases and athlete's heart, are suspected.

original: For patients who are nonusers of tobacco products, continued complete abstention from cigarette smoking, in addition to other tobacco products and electronic nicotine delivery systems, and avoidance of exposure to environmental tobacco smoke (secondhand smoke exposure) are recommended to avoid the associated increased risk of stroke.254,255,257–263,265–270 Cessation intervention
paraphrased: For individuals who do not use tobacco, it is advised to maintain total abstinence from smoking cigarettes, using other tobacco products, and electronic nicotine delivery systems, as well as to steer clear of secondhand smoke exposure, to reduce the heightened risk of stroke.

original: In patients in whom revascularization is planned within 1 week of the index stroke, it is reasonable to choose CEA over CAS to reduce the periprocedural stroke rate.372 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients scheduled for revascularization within a week following the initial stroke, opting for CEA instead of CAS is advisable to lower the risk of stroke during the procedure.

original: In patients with rheumatic MS in normal sinus rhythm with symptomatic resting or exertional sinus tachycardia, heart rate control can be beneficial to manage symptoms.9–15
paraphrased: For patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis who are in normal sinus rhythm and experience symptomatic sinus tachycardia at rest or during exertion, controlling the heart rate may help alleviate symptoms.

original: For patients who are active cigarette smokers, smoking cessation pharmacotherapy delivered along with behavioral counseling is recommended, in preference to behavioral counseling alone, to facilitate smoking cessation.271–277
paraphrased: For patients who actively smoke cigarettes, it is advised to combine smoking cessation medication with behavioral counseling, rather than relying solely on behavioral counseling, to aid in quitting smoking.

original: For adults with heatstroke, it is reasonable to initiate immediate active cooling by using whole- body (neck-down) cool- to cold-water immersion for 15 minutes or until neurological symptoms resolve (whichever occurs first).
paraphrased: For adults experiencing heatstroke, promptly starting active cooling with full-body immersion in cool to cold water for 15 minutes or until neurological symptoms subside, whichever comes first, is advisable.

original: In all patients ≥65 years of age and in those <64 years with perceived frailty who are undergoing elevated-risk NCS, preoperative frailty assessment using a validated tool can be useful for evaluating perioperative risk and guiding management.1–5
paraphrased: For patients aged 65 and older, as well as those under 64 who are considered frail, undergoing high-risk non-cardiac surgery, assessing frailty preoperatively with a validated tool can aid in evaluating perioperative risk and informing management strategies.

original: In patients with TIA or nondisabling stroke, when revascularization is indicated, it is reasonable to perform the procedure within 2 weeks of the index event rather than delay surgery to increase the likelihood of stroke- free outcome.373
paraphrased: For patients experiencing TIA or a nondisabling stroke, if revascularization is warranted, it is advisable to carry out the procedure within 2 weeks of the initial event to enhance the chances of avoiding a subsequent stroke.

original: In patients with known CVD, or age ≥65 years, or age ≥45 years with symptoms suggestive of CVD undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it is reasonable to measure B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N- terminal pro–B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) before surgery to supplement evaluation of perioperative risk.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with established cardiovascular disease, those aged 65 or older, or individuals aged 45 or older exhibiting symptoms indicative of cardiovascular disease who are undergoing high-risk non-cardiac surgery, it is advisable to assess B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal pro–B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) preoperatively to enhance the assessment of perioperative risk.

original: For patients who are active cigarette smokers and users of other tobacco products (eg, electronic nicotine delivery systems), assistance with cessation is recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.260,271,278–286
paraphrased: It is advised that individuals who actively smoke cigarettes or use other tobacco products, such as electronic nicotine delivery systems, receive support to quit in order to lower their risk of stroke.

original: In symptomatic patients (NYHA class II, III, or IV) with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) and favorable valve morphology with less than moderate (2+) MR* in the absence of LA thrombus, PMBC is recommended if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.1–12
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting symptoms (NYHA class II, III, or IV) with severe rheumatic mitral stenosis (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm², Stage D) and suitable valve morphology with no more than moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation and without left atrial thrombus, PMBC is advised if it can be conducted at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

original: For patients with HCM who are not otherwise identified as high risk for SCD, or in whom a deci- sion to proceed with ICD remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal or family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory electrocar- diographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial replacement fibrosis with late gadolinium enhancement (LGE).1–15
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who are not clearly at high risk for SCD, or when the decision to implant an ICD is still uncertain after evaluating personal or family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory ECG monitoring, CMR imaging is useful to evaluate maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and the degree of myocardial replacement fibrosis using late gadolinium enhancement (LGE).

original: For adults with heatstroke, it is reasonable to initiate other forms of active cooling, including commercial ice packs, cold showers, ice sheets and towels, cooling vests and jackets, and evaporative, fanning, or a combination of techniques when water immersion is not available.
paraphrased: For adults experiencing heatstroke, it is advisable to begin alternative active cooling methods, such as using commercial ice packs, taking cold showers, applying ice sheets and towels, wearing cooling vests and jackets, or employing evaporative and fanning techniques, or a combination thereof, when water immersion is not an option.

original: For patients with obstructive HCM in whom the ana- tomic mechanism of obstruction is inconclusive on echocardiography, CMR imaging is indicated to inform the selection and planning of SRT.16–20
paraphrased: CMR imaging is recommended for patients with obstructive HCM when echocardiography does not clearly identify the anatomical cause of obstruction, to aid in the selection and planning of SRT.

original: In patients with symptomatic severe stenosis (≥70%) in whom anatomic or medical condi- tions are present that increase the risk for surgery (such as radiation-induced stenosis or restenosis after CEA) it is reasonable to choose CAS to reduce the periprocedural complication rate.374
paraphrased: For patients with symptomatic severe stenosis (≥70%) who have anatomical or medical factors that elevate surgical risk, like radiation-induced stenosis or restenosis following CEA, opting for CAS is a reasonable approach to lower the risk of periprocedural complications.

original: In patients with known CVD, or age ≥65 years, or age ≥45 years with symptoms suggestive of CVD undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it may be reasonable to measure cardiac troponin (cTn) before surgery to supplement evaluation of peri­ operative risk.4–6
paraphrased: For patients with established cardiovascular disease (CVD), those aged 65 or older, or individuals aged 45 or older exhibiting symptoms indicative of CVD who are undergoing high-risk non-cardiac surgery, it may be appropriate to assess cardiac troponin (cTn) levels preoperatively to enhance the assessment of perioperative risk.

original: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) who 1) are not candidates for PMBC, 2) have failed a previous PMBC, 3) require other cardiac procedures, or 4) do not have access to PMBC, mitral valve surgery (repair, commissurotomy, or valve replacement) is indicated.6,7,13
paraphrased: For patients with severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) and advanced rheumatic mitral stenosis (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm², Stage D) who are either unsuitable for PMBC, have had an unsuccessful PMBC, need additional cardiac procedures, or lack access to PMBC, mitral valve surgery (repair, commissurotomy, or replacement) is recommended.

original: For children with heatstroke, it is reasonable to initi- ate immediate active cooling by using whole-body (neck-down) cool- to cold-water immersion for 15 minutes or until neurological symptoms resolve (whichever occurs first).
paraphrased: For children experiencing heatstroke, it is advisable to promptly begin active cooling by immersing the entire body from the neck down in cool to cold water for 15 minutes or until neurological symptoms subside, whichever comes first.

original: For patients who are active cigarette smokers encountered in the hospital setting, providing smoking cessation pharmacotherapy along with behavioral counseling as the default treatment (“opt-out”), in preference to providing such treat- ment only for patients expressing a willingness to quit smoking (“opt-in”), can be beneficial to facili- tate short-term smoking cessation and to increase engagement in smoking cessation treatment.287,288
paraphrased: For hospitalized patients who actively smoke cigarettes, offering smoking cessation medications and behavioral counseling as the standard treatment option, unless declined ("opt-out"), rather than only to those who express a desire to quit ("opt-in"), can aid in achieving short-term smoking cessation and enhance participation in cessation programs.

original: For patients with HCM, repeat contrast-enhanced CMR imaging on a periodic basis (every 3-5 years) for the purpose of SCD risk stratification may be considered to evaluate changes in LGE and other morphologic changes, including EF, development of apical aneurysm, or LV wall thickness (Figure 1,
paraphrased: For individuals with HCM, it may be advisable to periodically perform contrast-enhanced CMR imaging every 3-5 years to assess SCD risk by evaluating alterations in LGE and other morphological changes, such as EF, apical aneurysm formation, or LV wall thickness.

original: In symptomatic patients at average or low risk of complications associated with endovascular intervention, when the ICA stenosis is ≥70% by noninvasive imaging or >50% by catheter-based imaging and the anticipated rate of periprocedural stroke or death is <6%, CAS may be considered as an alternative to CEA for stroke preven- tion, particularly in patients with significant cardiovascular comorbidities predispos- ing to cardiovascular complications with endarterectomy.375
paraphrased: For symptomatic patients with average or low risk of endovascular intervention complications, when internal carotid artery stenosis is 70% or greater as determined by noninvasive imaging, or more than 50% by catheter-based imaging, and the expected periprocedural stroke or death rate is under 6%, carotid artery stenting (CAS) can be considered as an alternative to carotid endarterectomy (CEA) for stroke prevention, especially in those with significant cardiovascular comorbidities that increase the risk of complications from endarterectomy.

original: For patients who are active cigarette smokers, the long-term health benefits of using e-cigarettes in place of nicotine replacement therapy to facilitate cigarette smoking cessation are not well estab- lished.289–291
paraphrased: The long-term health advantages of substituting e-cigarettes for nicotine replacement therapy to aid in quitting smoking are not well-defined for patients who actively smoke cigarettes.

original: For patients with known coronary heart disease, signifi­ cant arrhythmia, peripheral arterial disease, cerebrovas­ cular disease, other significant structural heart disease, or symptoms* of CVD undergoing elevated-risk sur­ gery, a preoperative resting 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) is reasonable to establish a preoperative base­ line and guide perioperative management.1,2
paraphrased: For individuals with established coronary heart disease, notable arrhythmias, peripheral arterial disease, cerebrovascular disease, other significant structural heart conditions, or symptoms of cardiovascular disease who are undergoing high-risk surgery, it is advisable to perform a preoperative resting 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) to establish a baseline and assist in perioperative management.

original: In adult patients with suspected HCM, cardiac CT may be considered for diagnosis if the echocardiogram is not diagnostic and CMR imaging is unavailable.1–3
paraphrased: For adult patients suspected of having HCM, consider using cardiac CT for diagnosis when the echocardiogram is inconclusive and CMR imaging cannot be performed.

original: In patients undergoing NCS with a preoperative ECG exhibiting new abnormalities,† further evalu­ ation is reasonable to refine assessment of cardio­ vascular risk.3–8
paraphrased: For patients having NCS with a preoperative ECG showing new abnormalities, it is reasonable to conduct further evaluation to better assess cardiovascular risk.

original: For children with heatstroke, it is reasonable to initiate other forms of active cooling, including commercial ice packs, cold showers, ice sheets and towels, cooling vests and jackets, and evaporative, fanning, or a combination of techniques when water immersion is not available.
paraphrased: When water immersion is unavailable for children with heatstroke, it is appropriate to start other active cooling methods such as using commercial ice packs, taking cold showers, applying ice sheets and towels, wearing cooling vests and jackets, or employing evaporative and fanning techniques, either alone or in combination.

original: In the asymptomatic population, routine screen- ing for carotid artery stenosis is not recom- mended to reduce the risk of stroke.306,307 Other interventions
paraphrased: Routine screening for carotid artery stenosis is not advised for asymptomatic individuals to lower stroke risk.

original: In asymptomatic patients with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage C) and favorable valve morphology with less than 2+ MR in the absence of LA thrombus who have elevated pulmonary pressures (pulmonary artery systolic pressure >50 mm Hg), PMBC is reasonable if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.14
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with severe rheumatic mitral stenosis (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm², Stage C) who exhibit favorable valve morphology, have less than 2+ mitral regurgitation, no left atrial thrombus, and elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure (>50 mm Hg), percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy is a reasonable option if conducted at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

original: In patients with a recent stroke or TIA (past 6 months), the usefulness of transcarotid artery revascularization (TCAR) for prevention of recurrent stroke and TIA is uncertain.376
paraphrased: The effectiveness of transcarotid artery revascularization (TCAR) in preventing recurrent stroke and TIA in patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA within the last 6 months is unclear.

original: In patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is recommended in the initial evaluation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1-2 years) (Figure 1, Table 7).1–3
paraphrased: For individuals with HCM, it is advised to perform a 12-lead ECG during the initial assessment and regularly thereafter, every 1-2 years.

original: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and when the degree of stenosis is <50%, revascularization with CEA or CAS to reduce the risk of future stroke is not recom- mended.369
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a recent TIA or ischemic stroke and have stenosis less than 50%, it is advised against performing revascularization with CEA or CAS to lower the risk of subsequent strokes.

original: It may be reasonable for first aid providers, who are trained and willing, to measure core temperature during active cooling for heatstroke. The target core temperature to cool until is 39° C (102.2° F). Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: For first aid providers who are trained and willing, it might be appropriate to monitor core temperature during active cooling for heatstroke, aiming to reduce it to 39°C (102.2°F).

original: In asymptomatic patients with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage C) and favorable valve morphology with less than 2+/ MR* in the absence of LA thrombus who have new onset of AF, PMBC may be considered if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.15
paraphrased: For asymptomatic patients with severe rheumatic mitral stenosis (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm², Stage C) who have favorable valve morphology and less than 2+ mitral regurgitation, and no left atrial thrombus, percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy may be an option if they develop new-onset atrial fibrillation and the procedure can be done at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

original: For asymptomatic patients undergoing elevated-risk surgeries without known CVD, a preoperative rest­ ing 12-lead ECG may be considered to establish a baseline and guide perioperative management.3,9,10
paraphrased: For patients without known cardiovascular disease who are asymptomatic and facing high-risk surgeries, a preoperative resting 12-lead ECG can be considered to establish a baseline and assist in perioperative management.

original: In patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis (ACS) >70%, shared decision-making between the patient and the health care team to decide between the 2 courses of treatment (carotid revascularization or medical manage- ment) is recommended to determine the best method of reducing stroke risk.
paraphrased: For patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis greater than 70%, it is advised that the patient and healthcare team engage in shared decision-making to choose between carotid revascularization and medical management as the optimal approach to lower stroke risk.

original: In the absence of shock, confusion, or inability to swallow, first aid providers should assist or encourage individuals with exertional dehydration to orally rehydrate with any available rehydration drink or potable water.
paraphrased: If there is no shock, confusion, or swallowing difficulty, first aid responders should help or motivate those experiencing exertional dehydration to drink any available rehydration solution or safe water.

original: In patients with HCM, 24- to 48-hour ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring is recommended in the initial evaluation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1-2 years) to identify patients who are at risk for SCD and to guide management of arrhythmias (Figure 1).4–6
paraphrased: For individuals with HCM, it is advised to conduct 24- to 48-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring during the initial assessment and regularly every 1-2 years thereafter to detect those at risk for SCD and to manage arrhythmias effectively.

original: In symptomatic patients (NYHA class II, III, or IV) with rheumatic MS and an mitral valve area >1.5 cm2, if there is evidence of hemodynamically significant rheumatic MS on the basis of a pulmonary artery wedge pressure >25 mm Hg or a mean mitral valve gradient >15 mm Hg during exercise, PMBC may be considered if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.16
paraphrased: For patients with symptoms classified as NYHA class II, III, or IV who have rheumatic mitral stenosis and a mitral valve area greater than 1.5 cm², percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC) may be considered if performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center, provided there is hemodynamically significant rheumatic mitral stenosis indicated by a pulmonary artery wedge pressure exceeding 25 mm Hg or a mean mitral valve gradient over 15 mm Hg during exercise.

original: For asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk surgi­ cal procedures, a routine preoperative resting 12-lead ECG is not recommended to improve outcomes.11 *Active symptoms and signs of CVD include chest pain, dyspnea, undiagnosed palpitations, tachycardia, syncope, or murmurs. †Abnormalities may include ST-segment elevation, ST depression, T-wave inversions, left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy, significant pathologic Q-waves, Mo­ bitz type II or higher atrioventricular block, bundle branch block, QT prolonga­ tion, or AF.
paraphrased: For patients without symptoms undergoing low-risk surgical procedures, performing a routine preoperative resting 12-lead ECG is not advised to enhance outcomes.

original: In patients with asymptomatic atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis, medical treatment with statin can be beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.308–311
paraphrased: For patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis due to atherosclerosis, administering statins may help lower the risk of stroke.

original: In patients with a recent (within 120 days) TIA or ischemic stroke ipsilateral to atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion of the middle cerebral or carotid artery, extracranial- intracranial bypass surgery is not recom- mended.377
paraphrased: Extracranial-intracranial bypass surgery is not advised for patients who have experienced a TIA or ischemic stroke within the past 120 days on the same side as atherosclerotic stenosis or blockage of the middle cerebral or carotid artery.

original: In patients with HCM who develop palpitations or lightheadedness, extended (>24 hours) elec- trocardiographic monitoring or event recording is recommended for arrhythmia diagnosis and clinical correlation.6
paraphrased: For patients with HCM experiencing palpitations or dizziness, it is advised to conduct extended electrocardiographic monitoring or event recording for more than 24 hours to diagnose arrhythmias and correlate clinically.

original: In patients with recently symptomatic extra- cranial vertebral artery stenosis, intensive medical therapy (antiplatelet therapy, lipid lowering, BP control) is recommended to reduce stroke risk.378
paraphrased: For patients with recent symptoms of extracranial vertebral artery stenosis, it is advised to implement intensive medical treatment, including antiplatelet therapy, lipid management, and blood pressure control, to lower the risk of stroke.

original: It is reasonable to choose 4% to 9% carbohydrate- electrolyte drink over potable water, 0% to 3.9% carbohydrate-electrolyte drinks, coconut water, or low-fat cow’s milk, if each is readily available. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: Opting for a carbohydrate-electrolyte drink with a concentration of 4% to 9% is advisable over potable water, drinks with 0% to 3.9% carbohydrate-electrolyte content, coconut water, or low-fat cow's milk, provided all options are easily accessible.

original: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) who have a suboptimal valve anatomy and who are not candidates for surgery or are at high risk for surgery, PMBC may be considered if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.17–19 *2+ on a 0 to 4+ scale according to Sellar’s criteria or less than moderate by Doppler echocardiography.20
paraphrased: For patients with severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) and advanced rheumatic mitral stenosis (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm², Stage D) who have unsuitable valve anatomy and are either ineligible for surgery or face high surgical risks, PMBC may be an option if conducted at a Comprehensive Valve Center, provided the regurgitation is graded *2+ on a 0 to 4+ scale by Sellar’s criteria or is less than moderate by Doppler echocardiography.

original: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with severe MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) attributable to extensive mitral annular calcification, valve intervention may be considered only after discussion of the high procedural risk and the individual patient’s preferences and values.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) and significant mitral stenosis (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm², Stage D) due to extensive mitral annular calcification, valve intervention should be contemplated only after evaluating the high procedural risk and considering the patient's personal preferences and values.

original: In patients undergoing NCS with new dyspnea, physical examination findings of HF, or suspected new/worsening ventricular dysfunction, it is recom­ mended to perform preoperative evaluation of LV function to help guide perioperative management.1–8
paraphrased: For patients undergoing NCS who present with new shortness of breath, signs of heart failure, or suspected new or worsening ventricular dysfunction, a preoperative assessment of left ventricular function is advised to assist in perioperative management.

original: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is recommended as a component of the screening algorithm (Figure 1, Table 7).1–3
paraphrased: For screening first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, it is advised to include a 12-lead ECG as part of the evaluation process (Figure 1, Table 7).1–3

original: In patients with asymptomatic atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis >70% and low periopera- tive risk, the use of carotid revascularization, in addition to intensive medical therapy, may be reasonable to reduce the risk of stroke.309,312–314
paraphrased: For patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis exceeding 70% and low risk for perioperative complications, carotid revascularization alongside intensive medical treatment might be a reasonable approach to lower stroke risk.

original: In patients with a known diagnosis of HF with wors­ ening dyspnea or other change in clinical status undergoing NCS, preoperative assessment of LV function is reasonable to help guide perioperative management.1,4,7,9–11
paraphrased: For patients diagnosed with HF experiencing increased dyspnea or other clinical status changes undergoing NCS, it is reasonable to assess LV function preoperatively to assist in guiding perioperative management.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and extracranial vertebral artery stenosis who are having symptoms despite optimal medical treatment, the usefulness of stenting is not well established.378
paraphrased: For patients experiencing symptoms from ischemic stroke or TIA with extracranial vertebral artery stenosis, despite receiving optimal medical therapy, the efficacy of stenting remains uncertain.

original: In patients with known or suspected primary MR, TTE is indicated for baseline evaluation of LV size and function, RV function, LA size, pulmonary artery pressure, and the mechanism and severity of primary MR (Stages A to D).1–5
paraphrased: For patients with confirmed or suspected primary MR, TTE should be performed to assess baseline LV size and function, RV function, LA size, pulmonary artery pressure, and to determine the mechanism and severity of primary MR (Stages A to D).

original: It is beneficial for first aid providers to receive training in responding to opioid overdose, including the provision of naloxone.
paraphrased: First aid responders should be trained in handling opioid overdoses, including administering naloxone.

original: In patients with ACS >50%, annual carotid duplex ultrasound every 6 to 12 months might be reasonable to assess progression of disease and subsequent increased risk of stroke.308,315–318
paraphrased: For patients with ACS greater than 50%, it may be advisable to perform a carotid duplex ultrasound every 6 to 12 months to monitor disease progression and the associated elevated risk of stroke.

original: A first aid provider who encounters a person with suspected opioid overdose who is unresponsive and not breathing or not breathing normally should activate the emergency response system, provide high-quality CPR (compressions plus ventilation), and administer naloxone. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: If a first aid provider finds an individual suspected of opioid overdose who is unresponsive and either not breathing or breathing abnormally, they should call emergency services, perform high-quality CPR (including compressions and ventilation), and give naloxone.

original: In patients with HCM who are deemed to be at high risk for developing AF based on the presence of risk factors or as determined by a validated risk score, and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring is recommended to screen for AF as part of initial evaluation and annual follow-up (Figure 1).7–12
paraphrased: For patients with HCM identified as high risk for AF due to risk factors or a validated risk score, and who qualify for anticoagulation, it is advised to conduct extended ambulatory monitoring to detect AF during the initial assessment and annually thereafter.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and extracranial vertebral artery stenosis who are having symptoms despite optimal medical treatment, the usefulness of open surgical procedures, including vertebral endarterec- tomy and vertebral artery transposition, is not well established.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing symptoms from ischemic stroke or TIA with extracranial vertebral artery stenosis, despite receiving optimal medical therapy, the effectiveness of open surgical interventions such as vertebral endarterectomy and vertebral artery transposition remains uncertain.

original: In asymptomatic and clinically stable patients undergo­ ing NCS, routine preoperative evaluation of LV func­ tion is not recommended due to lack of benefit.12–15
paraphrased: Routine preoperative assessment of left ventricular function is not advised for asymptomatic and clinically stable patients undergoing non-cardiac surgery, as it offers no benefit.

original: In patients with asymptomatic atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis and high perioperative risk, the effectiveness of carotid revascular- ization to reduce risk of stroke is not estab- lished.314,319,320
paraphrased: For patients with asymptomatic atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis who are at high risk during surgery, the benefit of carotid revascularization in lowering stroke risk has not been determined.

original: Immediate skin decontamination is recommended after a chemical exposure.
paraphrased: Prompt skin decontamination is advised following chemical exposure.

original: In patients with primary MR, when TTE provides insufficient or discordant information, TEE is indicated for evaluation of the severity of MR, mechanism of MR, and status of LV function (Stages B to D).
paraphrased: For patients with primary MR, if TTE yields inadequate or conflicting data, TEE is recommended to assess MR severity, MR mechanism, and LV function status (Stages B to D).

original: In patients with a stroke or TIA and evidence of an aortic arch atheroma, intensive lipid management to an LDL cholesterol target <70 mg/dL is recommended to prevent recur- rent stroke.210
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA and have an aortic arch atheroma, it is advised to manage lipids intensively to achieve an LDL cholesterol level below 70 mg/dL to prevent another stroke.

original: In adult patients with HCM without risk factors for AF and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring may be considered to assess for asymptomatic paroxysmal AF as part of initial evaluation and periodic follow-up (every 1-2 years).7–12
paraphrased: For adult patients with HCM who lack AF risk factors and qualify for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring can be considered to detect asymptomatic paroxysmal AF during the initial assessment and at regular follow-ups every 1-2 years.

original: In adults with asymptomatic cerebral SVD (CSVD), including silent infarcts, assessment and management of risk factors (eg, hypertension, dyslipidemia, tobacco use, and diabetes) are recommended to reduce stroke risk.336–341
paraphrased: For adults with asymptomatic cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD), such as silent infarcts, it is advised to evaluate and control risk factors like hypertension, dyslipidemia, smoking, and diabetes to lower the risk of stroke.

original: For patients undergoing elevated-risk NCS with poor or unknown functional capacity and elevated risk for perioperative cardiovascular events based on a validated risk tool, stress testing may be consid­ ered to evaluate for inducible myocardial ischemia.1
paraphrased: For patients facing high-risk non-cardiac surgery with inadequate or uncertain functional capacity and a high likelihood of perioperative cardiovascular events as determined by a validated risk assessment, stress testing can be considered to assess for inducible myocardial ischemia.

original: In patients with a stroke or TIA and evidence of an aortic arch atheroma, antiplatelet therapy is recommended to prevent recurrent stroke.380–385
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA and have an aortic arch atheroma, it is advised to use antiplatelet therapy to prevent another stroke.

original: Unless otherwise recommended by local guide- lines or chemical-specific information, skin exposed to caustic chemical should be irrigated with running water for at least 15 minutes.
paraphrased: If not advised differently by local protocols or specific chemical data, skin that has come into contact with a caustic substance should be rinsed with flowing water for a minimum of 15 minutes.

original: In patients with primary MR, CMR is indicated to assess LV and RV volumes and function and may help with assessing MR severity when there is a discrepancy between the findings on clinical assessment and echocardiography.6–9
paraphrased: For patients with primary MR, CMR is recommended to evaluate LV and RV volumes and function, and it can aid in determining MR severity when clinical assessment and echocardiography results differ.

original: In patients with severe primary MR undergoing mitral intervention, intraoperative TEE is indicated to establish the anatomic basis for primary MR (Stages C and D) and to guide repair.10,11
paraphrased: For patients with severe primary MR who are undergoing mitral intervention, intraoperative TEE is recommended to determine the anatomical cause of primary MR (Stages C and D) and to assist in the repair process.

original: In patients who are at low risk for perioperative cardiovascular events, have adequate* functional capacity with stable symptoms, or who are undergo­ ing low-risk procedures, routine stress testing before NCS is not recommended due to lack of benefit.1–3 *Poor functional capacity is considered <4 METs or a DASI score of ≤34.
paraphrased: For patients with low risk of perioperative cardiovascular events, sufficient functional capacity with stable symptoms, or those undergoing low-risk procedures, routine preoperative stress testing before non-cardiac surgery is not advised, as it offers no benefit. Poor functional capacity is defined as less than 4 METs or a DASI score of 34 or lower.

original: For patients with symptomatic HCM for whom there is uncertainty regarding the presence or severity of LVOTO on noninvasive imaging studies, invasive hemodynamic assessment with cardiac catheterization is recommended.1–4
paraphrased: In patients with symptomatic HCM where noninvasive imaging does not clearly determine the presence or severity of LVOTO, cardiac catheterization for invasive hemodynamic evaluation is advised.

original: In patients with primary MR (Stages B to D) and new-onset or changing symptoms, TTE is indicated to evaluate the mitral valve apparatus and LV function.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with primary MR (Stages B to D) who experience new or altered symptoms, TTE is recommended to assess the mitral valve structure and LV function.

original: For patients undergoing elevated-risk surgery with poor* or unknown functional capacity, and elevated risk for perioperative cardiovascular events based on a validated risk tool, coronary computed tomog­ raphy angiography (CCTA) for the detection of high-risk coronary anatomy† may be considered.1–4
paraphrased: For patients facing high-risk surgery with inadequate or uncertain functional capacity and an increased likelihood of perioperative cardiovascular events as determined by a validated risk assessment tool, considering coronary computed tomography angiography (CCTA) to identify high-risk coronary anatomy may be appropriate.

original: In adults with silent cerebral infarcts (SCIs) who do not have an indication for statin therapy according to the 2019 ACC/AHA guideline (eg, 20–75 years of age with LDL-C level >190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], 10-year ASCVD risk ≥20%, or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%–<20% plus ≥1 more risk enhancers), use of low-dose statin therapy might be considered to reduce the risk of ischemic stroke.342–345
paraphrased: For adults with silent cerebral infarcts (SCIs) who do not meet the 2019 ACC/AHA guideline criteria for statin therapy (such as those aged 20–75 with LDL-C levels over 190 mg/dL, a 10-year ASCVD risk of 20% or higher, or a 10-year ASCVD risk between 7.5% and 20% with at least one additional risk enhancer), considering low-dose statin therapy may help lower the risk of ischemic stroke.

original: In patients with moyamoya disease and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA, surgi- cal revascularization with direct or indirect extracranial-intracranial bypass can be beneficial for the prevention of ischemic stroke or TIA.391–397
paraphrased: For patients with moyamoya disease who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, surgical revascularization using either direct or indirect extracranial-intracranial bypass may help prevent further ischemic strokes or TIAs.

original: It can be beneficial to follow local guidelines, fol- low chemical-specific procedures, or consult a regional poison center when assisting a person with chemical exposures.
paraphrased: Adhering to local protocols, using procedures tailored to specific chemicals, or seeking advice from a regional poison center can be advantageous when managing chemical exposures.

original: In adults with SCI, the benefit of antiplatelet therapy to reduce the risk of ischemic stroke is uncertain.346,347
paraphrased: For adults with SCI, it is unclear whether antiplatelet therapy effectively lowers the risk of ischemic stroke.

original: In patients with HCM who are at risk of coronary atherosclerosis, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is recommended before surgical myectomy.6 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who may develop coronary atherosclerosis, it is advised to perform coronary angiography (either CT or invasive) prior to undergoing surgical myectomy.

original: Contaminated clothing, jewelry, and other surrounding material should be removed from the area of a chemical exposure.
paraphrased: Clothing, jewelry, and other materials in contact with a chemical exposure should be taken off and removed from the vicinity.

original: In patients with HCM who have symptoms or evidence of myocardial ischemia, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is recommended.5
paraphrased: For patients with HCM experiencing symptoms or signs of myocardial ischemia, it is advised to perform coronary angiography, either via CT or invasive methods.

original: In patients who are at low risk for perioperative cardiovascular events, have adequate* functional capacity with stable symptoms, or who are undergo­ ing low-risk procedures, routine CCTA before NCS is not recommended due to lack of benefit.1,5 *Poor functional capacity is considered <4 METs or a DASI score of ≤34. †High-risk coronary anatomy is defined as patients with obstructive stenosis who have ≥50% left main stenosis or anatomically significant 3-vessel disease (≥70% stenosis).6
paraphrased: For patients with low risk of perioperative cardiovascular events, sufficient functional capacity with stable symptoms, or those undergoing low-risk procedures, routine CCTA prior to NCS is not advised as it offers no benefit.

original: In patients with moyamoya disease and a his- tory of ischemic stroke or TIA, the use of anti- platelet therapy, typically aspirin monotherapy, for the prevention of ischemic stroke or TIA may be reasonable.393,394,397–401
paraphrased: For individuals with moyamoya disease who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, it may be appropriate to use antiplatelet therapy, commonly aspirin alone, to prevent further ischemic strokes or TIAs.

original: EMS should be called when a person with chemi- cal exposure has respiratory symptoms, systemic symptoms, or large chemical exposures.
paraphrased: Contact emergency medical services if an individual exposed to chemicals exhibits respiratory or systemic symptoms, or if the exposure is extensive.

original: For symptomatic patients with HCM who do not have resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is recommended for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.1–6
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who exhibit symptoms but lack a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient of ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is advised to identify and measure dynamic LVOTO.

original: In adults 18 to 64 years of age with migraine with or without aura, evaluation and modification of vascular risk factors are recommended to address the elevated risk of stroke in this patient population.362–369
paraphrased: For adults aged 18 to 64 who experience migraines, whether accompanied by aura or not, it is advised to assess and adjust vascular risk factors to mitigate their increased stroke risk.

original: For asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR (Stages B and C1), TTE is indicated every 6 to 12 months for surveillance of LV function (estimated by LVEF, LVEDD, and LVESD) and assessment of pulmonary artery pressure.1–11
paraphrased: In asymptomatic individuals with severe primary MR (Stages B and C1), it is recommended to perform TTE every 6 to 12 months to monitor LV function (assessed by LVEF, LVEDD, and LVESD) and evaluate pulmonary artery pressure.

original: In patients undergoing NCS, routine preoperative invasive coronary angiography (ICA) is not recom­ mended to improve perioperative outcomes.1,2
paraphrased: For patients having non-cardiac surgery, performing routine preoperative invasive coronary angiography is not advised to enhance perioperative outcomes.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke related to small vessel disease, the usefulness of cilostazol for secondary stroke prevention is uncertain.382,384,408–410
paraphrased: The effectiveness of cilostazol for preventing recurrent strokes in patients with ischemic stroke due to small vessel disease remains unclear.

original: It is reasonable to brush off any dry chemical be- fore irrigation with water. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: Before rinsing with water, it is advisable to remove any dry chemicals.

original: In patients with nonvalvular AF and stroke or TIA, oral anticoagulation (eg, apixaban, dabi- gatran, edoxaban, rivaroxaban, or warfarin) is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.419–426
paraphrased: For patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation and a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack, it is advised to use oral anticoagulants such as apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban, rivaroxaban, or warfarin to lower the risk of another stroke.

original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV), cardiopul- monary exercise stress testing should be performed to quantify the degree of functional limitation and aid in selection of patients for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.7–9
paraphrased: For patients with nonobstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and severe heart failure (classified as NYHA class III or IV), cardiopulmonary exercise stress testing is recommended to assess the extent of functional impairment and assist in determining eligibility for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.

original: In patients with ACS being considered for elective NCS, coronary revascularization as appropriate and deferral of surgery is recommended to reduce peri­ operative cardiovascular events.1–9
paraphrased: For patients with ACS who are candidates for elective NCS, it is advised to perform coronary revascularization when suitable and postpone the surgery to minimize perioperative cardiovascular events.

original: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR (Stages B and C1), use of serum biomarkers and novel measurements of LV function, such as global longitudinal strain, may be considered as an adjunct to guide timing of intervention.12–21
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with severe primary MR (Stages B and C1), considering serum biomarkers and new LV function metrics, like global longitudinal strain, can aid in determining the timing for intervention.

original: In adults with migraine with aura who desire contraception, progestin-only or nonhormonal forms are recommended to avoid the increased risk of ischemic stroke associated with combined hormonal contraception.370–372
paraphrased: For adults experiencing migraine with aura who seek contraception, it is advised to use progestin-only or nonhormonal methods to prevent the heightened risk of ischemic stroke linked to combined hormonal contraceptives.

original: In patients with primary MR (Stages B and C) and symptoms that might be attributable to MR, hemodynamic exercise testing using Doppler echocardiography or cardiac catheterization or cardiopulmonary exercise testing is reasonable.1–4
paraphrased: For patients with primary MR in Stages B and C who exhibit symptoms potentially linked to MR, it is reasonable to conduct hemodynamic exercise testing using Doppler echocardiography, cardiac catheterization, or cardiopulmonary exercise testing.

original: In pediatric patients with HCM, regardless of symptom status, exercise stress testing is recom- mended to determine functional capacity and to provide prognostic information.10
paraphrased: For children with HCM, exercise stress testing is advised to assess functional capacity and offer prognostic insights, irrespective of their symptom status.

original: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD (Hb SS or Hb S-beta0-thalassemia), transcranial Doppler (TCD) screening at a frequency based on the highest mean flow velocity in the terminal portion of the internal carotid or the proximal portion of the middle cerebral artery is recommended.381–384 Other interventions
paraphrased: For children aged 2 to 16 with SCD (Hb SS or Hb S-beta0-thalassemia), it is advised to conduct transcranial Doppler (TCD) screening, with the frequency determined by the highest mean flow velocity in the terminal segment of the internal carotid or the proximal segment of the middle cerebral artery.

original: Decontamination by irrigation should be performed immediately after chemical exposure to the eyes.
paraphrased: Irrigate the eyes right away following chemical exposure to ensure decontamination.

original: In patients with CCD and hemodynamically signifi­ cant left main coronary artery stenosis ≥50% who are planning elective NCS, coronary revasculariza­ tion and deferral of surgery is reasonable to reduce perioperative cardiovascular events.10,11
paraphrased: For patients with CCD and significant left main coronary artery stenosis of 50% or more who are considering elective NCS, it is advisable to undergo coronary revascularization and postpone the surgery to lower the risk of cardiovascular events during the perioperative period.

original: In symptomatic or asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and LV systolic dysfunction (Stages C2 and D) in whom surgery is not possible or must be delayed, GDMT for systolic dysfunction is reasonable.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with severe primary MR and LV systolic dysfunction (Stages C2 and D), whether symptomatic or not, where surgery is not feasible or must be postponed, it is reasonable to implement GDMT for systolic dysfunction.

original: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA, oral anticoagulation is indicated to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke regardless of whether the AF pattern is paroxysmal, persistent, or permanent.427
paraphrased: For patients with AF who have experienced a stroke or TIA, oral anticoagulation is recommended to lower the risk of another stroke, irrespective of whether the AF is paroxysmal, persistent, or permanent.

original: Unless otherwise recommended by local guide- lines, irrigation with a copious amount of tap water for 15 minutes should be performed.
paraphrased: If not advised differently by local guidelines, a thorough rinse with plenty of tap water for 15 minutes should be conducted.

original: In adult patients with HCM, exercise stress testing is reasonable to determine functional capacity and to provide prognostic information as part of initial evaluation.9,11,12
paraphrased: For adult patients with HCM, conducting an exercise stress test is advisable to assess functional capacity and offer prognostic insights during the initial evaluation.

original: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD at elevated risk per TCD measurements, regularly scheduled transfusion therapy (target reduction of hemoglobin S <30%) is effective for reducing stroke risk.382,383
paraphrased: For children aged 2 to 16 with SCD who are at high risk according to TCD results, routine transfusion therapy aimed at lowering hemoglobin S to below 30% effectively reduces the risk of stroke.

original: In patients with non–left main CAD who are planned for NCS, routine preoperative coronary revascularization is not recommended to reduce perioperative cardiovascular events.*12–15 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re­ vascularization.”16
paraphrased: For patients with non-left main coronary artery disease scheduled for non-cardiac surgery, preoperative coronary revascularization should not be routinely performed to decrease perioperative cardiovascular events.

original: In asymptomatic patients with primary MR and normal LV systolic function (Stages B and C1), vasodilator therapy is not indicated if the patient is normotensive.4–8
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with primary MR and normal LV systolic function (Stages B and C1), vasodilator therapy is not recommended if they are normotensive.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA and AF who do not have moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, apixaban, dabi- gatran, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban is recom- mended in preference to warfarin to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.419–426
paraphrased: For patients with stroke or TIA and AF who do not have moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, it is advised to use apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban, or rivaroxaban over warfarin to lower the risk of recurrent stroke.

original: In children 2 to 16 years of age and young adults with Hb SS or Hb S-beta0-thalassemia, an MRI of the brain without sedation should be performed as soon as possible to evaluate for SCI and to deter- mine the need for chronic red cell transfusions (CRCTs) for stroke prevention.385,386
paraphrased: For children aged 2 to 16 and young adults with Hb SS or Hb S-beta0-thalassemia, a non-sedated brain MRI should be conducted promptly to assess for SCI and determine if chronic red cell transfusions are necessary for stroke prevention.

original: When providing first aid for chemical eye injury, first aid providers should avoid contaminating other individuals, areas, or the other eye with the caustic substance.
paraphrased: In administering first aid for chemical eye injuries, caregivers must prevent the spread of the corrosive material to other people, surfaces, or the unaffected eye.

original: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.1,3–6,13,14
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who show no symptoms and lack a resting or inducible outflow tract peak gradient of 50 mm Hg or more on standard TTE, it is reasonable to use exercise TTE to detect and measure dynamic LVOTO.

original: In most* patients with hypertension planned for elec­ tive NCS, it is reasonable to continue medical therapy for hypertension throughout the perioperative period.†
paraphrased: For the majority of patients with hypertension scheduled for elective non-cardiac surgery, it is advisable to maintain their hypertension medication during the perioperative period.

original: In patients with atrial flutter and stroke or TIA, anticoagulant therapy similar to that in AF is indicated to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.427
paraphrased: For patients with atrial flutter who have experienced a stroke or TIA, anticoagulant treatment akin to that used in AF is recommended to lower the risk of another stroke.

original: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD whose TCD velocities revert to normal, continued transfu- sion therapy can be beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.384
paraphrased: For children aged 2 to 16 with SCD who have normalized TCD velocities, ongoing transfusion therapy may help lower the risk of stroke.

original: In symptomatic patients with severe primary MR (Stage D), mitral valve intervention is recommended irrespective of LV systolic function.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with severe primary MR (Stage D) who are symptomatic, mitral valve intervention is advised regardless of LV systolic function.

original: Eye irrigation with normal saline, Ringer’s lactate solution, or a commercial eye wash solution if immediately available is reasonable.
paraphrased: It is appropriate to perform eye irrigation using normal saline, Ringer's lactate solution, or a commercial eye wash solution if one is readily accessible.

original: In patients with obstructive HCM and ambiguous functional capacity, exercise stress testing may be reasonable to guide therapy (Figure 1).15,16
paraphrased: For patients with obstructive HCM and unclear functional capacity, it may be appropriate to use exercise stress testing to inform treatment decisions (Figure 1).

original: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA, without moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, who are unable to maintain a therapeutic INR level with warfa- rin, use of dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, or edoxaban is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation and a history of stroke or TIA, who do not have moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve and cannot consistently achieve a therapeutic INR with warfarin, it is advised to use dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, or edoxaban to lower the risk of another stroke.

original: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD and normalized mean flow velocities and no intra- cranial stenosis, transition from transfusion to hydroxyurea therapy can be considered to prevent stroke.387
paraphrased: For children aged 2 to 16 with SCD who have normalized mean flow velocities and no intracranial stenosis, switching from transfusion to hydroxyurea therapy may be considered to prevent stroke.

original: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF ≤60%, LVESD ≥40 mm) (Stage C2), mitral valve surgery is recommended.3–10
paraphrased: Mitral valve surgery is advised for asymptomatic individuals with severe primary mitral regurgitation and left ventricular systolic dysfunction, indicated by an LVEF of 60% or less and an LVESD of 40 mm or more (Stage C2).

original: It is reasonable for individuals with ocular exposure to industrial chemicals to adhere to local guidelines or recommendations from a poison center. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: For those exposed to industrial chemicals in the eyes, following local guidelines or advice from a poison center is advisable.

original: In patients undergoing elective elevated-risk surgery who have cardiovascular risk factors for periopera­ tive complications‡ and recent history of poorly con­ trolled hypertension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure [DBP] ≥110 mm Hg before the day of surgery), deferring surgery may be considered to reduce the risk of perioperative complications.†1,2 Intraoperative Blood Pressure Management
paraphrased: For patients scheduled for elective high-risk surgery with cardiovascular risk factors for perioperative complications and a recent history of poorly controlled hypertension (SBP ≥180 mm Hg or DBP ≥110 mm Hg prior to the surgery day), postponing the surgery might be considered to lower the risk of perioperative complications.

original: In patients with HCM for whom it is unclear if their functional capacity has declined, exercise stress testing may be considered every 2 to 3 years (Figure 1).
paraphrased: For patients with HCM where there is uncertainty about a decline in functional capacity, exercise stress testing can be considered every 2 to 3 years (Figure 1).

original: Direct manual pressure should be applied to achieve initial control of external bleeding.
paraphrased: To initially manage external bleeding, apply direct manual pressure.

original: In patients undergoing NCS, maintaining an intraop­ erative mean arterial pressure (MAP) ≥60 to 65 mm Hg or SBP ≥90 mm Hg is recommended to reduce the risk of myocardial injury.3–9 Postoperative Blood Pressure Management
paraphrased: For patients having non-cardiac surgery, it is advised to keep the intraoperative mean arterial pressure at or above 60 to 65 mm Hg or the systolic blood pressure at or above 90 mm Hg to minimize the risk of myocardial injury.

original: In patients with stroke at high risk of hemor- rhagic conversion in the setting of AF, it is reasonable to delay initiation of oral antico- agulation beyond 14 days to reduce the risk of ICH.428–431
paraphrased: For stroke patients with a high risk of hemorrhagic transformation due to atrial fibrillation, postponing the start of oral anticoagulation for more than 14 days is advisable to lower the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage.

original: In patients with severe primary MR for whom surgery is indicated, mitral valve repair is recommended in preference to mitral valve replacement when the anatomic cause of MR is degenerative disease, if a successful and durable repair is possible.11–15
paraphrased: For patients with severe primary MR who require surgery, mitral valve repair is advised over replacement when the MR is due to degenerative disease, provided a successful and lasting repair can be achieved.

original: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is recommended as part of the initial assessment.1–7
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is advised to assess familial inheritance by obtaining a family history spanning three generations during the initial evaluation.

original: In patients with TIA in the setting of nonvalvu- lar AF, it is reasonable to initiate anticoagu- lation immediately after the index event to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a TIA with nonvalvular AF, starting anticoagulation right after the initial event is advisable to lower the risk of another stroke.

original: In patients undergoing NCS, treatment of hypoten­ sion (MAP <60-65 or SBP <90 mm Hg) in the postoperative period is recommended to limit the risk of cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, renal events, and mortality.6
paraphrased: For patients undergoing NCS, it is advised to manage hypotension (MAP below 60-65 or SBP under 90 mm Hg) after surgery to reduce the risk of cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, renal complications, and death.

original: In patients with CADASIL, counseling on smok- ing cessation and treatment of hypertension and other vascular risk factors are beneficial to reduce the risk of incident stroke.407–412
paraphrased: For patients with CADASIL, advising them to quit smoking and managing hypertension along with other vascular risk factors can help lower the risk of a first-time stroke.

original: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD at high risk for stroke (TCD mean flow velocities ≥200 cm/s) but without intracranial stenosis who are unable to continue or cannot be treated with periodic red cell transfusion, hydroxyurea or bone marrow transplantation may be reasonable to prevent stroke.387–390
paraphrased: For children aged 2 to 16 with SCD who are at high risk for stroke (TCD mean flow velocities of 200 cm/s or higher) and do not have intracranial stenosis, but cannot undergo regular red cell transfusions, considering hydroxyurea or bone marrow transplantation may be appropriate to prevent stroke.

original: A hemostatic dressing can be useful as adjunctive therapy to improve the effectiveness of direct manual pressure.
paraphrased: A hemostatic dressing may enhance the efficacy of direct manual pressure when used as a supplementary treatment.

original: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is beneficial to elucidate the genetic basis to facilitate the identification of family members at risk for developing HCM (cascade testing).8–11
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, genetic testing is advantageous to clarify the genetic cause, aiding in the detection of family members who may be at risk for HCM through cascade testing.

original: In adults with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiecta- sia (HHT), screening for pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (PAVMs) is reasonable to identify the need for multidisciplinary evaluation to man- age stroke risk.413–421
paraphrased: For adults with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), it is advisable to screen for pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (PAVMs) to determine the necessity for a multidisciplinary assessment to address stroke risk.

original: In patients with hypertension undergoing NCS, it is recommended that preoperative antihypertensive medications be restarted as soon as clinically rea­ sonable to avoid complications from postoperative hypertension. *Caution is advised when continuing antihypertensive therapy in patients with low or low-normal perioperative BPs, older adults (≥65 years),10 and patients in whom the risk for perioperative hypotension is high based on an evaluation of the patient’s overall clinical status, surgery type, and anesthetic plan. †Modified from the “2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA High Blood Pressure Guideline.”11 ‡One or more components of the RCRI: CAD, congestive heart failure, cere­ brovascular accident, baseline serum creatinine >2.0 mg/dL, or preoperative in­ sulin treatment.12
paraphrased: For patients with hypertension undergoing non-cardiac surgery, it is advised to resume preoperative antihypertensive medications as soon as it is clinically appropriate to prevent postoperative hypertension complications. Exercise caution when maintaining antihypertensive treatment in patients with low or low-normal perioperative blood pressures, those aged 65 and older, and individuals at high risk for perioperative hypotension, based on their overall clinical condition, type of surgery, and anesthetic plan.

original: Once bleeding has been controlled, it may be reasonable to apply a pressure dressing to maintain bleeding cessation.
paraphrased: After achieving hemostasis, it might be appropriate to use a pressure dressing to sustain the cessation of bleeding.

original: In patients with an atypical clinical presentation of HCM or when another genetic condition is suspected to be the cause, a workup including genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy (“HCM phenocopies”) is recommended.12–14
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting unusual symptoms of HCM or when another genetic disorder is suspected as the underlying cause, it is advised to conduct an evaluation that includes genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy, known as "HCM phenocopies."

original: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and normal LV systolic function (LVEF >60% and LVESD <40 mm) (Stage C1) but with a progressive increase in LV size or decrease in EF on ≥3 serial imaging studies, mitral valve surgery may be considered irrespective of the probability of a successful and durable repair.16
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with severe primary mitral regurgitation and normal left ventricular systolic function (LVEF over 60% and LVESD under 40 mm) (Stage C1), who exhibit a progressive increase in left ventricular size or a decrease in ejection fraction across three or more consecutive imaging studies, mitral valve surgery can be considered regardless of the likelihood of achieving a successful and lasting repair.

original: In patients with HF undergoing elective NCS, sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) should be withheld for 3 to 4 days* before surgery when feasible to reduce the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure scheduled for elective non-cardiac surgery, it is advisable to discontinue sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) 3 to 4 days prior to the procedure, if possible, to minimize the risk of metabolic acidosis during the perioperative period.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of nonvalvular AF who have contraindications for lifelong anticoagulation but can tolerate at least 45 days, it may be reasonable to consider percutaneous closure of the left atrial appendage with the Watchman device to reduce the chance of recurrent stroke and bleeding.432–436
paraphrased: For patients with stroke or TIA and nonvalvular AF who cannot undergo lifelong anticoagulation but can manage at least 45 days, considering percutaneous left atrial appendage closure with the Watchman device might be a reasonable option to lower the risk of recurrent stroke and bleeding.

original: In patients with stroke at low risk for hemor- rhagic conversion in the setting of AF, it may be reasonable to initiate anticoagulation 2 to 14 days after the index event to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.428,429,437
paraphrased: For patients with stroke who have a low risk of hemorrhagic conversion and are experiencing atrial fibrillation, starting anticoagulation therapy between 2 and 14 days after the initial event might be advisable to lower the chance of another stroke.

original: In patients with Fabry disease, the effectiveness of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) to reduce the risk of stroke is not well established.422–427
paraphrased: For individuals with Fabry disease, the ability of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) to lower the risk of stroke remains uncertain.

original: The utility of indirect manual pressure (ie, pres- sure points) for bleeding control is uncertain.
paraphrased: The effectiveness of using indirect manual pressure, such as pressure points, for controlling bleeding is unclear.
