original: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with primary severe MR and high or prohibitive surgical risk, transcatheter edge-to- edge repair (TEER) is reasonable if mitral valve anatomy is favorable for the repair procedure and patient life expectancy is at least 1 year.17,18
paraphrased: For patients with severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) and primary severe MR who are at high or prohibitive risk for surgery, transcatheter edge-to-edge repair (TEER) is a reasonable option if the mitral valve anatomy is suitable for the procedure and the patient is expected to live at least one more year.

original: In adults with a recent MI, the addition of low- dose colchicine to intensive statin therapy might be reasonable to decrease the risk of ischemic stroke.457,458
paraphrased: For adults who have recently experienced an MI, incorporating low-dose colchicine alongside intensive statin therapy could be a sensible approach to reduce the risk of ischemic stroke.

original: In patients with HCM, genetic counseling by an expert in the genetics of cardiovascular disease is recommended so that risks, benefits, test results, and their clinical significance can be reviewed and discussed with the patient in a shared decision-making process.1–3,15 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For individuals with HCM, it is advised to consult a specialist in cardiovascular genetics for genetic counseling, enabling a collaborative discussion with the patient about the risks, benefits, test outcomes, and their clinical implications.

original: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA who have end-stage renal disease or are on dialysis, it may be reasonable to use warfarin or apixaban (dose adjusted if indicated) for anticoagulation to reduce the chance of recurrent stroke.438
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation and a history of stroke or TIA who have end-stage renal disease or are undergoing dialysis, using warfarin or apixaban (with dose adjustments if necessary) for anticoagulation might be a reasonable approach to lower the risk of another stroke.

original: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and normal LV systolic function (LVEF ≥60% and LVESD ≤40 mm) (Stage C1), mitral valve repair is reasonable when the likelihood of a successful and durable repair without residual MR is >95% with an expected mortality rate of <1%, when it can be performed at a Primary or Comprehensive Valve Center.4,13,16
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with severe primary mitral regurgitation and normal left ventricular systolic function (LVEF ≥60% and LVESD ≤40 mm) (Stage C1), it is reasonable to consider mitral valve repair if the probability of achieving a successful and lasting repair without residual mitral regurgitation exceeds 95% and the anticipated mortality rate is below 1%, provided the procedure is conducted at a Primary or Comprehensive Valve Center.

original: In symptomatic patients with severe primary MR attributable to rheumatic valve disease, mitral valve repair may be considered at a Comprehensive Valve Center by an experienced team when surgical treatment is indicated, if a durable and successful repair is likely.19
paraphrased: For patients showing symptoms of severe primary mitral regurgitation due to rheumatic valve disease, mitral valve repair can be contemplated at a Comprehensive Valve Center by a skilled team when surgery is warranted, provided a lasting and effective repair is probable.

original: Mechanical pressure such as pressure bandages or devices might be considered in some situa- tions when direct manual pressure is not feasible. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: In certain cases where direct manual pressure cannot be applied, mechanical pressure using bandages or devices may be an option.

original: In patients with compensated HF undergoing NCS, it is reasonable to continue GDMT (excluding SGLT2i) in the perioperative period, unless contraindicated, to reduce the risk of worsening HF.4–8 *Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should be stopped ≥3 days and ertugliflozin ≥4 days before scheduled surgery.3
paraphrased: For patients with compensated heart failure undergoing non-cardiac surgery, it is advisable to maintain guideline-directed medical therapy during the perioperative period, except for SGLT2 inhibitors, unless contraindications exist, to minimize the risk of heart failure exacerbation. Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should be discontinued at least 3 days prior to the planned surgery, while ertugliflozin should be stopped at least 4 days before.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and valvular AF (moderate to severe mitral steno- sis or any mechanical heart valve), warfarin is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.452–457
paraphrased: For patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who have valvular AF, such as moderate to severe mitral stenosis or any mechanical heart valve, warfarin is advised to lower the risk of another stroke or TIA.

original: When performing genetic testing in a proband with HCM, the initial tier of genes tested should include genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.*8,11,16,17
paraphrased: In a proband with HCM, the first set of genes to be tested should consist of those with robust evidence of being causative for the disease.

original: In patients receiving stable doses of targeted medi­ cal therapies* for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) undergoing NCS, it is recommended to con­ tinue these agents to reduce the risk for the devel­ opment of perioperative MACE.1
paraphrased: For patients on stable doses of targeted medical therapies for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) who are undergoing non-cardiac surgery (NCS), it is advised to maintain these medications to lower the risk of perioperative major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE).

original: In patients with severe primary MR where leaflet pathology is limited to less than one half the posterior leaflet, mitral valve replacement should not be performed unless mitral valve repair has been attempted at a Primary or Comprehensive Valve Center and was unsuccessful.11–14,20–22
paraphrased: For patients with severe primary MR and posterior leaflet pathology affecting less than half of the leaflet, mitral valve replacement should only be considered if mitral valve repair has been attempted and failed at a Primary or Comprehensive Valve Center.

original: For life-threatening extremity bleeding, a tourniquet should be applied and tightened until the bleeding stops.
paraphrased: In cases of life-threatening bleeding from an extremity, apply a tourniquet and tighten it until the bleeding ceases.

original: In patients without a history of stroke and no clini- cal indication for anticoagulation, with a high-risk aPL profile (ie, triple-positive antiphospholipid testing [lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin anti- body, anti–β2 glycoprotein 1] or double-positive [any combination] or isolated lupus anticoagulant or isolated persistently positive anticardiolipin antibody at medium to high titers), prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is rec- ommended to reduce the risk of stroke.462,463
paraphrased: For patients who have no history of stroke and lack a clinical need for anticoagulation, but possess a high-risk antiphospholipid antibody profile—such as triple-positive results (lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibody, anti–β2 glycoprotein 1), double-positive results (any combination), or isolated lupus anticoagulant or persistently positive anticardiolipin antibody at medium to high levels—daily aspirin (75–100 mg) is advised to lower the risk of stroke.

original: In patients with severe† PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, referral to or consultation with a special­ ized PH center that can support risk assessment, optimization, and postoperative management (with consideration of intensive care after NCS) is reason­ able to reduce perioperative cardiopulmonary compli­ cations.2
paraphrased: For patients with severe† PH facing high-risk NCS, it is advisable to refer them to or consult with a specialized PH center capable of providing risk evaluation, optimization, and postoperative care (including potential intensive care post-NCS) to minimize perioperative cardiopulmonary complications.

original: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, both clinical screening (ECG and 2D echocardiogram) and cascade genetic testing (when a pathogenic/ likely pathogenic variant has been identified in the proband) should be offered.3,7,12,18–20
paraphrased: For first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, it is advised to provide both clinical evaluations (including ECG and 2D echocardiogram) and cascade genetic testing if a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant has been detected in the proband.

original: In patients with a mechanical mitral valve and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA before valve replacement, aspirin (75–100 mg/d) is recom- mended in addition to warfarin with an INR target of 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) to reduce the risk of thrombosis and recurrent stroke or TIA.458,459
paraphrased: For patients who have a mechanical mitral valve and a prior ischemic stroke or TIA before valve replacement, it is advised to use aspirin (75–100 mg daily) alongside warfarin, aiming for an INR of 3.0 (range 2.5–3.5), to lower the risk of thrombosis and recurrent stroke or TIA.

original: A commercial tourniquet is probably superior to an improvised tourniquet.
paraphrased: A commercial tourniquet is likely more effective than an improvised one.

original: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), TTE is useful to establish the etiology and to assess the extent of regional and global LV remodeling and systolic dysfunction, severity of MR, and magnitude of pulmonary hypertension.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), TTE is beneficial for determining the cause and evaluating the degree of both regional and global LV remodeling, systolic dysfunction, MR severity, and the extent of pulmonary hypertension.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and native aortic or nonrheumatic mitral valve disease (eg, mitral annular calcification or mitral valve prolapse) who do not have AF or another indication for anticoagulation, anti- platelet therapy is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke or TIA with native aortic or nonrheumatic mitral valve conditions (such as mitral annular calcification or mitral valve prolapse) and without AF or another reason for anticoagulation, it is advised to use antiplatelet therapy to lower the risk of another stroke or TIA.

original: In families where a sudden unexplained death has occurred with a postmortem diagnosis of HCM, postmortem genetic testing is beneficial to facilitate cascade genetic testing and clinical screening in first-degree relatives.21,22
paraphrased: In cases where a sudden unexplained death has been attributed to HCM after autopsy, conducting postmortem genetic testing is advantageous for enabling cascade genetic testing and clinical screening in first-degree relatives.

original: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), noninvasive imaging (stress nuclear/ PET, CMR, or stress echocardiography), coronary CT angiography, or coronary arteriography is useful to establish etiology of
paraphrased: For patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), utilizing noninvasive imaging techniques such as stress nuclear/PET, CMR, stress echocardiography, coronary CT angiography, or coronary arteriography is beneficial for determining the etiology.

original: In patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing, serial reevaluation of the clinical significance of the variant(s) identified is recommended to assess for variant reclassification, which may impact diagnosis and cascade genetic testing in family members23–25 (Figures 1 and 2).
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who have had genetic testing, it is advised to periodically reassess the clinical relevance of the identified variant(s) to determine if reclassification is needed, as this could affect diagnosis and genetic testing of family members.

original: If an improvised tourniquet is used, it is reason- able for the tourniquet to be at least 2 in width. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: When using an improvised tourniquet, it is advisable for it to be a minimum of 2 inches wide.

original: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a high-risk antiphospholipid profile (ie, lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibody, anti–β2-glycoprotein 1, or double-positive [any combination] or isolated lupus anticoagulant or isolated persistently positive anticardiolipin antibody at medium to high titers), prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is rec- ommended to reduce the risk of stroke.462,463
paraphrased: For patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) who have no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications but possess a high-risk antiphospholipid profile—such as lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibody, anti–β2-glycoprotein 1, or any combination thereof, or isolated lupus anticoagulant, or consistently elevated anticardiolipin antibody at medium to high levels—daily prophylactic aspirin (75–100 mg) is advised to lower the risk of stroke.

original: In patients with severe† PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, invasive hemodynamic monitoring is reasonable to guide intraoperative and postoperative care.3–5 Table 9.  Preoperative and Intraoperative Management Considerations in Patients With Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Management Considerations Continue beta blockers and/or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers without interruption in the perioperative period Avoid hypovolemia and reduced preload (can worsen LVOT obstruction) Avoid hypotension and reduced afterload (can worsen LVOT obstruction) Avoid tachycardia to ensure adequate LV filling If hypotension develops: Prioritize intravenous fluid administration to correct hypovolemia Use alpha-agonists, such as phenylephrine or vasopressin,7 rather than beta-agonists, which can worsen LVOT obstruction Consider intraoperative echocardiography to evaluate LVOT obstruction in the setting of hypotension In selected cases, intravenous beta-blockade may be necessary to reduce LV myocardial contractility and relieve LVOT obstruction
paraphrased: For patients with severe PH undergoing high-risk NCS, it is advisable to use invasive hemodynamic monitoring to guide care during and after surgery. Table 9. Preoperative and Intraoperative Management Considerations for Patients with Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Management Considerations: Maintain continuous use of beta blockers and/or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers during the perioperative period; avoid hypovolemia and decreased preload, as they may exacerbate LVOT obstruction; prevent hypotension and decreased afterload, which can worsen LVOT obstruction; avoid tachycardia to ensure sufficient LV filling. If hypotension occurs: prioritize intravenous fluids to address hypovolemia; use alpha-agonists like phenylephrine or vasopressin instead of beta-agonists, which may aggravate LVOT obstruction; consider intraoperative echocardiography to assess LVOT obstruction in cases of hypotension. In certain situations, intravenous beta-blockade may be required to decrease LV myocardial contractility and alleviate LVOT obstruction.

original: In patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) with prior unprovoked venous thrombosis, it is reasonable to choose vitamin K antagonist (VKA) therapy with a target international normalized ratio of 2 to 3 in preference to aspirin or direct oral anticoagulants for prevention of recurrent throm- botic events, including stroke.457,458.464,465
paraphrased: For patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) who have experienced previous unprovoked venous thrombosis, opting for vitamin K antagonist (VKA) therapy with a target international normalized ratio of 2 to 3 is advisable over aspirin or direct oral anticoagulants to prevent recurrent thrombotic events, such as stroke.

original: In patients with chronic secondary MR with severe symptoms (Stage D) that are unresponsive to GDMT who are being considered for transcatheter mitral valve interventions, TEE is indicated to determine suitability for the procedure.3–8
paraphrased: For patients with chronic secondary MR experiencing severe symptoms (Stage D) that do not respond to GDMT, TEE is recommended to assess their eligibility for transcatheter mitral valve procedures.

original: In patients with a bioprosthetic aortic or mitral valve, a history of ischemic stroke or TIA before valve replacement, and no other indication for anticoagulation therapy beyond 3 to 6 months from the valve placement, long-term therapy with aspirin is recommended in preference to long-term anticoagulation to reduce the risk of recur- rent stroke or TIA.
paraphrased: For patients with a bioprosthetic aortic or mitral valve who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA prior to valve replacement and lack other reasons for anticoagulation therapy beyond 3 to 6 months post-surgery, it is advised to opt for long-term aspirin therapy over long-term anticoagulation to lower the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

original: In patients with rheumatoid arthritis, statin treat- ment may be reasonable to reduce major adverse cardiovascular events, including stroke.466,467
paraphrased: For individuals with rheumatoid arthritis, using statins could be a sensible approach to lower the risk of significant cardiovascular events, such as stroke.

original: An open chest wound is a medical emergency requiring immediate activation of the emergency response system.
paraphrased: A chest wound that is open is an urgent medical situation necessitating the prompt initiation of the emergency response system.

original: In patients with chronic secondary MR undergoing transcatheter mitral valve intervention, intraprocedural guidance with TEE is recommended.4,7,9–13
paraphrased: For patients with chronic secondary mitral regurgitation undergoing transcatheter mitral valve procedures, it is advised to use TEE for guidance during the procedure.

original: In patients with intermediate- to elevated-risk congenital heart disease (CHD) lesions (Table 10) undergoing elective NCS, preoperative con­ sultation with an adult congenital heart disease (ACHD) specialist is recommended before the surgery.*1–4 *Modified from the “2018 AHA/ACC Guideline for Management of ACHD.”5 Table 10.  Adult Congenital Heart Disease Risk Stratification Before Noncardiac Surgery Risk Anatomy Functional/Hemodynamic Status Low Risk Patients with isolated small CHD lesions Patients with repaired CHD lesion with no residual shunt Patients with bicuspid aortic valve disease and aortopathy NYHA class I functional status, normal exercise capacity No chamber enlargement on imaging No residual shunt No PAH No arrhythmias Intermediate risk Unrepaired moderate-large shunts (ASD, VSD, PDA, AVSD) Repaired CHD with moderate to large residual shunt (ASD, VSD, PDA, AVSD) Obstructive left-sided lesions (congenital mitral stenosis, subaortic stenosis, supravalvular aortic stenosis, coarctation of aorta) except the ones described as low risk Obstructive right-sided lesion (pulmonary stenosis, branch pulmonary stenosis, repaired tetralogy of Fallot) Ebstein anomaly (disease spectrum includes mild, moderate, and severe variations) Anomalous coronary artery arising from the pulmonary artery Anomalous aortic origin of a coronary artery from the opposite sinus, especially with an interarterial or intramural course NYHA class II-IV functional status Limited exercise capacity Presence of residual shunt Presence of PAH Presence of cardiac chamber enlargement Significant valvular dysfunction (more than mild in severity) Arrhythmias requiring treatment Presence of HF Elevated risk Single-ventricle patients (palliated or status post Fontan procedure), unrepaired or palliated cyanotic CHD, double outlet right ventricle, pulmonary atresia, truncus arteriosus, TGA (classic or d-TGA; CCTGA or l-TGA), interrupted aortic arch NYHA class II-IV functional status Limited exercise capacity Significant valvular dysfunction (more than mild in severity) Arrhythmias requiring treatment Presence of PAH Presence of HF
paraphrased: For patients with congenital heart disease (CHD) lesions of intermediate to high risk who are undergoing elective noncardiac surgery, it is advised to have a preoperative consultation with an adult congenital heart disease (ACHD) specialist prior to the procedure.

original: In affected families with HCM, preconception and prenatal reproductive and genetic counseling should be offered.1–3,15
paraphrased: For families impacted by HCM, it is advised to provide reproductive and genetic counseling before conception and during pregnancy.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and IE who present with recurrent emboli and persistent vegetations despite appropri- ate antibiotic therapy, early surgery (during initial hospitalization before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent embolism if there is no evidence of intracra- nial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage.460–465
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke or TIA and IE with ongoing embolic events and persistent vegetations despite adequate antibiotic treatment, it is advisable to consider early surgical intervention during the initial hospital stay, prior to completing the full antibiotic course, to lower the risk of recurrent embolism, provided there is no intracranial hemorrhage or significant neurological injury.

original: In adult patients with HCM, the usefulness of genetic testing in the assessment of risk of SCD is uncertain.10,25–27
paraphrased: The value of genetic testing for evaluating SCD risk in adults with HCM remains unclear.

original: If a dressing is placed, the first aid provider should monitor the person for worsening of breathing/symptoms and loosen or remove the dressing if breathing worsens.
paraphrased: If a dressing is applied, the first aid provider must observe the individual for any deterioration in breathing or symptoms and should loosen or remove the dressing if breathing becomes more difficult.

original: In patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), coordination with the LVAD care team on the appro­ priate timing and perioperative considerations of elective NCS is recommended to mitigate the risk of perioperative MACE.
paraphrased: For patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), it is advised to collaborate with the LVAD care team regarding the optimal timing and perioperative factors of elective non-cardiac surgery (NCS) to reduce the risk of major adverse cardiac events (MACE) during the perioperative period.

original: Patients with chronic severe secondary MR (Stages C and D) and HF with reduced LVEF should receive standard GDMT for HF, including ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta blockers, aldosterone antagonists, and/or sacubitril/valsartan, and biventricular pacing as indicated.1–11
paraphrased: Individuals with chronic severe secondary mitral regurgitation (Stages C and D) and heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction should be treated with standard guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure, which includes ACE inhibitors, ARBs, beta blockers, aldosterone antagonists, and/or sacubitril/valsartan, along with biventricular pacing when appropriate.

original: In patients with history of ischemic stroke or TIA and a mechanical aortic valve, anti- coagulation with higher-intensity warfarin to achieve an INR of 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) or the addition of aspirin (75–100 mg/d) can be beneficial to reduce the risk of thromboem- bolic events.
paraphrased: For patients with a history of ischemic stroke or TIA and a mechanical aortic valve, using higher-intensity warfarin to maintain an INR of 3.0 (range 2.5–3.5) or adding aspirin (75–100 mg daily) may help lower the risk of thromboembolic events.

original: In patients with precapillary PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, perioperative administration of short-acting inhaled pulmonary vasodilators (eg, nitric oxide, aero­ solized prostacyclins) may be reasonable to reduce elevated RV afterload and prevent acute decompen­ sated right HF.6 *For example, nitric oxide pathway mediators, endothelin receptor antagonists, prostacyclin pathway agonists, or a combination of these. †Severe PH is defined according to hemodynamics (severe precapillary PH component by right heart catheterization and echocardiography) and additional data derived from clinical assessment, exercise tests, and laboratory biomarkers. Hemodynamically, severe PH displays a mean pulmonary artery (PA) pressure >40 mm Hg, pulmonary vascular resistance >5 Wood units, or echocardiographic evidence of significant RV dysfunction (eg, RV-to-LV diastolic diameter ratio >0.8 or RV dysfunction that is graded as moderate or severe). Although all 5 World Symposium on Pulmonary Hypertension group classifications display some de­ gree of risk for developing severe PH, Group 1 (PAH), Group 3 (PH due to lung disease), and Group 4 (chronic thromboembolic PH) are at high risk for devel­ oping severe PH if left untreated and may be best managed and followed at a center with PH specialists.
paraphrased: For patients with precapillary pulmonary hypertension undergoing high-risk non-cardiac surgery, it may be advisable to administer short-acting inhaled pulmonary vasodilators, such as nitric oxide or aerosolized prostacyclins, during the perioperative period to lower elevated right ventricular afterload and prevent acute right heart failure. *Examples include nitric oxide pathway mediators, endothelin receptor antagonists, prostacyclin pathway agonists, or their combinations. †Severe pulmonary hypertension is defined by hemodynamic criteria (severe precapillary pulmonary hypertension component via right heart catheterization and echocardiography) and additional clinical, exercise, and laboratory data. Hemodynamically, severe pulmonary hypertension is characterized by a mean pulmonary artery pressure >40 mm Hg, pulmonary vascular resistance >5 Wood units, or echocardiographic signs of significant right ventricular dysfunction (e.g., RV-to-LV diastolic diameter ratio >0.8 or moderate to severe RV dysfunction). Although all five World Symposium on Pulmonary Hypertension groups have some risk of severe pulmonary hypertension, Groups 1 (pulmonary arterial hypertension), 3 (PH due to lung disease), and 4 (chronic thromboembolic PH) are at high risk if untreated and may benefit from management at a specialized PH center.

original: In nonpregnant adults with a history of obstetric APS only, prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) after adequate risk/benefit evaluation (ie, aPL profile, coexistent traditional cardiovascular risk fac- tors, intolerance, or contraindication to aspirin) may be considered to reduce the risk of stroke.462,468
paraphrased: For nonpregnant adults who have a history of obstetric APS alone, considering prophylactic aspirin therapy at a dose of 75–100 mg daily may be appropriate to lower stroke risk, following a thorough assessment of risks and benefits, including aPL profile, existing traditional cardiovascular risk factors, and any aspirin intolerance or contraindications.

original: In patients with SLE and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a low-risk antiphospholipid profile (ie, isolated anticardiolipin antibody or anti–β2-glycoprotein 1 antibodies at low to medium titers, particularly if transiently pos- itive), prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) may be considered to reduce the risk of stroke.462,463,469,470
paraphrased: For patients with SLE who have no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and exhibit a low-risk antiphospholipid profile (such as isolated anticardiolipin or anti–β2-glycoprotein 1 antibodies at low to medium levels, especially if temporarily positive), considering daily aspirin (75–100 mg) as a preventive measure against stroke may be appropriate.

original: Patients with severe AS should be evaluated for the need for aortic valve intervention before elective NCS to reduce perioperative risk.*1,2
paraphrased: Before undergoing elective non-cardiac surgery, patients with severe aortic stenosis should be assessed for potential aortic valve intervention to minimize perioperative risk.

original: In the first aid situation, it is reasonable to leave an open chest wound exposed to ambient air; place a clean, nonocclusive, dry dressing (eg, gauze dressing, part of a tee shirt); or place a specialized dressing such as a vented chest seal. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: In a first aid scenario, it is appropriate to either leave an open chest wound uncovered, apply a clean, dry, nonocclusive dressing like gauze or a piece of a tee shirt, or use a specialized dressing such as a vented chest seal.

original: In patients with HCM who have a variant of uncertain significance (VUS), the usefulness of clinical genetic testing of phenotype-negative relatives for the purpose of variant reclassification is uncertain.4,7,8,28
paraphrased: For patients with HCM possessing a variant of uncertain significance (VUS), the effectiveness of conducting clinical genetic testing on relatives without the phenotype to aid in variant reclassification remains unclear.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and native left-sided valve endocarditis who exhibit mobile vegetations >10 mm in length, early surgery (during initial hospitalization before completion of a full therapeutic course of anti- biotics) may be considered to reduce the risk of recurrent embolism if there is no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurologi- cal damage.460–465
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke or TIA with native left-sided valve endocarditis and mobile vegetations exceeding 10 mm, early surgical intervention during the initial hospital stay, prior to completing a full course of antibiotics, can be considered to lower the risk of recurrent embolism, provided there is no intracranial hemorrhage or significant neurological damage.

original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR and HF with reduced LVEF, a cardiologist expert in the management of patients with HF and LV systolic dysfunction should be the primary MDT member responsible for implementing and monitoring optimal GDMT.9,12
paraphrased: For patients with chronic severe secondary MR and heart failure with reduced LVEF, a cardiologist specializing in heart failure and left ventricular systolic dysfunction should lead the multidisciplinary team in administering and overseeing optimal guideline-directed medical therapy.

original: Superficial wounds and abrasions should be thoroughly irrigated until there is no obvious debris or foreign matter in the wound.
paraphrased: Superficial wounds and abrasions need to be carefully rinsed until all visible debris or foreign material is removed.

original: In patients with periodontal disease (PD), good oral hygiene and regular dental care can be ben- eficial to lower stroke risk.486–488
paraphrased: For patients with periodontal disease, maintaining good oral hygiene and receiving regular dental care can help reduce the risk of stroke.

original: For patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing and were found to have no pathogenic variants (ie, harbor only benign or likely benign variants), cascade genetic testing of the family is not useful.4,8–10
paraphrased: Cascade genetic testing of the family is not beneficial for patients with HCM who have had genetic testing and only possess benign or likely benign variants, with no pathogenic variants detected.

original: In patients with suspected moderate or severe AS who are undergoing elevated-risk NCS, preoperative echocardiography is recommended before elective NCS to guide perioperative management.*
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having moderate or severe AS and facing high-risk NCS, it is advised to perform preoperative echocardiography prior to elective NCS to inform perioperative management.

original: A superficial wound caused by an animal or human bite or with contamination with human or animal saliva should be evaluated in a medical facility as soon as possible.
paraphrased: A superficial wound resulting from an animal or human bite, or contaminated with human or animal saliva, should be promptly assessed at a medical facility.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and IE, early valve surgery (during initial hospital- ization before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) may be considered in patients with an indication for surgery who have no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage.466,467
paraphrased: For patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and infective endocarditis, early valve surgery during the initial hospitalization, before completing a full course of antibiotics, can be considered if surgery is indicated and there is no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or significant neurological damage.

original: In patients hospitalized with COVID-19, treat- ment with full-dose anticoagulation (eg, enoxa- parin, apixaban) is not recommended to prevent stroke.489,490
paraphrased: For patients admitted to the hospital with COVID-19, using full-dose anticoagulation (such as enoxaparin or apixaban) is not advised for stroke prevention.

original: Ongoing clinical screening is not indicated in genotype-negative relatives in families with genotype-positive HCM, unless the disease- causing variant is downgraded to a VUS, likely benign, or benign variant during follow-up.23,29–32 *Strong evidence HCM genes include, at the time of this publication: MYH7,
paraphrased: Routine clinical screening is unnecessary for relatives without the genotype in families with genotype-positive HCM, unless the pathogenic variant is reclassified as a variant of uncertain significance, likely benign, or benign during follow-up.

original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR related to LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%) who have persistent symptoms (NYHA class II, III, or IV) while on optimal GDMT for HF (Stage D), TEER is reasonable in patients with appropriate anatomy as defined on TEE and with LVEF between 20% and 50%, LVESD ≤70 mm, and pulmonary artery systolic pressure ≤70 mm Hg.1–8
paraphrased: For patients with chronic severe secondary MR due to LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%) who continue to experience symptoms (NYHA class II, III, or IV) despite optimal GDMT for HF (Stage D), TEER is a reasonable option if they have suitable anatomy as determined by TEE, with LVEF between 20% and 50%, LVESD ≤70 mm, and pulmonary artery systolic pressure ≤70 mm Hg.

original: In all adults, screening for substance misuse and substance use disorders (eg, alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, opioids, amphetamines) is recommended to inform stroke risk.506–520 Other interventions
paraphrased: It is advised to screen all adults for substance misuse and substance use disorders, such as alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, opioids, and amphetamines, to assess stroke risk.

original: In patients with severe secondary MR (Stages C and D), mitral valve surgery is reasonable when CABG is undertaken for the treatment of myocardial ischemia.9–15
paraphrased: For patients with severe secondary MR (Stages C and D), it is appropriate to perform mitral valve surgery concurrently with CABG for myocardial ischemia treatment.

original: In patients with IE and major ischemic stroke, delaying valve surgery for at least 4 weeks may be considered for patients with IE and major ischemic stroke or intracranial hemorrhage if the patient is hemodynamically stable.460,468
paraphrased: For patients with IE and major ischemic stroke or intracranial hemorrhage who are hemodynamically stable, it may be advisable to postpone valve surgery for a minimum of 4 weeks.

original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe AS and normal LV systolic function as assessed by echocardiography within the past year, it is reason­ able to proceed with elective low-risk NCS.3–5 *Modified from the “2020 ACC/AHA Guideline for the Management of Pa­ tients With Valvular Heart Disease.”6
paraphrased: For patients without symptoms who have moderate or severe aortic stenosis and normal left ventricular systolic function confirmed by echocardiography in the last year, it is appropriate to undergo elective low-risk non-cardiac surgery.

original: It is reasonable to use running tap water or sterile saline solutions for wound irrigation instead of antiseptic agents such as povidone-iodine.
paraphrased: Using running tap water or sterile saline for wound irrigation is a sensible alternative to antiseptic agents like povidone-iodine.

original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assess- ment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are recommended at periodic intervals depending on age (every 1-2 years in children and adolescents and every 3-5 years in adults) and change in clinical status (Figures 1 and 2, Table 7).1–5
paraphrased: For those with a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression of HCM, it is advised to conduct regular clinical evaluations, electrocardiograms, and cardiac imaging at intervals based on age—every 1-2 years for children and adolescents, and every 3-5 years for adults—as well as any changes in clinical condition.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and mechanical heart valves, treatment with dabigatran causes harm.*457 *A similar recommendation in another guideline is worded slightly differently; however, the process used to reach consensus was the same in both cases.
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA and have mechanical heart valves, using dabigatran is detrimental.

original: Patients with severe mitral stenosis (MS) should be evaluated for the need for mitral valve (MV) interven­ tion before elective NCS.1–17
paraphrased: Before undergoing elective non-cardiac surgery, individuals with severe mitral stenosis should be assessed to determine if mitral valve intervention is necessary.

original: It is reasonable to cover clean superficial wounds and abrasions with an occlusive dressing to promote wound healing.
paraphrased: Applying an occlusive dressing to clean superficial wounds and abrasions is advisable to enhance healing.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA and LV thrombus, anticoagulation with therapeutic warfarin for at least 3 months is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.504–508
paraphrased: For patients experiencing stroke or TIA with LV thrombus, it is advised to administer therapeutic warfarin for a minimum of 3 months to lower the risk of another stroke.

original: In patients who use recreational drugs (eg, cannabis, synthetic cannabinoids, cocaine, heroin, methamphet- amine), misuse alcohol or prescription medications (eg, stimulants and opioids), or have a substance use disorder, counseling to stop or appropriate substance use disorder treatments (eg, pharmacological, behav- ioral, or multimodal) as appropriate are reasonable to reduce stroke risk.521–531 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For individuals who consume recreational drugs (such as cannabis, synthetic cannabinoids, cocaine, heroin, methamphetamine), misuse alcohol or prescription drugs (like stimulants and opioids), or have a substance use disorder, it is advisable to provide counseling to cease use or to administer suitable treatments for substance use disorder (including pharmacological, behavioral, or multimodal approaches) to effectively lower the risk of stroke.

original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive sports of any intensity is reasonable.6,7
paraphrased: For those who have a positive genotype but do not exhibit the phenotype for HCM, engaging in competitive sports at any level is considered reasonable.

original: In patients with severe MS who cannot undergo MV intervention before NCS, perioperative invasive hemodynamic monitoring is reasonable to guide management to reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications.
paraphrased: For patients with severe MS who are unable to have MV intervention prior to NCS, it is advisable to use perioperative invasive hemodynamic monitoring to help manage and lower the risk of cardiovascular complications.

original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR from atrial annular dilation with preserved LV systolic function (LVEF ≥50%) who have severe persistent symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) despite therapy for HF and therapy for associated AF or other comorbidities (Stage D), mitral valve surgery may be considered.16–20
paraphrased: For patients experiencing chronic severe secondary mitral regurgitation due to atrial annular dilation, with maintained left ventricular systolic function (LVEF ≥50%) and enduring severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) despite heart failure treatment and management of associated atrial fibrillation or other comorbidities (Stage D), mitral valve surgery can be considered.

original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR related to LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%) who have persistent severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) while on optimal GDMT for HF (Stage D), mitral valve surgery may be considered.9,12,21–43
paraphrased: For patients with chronic severe secondary mitral regurgitation due to left ventricular systolic dysfunction (LVEF below 50%) who continue to experience severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) despite receiving optimal guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure (Stage D), mitral valve surgery can be considered.

original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, ICD is not recommended for primary prevention.2–6,8
paraphrased: For those with a positive genotype but negative phenotype for HCM, an ICD is not advised for primary prevention.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of acute MI, it is reasonable to perform advanced cardiac imaging (eg, contrasted echocar- diogram or cardiac MRI) to assess for the presence of LV thrombus.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a stroke or TIA alongside an acute MI, it is advisable to conduct advanced cardiac imaging, such as a contrasted echocardiogram or cardiac MRI, to evaluate for LV thrombus.

original: If a person with superficial wound or abrasion develops redness, swelling, foul-smelling wound drainage, increased pain, or fever, it is reasonable to remove the dressing, inspect the wound, and obtain medical care. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: If an individual with a superficial wound or abrasion experiences redness, swelling, malodorous discharge, heightened pain, or fever, it is advisable to take off the dressing, examine the wound, and seek medical attention.

original: In pregnant or early postpartum (within 6 weeks of delivery), patients with severe hypertension (2 measurements of SBP ≥160 mm Hg or DBP ≥110 mm Hg, 15 minutes apart), BP-lowering treatment to a target <160/110 mm Hg as soon as possible is recommended to reduce the risk of fatal maternal ICH.551–558
paraphrased: For patients who are pregnant or within six weeks postpartum and experiencing severe hypertension (with two blood pressure readings of SBP ≥160 mm Hg or DBP ≥110 mm Hg taken 15 minutes apart), it is advised to promptly administer BP-lowering treatment to achieve a target below 160/110 mm Hg to minimize the risk of fatal maternal intracerebral hemorrhage.

original: In patients with severe MS who cannot undergo MV intervention before NCS, perioperative heart-rate control (eg, beta blockers, calcium channel blockers [CCBs], ivabradine, digoxin) may be considered to prolong diastolic filling time and decrease periopera­ tive cardiovascular complications.18–21
paraphrased: For patients with severe mitral stenosis who are unable to have mitral valve intervention prior to non-cardiac surgery, controlling heart rate perioperatively with agents such as beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, ivabradine, or digoxin may be considered to extend diastolic filling time and reduce cardiovascular complications during the perioperative period.

original: In patients with CAD and chronic severe secondary MR related to LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%) (Stage D) who are undergoing mitral valve surgery because of severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) that persist despite GDMT for HF, chordal-sparing mitral valve replacement may be reasonable to choose over downsized annuloplasty repair.9,12,21–32,44–47
paraphrased: For patients with CAD and chronic severe secondary MR due to LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%) (Stage D) who continue to experience severe symptoms (NYHA class III or IV) despite GDMT for HF and are undergoing mitral valve surgery, opting for chordal-sparing mitral valve replacement might be a reasonable alternative to downsized annuloplasty repair.

original: In adult patients with HCM, a comprehensive, systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment at initial evaluation and every 1 to 2 years thereafter is recommended and should include evaluation of these risk factors (Figures 1 and 3, Table 8)1–25: a.   Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; b.   Personal history of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic; c.   Family history in close relative of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; d.   Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm; e.   NSVT episodes on continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring.
paraphrased: For adult patients with HCM, it is advised to conduct a thorough and systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment during the initial evaluation and subsequently every 1 to 2 years. This assessment should encompass the following risk factors: a. Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; b. Personal history of syncope suspected to be arrhythmic based on clinical history; c. Family history of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias in close relatives; d. Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm; e. NSVT episodes observed on continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring.

original: For a person with a suspected spinal injury, the first aid provider should have the person remain as still as possible (unless safety considerations warrant movement) and activate the emergency response system.
paraphrased: If a spinal injury is suspected, the first aid responder should ensure the individual stays immobile unless movement is necessary for safety, and should contact emergency services.

original: In patients with HDP, including chronic hyperten- sion in pregnancy, treatment with antihypertensive medication to a goal BP of <140/90 mm Hg is reasonable to reduce the risk of pregnancy- associated stroke.559–566
paraphrased: For patients with hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, such as chronic hypertension during pregnancy, it is advisable to use antihypertensive drugs to achieve a target blood pressure below 140/90 mm Hg to lower the risk of stroke related to pregnancy.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA and new LV thrombus (<3 months), the safety of antico- agulation with a direct oral anticoagulant to reduce risk of recurrent stroke is uncertain.509
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA and have developed a new LV thrombus within the past three months, the safety of using a direct oral anticoagulant to lower the risk of another stroke is unclear.

original: In patients with TR, TTE is indicated to evaluate the presence and severity of TR, determine the etiology, measure the sizes of the right- sided chambers and inferior vena cava, assess RV systolic function, estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure, and characterize any associated left-sided heart disease.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with TR, TTE is recommended to assess the presence and severity of TR, identify its cause, evaluate the dimensions of the right-sided chambers and inferior vena cava, assess RV systolic function, estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure, and identify any related left-sided heart disease.

original: In patients with suspected moderate or severe val­ vular regurgitation, preoperative echocardiography is recommended before elective NCS to guide periop­ erative management.*
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having moderate or severe valvular regurgitation, it is advised to perform preoperative echocardiography prior to elective non-cardiac surgery to assist in perioperative management.

original: A person with signs and symptoms of a concus- sion should be immediately removed from activity (play/sports) and not allowed to return to activity until evaluated by a health care professional.
paraphrased: Anyone exhibiting concussion symptoms should be promptly taken out of activity (such as play or sports) and not permitted to resume until assessed by a healthcare professional.

original: In patients with TR, invasive measurement of the cardiac index, right-sided diastolic pressures, pulmonary artery pressures, and pulmonary vascular resistance, as well as right ventriculography, can be useful when clinical and noninvasive data are discordant or inadequate.3–5
paraphrased: For patients with TR, when clinical and noninvasive data are inconsistent or insufficient, it may be beneficial to perform invasive assessments of the cardiac index, right-sided diastolic pressures, pulmonary artery pressures, and pulmonary vascular resistance, along with right ventriculography.

original: In adults, screening for a history of certain adverse pregnancy outcomes (APOs), including HDP, preterm birth, gestational diabetes, and placental disorders, followed by subsequent evalu- ation and management of vascular risk factors, is recommended to reduce the risk of stroke. Other intervention
paraphrased: It is advised that adults be screened for a history of specific adverse pregnancy outcomes, such as hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, preterm birth, gestational diabetes, and placental disorders, and then evaluated and managed for vascular risk factors to lower the risk of stroke.

original: In patients with VHD who meet indications for valvular intervention based on clinical presentation and severity of regurgitation, the need for valvular intervention should be considered before elective elevated-risk NCS to reduce perioperative risk.*1–3
paraphrased: For patients with VHD who qualify for valvular intervention due to their clinical symptoms and regurgitation severity, it is advisable to evaluate the necessity of this intervention prior to elective high-risk NCS to minimize perioperative risk.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of acute anterior MI with reduced ejection fraction (EF; <50%) but no evidence of LV thrombus, empirical anticoagulation for at least
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a stroke or TIA alongside acute anterior MI with an ejection fraction below 50% and without signs of LV thrombus, it is advised to initiate empirical anticoagulation for a minimum duration.

original: For adult patients with HCM who are not otherwise identified as high risk for SCD, or in whom a decision to proceed with ICD placement remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal/ family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with LGE (Table 8).1,11,12,15–20
paraphrased: For adult patients with HCM who are not classified as high risk for SCD, or when the decision to implant an ICD is still uncertain after evaluating personal/family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory ECG monitoring, CMR imaging is useful to evaluate maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and the degree of myocardial fibrosis using LGE.

original: For a person with signs or symptoms of severe head injury (such as loss of consciousness, worsening headache, vomiting, altered mental status, seizures, visual changes, swelling, or deformities of the scalp), EMS should be activated. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: If an individual exhibits signs or symptoms indicative of a severe head injury, including loss of consciousness, worsening headache, vomiting, altered mental status, seizures, visual disturbances, scalp swelling, or deformities, emergency medical services should be contacted.

original: For patients who are ≥16 years of age with HCM, it is reasonable to obtain echocardiography-derived left atrial diameter and maximal LVOT gradient to aid in calculating an estimated 5-year sudden death risk that may be useful during shared decision-making for ICD placement (Table 8).2,22
paraphrased: For patients aged 16 years and older with HCM, it is advisable to measure the left atrial diameter and maximal LVOT gradient via echocardiography to help estimate the 5-year risk of sudden death, which can be beneficial in shared decision-making regarding ICD placement (Table 8).

original: In patients with signs and symptoms of right-sided HF attributable to severe TR (Stages C and D), diuretics can be useful.
paraphrased: Diuretics may be beneficial for patients exhibiting signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure due to severe tricuspid regurgitation (Stages C and D).

original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe MR, normal LV systolic function, and estimated PA systolic pressure <50 mm Hg, it is reasonable to perform elective NCS.*45
paraphrased: For asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe mitral regurgitation, normal left ventricular systolic function, and an estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure below 50 mm Hg, elective non-cardiac surgery is considered reasonable.

original: In patients with a history of HDP or other APOs, early evaluation and management of chronic hypertension are recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.609–613
paraphrased: For patients with a history of HDP or other APOs, it is advised to assess and manage chronic hypertension early to lower the risk of stroke.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and left atrial or left atrial appendage thrombus in the setting of ischemic, nonischemic, or restrictive cardiomyopathy and LV dysfunction, antico- agulant therapy with warfarin is recommended for at least 3 months to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke or TIA who have a thrombus in the left atrium or left atrial appendage due to ischemic, nonischemic, or restrictive cardiomyopathy and left ventricular dysfunction, it is advised to administer warfarin as an anticoagulant for a minimum of 3 months to lower the risk of another stroke or TIA.

original: A person with a painful extremity injury that limits use should avoid activities that cause pain and seek medical attention.
paraphrased: Individuals experiencing a painful injury in a limb that restricts movement should refrain from activities that induce pain and consult a healthcare professional.

original: In adults, screening for a history of endometriosis is reasonable to inform the risk of stroke.649–653 Other intervention
paraphrased: For adults, evaluating a history of endometriosis is advisable to assess stroke risk.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in the setting of a mechanical assist device, treatment with warfarin and aspirin can be beneficial to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.516–523
paraphrased: For patients experiencing an ischemic stroke or TIA while using a mechanical assist device, administering warfarin alongside aspirin may help lower the risk of another stroke or TIA.

original: In individuals with endometriosis, vascular risk factor evaluation and modification of vascular risk factors are reasonable to reduce the risk of stroke.649–653
paraphrased: For those with endometriosis, assessing and adjusting vascular risk factors is advisable to lower the likelihood of stroke.

original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe aor­ tic regurgitation and normal LV systolic function (LVEF >55%), it is reasonable to perform elective NCS.*6 *Modified from the “2020 ACC/AHA Guideline for the Management of Pa­ tients With Valvular Heart Disease.”3
paraphrased: For patients without symptoms who have moderate or severe aortic regurgitation and normal left ventricular systolic function (LVEF greater than 55%), it is appropriate to consider elective non-cardiac surgery.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in the setting of LV noncompaction, treatment with warfarin can be beneficial to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke or TIA due to LV noncompaction, using warfarin may help lower the risk of another stroke or TIA.

original: For patients who undergo successful transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI), it is reasonable to perform NCS early* as clinically indicated.1–3
paraphrased: For patients who have had a successful transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI), it is appropriate to conduct NCS early when clinically necessary.

original: In patients with signs and symptoms of right-sided HF attributable to severe secondary TR (Stages C and D), therapies to treat the primary cause of HF (eg, pulmonary vasodilators to reduce elevated pulmonary artery pressures, GDMT for HF with reduced LVEF, or rhythm control of AF) can be useful1,2
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure due to severe secondary tricuspid regurgitation (Stages C and D), addressing the underlying cause of heart failure—such as using pulmonary vasodilators to lower high pulmonary artery pressures, guideline-directed medical therapy for heart failure with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, or rhythm control for atrial fibrillation—can be beneficial.

original: In patients with severe TR (Stages C and D) undergoing left-sided valve surgery, tricuspid valve surgery is recommended.1–8
paraphrased: For patients with severe tricuspid regurgitation (Stages C and D) who are having left-sided valve surgery, it is advised to perform tricuspid valve surgery.

original: For children and adolescents with HCM who have a borderline risk for SCD, or in whom a decision to proceed with ICD placement remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal and family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory electro- cardiographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for extent of myocardial fibrosis with LGE (Table 8).9–11
paraphrased: In children and adolescents with HCM who have an uncertain risk of SCD, or when the decision to implant an ICD is still unclear after evaluating personal and family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory ECG monitoring, CMR imaging is useful for assessing the extent of myocardial fibrosis using LGE (Table 8).

original: It can be useful for first aid providers to apply cold (such as with ice and water surrounded by a damp cloth) to an acute sprain or strain for pain and swelling. Cold application should be limited to 20 to 30 minutes per application without direct contact on the skin to avoid cold injury.
paraphrased: First aid responders may find it beneficial to use cold therapy, like ice wrapped in a damp cloth, on a new sprain or strain to reduce pain and swelling. Limit each application to 20 to 30 minutes and avoid direct skin contact to prevent cold injury.

original: For children and adolescents with HCM, a compre- hensive, systematic noninvasive SCD risk assess- ment at initial evaluation and every 1 to 2 years thereafter is recommended and should include evaluation of these risk factors (Figures 1 and 3, Table 8)1–8: a.   Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; b.   Personal history of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic; c.   Family history in close relative of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; d.   Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneu- rysm; e.   NSVT episodes on continuous ambulatory elec- trocardiographic monitoring.
paraphrased: For children and adolescents with HCM, it is advised to conduct a thorough and systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment during the initial evaluation and every 1 to 2 years thereafter, which should include assessing the following risk factors: a. Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; b. Personal history of syncope suspected to be arrhythmic based on clinical history; c. Family history of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias in close relatives; d. Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm; e. NSVT episodes detected through continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring.

original: In individuals considering CHC, lower doses of ethinyl estradiol are recommended to minimize potential increased stroke risk.658–663
paraphrased: For those contemplating CHC use, it is advised to opt for lower doses of ethinyl estradiol to reduce the potential risk of stroke.

original: First aid providers may consider applying a com- pression wrap after an acute ankle sprain or strain to promote comfort after an injury. Application of the compression wrap should be performed with- out compromising circulation. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: First aid responders might apply a compression wrap following a sudden ankle sprain or strain to enhance comfort, ensuring it does not impede circulation.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in sinus rhythm with ischemic or nonischemic cardio- myopathy and reduced EF without evidence of left atrial or LV thrombus, the effectiveness of anticoagulation compared with antiplatelet therapy is uncertain, and the choice should be individualized.524–528
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke or TIA who have sinus rhythm, ischemic or nonischemic cardiomyopathy, and reduced ejection fraction without left atrial or LV thrombus, the relative effectiveness of anticoagulation versus antiplatelet therapy remains unclear, necessitating a personalized treatment decision.

original: For patients who undergo MV TEER, it is reasonable to perform NCS after the successful MV intervention as clinically indicated.4 *Evidence supports the safety of NCS within 30 days of TAVI, if indicated.
paraphrased: For patients receiving MV TEER, it is appropriate to conduct NCS following a successful MV procedure when clinically warranted. Evidence indicates that NCS is safe within 30 days post-TAVI, if necessary.

original: For patients <16 years of age with HCM, it is rea- sonable to calculate an estimated 5-year sudden death risk that includes echocardiographic param- eters (interventricular septal thickness in diastole, LV posterior wall thickness in end-diastole, left atrial diameter, maximal LVOT gradient) and genotype, which may be useful during shared decision-making for ICD placement (Table 8).1,12
paraphrased: For patients under 16 with HCM, it is advisable to estimate a 5-year sudden death risk using echocardiographic parameters (such as interventricular septal thickness during diastole, LV posterior wall thickness at end-diastole, left atrial diameter, and maximal LVOT gradient) along with genotype, as this information can aid in shared decision-making regarding ICD placement (Table 8).

original: In patients with progressive TR (Stage B) undergoing left-sided valve surgery, tricuspid valve surgery can be beneficial in the context of either 1) tricuspid annular dilation (tricuspid annulus end diastolic diameter >4.0 cm) or 2) prior signs and symptoms of right-sided HF.3–10
paraphrased: For patients with progressive TR (Stage B) who are having left-sided valve surgery, performing tricuspid valve surgery may be advantageous if there is either 1) dilation of the tricuspid annulus (end diastolic diameter >4.0 cm) or 2) a history of signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure.

original: In individuals with specific stroke risk factors (ie, age >35 years, tobacco use, hypertension, or migraine with aura) who are considering contra- ception, shared decision-making is recommended to determine the best contraceptive choice to bal- ance the risk of stroke from contraception and the risk of stroke with pregnancy.
paraphrased: For individuals with certain stroke risk factors, such as being over 35, using tobacco, having hypertension, or experiencing migraines with aura, it is advised to engage in shared decision-making to select the most suitable contraceptive method that balances the stroke risk associated with contraception against the stroke risk during pregnancy.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA and LV assist devices (LVADs), treatment with dabigatran instead of warfarin for the primary or second- ary prevention of ischemic stroke or TIA causes harm.529
paraphrased: For patients with stroke or TIA who have LV assist devices (LVADs), using dabigatran rather than warfarin for primary or secondary prevention of ischemic stroke or TIA is harmful.

original: In patients with rapid AF identified in the setting of NCS, it is reasonable to treat potential underlying triggers contributing to AF and rapid ventricular response (eg, sepsis, anemia, pain).*1–5
paraphrased: For patients experiencing rapid atrial fibrillation during NCS, addressing possible underlying causes such as sepsis, anemia, or pain that may contribute to AF and a rapid ventricular response is advisable.

original: If a fracture is associated with an open wound and severe bleeding, the First Aid for Severe External Bleeding and First Aid for Life- Threatening Extremity Bleeding That Is Not Controlled by Direct Pressure recommendations should be followed.
paraphrased: In cases where a fracture is accompanied by an open wound and significant bleeding, adhere to the guidelines for First Aid for Severe External Bleeding and for Life-Threatening Extremity Bleeding that cannot be managed with direct pressure.

original: In patients with HCM, application of individual clinical judgment is recommended when assessing the prognostic strength of conventional risk marker(s) within the clinical profile of the individual patient, as well as a thorough and balanced discussion of the evidence, benefits, and estimated risks to engage the fully informed patient’s active participation in ICD decision-making.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is advised to use personal clinical judgment to evaluate the prognostic value of traditional risk markers in the patient's clinical profile, alongside a comprehensive and balanced discussion of the evidence, benefits, and potential risks, to ensure the patient is fully informed and actively involved in the ICD decision-making process.

original: In patients with signs and symptoms of right-sided HF and severe primary TR (Stage D), isolated tricuspid valve surgery can be beneficial to reduce symptoms and recurrent hospitalizations.11–14
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting symptoms of right-sided heart failure and severe primary tricuspid regurgitation (Stage D), performing isolated tricuspid valve surgery may help alleviate symptoms and decrease the frequency of hospital readmissions.

original: If a fractured extremity is blue, purple, or pale, the emergency response system should be activated immediately.
paraphrased: Activate the emergency response system right away if a broken limb appears blue, purple, or pale.

original: In individuals with specific stroke risk factors (ie, age >35 years, tobacco use, hypertension, or migraine with aura) who are considering contra- ception, progestin-only contraception or nonhor- monal contraception is reasonable to prevent the increased stroke risk associated with estrogen- containing contraception.370,661–670
paraphrased: For individuals with certain stroke risk factors, such as being over 35, smoking, having high blood pressure, or experiencing migraines with aura, it is advisable to use progestin-only or non-hormonal contraception to avoid the heightened stroke risk linked to estrogen-containing contraceptives.

original: In patients with a nonlacunar ischemic stroke of undetermined cause and a PFO, recom- mendations for PFO closure versus medical management should be made jointly by the patient, a cardiologist, and a neurologist, taking into account the probability of a causal role for the PFO.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a nonlacunar ischemic stroke of unknown origin with a PFO, the decision between PFO closure and medical treatment should be collaboratively determined by the patient, cardiologist, and neurologist, considering the likelihood that the PFO is causally involved.

original: For patients with HCM and previous documented cardiac arrest or sustained VT, ICD placement is recommended (Figure 3, Table 8).2–6
paraphrased: ICD implantation is advised for patients with HCM who have a history of documented cardiac arrest or sustained VT (Figure 3, Table 8).2–6

original: In patients with signs and symptoms of right- sided HF and severe isolated secondary TR attributable to annular dilation (in the absence of pulmonary hypertension or left-sided disease) who are poorly responsive to medical therapy (Stage D), isolated tricuspid valve surgery can be beneficial to reduce symptoms and recurrent hospitalizations.11,12,15–19
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting signs and symptoms of right-sided heart failure and severe isolated secondary tricuspid regurgitation due to annular dilation, without pulmonary hypertension or left-sided disease, and who do not respond well to medical treatment (Stage D), isolated tricuspid valve surgery may help alleviate symptoms and decrease the frequency of hospital readmissions.

original: In patients with new-onset AF identified in the set­ ting of NCS, initiation of postoperative anticoagula­ tion therapy can be beneficial after considering the competing risks associated with thromboembolism and perioperative bleeding.*4,6 Postdischarge
paraphrased: For patients experiencing new-onset AF during NCS, starting anticoagulation therapy post-surgery may be advantageous after evaluating the competing risks of thromboembolism and bleeding during the perioperative period.

original: Screening for a history of premature ovarian failure (before 40 years of age) and early meno- pause (before 45 years of age) can be beneficial to inform the risk of stroke.674–678 Other interventions
paraphrased: Assessing for a history of premature ovarian failure (occurring before age 40) and early menopause (occurring before age 45) can be advantageous in evaluating stroke risk.

original: In patients with new-onset AF identified in the set­ ting of NCS, outpatient follow-up for thromboembolic risk stratification and AF surveillance are recom­ mended given a high risk of AF recurrence.*7–11 *Adapted from the “2023 ACC/AHA/ACCP/HRS Guideline for the Diagnosis and Management of Atrial Fibrillation.”12
paraphrased: For patients newly diagnosed with AF during NCS, it is advised to have outpatient follow-up to assess thromboembolic risk and monitor AF due to the high likelihood of recurrence.

original: Splinting of a fractured extremity can be useful to reduce pain, reduce risk for further injury, and facilitate transport to a medical facility.
paraphrased: Applying a splint to a broken limb can help alleviate pain, minimize the chance of additional injury, and aid in transporting the patient to a healthcare facility.

original: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary TR (Stage C) and progressive RV dilation or systolic dysfunction, isolated tricuspid valve surgery may be considered.12,20
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with severe primary TR (Stage C) experiencing progressive right ventricular dilation or systolic dysfunction, isolated tricuspid valve surgery can be contemplated.

original: In patients with premature ovarian failure (meno- pause before 40 years of age) or early meno- pause (before 45 years of age), evaluation and modification of vascular risk factors are recom- mended to reduce the elevated stroke risk in this population.674,675,677–679
paraphrased: For individuals experiencing premature ovarian failure (menopause before age 40) or early menopause (before age 45), it is advised to assess and adjust vascular risk factors to mitigate the increased risk of stroke in this group.

original: In patients 18 to 60 years of age with a nonla- cunar ischemic stroke of undetermined cause despite a thorough evaluation and a PFO with high-risk anatomic features,* it is reasonable to choose closure with a transcatheter device and long-term antiplatelet therapy over anti- platelet therapy alone for preventing recurrent stroke.552–557
paraphrased: For patients aged 18 to 60 who have experienced a non-lacunar ischemic stroke of unknown origin after comprehensive assessment and possess a PFO with high-risk anatomical characteristics, opting for closure using a transcatheter device combined with long-term antiplatelet therapy is a reasonable choice over solely using antiplatelet therapy to prevent recurrent strokes.

original: For adult patients with HCM with ≥1 major risk factors for SCD, it is reasonable to offer an ICD. These major risk factors include (Figure 3, Table 8)2,3,7–21: a.   Sudden death judged definitively or likely attributable to HCM in ≥1 first-degree or close relatives who are ≤50 years of age; b.   Massive LVH ≥30 mm in any LV segment; c.   ≥1 recent episodes of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic (ie, unlikely to be of neurocardiogenic [vasovagal] etiology, or related to LVOTO); d.    LV apical aneurysm with transmural scar or LGE; e.    LV systolic dysfunction (EF <50%).
paraphrased: For adult patients with HCM who have one or more significant risk factors for SCD, it is advisable to consider an ICD. These key risk factors include: a. Sudden death in one or more first-degree or close relatives aged 50 or younger, likely or definitely due to HCM; b. Massive LVH of 30 mm or more in any LV segment; c. One or more recent syncope episodes suspected to be arrhythmic based on clinical history (i.e., unlikely to be neurocardiogenic or related to LVOTO); d. LV apical aneurysm with transmural scar or LGE; e. LV systolic dysfunction with an EF below 50%.

original: For children with HCM who have ≥1 conventional risk factors, including unexplained syncope, massive LVH, NSVT, or family history of early HCM-related SCD, ICD placement is reasonable after considering the relatively high complication rates of long-term ICD placement in younger patients (Figure 3, Table 8).22–30
paraphrased: In children with HCM who present with one or more traditional risk factors—such as unexplained syncope, significant LVH, NSVT, or a family history of early SCD related to HCM—considering ICD placement is advisable, while taking into account the relatively high complication rates associated with long-term ICD use in younger individuals (Figure 3, Table 8).

original: In patients 18 to 60 years of age with a nonla- cunar ischemic stroke of undetermined cause despite a thorough evaluation and a PFO without high-risk anatomic features,* the ben- efit of closure with a transcatheter device and long-term antiplatelet therapy over antiplatelet therapy alone for preventing recurrent stroke is not well established,552–557
paraphrased: For patients aged 18 to 60 who have experienced a non-lacunar ischemic stroke of unknown origin after comprehensive assessment and possess a PFO lacking high-risk anatomical characteristics, the advantage of using a transcatheter device for closure combined with long-term antiplatelet therapy, compared to antiplatelet therapy alone, in preventing recurrent strokes is not clearly determined.

original: In transgender women and gender-diverse indi- viduals taking estrogens for gender affirmation, evaluation and modification of risk factors can be beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.700–703
paraphrased: For transgender women and gender-diverse individuals using estrogens for gender affirmation, assessing and adjusting risk factors may help lower the likelihood of stroke.

original: In patients with signs and symptoms of right- sided HF and severe TR (Stage D) who have undergone previous left-sided valve surgery, reoperation with isolated tricuspid valve surgery may be considered in the absence of severe pulmonary hypertension or severe RV systolic dysfunction.1,2,11,18
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting right-sided heart failure symptoms and severe tricuspid regurgitation (Stage D) who have previously had left-sided valve surgery, isolated tricuspid valve surgery can be contemplated if severe pulmonary hypertension or severe right ventricular systolic dysfunction is not present.

original: Covering open wounds associated with a suspected fracture with a clean dressing may be useful to lower the risk for further contamination and infection. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: Applying a clean dressing to open wounds linked to a suspected fracture can help reduce the risk of additional contamination and infection.

original: It may be reasonable to treat a deformed frac- tured extremity in the position found unless straightening the fracture is necessary to facilitate safe and prompt transport to a medical facility.
paraphrased: Treating a deformed fractured limb in its current position might be appropriate unless realigning the fracture is essential for ensuring safe and quick transport to a healthcare facility.

original: For patients with mixed valve disease, TTE is recommended to assess the etiology, severity, and pathophysiological impact.
paraphrased: TTE is advised for evaluating the cause, severity, and physiological effects in patients with mixed valve disease.

original: Patients with cardiovascular implantable electronic devices (CIED) having elective NCS should have a management plan developed before surgery if elec­ tromagnetic interference (EMI) is anticipated, includ­ ing identification of the type of CIED (eg, pacemaker, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator [ICD], implant­ able monitor), manufacturer, and model.1–6
paraphrased: Before undergoing elective non-cardiac surgery, patients with cardiovascular implantable electronic devices (CIEDs) should have a pre-surgical management plan in place if electromagnetic interference (EMI) is expected. This plan should include identifying the CIED type (such as pacemaker, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator [ICD], or implantable monitor), as well as the manufacturer and model.

original: Patients who are pacemaker-dependent having surgeries above the umbilicus with anticipated EMI should have the pacemaker reprogrammed or have a magnet placed on the generator to provide an asyn­ chronous mode to avoid pacing inhibition.1,7
