original: The benefit of strategies other than rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling is unclear.
paraphrased: The effectiveness of methods besides the quick administration of cold IV fluids for cooling before hospital arrival is uncertain.

original: In patients with diabetes or impaired glucose toler­ ance, continuation of metformin during the periop­ erative period is reasonable to maintain glycemic control.8–12 *Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should be stopped ≥3 days and ertugliflozin ≥4 days before scheduled surgery.13
paraphrased: For individuals with diabetes or glucose intolerance, it is advisable to continue metformin throughout the perioperative period to manage blood sugar levels. Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should be discontinued at least 3 days prior to planned surgery, while ertugliflozin should be stopped at least 4 days before.

original: In patients for whom the optimal treatment strategy is unclear, a Heart Team approach that includes representatives from interven- tional cardiology, cardiac surgery, and clinical cardiology is recommended to improve patient outcomes.1-7
paraphrased: For patients where the best treatment plan is uncertain, it is advised to use a Heart Team approach involving specialists from interventional cardiology, cardiac surgery, and clinical cardiology to enhance patient outcomes.

original: We do not recommend the routine use of rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling of patients after ROSC. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: We advise against the regular practice of rapidly infusing cold IV fluids for cooling patients in the prehospital setting following ROSC.

original: In patients with ESUS, treatment with ticagre- lor is not recommended to reduce the risk of secondary stroke.781
paraphrased: For patients with ESUS, using ticagrelor is not advised for lowering the risk of a secondary stroke.

original: In patients with HCM and persistent LVEF <50%, ICD placement can be beneficial.3,20
paraphrased: For patients with HCM and a sustained LVEF below 50%, ICD implantation may be advantageous.

original: We recommend treatment of clinically apparent seizures in adult survivors of cardiac arrest.
paraphrased: We advise treating seizures that are clinically evident in adult cardiac arrest survivors.

original: In patients undergoing NCS, use of a volatile-based anesthetic agent or total intravenous anesthesia is reasonable for general anesthesia with no apparent difference in associated cardiovascular events (eg, MI, ischemia).1–3
paraphrased: For patients having NCS, it is acceptable to use either a volatile-based anesthetic or total intravenous anesthesia for general anesthesia, as there is no evident difference in related cardiovascular events such as myocardial infarction or ischemia.

original: In patients who are being considered for CABG, calculation of the STS risk score is recommended to help stratify patient risk.1,2
paraphrased: For patients evaluated for CABG, it is advised to calculate the STS risk score to assist in risk stratification.

original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite GDMT) who are candidates for heart transplantation, continuous-flow LVAD therapy is reasonable as a bridge to heart transplantation.15–19
paraphrased: For patients with nonobstructive HCM experiencing advanced heart failure (NYHA class III to IV) who remain symptomatic despite GDMT and are eligible for heart transplantation, using continuous-flow LVAD therapy as a bridge to transplantation is a reasonable option.

original: For patients with mechanical heart valves who are undergoing minor procedures (eg, dental extractions or cataract removal) where bleeding is easily controlled, continuation of VKA anticoagulation with a therapeutic INR is recommended.
paraphrased: It is advised that patients with mechanical heart valves maintain VKA anticoagulation with a therapeutic INR during minor procedures, such as dental extractions or cataract surgery, where bleeding can be easily managed.

original: In patients undergoing NCS where neuraxial is feasible, either neuraxial or general anesthesia is reasonable with no apparent difference in associated cardiovascular events.4–6
paraphrased: For patients having NCS where neuraxial anesthesia is possible, choosing between neuraxial or general anesthesia is appropriate, as there is no evident difference in cardiovascular event risk.

original: In patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, antiplatelet therapy is indicated in preference to oral anticoagulation to reduce the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke and other cardiovascular events while minimizing the risk of bleeding.789,790
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, it is recommended to use antiplatelet therapy instead of oral anticoagulation to lower the risk of another ischemic stroke and other cardiovascular incidents, while also reducing the likelihood of bleeding.

original: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, NYHA functional class II to class IV symptoms despite GDMT, and LBBB, CRT can be beneficial to improve symptoms.21–25
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, LVEF below 50%, and NYHA class II to IV symptoms that persist despite GDMT, CRT may help alleviate symptoms if LBBB is present.

original: In patients with multivessel CAD, an assessment of CAD complexity, such as the SYNTAX score, may be useful to guide revascularization.1-4
paraphrased: For patients with multivessel coronary artery disease, evaluating the complexity of the condition, for instance using the SYNTAX score, can aid in directing revascularization decisions.

original: In patients with HCM and clinical AF, anticoagulation is recommended with direct-acting oral anticoagu- lants (DOACs) as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, independent of CHA2DS2-VASc score.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with HCM and clinical AF, it is advised to use direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) as the primary choice for anticoagulation, with vitamin K antagonists as the secondary option, regardless of the CHA2DS2-VASc score.

original: For patients with a bileaflet mechanical AVR and no other risk factors for thromboembolism who are undergoing invasive procedures, temporary interruption of VKA anticoagulation, without bridging agents while the INR is subtherapeutic, is recommended.
paraphrased: For patients with a bileaflet mechanical AVR and no additional thromboembolism risk factors undergoing invasive procedures, it is advised to temporarily stop VKA anticoagulation without using bridging agents when the INR is below therapeutic levels.

original: We recommend promptly performing and interpreting electroencephalography (EEG) for the diagnosis of seizures in patients who do not follow commands after ROSC.
paraphrased: We advise conducting and analyzing an electroencephalogram (EEG) without delay to diagnose seizures in patients who remain unresponsive to commands following ROSC.

original: For patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, aspirin 50 to 325 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg, or the combination of aspi- rin 25 mg and extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg twice daily is indicated for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke.*791–794
paraphrased: For secondary prevention of ischemic stroke in patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, it is recommended to use aspirin at a dose of 50 to 325 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, or a combination of aspirin 25 mg with extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg taken twice daily.

original: Monitoring EEG repeatedly or continuously is reasonable for patients who do not follow commands after ROSC.
paraphrased: It is advisable to perform repeated or continuous EEG monitoring for patients who remain unresponsive to commands following ROSC.

original: For patients undergoing major abdominal surgery, the use of epidural analgesia for postoperative pain relief is reasonable to decrease the incidence of perioperative cardiac events.1,2
paraphrased: For individuals having major abdominal surgery, employing epidural analgesia for pain management after the procedure is advisable to reduce the risk of cardiac events during the perioperative period.

original: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis receiving VKA therapy who require immediate/ emergency noncardiac surgery or an invasive procedure, administration of 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (or its activated form) is reasonable.
paraphrased: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis on VKA therapy needing urgent or emergency noncardiac surgery or an invasive procedure, it is reasonable to administer 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate or its activated form.

original: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external cardiac device or monitor of >24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation is recommended with DOACs as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, inde- pendent of CHA2DS2-VASc score.1,6–8
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who have subclinical AF identified by an internal or external cardiac device or monitor lasting more than 24 hours per episode, anticoagulation is advised, with DOACs as the preferred first-line treatment and vitamin K antagonists as the second-line choice, regardless of the CHA2DS2-VASc score.

original: For patients with a hip fracture waiting for surgi­ cal repair, epidural analgesia may be considered to decrease the incidence of preoperative cardiac events.3
paraphrased: Epidural analgesia can be considered for patients with a hip fracture awaiting surgical repair to reduce the risk of preoperative cardiac events.

original: For patients already taking aspirin at the time of noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, the effectiveness of increasing the dose of aspirin or changing to another antiplatelet medication is not well established.410,798–800
paraphrased: For patients on aspirin during a noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, the benefits of either increasing the aspirin dose or switching to a different antiplatelet drug remain uncertain.

original: Treatment of nonconvulsive seizures (diagnosed by EEG only) is reasonable in adult survivors of cardiac arrest.
paraphrased: It is appropriate to treat nonconvulsive seizures identified solely by EEG in adults who have survived cardiac arrest.

original: In patients with angina or an anginal equiva- lent, undocumented ischemia, and angio- graphically intermediate stenoses, the use of fractional flow reserve (FFR) or instantaneous wave-free ratio (iFR) is recommended to guide the decision to proceed with PCI.1-6
paraphrased: For patients experiencing angina or similar symptoms, with unverified ischemia and angiographically moderate stenoses, it is advised to use fractional flow reserve (FFR) or instantaneous wave-free ratio (iFR) to determine whether to proceed with PCI.

original: In stable patients with angiographically inter- mediate stenoses and FFR >0.80 or iFR >0.89, PCI should not be performed.7-10
paraphrased: For patients who are stable and have angiographically intermediate stenoses with an FFR greater than 0.80 or an iFR greater than 0.89, PCI is not recommended.

original: In patients with AF in whom rate control strategy is planned, beta blockers, verapamil, or diltiazem are recommended, with the choice of agents according to patient preferences and comorbid conditions.9,10
paraphrased: For patients with AF where a rate control approach is intended, it is advised to use beta blockers, verapamil, or diltiazem, selecting the medication based on patient preferences and existing comorbidities.

original: For patients with bioprosthetic heart valves or annuloplasty rings who are receiving anticoagulation for AF, it is reasonable to consider the need for bridging anticoagulant therapy around the time of invasive procedures on the basis of the CHA2DS2-VASc score weighed against the risk of bleeding.
paraphrased: For patients with bioprosthetic heart valves or annuloplasty rings on anticoagulation for AF, evaluating the necessity of bridging anticoagulant therapy during invasive procedures should be based on the CHA2DS2-VASc score and balanced against bleeding risk.

original: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, maintenance of normothermia is reasonable to avoid perioperative complications overall.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with cardiovascular disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery, it is advisable to maintain normal body temperature to prevent perioperative complications.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, voluntary hospital-based or outpatient-focused quality monitoring and improvement programs are recommended to improve short-term and long-term adherence to nationally accepted, evidence-based guidelines for secondary stroke prevention.
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, it is advised to implement voluntary quality monitoring and improvement initiatives within hospitals or outpatient settings to enhance adherence to nationally recognized, evidence-based guidelines for secondary stroke prevention in both the short and long term.

original: A therapeutic trial of a nonsedating antiseizure medication may be reasonable in adult survivors of cardiac arrest with EEG patterns on the ictal-interictal continuum.
paraphrased: It may be appropriate to consider a trial of a nonsedating antiseizure drug in adult cardiac arrest survivors who exhibit EEG patterns on the ictal-interictal continuum.

original: For patients who are undergoing invasive procedures and have 1) a mechanical AVR and any thromboembolic risk factor, 2) an older-generation mechanical AVR, or 3) a mechanical mitral valve replacement, bridging anticoagulation therapy during the preoperative time interval when the INR is subtherapeutic is reasonable on an individualized basis, with the risks of bleeding weighed against the benefits of thromboembolism prevention.
paraphrased: For patients undergoing invasive procedures who have 1) a mechanical aortic valve replacement (AVR) with any thromboembolic risk factor, 2) an older-generation mechanical AVR, or 3) a mechanical mitral valve replacement, it is reasonable to consider bridging anticoagulation therapy during the preoperative period when the INR is below therapeutic levels, balancing the bleeding risks against the benefits of preventing thromboembolism on an individual basis.

original: In patients with acute, severe hemodynamic instabil­ ity and cardiopulmonary dysfunction undergoing urgent or emergency NCS, temporary MCS devices may be used preemptively or as rescue therapy.1–5
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute, severe hemodynamic instability and cardiopulmonary dysfunction who are undergoing urgent or emergency non-cardiac surgery, temporary mechanical circulatory support devices can be employed either proactively or as a rescue measure.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, a mul- tidisciplinary outpatient team-based approach (ie, care provision with active medication adjust- ment from advanced practice providers, nurses, or pharmacists) can be effective to control BP, lipids, and other vascular risk factors.810–817
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, managing blood pressure, lipids, and other vascular risk factors can be effectively achieved through a multidisciplinary outpatient team approach, involving active medication adjustments by advanced practice providers, nurses, or pharmacists.

original: The same antiseizure medications used for treatment of seizures caused by other etiologies may be considered for seizures detected after cardiac arrest.
paraphrased: Antiseizure medications that are used for seizures from other causes can also be considered for those occurring after cardiac arrest.

original: For patients with mechanical valves and uncontrollable bleeding who require immediate reversal of anticoagulation, administration of 4-factor prothrombin complex (or its activated form) is reasonable.
paraphrased: Administering 4-factor prothrombin complex, or its activated variant, is advisable for patients with mechanical valves experiencing uncontrollable bleeding who need rapid anticoagulation reversal.

original: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external device or monitor, of >5 minutes’ duration but <24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation with DOACs as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option can be beneficial, taking into consideration duration of AF episodes, total AF burden, underlying risk factors, and bleeding risk.1,6–8,11
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who have subclinical AF episodes lasting more than 5 minutes but less than 24 hours, identified by internal or external monitoring devices, using DOACs as the primary anticoagulation choice and vitamin K antagonists as a secondary option may be advantageous, considering the duration and total burden of AF, as well as underlying risk factors and bleeding risk.

original: In patients with STEMI and ischemic symp- toms for <12 hours, PCI should be performed to improve survival.1-5
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI with ischemic symptoms lasting less than 12 hours, performing PCI is recommended to enhance survival.

original: In patients with intermediate stenosis of the left main artery, intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) is reasonable to help define lesion severity.1-5
paraphrased: For patients with moderate narrowing of the left main artery, using intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) is a sensible approach to assess the severity of the lesion.

original: In patients with HCM and poorly tolerated AF, a rhythm-control strategy with cardioversion or antiar- rhythmic drugs can be beneficial with the choice of an agent according to AF symptom severity, patient preferences, and comorbid conditions.9,12–24
paraphrased: For patients with HCM experiencing poorly tolerated AF, employing a rhythm-control approach using cardioversion or antiarrhythmic medications may be advantageous, with the selection of the agent based on the severity of AF symptoms, patient preferences, and existing comorbidities.

original: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, the use of PA catheterization may be considered when under­ lying medical conditions that significantly affect hemodynamics (eg, decompensated HF, severe valvular disease, combined shock states, PH) cannot be corrected before surgery.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with cardiovascular disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery, pulmonary artery catheterization might be considered if there are underlying medical conditions that significantly impact hemodynamics, such as decompensated heart failure, severe valvular disease, combined shock states, or pulmonary hypertension, which cannot be corrected prior to the procedure.

original: Seizure prophylaxis in adult survivors of cardiac arrest is not recommended.
paraphrased: It is advised against using seizure prevention measures in adult cardiac arrest survivors.

original: For patients with mechanical valves and uncontrollable bleeding who have received 4-factor prothrombin concentrate complex, adjunctive use of intravenous vitamin K is reasonable if resumption of VKA therapy is not anticipated for 7 days.
paraphrased: In patients with mechanical valves experiencing uncontrollable bleeding who have been given 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate, it is reasonable to administer intravenous vitamin K if restarting VKA therapy is not expected within 7 days.

original: In patients with STEMI and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, PCI or CABG (when PCI is not feasible) is indicated to improve survival, irrespective of the time delay from MI onset.6,7
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI with cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, PCI is recommended to enhance survival, and if PCI is not possible, CABG should be performed, regardless of the time elapsed since the onset of MI.

original: In patients with HCM and symptomatic AF, as part of an AF rhythm-control strategy, catheter ablation for AF can be effective when drug therapy is ineffective, contraindicated, or not the patient’s preference.12,25,26
paraphrased: For patients with HCM experiencing symptomatic AF, catheter ablation may be a viable option for AF rhythm control if medication is ineffective, unsuitable, or not preferred by the patient.

original: In patients presenting to their primary care provider as the first contact after TIA or minor stroke, it is reasonable to use a decision sup- port tool that improves diagnostic accuracy, stratifies patients in risk categories to support appropriate triage, and prompts the initiation of medications and counseling for lifestyle modification for secondary stroke prevention to reduce the 90-day risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.818
paraphrased: For patients who first consult their primary care provider following a TIA or minor stroke, employing a decision support tool is advisable to enhance diagnostic precision, categorize patients by risk for proper triage, and initiate medication and lifestyle counseling for secondary stroke prevention, thereby lowering the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA within 90 days.

original: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, routine use of PA catheterization is not recommended to reduce morbidity or mortality.3 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with cardiovascular disease undergoing non-cardiac surgery, it is not advised to routinely use pulmonary artery catheterization to decrease morbidity or mortality.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, behavior change interventions targeting stroke literacy, lifestyle factors, and medica- tion adherence are recommended to reduce cardiovascular events.131,134,840
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, it is advised to implement behavior change strategies that focus on improving stroke literacy, lifestyle habits, and medication adherence to decrease the risk of cardiovascular events.

original: Organ donation should be considered in all patients resuscitated from cardiac arrest who meet neurological criteria for death.
paraphrased: Organ donation ought to be evaluated for every patient who has been revived from cardiac arrest and fulfills the neurological criteria for death.

original: In patients with HCM and AF who require surgical myectomy, concomitant surgical AF ablation proce- dure can be beneficial for AF rhythm control.13,27–29 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with HCM and AF undergoing surgical myectomy, performing a simultaneous surgical AF ablation procedure may aid in controlling AF rhythm.

original: For patients with bioprosthetic valves or annuloplasty rings who are receiving a direct oral anticoagulant and who require immediate reversal of anticoagulation because of uncontrollable bleeding, treatment with idarucizumab (for dabigatran) or andexanet alfa (for anti-Xa agents) is reasonable.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with bioprosthetic valves or annuloplasty rings on direct oral anticoagulants who need urgent anticoagulation reversal due to uncontrollable bleeding, using idarucizumab for dabigatran or andexanet alfa for anti-Xa agents is advisable.

original: In patients with STEMI who have mechanical complications (eg, ventricular septal rupture, mitral valve insufficiency because of papillary muscle infarction or rupture, or free wall rup- ture), CABG is recommended at the time of surgery, with the goal of improving survival.8,9
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI with mechanical complications such as ventricular septal rupture, mitral valve insufficiency due to papillary muscle infarction or rupture, or free wall rupture, it is advised to perform CABG during surgery to enhance survival rates.

original: For patients with a mechanical prosthetic valve and supratherapeutic INR (>5.0) who are not actively bleeding, the benefit of individualized treatment with oral vitamin K, in addition to temporary withdrawal of the VKA, is uncertain.
paraphrased: In patients with a mechanical prosthetic valve and an INR above 5.0 who are not experiencing active bleeding, the advantage of personalized treatment with oral vitamin K, alongside temporarily stopping the VKA, remains unclear.

original: Organ donation should be considered in all patients resuscitated from cardiac arrest before planned withdrawal of life-sustaining therapies.
paraphrased: Before planning to withdraw life-sustaining treatments, organ donation should be evaluated for all patients who have been resuscitated from cardiac arrest.

original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, teaching self-management skills or using behavior change theory (eg, motivational interviewing) can be ben- eficial in improving medication adherence.840–843
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced an ischemic stroke or TIA, employing self-management education or behavior change strategies, such as motivational interviewing, may help enhance adherence to medication.

original: In patients having NCS with expected blood loss, tranexamic acid is reasonable to reduce intraoperative blood loss, reduce transfusions, and avoid anemia.1–3
paraphrased: For patients undergoing NCS with anticipated blood loss, it is appropriate to use tranexamic acid to minimize intraoperative bleeding, decrease the need for transfusions, and prevent anemia.

original: In patients with STEMI who are treated with fibrinolytic therapy, angiography within 3 to 24 hours with the intent to perform PCI is reason- able to improve clinical outcomes.14-20
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI receiving fibrinolytic therapy, undergoing angiography within 3 to 24 hours with the aim of performing PCI is advisable to enhance clinical outcomes.

original: In patients with HCM and recurrent, poorly toler- ated life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias refractory to maximal antiarrhythmic drug therapy and ablation, heart transplantation assessment is indicated in accordance with current listing criteria.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with HCM experiencing recurrent, poorly tolerated life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias that do not respond to maximum antiarrhythmic drug therapy and ablation, evaluation for heart transplantation should be considered based on current listing criteria.

original: In patients with STEMI who are stable and presenting 12 to 24 hours after symptom onset, PCI is reasonable to improve clinical outcomes.21,22
paraphrased: For stable patients with STEMI presenting 12 to 24 hours after symptoms begin, performing PCI can be beneficial for enhancing clinical outcomes.

original: Decisions about organ donation should follow local legal and regulatory requirements.
paraphrased: Organ donation decisions must comply with local laws and regulations.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA, combined exercise-based and behavior change interven- tions are probably indicated in preference to behavior interventions alone, exercise interven- tions alone, or usual care to reduce physiologi- cal stroke risk factors such as SBP.111–113,829
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA, it is likely advisable to prioritize a combination of exercise-based and behavior change interventions over solely behavior interventions, solely exercise interventions, or standard care to lower physiological stroke risk factors like SBP.

original: In patients with iron deficiency anemia having elec­ tive NCS, iron therapy (either oral or intravenous) administered preoperatively is reasonable to reduce blood transfusions and to increase hemoglobin.4–18
paraphrased: For patients with iron deficiency anemia undergoing elective non-cardiac surgery, administering iron therapy (either orally or intravenously) before the operation is advisable to decrease the need for blood transfusions and to raise hemoglobin levels.

original: In children with HCM and recurrent ventricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker use, antiarrhythmic drug therapy (eg, amiodarone,3,4 mexiletine,6 sotalol3,4) is recommended, with the choice of agent guided by age, underlying comorbidities, severity of disease, patient prefer- ences, and balance of efficacy and safety.
paraphrased: For children with HCM experiencing recurrent ventricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker treatment, it is advised to use antiarrhythmic medications such as amiodarone, mexiletine, or sotalol, with the selection based on age, existing health conditions, disease severity, patient preferences, and the balance between effectiveness and safety.

original: In patients with a mechanical AVR who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while in therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is reasonable to increase the INR goal from 2.5 (range, 2.0–3.0) to 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) or to add daily low-dose aspirin (75– 100 mg), with assessment of bleeding risk.
paraphrased: For patients with a mechanical aortic valve replacement who suffer a stroke or systemic embolism while maintaining a therapeutic INR on VKA anticoagulation, it is advisable to either raise the INR target to 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) or incorporate a daily low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg), while evaluating the risk of bleeding.

original: Organ donation is an important outcome that should be considered in the development and evaluation of systems of care.
paraphrased: The significance of organ donation should be taken into account when designing and assessing care systems.

original: In patients with TIA or nondisabling stroke, engagement in targeted secondary prevention programs (eg, cardiac rehabilitation programs or exercise and lifestyle counseling programs) can be beneficial to reduce risk factors and recurrent ischemic events.133,134
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a TIA or a nondisabling stroke, participating in specific secondary prevention initiatives, such as cardiac rehabilitation or exercise and lifestyle counseling, may help lower risk factors and prevent recurrent ischemic events.

original: In patients with known CVD, symptoms of CVD, or age ≥65 years with cardiovascular risk factors undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it may be reasonable to measure cTn at 24 and 48 hours after surgery to identify myocardial injury.1–4
paraphrased: For patients with established CVD, those exhibiting CVD symptoms, or individuals aged 65 and older with cardiovascular risk factors undergoing high-risk non-cardiac surgery, measuring cTn at 24 and 48 hours post-surgery may be advisable to detect myocardial injury.

original: In patients with HCM and pacing-capable ICDs, programming antitachycardia pacing is recommended to minimize risk of shocks.7,8
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who have ICDs capable of pacing, it is advised to program antitachycardia pacing to reduce the likelihood of shocks.

original: In patients with STEMI in whom PCI is not feasible or successful, with a large area of myocardium at risk, emergency or urgent CABG can be effective as a reperfusion modality to improve clinical outcomes.23,24
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI where PCI cannot be performed or has failed, and a significant myocardial area is at risk, emergency or urgent CABG may serve as an effective reperfusion strategy to enhance clinical outcomes.

original: It is reasonable for researchers studying cardiac arrest to develop and implement methods to promote recruitment and representation of participants from diverse backgrounds.
paraphrased: Researchers investigating cardiac arrest should consider creating and applying strategies to enhance the recruitment and inclusion of participants from varied backgrounds.

original: In patients with a bioprosthetic surgical or transcatheter aortic valve or bioprosthetic mitral valve who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while on antiplatelet therapy, VKA anticoagulation, instead of antiplatelet therapy may be considered after assessment of bleeding risk.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with a bioprosthetic aortic or mitral valve who suffer a stroke or systemic embolism while on antiplatelet therapy, VKA anticoagulation may be considered as an alternative to antiplatelet therapy after evaluating the risk of bleeding.

original: In patients undergoing low-risk NCS, routine post­ operative screening with cTn levels is not indicated without signs or symptoms suggestive of myocardial ischemia or MI.5,6 MINS Management
paraphrased: For patients having low-risk NCS, routine postoperative cTn level screening is unnecessary unless there are signs or symptoms indicating myocardial ischemia or MI.

original: In patients with a mechanical mitral valve replacement who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while in therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is reasonable to increase the INR goal from 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) to 4.0 (range, 3.5–4.0) or to add daily low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg), with assessment of bleeding risk.
paraphrased: For patients with a mechanical mitral valve replacement who suffer a stroke or systemic embolism despite being within the therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is advisable to either raise the INR target to 4.0 (range, 3.5–4.0) or introduce a daily low-dose aspirin regimen (75–100 mg), while evaluating the risk of bleeding.

original: For patients with disabling stroke who are discharged from acute services, engaging in targeted secondary prevention programs (eg, an adapted cardiac rehabilitation program or struc- tured exercise including aerobic activity and healthy lifestyle counseling) can be beneficial to reduce vascular risk factors and mortality.111,844
paraphrased: Patients with debilitating stroke who leave acute care services may benefit from participating in specific secondary prevention programs, such as modified cardiac rehabilitation or structured exercise involving aerobic activities and lifestyle counseling, to lower vascular risk factors and mortality.

original: It is beneficial for researchers studying cardiac arrest to collect and report complete demographic data.
paraphrased: Researchers examining cardiac arrest should gather and disclose comprehensive demographic information.

original: In patients who develop MINS, especially in those not previously known to have excess cardiovascular risk, outpatient follow-up is reasonable for optimiza­ tion of cardiovascular risk factors.4,7–10
paraphrased: For patients experiencing MINS, particularly those without a prior history of elevated cardiovascular risk, it is advisable to conduct outpatient follow-up to optimize cardiovascular risk factors.

original: In patients with HCM and recurrent symptomatic sustained monomorphic VT, or recurrent ICD shocks despite optimal device programming, and in whom antiarrhythmic drug therapy is either ineffective, not tolerated, or not preferred, catheter ablation can be useful for reducing arrhythmia burden.9–11 *Indicates the LOE for amiodarone. †Indicates the LOE for dofetilide, mexi- letine, or sotalol.
paraphrased: For patients with HCM experiencing recurrent symptomatic sustained monomorphic VT or frequent ICD shocks despite optimal device settings, and where antiarrhythmic drugs are ineffective, intolerable, or undesirable, catheter ablation may be beneficial in decreasing arrhythmia burden.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA, provision of health information or advice about stroke prevention is essential; however, information or advice alone, in the absence of a behavioral intervention, is not an effective means to change modifiable, lifestyle-related risk factors in order to reduce future ischemic events.129,829,845
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA, delivering health information or guidance on stroke prevention is crucial; nonetheless, without accompanying behavioral interventions, such information or advice alone is insufficient to alter modifiable lifestyle-related risk factors to prevent future ischemic events.

original: In patients with suspected mechanical prosthetic valve thrombosis, urgent evaluation with TTE, TEE, fluoroscopy, and/ or multidetector CT imaging is indicated to assess valve function, leaflet motion, and the presence and extent of thrombus.1–7
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having mechanical prosthetic valve thrombosis, it is crucial to promptly evaluate valve function, leaflet motion, and thrombus presence and extent using TTE, TEE, fluoroscopy, and/or multidetector CT imaging.

original: In patients with STEMI complicated by ongo- ing ischemia, acute severe heart failure, or life- threatening arrhythmia, PCI can be beneficial to improve clinical outcomes, irrespective of time delay from MI onset.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI with persistent ischemia, acute severe heart failure, or life-threatening arrhythmias, PCI may enhance clinical outcomes, regardless of the time elapsed since the MI began.

original: In patients who develop MINS, antithrombotic ther­ apy may be considered to reduce thromboembolic events.4,11
paraphrased: For patients with MINS, considering antithrombotic therapy could help decrease the risk of thromboembolic events.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA, evaluating and addressing social determinants of health (eg, literacy level, language proficiency, medica- tion affordability, food insecurity, housing, and transportation barriers) when managing stroke risk factors is recommended to reduce healthcare disparities.
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA, it is advised to assess and address social determinants of health, such as literacy, language skills, medication costs, food insecurity, housing, and transportation challenges, in order to manage stroke risk factors and minimize healthcare disparities.

original: For patients with HCM, mild- to moderate-intensity* recreational† exercise is beneficial to improve cardiorespiratory fitness, physical functioning, and quality of life, and for overall health in keeping with physical activity guidelines for the general population.1–3
paraphrased: Patients with HCM can enhance their cardiorespiratory fitness, physical functioning, and quality of life, as well as overall health, by engaging in mild- to moderate-intensity recreational exercise, aligning with general population physical activity guidelines.

original: For patients with a thrombosed left-sided mechanical prosthetic heart valve who present with symptoms of valve obstruction, urgent initial treatment with either slow-infusion, low- dose fibrinolytic therapy or emergency surgery is recommended.1–12
paraphrased: For patients experiencing symptoms of obstruction due to a thrombosed mechanical prosthetic heart valve on the left side, it is advised to promptly initiate treatment with either a slow-infusion, low-dose fibrinolytic therapy or perform emergency surgery.

original: In patients with stroke, including spontaneous ICH, design and implementation of stroke public education programs for diverse popula- tions focused on early recognition and the need to seek emergency care rapidly is useful to reduce time to diagnosis and treatment.31–35
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a stroke, such as spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, creating and executing public education initiatives aimed at diverse groups to promote early recognition and prompt emergency care is beneficial in shortening the time to diagnosis and treatment.

original: In patients with STEMI, emergency CABG should not be performed after failed primary PCI: •  In the absence of ischemia or a large area of myocardium at risk, or •  If surgical revascularization is not feasible because of a no-reflow state or poor distal targets.
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI, emergency CABG is not advised following unsuccessful primary PCI unless there is ischemia or a significant myocardial area at risk, or if surgical revascularization is impractical due to a no-reflow condition or inadequate distal targets.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA, monitoring the achievement of nationally accepted, evidence- based performance measures is recommended to allow inequities to be identified and addressed.
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA, it is advised to track adherence to nationally recognized, evidence-based performance standards to identify and rectify disparities.

original: For athletes with HCM, a comprehensive evaluation and shared decision-making about sports participation with an expert professional is recommended.4
paraphrased: Athletes diagnosed with HCM should undergo a thorough assessment and engage in collaborative decision-making with a specialist regarding their involvement in sports.

original: In asymptomatic stable patients with STEMI who have a totally occluded infarct artery >24 hours after symptom onset and are without evidence of severe ischemia, PCI should not be performed.25,26
paraphrased: For asymptomatic stable patients with STEMI and a completely blocked infarct artery more than 24 hours after symptoms begin, and who show no signs of severe ischemia, PCI is not recommended.

original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive sports of any intensity is reasonable.5,6
paraphrased: For individuals with a positive genotype but negative phenotype for HCM, engaging in competitive sports at any level is considered reasonable.

original: In patients with suspected bioprosthetic valve thrombosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging can be useful to rule out leaflet thrombosis.1–5
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having bioprosthetic valve thrombosis, utilizing 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging can help exclude the presence of leaflet thrombosis.

original: Patients who develop STEMI after NCS should be considered for GDMT, including consideration of ICA, balancing bleeding and thrombotic risks with the severity of the clinical presentation.1–3 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI following NCS, GDMT should be evaluated, including the potential for ICA, while weighing the risks of bleeding and thrombosis against the clinical severity.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA, systematic adoption of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality Universal Precautions Toolkit for Health Literacy is recommended to integrate health literacy into the secondary prevention of stroke.
paraphrased: For patients who have experienced a stroke or TIA, it is advised to systematically implement the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality's Universal Precautions Toolkit for Health Literacy to incorporate health literacy into stroke secondary prevention.

original: In patients with suspected or confirmed bioprosthetic valve thrombosis who are hemodynamically stable and have no contraindications to anticoagulation, initial treatment with a VKA is reasonable.1–6
paraphrased: For patients with suspected or confirmed bioprosthetic valve thrombosis who are hemodynamically stable and have no contraindications to anticoagulation, starting treatment with a VKA is advisable.

original: In patients with sudden onset of neurological symptoms or signs attributable to potential spontaneous ICH, use of stroke recogni- tion and severity tools is recommended for dispatch personnel and first responders to identify potential stroke and facilitate rapid transport to reduce time to diagnosis and treatment.36–41
paraphrased: For patients experiencing sudden neurological symptoms or signs suggestive of possible spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, it is advised that dispatch personnel and first responders employ stroke recognition and severity assessment tools to identify potential strokes and expedite transport, thereby minimizing the time to diagnosis and treatment.

original: In patients with stroke symptoms attributable to potential spontaneous ICH, immediate activation of the emergency response system (9-1-1 in North America) is recommended to reduce time to diagnosis and treatment.32,42
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting stroke symptoms possibly due to spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, it is advised to promptly contact emergency services (such as 9-1-1 in North America) to minimize the delay in diagnosis and treatment.

original: In selected hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and multivessel disease, after successful primary PCI, staged PCI of a sig- nificant non-infarct artery stenosis is recom- mended to reduce the risk of death or MI.1-4
paraphrased: For certain hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and multivessel disease, it is advised to perform staged PCI on a significant non-infarct artery stenosis following successful primary PCI to lower the risk of death or myocardial infarction.

original: Patients who develop NSTEMI after NCS should receive medical therapy as recommended for patients with spontaneous MI but after consideration of postoperative bleeding risks and hemodynamic status.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing NSTEMI following NCS, medical treatment should align with guidelines for spontaneous MI, taking into account the risks of postoperative bleeding and their hemodynamic condition.

original: Patients who develop NSTEMI after NCS can be considered for ICA, balancing bleeding and throm­ botic risks with the severity of clinical presentation.2,3
paraphrased: For patients experiencing NSTEMI following NCS, ICA may be considered, weighing the bleeding and thrombotic risks against the severity of their clinical condition.

original: In patients with suspected mechanical or bioprosthetic valve stenosis, TTE and TEE are recommended to diagnosis the cause and severity of valve obstruction, assess ventricular function, and estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure.1,2
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having mechanical or bioprosthetic valve stenosis, it is advised to use TTE and TEE to determine the cause and severity of the obstruction, evaluate ventricular function, and estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure.

original: In patients with potential spontaneous ICH, early notification by emergency medical ser- vices (EMS) staff to the receiving hospital is recommended to improve time to diagnosis and treatment.43,44
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having spontaneous ICH, it is advised that EMS personnel promptly alert the receiving hospital to enhance the speed of diagnosis and treatment.

original: In patients from urban, predominantly minority, or low-socioeconomic-status groups with stroke or TIA, the optimal intervention model for improving stroke risk factor control and reducing disparities is unknown.815,856–859
paraphrased: For patients from urban areas, predominantly minority backgrounds, or low socioeconomic status who have experienced a stroke or TIA, the best approach to enhance control of stroke risk factors and minimize disparities remains unidentified.

original: For patients with HCM, participation in vigorous* recreational activities is reasonable after an annual comprehensive evaluation and shared decision-making with an expert professional who balances potential benefits and risks, with this process being repeated annually.4,5,7,8
paraphrased: Patients with HCM may reasonably engage in vigorous recreational activities following a yearly thorough assessment and collaborative decision-making with a specialist who weighs the potential benefits and risks, with this evaluation repeated each year.

original: In selected patients with STEMI with com- plex multivessel non-infarct artery disease, after successful primary PCI, elective CABG is reasonable to reduce the risk of cardiac events.
paraphrased: For certain patients with STEMI who have complex multivessel disease in non-infarct arteries, undergoing elective CABG following successful primary PCI is advisable to lower the risk of cardiac events.

original: In patients with HF, vital signs and evidence of clinical congestion should be assessed at each encounter to guide overall management, includ- ing adjustment of diuretics and other medica- tions.1–6
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, evaluate vital signs and signs of clinical congestion at every visit to inform management decisions, such as modifying diuretics and other medications.

original: In patients with mechanical valve stenosis, fluoroscopy or cine-CT is recommended to assess motion of the mechanical valve leaflets.
paraphrased: For patients with mechanical valve stenosis, it is advised to use fluoroscopy or cine-CT to evaluate the movement of the mechanical valve leaflets.

original: In selected hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and low-complexity multivessel disease, PCI of a non-infarct artery stenosis may be considered at the time of primary PCI to reduce cardiac event rates.1,2,5-7
paraphrased: For certain hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and uncomplicated multivessel disease, performing PCI on a non-infarct artery stenosis during the initial PCI may be an option to lower cardiac event rates.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, regional systems of stroke care are recommended so all potentially beneficial therapies can be made available when appropriate as rapidly as possible‚ including, at minimum, (a) health care facilities that provide initial spontaneous ICH care, including diagnosis and treatment, and (b) health care facilities with neurocritical care and neurosurgical capabilities.45
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), it is advised to establish regional stroke care systems to ensure that all potentially beneficial treatments are accessible promptly when needed. This should include, at a minimum, (a) healthcare facilities equipped for the initial management of spontaneous ICH, encompassing diagnosis and treatment, and (b) facilities with neurocritical care and neurosurgical resources.

original: For patients with HCM who are capable of a high level of physical performance, participation in competitive sports† may be considered after review by an expert provider with experience managing athletes with HCM who conducts an annual comprehensive evaluation and shared decision- making that balances potential benefits and risks.5,9–14
paraphrased: Patients with HCM who can perform at a high physical level may consider engaging in competitive sports† following an assessment by a specialist experienced in managing athletes with HCM. This should include an annual thorough evaluation and a shared decision-making process that weighs the potential benefits and risks.

original: Patients with AF, regardless of sex1 and gender diversity, race and ethnicity,2 or adverse social determinants of health (SDOH),3,4* should be equitably offered guideline-directed stroke risk reduction therapies as well as rate or rhythm control strategies and LRFM as indicated to improve quality of life (QOL) and prevent adverse outcomes. *Including lower income, lower education, inadequate or lack of insurance cov- erage, or rurality.3–5
paraphrased: All patients with AF, irrespective of sex, gender identity, race, ethnicity, or negative social determinants of health such as low income, limited education, insufficient insurance, or rural residence, should be equally provided with guideline-recommended therapies for stroke risk reduction, as well as rate or rhythm control strategies and LRFM, to enhance quality of life and avert negative outcomes.

original: For most patients with HCM, universal restriction from vigorous physical activity or competitive sports is not indicated.5,11–13
paraphrased: For the majority of patients with HCM, it is not necessary to universally prohibit vigorous physical activity or participation in competitive sports.

original: In patients with STEMI complicated by car- diogenic shock, routine PCI of a non-infarct artery at the time of primary PCI should not be performed because of the higher risk of death or renal failure.8-10 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI with accompanying cardiogenic shock, performing routine PCI on a non-infarct artery during the initial PCI is not advised due to an increased risk of mortality or renal failure.

original: In patients with AF, the use of evidence-based decision aids might be useful to guide stroke reduction therapy treatment decisions throughout the disease course to improve engagement, decisional quality, and patient satisfaction.1–4
paraphrased: For patients with AF, employing evidence-based decision aids can be beneficial in directing stroke prevention therapy choices during the disease progression, enhancing engagement, decision quality, and patient satisfaction.

original: In patients with bioprosthetic valve stenosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging can be useful to rule out leaflet thrombosis.3–7
paraphrased: For patients with bioprosthetic valve stenosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging may be beneficial in excluding leaflet thrombosis.

original: In patients with symptomatic HF, clinical factors indicating the presence of advanced HF should be sought via the history and physical examina- tion.7–12
paraphrased: For patients with symptomatic heart failure, clinical indicators of advanced heart failure should be identified through history taking and physical examination.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at ele- vated risk of recurrent ischemic events and are appropriate candidates for revascular- ization, an invasive strategy with the intent to proceed with revascularization is indi- cated to reduce cardiovascular events.1-4
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS at high risk for recurrent ischemic events and suitable for revascularization, an invasive approach aimed at revascularization is recommended to decrease cardiovascular events.

original: For patients with HCM, it is reasonable to follow Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration cardiovascular disease guidelines that permit driving commercial motor vehicles, if they do not have an ICD or any major risk factors for SCD and are using a GDMT plan.1
paraphrased: For individuals with HCM, it is appropriate to adhere to the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration's cardiovascular disease guidelines allowing commercial vehicle operation, provided they lack an ICD, have no significant SCD risk factors, and are on a GDMT regimen.

original: In patients with cardiomyopathy, a 3-generation family history should be obtained or updated when assessing the cause of the cardiomyopa- thy to identify possible inherited disease.13,14
paraphrased: For patients with cardiomyopathy, it is important to gather or update a family history spanning three generations to determine if the condition may be inherited.

original: In patients with symptomatic severe stenosis of a bioprosthetic or mechanical prosthetic valve, repeat surgical intervention is indicated unless surgical risk is high or prohibitive.1–3
paraphrased: For patients experiencing symptoms due to severe stenosis of a bioprosthetic or mechanical valve, another surgical procedure is recommended unless the surgical risk is deemed high or prohibitive.

original: In patients with newly diagnosed AF, a transthoracic echocardiogram1–4 to assess cardiac structure, laboratory testing to include a complete blood count, metabolic panel, and thyroid function,5–7 and when clinical suspicion exists, targeted testing to assess for other medical conditions associated with AF are recommended to determine stroke and bleeding risk factors, as well as underlying conditions that will guide further management.
paraphrased: For patients newly diagnosed with AF, it is advised to perform a transthoracic echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac structure, conduct laboratory tests including a complete blood count, metabolic panel, and thyroid function tests, and, if clinically indicated, carry out specific tests for other conditions linked to AF to identify stroke and bleeding risk factors and underlying conditions that will inform subsequent management.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS and cardiogenic shock who are appropriate candidates for revascularization, emergency revascular- ization is recommended to reduce risk of death.5-9
paraphrased: For patients experiencing NSTE-ACS and cardiogenic shock who qualify for revascularization, urgent revascularization is advised to lower the risk of mortality.

original: In patients with potential stroke, including spontaneous ICH, in geographic regions where mobile stroke units (MSUs) operate, such mobile units are reasonable to enable more rapid diagnosis and treatment than achievable by ambulance transfer to the clos- est stroke-capable facility.46,47
paraphrased: For patients who may be experiencing a stroke, such as spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, in areas where mobile stroke units are available, utilizing these units is advisable for faster diagnosis and treatment compared to ambulance transport to the nearest stroke-capable facility.

original: In patients with potential spontaneous ICH, first responder training in stroke evaluation and care with the ability to provide airway and circulatory support when necessary is reason- able to detect and manage prehospital neuro- logical deterioration (ND).48,49
paraphrased: For patients at risk of spontaneous ICH, it is advisable for first responders to be trained in stroke assessment and care, including airway and circulatory support, to identify and address prehospital neurological deterioration.

original: In patients with newly diagnosed AF, protocolized testing for ischemia, acute coronary syndrome (ACS), and pulmonary embolism (PE) should not routinely be performed to assess the etiology of AF unless there are additional signs or symptoms to indicate those disorders.8–10
paraphrased: For patients newly diagnosed with AF, standardized tests for ischemia, acute coronary syndrome (ACS), and pulmonary embolism (PE) should not be routinely conducted to determine the cause of AF unless there are other signs or symptoms suggesting these conditions.

original: In patients presenting with HF, a thorough history and physical examination should direct diagnos- tic strategies to uncover specific causes that may warrant disease-specific management.15,16
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, a comprehensive history and physical exam should guide diagnostic approaches to identify particular causes that may require targeted disease management.

original: For severely symptomatic patients with bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis and high or prohibitive surgical risk, a transcatheter ViV procedure is reasonable when performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.4,5
paraphrased: For patients with severe symptoms from bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis who face high or prohibitive surgical risks, undergoing a transcatheter ViV procedure at a Comprehensive Valve Center is a reasonable option.

original: In appropriate patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemody- namic or electrical instability, an immediate invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization is indicated to improve outcomes.10
paraphrased: For suitable patients with NSTE-ACS experiencing persistent angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability, an immediate invasive approach aimed at revascularization is recommended to enhance outcomes.

original: For pilot aircrew with a diagnosis of HCM, it is reasonable to follow Federal Aviation Administration guidelines that permit consideration of multicrew flying duties, provided they are asymptomatic, are deemed low risk for SCD, and can complete a maxi- mal treadmill stress test at 85% peak heart rate.2
paraphrased: For aircrew pilots diagnosed with HCM, it is appropriate to adhere to Federal Aviation Administration guidelines allowing them to be considered for multicrew flying roles, as long as they show no symptoms, are assessed as low risk for sudden cardiac death, and can successfully perform a maximal treadmill stress test reaching 85% of their peak heart rate.

original: It is reasonable for patients with HCM to consider occupations that require manual labor, heavy lifting, or a high level of physical performance after a comprehensive clinical evaluation, risk stratification for SCD, and implementation of GDMT in the con- text of shared decision-making.
paraphrased: Patients with HCM may contemplate engaging in jobs involving manual labor, heavy lifting, or intense physical activity following a thorough clinical assessment, SCD risk evaluation, and the application of GDMT, all within a shared decision-making framework.

original: Among individuals without a known history of AF, it is recommended that an initial AF diagnosis be made by a clinician using visual interpretation of the electrocardiographic signals, regardless of the type of rhythm or monitoring device.1–5
paraphrased: For individuals with no prior AF history, a clinician should visually interpret electrocardiographic signals to initially diagnose AF, irrespective of the rhythm type or monitoring device used.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, focused history, physical examination, and routine labo- ratory work and tests on hospital admission (eg, complete blood count, prothrombin time/ international normalized ratio [INR]/partial thromboplastin time, creatinine/estimated glomerular filtration rate, glucose, cardiac tro- ponin and ECG, toxicology screen, and inflam- matory markers) should be performed to help identify the type of hemorrhage, active medical issues, and risk of unfavorable outcomes.67–72
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH, a detailed history, physical examination, and standard laboratory tests upon hospital admission (such as complete blood count, prothrombin time/INR/partial thromboplastin time, creatinine/estimated glomerular filtration rate, glucose, cardiac troponin and ECG, toxicology screen, and inflammatory markers) should be conducted to determine the hemorrhage type, identify active medical issues, and assess the risk of adverse outcomes.

original: In patients presenting with HF, a thorough history and physical examination should be obtained and performed to identify cardiac and noncardiac disorders, lifestyle and behavioral factors, and social determinants of health that might cause or accelerate the development or progression of HF.
paraphrased: For patients with HF, it is essential to conduct a comprehensive history and physical exam to detect cardiac and noncardiac conditions, lifestyle and behavioral influences, and social health determinants that could contribute to or hasten HF onset or progression.

original: For patients with significant bioprosthetic valve stenosis attributable to suspected or documented valve thrombosis, oral anticoagulation with a VKA is reasonable.6–13
paraphrased: Oral anticoagulation with a VKA is advisable for patients experiencing notable bioprosthetic valve stenosis due to suspected or confirmed valve thrombosis.

original: In patients presenting with stroke-like symp- toms, rapid neuroimaging with CT or MRI is recommended to confirm the diagnosis of spontaneous ICH.94–96
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting stroke-like symptoms, it is advised to promptly perform neuroimaging using CT or MRI to verify a diagnosis of spontaneous ICH.

original: For patients presenting with HF, the specific cause of HF should be explored using addi- tional laboratory testing for appropriate man- agement.1–8
paraphrased: For individuals with heart failure, further laboratory tests should be conducted to identify the underlying cause, ensuring proper management.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are initially stabilized and are at high risk of clinical events, it is reasonable to choose an early invasive strategy (within 24 hours) over a delayed invasive strategy to improve out- comes.11-16
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS who have been initially stabilized and are at high risk for clinical events, opting for an early invasive approach (within 24 hours) rather than a delayed one is advisable to enhance outcomes.

original: For pregnant women with HCM and AF or other indications for anticoagulation, low-molecular-weight heparin or vitamin K antagonists (at maximum therapeutic dose of <5 mg daily) are recommended for stroke prevention.1,2 Recommendations for Occupation in Patients With HCM (Continued) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For pregnant women with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and atrial fibrillation (AF) or other reasons requiring anticoagulation, it is advised to use low-molecular-weight heparin or vitamin K antagonists (not exceeding a daily dose of 5 mg) to prevent stroke.

original: In patients with suspected mechanical or bioprosthetic valve regurgitation, TTE and TEE are recommended to determine the cause and severity of the leak, assess ventricular function, and estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure.1–4
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having regurgitation in mechanical or bioprosthetic valves, it is advised to use TTE and TEE to identify the cause and severity of the leak, evaluate ventricular function, and estimate pulmonary artery systolic pressure.

original: In patients with an intracardiac rhythm device capable of a diagnosis of AF, such as from an atrial pacemaker lead, a diagnosis of AF should only be made after it is visually confirmed by reviewing intracardiac tracings to exclude signal artifacts and other arrhythmias.6–9
paraphrased: For patients with an intracardiac rhythm device that can detect atrial fibrillation, like an atrial pacemaker lead, AF should be diagnosed only after visually confirming intracardiac tracings to rule out signal artifacts and other arrhythmias.

original: In pregnant women with HCM, selected beta blockers should be administered for symptoms related to outflow tract obstruction or arrhythmias, with monitoring of fetal growth.3,4
paraphrased: For pregnant women with HCM, specific beta blockers should be given to manage symptoms of outflow tract obstruction or arrhythmias, while monitoring fetal growth.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are initially stabilized and are at intermediate or low risk of clinical events, an invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization is reason- able before hospital discharge to improve outcomes.11-16
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS who have been initially stabilized and present an intermediate or low risk of clinical events, it is advisable to pursue an invasive strategy aimed at revascularization before hospital discharge to enhance outcomes.

original: For patients who are diagnosed with HF, laboratory evaluation should include com- plete blood count, urinalysis, serum electro- lytes, blood urea nitrogen, serum creatinine, glucose, lipid profile, liver function tests, iron studies, and thyroid-stimulating hormone to optimize management.
paraphrased: For individuals diagnosed with heart failure, laboratory assessments should encompass a complete blood count, urinalysis, serum electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen, serum creatinine, glucose, lipid profile, liver function tests, iron studies, and thyroid-stimulating hormone to enhance management.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and/or IVH, serial head CT can be useful within the first 24 hours after symptom onset to evaluate for hemorrhage expansion.97–99
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH and/or IVH, conducting serial head CT scans within the initial 24 hours after symptoms begin can help assess the potential for hemorrhage expansion.

original: In most pregnant women with HCM, vaginal delivery is recommended as the first-choice delivery option.3,5
paraphrased: For the majority of pregnant women with HCM, vaginal delivery is advised as the preferred method of childbirth.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have failed PCI and have ongoing ischemia, hemodynamic compromise, or threatened occlusion of an artery with substantial myocardium at risk, who are appropriate candidates for CABG, emer- gency CABG is reasonable.5-7,17
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS experiencing unsuccessful PCI and persistent ischemia, hemodynamic instability, or an artery at risk of significant myocardial damage, emergency CABG is advisable if they are suitable candidates.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and/or IVH and with low GCS score or ND, serial head CT can be useful to evaluate for hemorrhage expansion, development of hydrocephalus, brain swelling, or herniation.100–102 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage with a low Glasgow Coma Scale score or neurological deterioration, repeated head CT scans may be beneficial to assess for hemorrhage expansion, hydrocephalus, brain swelling, or herniation.

original: In patients undergoing a transcatheter procedure for paravalvular prosthetic regurgitation, 3D TEE is recommended for intraprocedural guidance.4–7
paraphrased: For patients having a transcatheter procedure to address paravalvular prosthetic regurgitation, it is advised to use 3D TEE for guidance during the procedure.

original: For patients who have had a systemic thromboembolic event without a known history of AF and in whom maximum sensitivity to detect AF is sought, an implantable cardiac monitor is reasonable.10,11
paraphrased: An implantable cardiac monitor is appropriate for patients who experienced a systemic thromboembolic event without a known history of atrial fibrillation, and where maximum sensitivity for detecting atrial fibrillation is desired.

original: For all patients presenting with HF, a 12-lead ECG should be performed at the initial encoun- ter to optimize management.
paraphrased: A 12-lead ECG should be conducted at the first visit for any patient with heart failure to enhance treatment.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, CT angiog- raphy (CTA) within the first few hours of ICH onset may be reasonable to identify patients at risk for subsequent HE.103–108
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, performing CT angiography (CTA) within the initial hours after onset might be appropriate to detect those at risk for later HE.

original: In patients with intractable hemolysis or HF attributable to prosthetic transvalvular or paravalvular leak, surgery is recommended unless surgical risk is high or prohibitive.1–4
paraphrased: For patients experiencing severe hemolysis or heart failure due to prosthetic transvalvular or paravalvular leaks, surgery is advised unless the surgical risk is deemed high or prohibitive.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who present in cardiogenic shock, routine multivessel PCI of non-culprit lesions in the same setting should not be performed.18,19
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS experiencing cardiogenic shock, performing routine multivessel PCI on non-culprit lesions during the same procedure is not advised.

original: In affected families with HCM, preconceptional and prenatal reproductive and genetic counseling should be offered.3–6
paraphrased: For families impacted by HCM, reproductive and genetic counseling should be provided before conception and during pregnancy.

original: Among patients with AF in whom cardiac monitor- ing is advised, it is reasonable to recommend use of a consumer-accessible electrocardiographic device that provides a high-quality tracing to detect recur- rences.13
paraphrased: For patients with AF who require cardiac monitoring, it is appropriate to suggest using a consumer-accessible electrocardiographic device that delivers high-quality tracings to identify recurrences.

original: In asymptomatic patients with severe prosthetic regurgitation and low operative risk, surgery is reasonable.1–4
paraphrased: Surgery is advisable for asymptomatic patients experiencing severe prosthetic regurgitation who have a low risk for surgery.

original: In patients presenting with dyspnea, measure- ment of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal prohormone of B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) is useful to support a diagnosis or exclusion of HF.1–12
paraphrased: For patients experiencing dyspnea, assessing B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal prohormone of B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) is beneficial for confirming or ruling out heart failure.

original: Among patients with a diagnosis of AF, it is reason- able to infer AF frequency, duration, and burden using automated algorithms available from electrocardio- graphic monitors, implantable cardiac monitors, and cardiac rhythm devices with an atrial lead, recognizing that periodic review can be required to exclude other arrythmias.1,4,5,12
paraphrased: For patients diagnosed with AF, it is appropriate to determine the frequency, duration, and burden of AF using automated algorithms from ECG monitors, implantable cardiac monitors, and cardiac rhythm devices with an atrial lead, while acknowledging that periodic evaluations may be necessary to rule out other arrhythmias.

original: Patients at increased risk of AF should receive com- prehensive guideline-directed LRFM for AF, targeting obesity,1 physical inactivity,2 unhealthy alcohol con- sumption,3 smoking,4 diabetes,5 and hypertension.6
paraphrased: Individuals with a higher likelihood of developing AF should undergo thorough guideline-based LRFM for AF, focusing on obesity,1 lack of physical activity,2 excessive alcohol intake,3 smoking,4 diabetes,5 and high blood pressure.6

original: In patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD appropriate for CABG with severe left ventric- ular systolic dysfunction (left ventricular ejec- tion fraction <35%), CABG is recommended to improve survival.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD who are suitable candidates for CABG and have severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction below 35%), CABG is advised to enhance survival.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, using non- contrast computed tomography (NCCT) mark- ers of HE to identify patients at risk for HE may be reasonable.106
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH, it may be appropriate to use non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) markers to identify those at risk for HE.

original: For pregnant women with HCM, care should be coordinated between their cardiologist and an obstetrician. For patients with HCM who are deemed high risk, consultation is advised with an expert in maternal-fetal medicine.
paraphrased: Pregnant women with HCM should have their care managed jointly by a cardiologist and an obstetrician, and those considered high risk should consult a maternal-fetal medicine specialist.

original: In patients with chronic HF, measurements of BNP or NT-proBNP levels are recommended for risk stratification.11,13–29
paraphrased: For patients with chronic heart failure, assessing BNP or NT-proBNP levels is advised for risk stratification.

original: In patients hospitalized for HF, measurement of BNP or NT-proBNP levels at admission is recommended to establish prognosis.11,13–19
paraphrased: For patients admitted with heart failure, it is advised to measure BNP or NT-proBNP levels upon admission to determine prognosis.

original: In patients with prosthetic paravalvular regurgitation with the following: 1) either intractable hemolysis or NYHA class III or IV symptoms and 2) who are at high or prohibitive surgical risk and 3) have anatomic features suitable for catheter-based therapy, percutaneous repair of paravalvular leak is reasonable when performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.5–9
paraphrased: For patients experiencing prosthetic paravalvular regurgitation with either uncontrollable hemolysis or NYHA class III or IV symptoms, who also face high or prohibitive surgical risks and possess anatomical characteristics amenable to catheter-based intervention, it is reasonable to consider percutaneous repair of the paravalvular leak at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

original: In selected patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD appropriate for CABG and mild-to-moder- ate left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction 35%–50%), CABG (to include a left internal mammary artery [LIMA] graft to the LAD) is reasonable to improve survival.3-8 Left main CAD
paraphrased: For patients with stable ischemic heart disease (SIHD) and multivessel coronary artery disease (CAD) who are suitable candidates for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and have mild-to-moderate left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction between 35% and 50%), undergoing CABG with a left internal mammary artery (LIMA) graft to the left anterior descending artery (LAD) is a reasonable option to enhance survival.

original: For women with clinically stable HCM who wish to become pregnant, it is reasonable to advise that pregnancy is generally safe as part of a shared discussion regarding potential maternal and fetal risks, and initiation of GDMT.7–10
paraphrased: For women with clinically stable hypertrophic cardiomyopathy considering pregnancy, it is appropriate to suggest that pregnancy is typically safe, as part of a collaborative discussion about possible maternal and fetal risks and the start of guideline-directed medical therapy.

original: In patients with lobar spontaneous ICH and age <70 years, deep/posterior fossa spon- taneous ICH and age <45 years, or deep/ posterior fossa and age 45 to 70 years with- out history of hypertension, acute CTA plus consideration of venography is recommended to exclude macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.117,118
paraphrased: For patients under 70 with lobar spontaneous ICH, those under 45 with deep/posterior fossa spontaneous ICH, or those aged 45 to 70 with deep/posterior fossa ICH and no hypertension history, it is advised to perform an acute CTA and consider venography to rule out macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.

original: In patients with spontaneous IVH and no detectable parenchymal hemorrhage, catheter intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is recommended to exclude a macro- vascular cause.119
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and no visible parenchymal bleeding, catheter-based intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is advised to rule out a macrovascular cause.

original: In patients with SIHD and significant left main stenosis, CABG is recommended to improve survival.9-12
paraphrased: For patients with SIHD and notable left main stenosis, CABG is advised to enhance survival.

original: For patients with severe HF symptoms caused by bioprosthetic valve regurgitation who are at high to prohibitive surgical risk, a transcatheter ViV procedure is reasonable when performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.10–12
paraphrased: For patients experiencing severe heart failure symptoms due to bioprosthetic valve regurgitation and who face high or prohibitive surgical risks, undergoing a transcatheter valve-in-valve procedure at a Comprehensive Valve Center is a reasonable option.

original: In pregnant women with HCM, cardioversion for new or recurrent AF, particularly if symptomatic, is reasonable.6,11
