paraphrased: Cardioversion is advisable for pregnant women with HCM experiencing new or recurrent AF, especially if they show symptoms.

original: In patients at risk of developing HF, BNP or NT-proBNP–based screening followed by team-based care, including a cardiovascular specialist, can be useful to prevent the devel- opment of LV dysfunction or new-onset HF.30,31
paraphrased: For patients at risk of heart failure, screening with BNP or NT-proBNP followed by collaborative care involving a cardiovascular specialist may help prevent the onset of left ventricular dysfunction or new heart failure.

original: In individuals with AF,* moderate-to-vigorous exercise training to a target of 210 minutes per week is rec- ommended to reduce AF symptoms1–3 and burden,2,3 increase maintenance of sinus rhythm,3–5 increase functional capacity, and improve QOL.3,5,6 *In patients without AF related to excessive exercise training.
paraphrased: For individuals with AF, it is advised to engage in moderate-to-vigorous exercise for 210 minutes weekly to alleviate AF symptoms and burden, enhance sinus rhythm maintenance, boost functional capacity, and improve quality of life, provided the AF is not linked to excessive exercise training.

original: In selected patients with SIHD and significant left main stenosis for whom PCI can provide equivalent revascularization to that possible with CABG, PCI is reasonable to improve survival.9 Multivessel CAD
paraphrased: For certain patients with SIHD and significant left main stenosis where PCI offers revascularization comparable to CABG, opting for PCI is a reasonable approach to enhance survival.

original: In pregnant women with HCM, general or epidural anesthesia is reasonable, with precautions to avoid hypotension.8
paraphrased: For pregnant women with HCM, it is advisable to use general or epidural anesthesia, taking care to prevent hypotension.

original: Patients with a history of AF who smoke cigarettes should be strongly advised to quit smoking and should receive GDMT for tobacco cessation1,2 to mitigate increased risks of AF-related cardiovascular complications and other adverse outcomes.3–6
paraphrased: Individuals with a history of atrial fibrillation who smoke should be firmly encouraged to stop smoking and be provided with guideline-directed medical therapy for tobacco cessation to reduce the heightened risk of cardiovascular complications related to AF and other negative outcomes.

original: In patients at risk of IE (eg, those with congenital or acquired VHD, previous IE, prosthetic heart valves, certain congenital or heritable heart malformations, immunodeficiency states, or injection drug use) who have unexplained fever blood, culture samples should be obtained.1
paraphrased: For patients susceptible to IE, such as those with congenital or acquired VHD, a history of IE, prosthetic heart valves, specific congenital or inherited heart defects, immunodeficiency conditions, or who use injection drugs, blood cultures should be collected if they present with an unexplained fever.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and a CTA or magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) suggestive of a macrovascular cause, catheter intra-arterial DSA should be performed as soon as possible to confirm and manage underlying intracranial vascular malformations.117,118,120–122
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage with CTA or MRA indicating a macrovascular origin, catheter intra-arterial DSA should be conducted promptly to verify and address any intracranial vascular malformations.

original: In patients with the recent onset of left-sided valve regurgitation, at least 2 sets of blood culture samples should be obtained.1–12
paraphrased: For patients who have recently developed left-sided valve regurgitation, a minimum of two sets of blood cultures should be collected.

original: In patients with AF who are overweight or obese (with body mass index [BMI] >27 kg/m2), weight loss is recommended, with an ideal target of at least 10% weight loss to reduce AF symptoms, burden, recurrence, and progression to persistent AF.1–4
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) who have a BMI greater than 27 kg/m², it is advised to lose weight, aiming for a minimum of 10% reduction, to alleviate AF symptoms, decrease its burden, and prevent its recurrence and progression to persistent AF.

original: In patients with SIHD, normal ejection frac- tion, significant stenosis in 3 major coronary arteries (with or without proximal LAD), and anatomy suitable for CABG, CABG may be reasonable to improve survival.10,13-15
paraphrased: For patients with SIHD, normal ejection fraction, and significant stenosis in three major coronary arteries (including or excluding the proximal LAD), who have anatomy appropriate for CABG, undergoing CABG might be a reasonable option to enhance survival.

original: In pregnant women with HCM, it is reasonable to perform serial echocardiography, particularly during the second or third trimester when hemodynamic load is highest, or if clinical symptoms develop.
paraphrased: For pregnant women with HCM, conducting regular echocardiograms is advisable, especially in the second or third trimester when hemodynamic stress peaks, or if symptoms arise.

original: In first-degree relatives of selected patients with genetic or inherited cardiomyopathies, genetic screening and counseling are recom- mended to detect cardiac disease and prompt consideration of treatments to decrease HF progression and sudden death.1,2
paraphrased: Genetic screening and counseling are advised for first-degree relatives of certain patients with genetic or inherited cardiomyopathies to identify cardiac disease and consider early interventions to reduce the risk of heart failure progression and sudden death.

original: Patients with AF seeking a rhythm-control strategy should minimize or eliminate alcohol consumption to reduce AF recurrence and burden.1–3
paraphrased: Patients with AF who opt for a rhythm-control approach should reduce or abstain from alcohol intake to decrease the recurrence and impact of AF.

original: In patients with suspected IE, the Modified Duke Criteria should be used for diagnosis (Tables 24 and 25).2–10
paraphrased: For diagnosing patients with suspected infective endocarditis, the Modified Duke Criteria should be applied (refer to Tables 24 and 25).

original: In pregnant women with HCM, fetal echocardiography may be considered for diagnosis of fetal HCM in the context of prenatal counseling.
paraphrased: For pregnant women with HCM, fetal echocardiography can be contemplated to diagnose fetal HCM during prenatal counseling.

original: In patients with (a) lobar spontaneous ICH and age <70 years, (b) deep/posterior fossa ICH and age <45 years, or (c) deep/posterior fossa and age 45 to 70 years without history of hypertension and negative noninvasive imaging (CTA±venography and MRI/MRA), catheter intra-arterial DSA is reasonable to exclude a macrovascular cause.117,118,120–122
paraphrased: For patients with (a) lobar spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) under 70 years old, (b) deep or posterior fossa ICH under 45 years old, or (c) deep or posterior fossa ICH aged 45 to 70 years without a history of hypertension and negative results on noninvasive imaging (CTA±venography and MRI/MRA), it is reasonable to use catheter intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography (DSA) to rule out a macrovascular cause.

original: In patients hospitalized for HF, a predischarge BNP or NT-proBNP level can be useful to inform the trajectory of the patient and estab- lish a postdischarge prognosis.14,17,20–29
paraphrased: For patients admitted with heart failure, measuring BNP or NT-proBNP levels before discharge can help assess the patient's progress and predict their prognosis after leaving the hospital.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH with a negative CTA/venography, it is reasonable to perform MRI and MRA to establish a nonmac- rovascular cause of ICH (such as CAA, deep perforating vasculopathy, cavernous malforma- tion, or malignancy).118,123,124
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage with a negative CTA or venography, conducting an MRI and MRA is advisable to identify a non-macrovascular cause of the hemorrhage, such as cerebral amyloid angiopathy, deep perforating vasculopathy, cavernous malformation, or malignancy.

original: In patients with SIHD, normal ejection frac- tion, significant stenosis in 3 major coronary arteries (with or without proximal LAD), and anatomy suitable for PCI, the usefulness of PCI to improve survival is uncertain.14-24 Stenosis in the proximal LAD artery
paraphrased: For patients with SIHD, normal ejection fraction, and significant stenosis in three major coronary arteries (including or excluding the proximal LAD), where the anatomy is appropriate for PCI, the benefit of PCI in enhancing survival remains unclear.

original: In select patients with nonischemic cardio- myopathy, referral for genetic counseling and testing is reasonable to identify conditions that could guide treatment for patients and family members.3,4
paraphrased: For certain individuals with nonischemic cardiomyopathy, it is advisable to consider genetic counseling and testing to detect conditions that may inform treatment strategies for both the patients and their relatives.

original: For patients with AF, recommending caffeine abstention to prevent AF episodes is of no benefit, although it may reduce symptoms in patients who report caffeine triggers or worsens AF symptoms.1–9
paraphrased: Advising patients with AF to avoid caffeine does not prevent AF episodes, but it may alleviate symptoms in those who experience caffeine as a trigger or find it exacerbates their AF symptoms.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH who undergo CT or MRI at admission, CTA plus consideration of venography or MRA plus con- sideration of venography performed acutely can be useful to exclude macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.118
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH who receive a CT or MRI upon admission, performing a CTA with possible venography or an MRA with potential venography acutely can be beneficial to rule out macrovascular causes or cerebral venous thrombosis.

original: In patients with SIHD, normal left ventricular ejection fraction, and significant stenosis in the proximal LAD, the usefulness of coronary revascularization to improve survival is uncer- tain.10,14,17,24-27 Single- or double-vessel disease not involving the proximal LAD
paraphrased: For patients with stable ischemic heart disease, normal left ventricular ejection fraction, and significant narrowing in the proximal left anterior descending artery, the benefit of coronary revascularization for enhancing survival is unclear.

original: For patients with AF and hypertension, optimal BP control is recommended to reduce AF recurrence and AF-related cardiovascular events.1–7
paraphrased: It is advised that patients with atrial fibrillation and hypertension maintain optimal blood pressure control to decrease the recurrence of atrial fibrillation and related cardiovascular events.

original: Patients with IE should be evaluated and managed with consultation with a multispecialty Heart Valve Team, which includes an infectious disease specialist, cardiologist, and cardiac surgeon; a cardiac anesthesiologist for surgically managed patients11; and a neurologist for patients with neurological events.11–13
paraphrased: Patients with infective endocarditis should be assessed and treated in collaboration with a multidisciplinary Heart Valve Team, comprising an infectious disease expert, a cardiologist, and a cardiac surgeon. For those undergoing surgery, a cardiac anesthesiologist should be involved, and a neurologist should be consulted for patients experiencing neurological events.

original: In patients with suspected IE, TTE is recommended to identify vegetations, characterize the hemodynamic severity of valvular lesions, assess ventricular function and pulmonary pressures, and detect complications.14–23
paraphrased: For patients with suspected infective endocarditis, it is advised to use transthoracic echocardiography to detect vegetations, evaluate the hemodynamic severity of valve lesions, assess ventricular function and pulmonary pressures, and identify any complications.

original: In patients with suspected or new-onset HF, or those presenting with acute decompensated HF, a chest x-ray should be performed to assess heart size and pulmonary congestion and to detect alternative cardiac, pulmonary, and other diseases that may cause or contrib- ute to the patient’s symptoms.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with suspected or newly diagnosed heart failure, or those experiencing acute decompensated heart failure, a chest x-ray is recommended to evaluate heart size, check for pulmonary congestion, and identify other cardiac, pulmonary, or additional conditions that might be causing or contributing to the symptoms.

original: In patients with HCM, adherence to the ACC/AHA primary prevention guideline is recommended to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.1
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, following the ACC/AHA primary prevention guideline is advised to lower the risk of cardiovascular events.

original: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss1 and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.2–4
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, it is advised to provide counseling and implement comprehensive lifestyle changes to achieve and sustain weight loss, which may help reduce the risk of LVOTO, HF, and AF.

original: In patients with SIHD, normal left ventricular ejection fraction, and 1- or 2-vessel CAD not involving the proximal LAD, coronary revas- cularization is not recommended to improve survival.10,14,16,26,28,29
paraphrased: For patients with stable ischemic heart disease, normal left ventricular ejection fraction, and 1- or 2-vessel coronary artery disease excluding the proximal left anterior descending artery, coronary revascularization is not advised for enhancing survival.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and a nega- tive catheter intra-arterial DSA and no clear microvascular diagnosis or other defined structural lesion, it may be reasonable to per- form a repeat catheter intra-arterial DSA 3 to 6 months after ICH onset to identify a previ- ously obscured vascular lesion.125
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) who have a negative catheter intra-arterial digital subtraction angiography (DSA) and lack a clear microvascular diagnosis or identifiable structural lesion, it might be advisable to conduct a follow-up catheter intra-arterial DSA 3 to 6 months after the ICH onset to detect any vascular lesion that was initially hidden.

original: In patients with suspected or newly diag- nosed HF, transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) should be performed during initial evaluation to assess cardiac structure and function.3
paraphrased: For patients with suspected or newly diagnosed heart failure, an initial evaluation should include transthoracic echocardiography to evaluate cardiac structure and function.

original: In all patients with known or suspected IE and nondiagnostic TTE results, when complications have developed or are clinically suspected or when intracardiac device leads are present, TEE is recommended.21,23–40
paraphrased: For patients with confirmed or suspected IE who have nondiagnostic TTE results, TEE is advised if complications have arisen or are clinically suspected, or if intracardiac device leads are present.

original: Among patients with AF, it may be reasonable to screen for obstructive sleep apnea, given its high prevalence in patients with AF, although the role of treatment of sleep-disordered breathing (SDB) to maintain sinus rhythm is uncertain.1–13
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation, screening for obstructive sleep apnea could be considered due to its common occurrence in these individuals, despite the unclear impact of treating sleep-disordered breathing on maintaining sinus rhythm.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH requiring acute BP lowering, careful titration to ensure continuous smooth and sustained control of BP, avoiding peaks and large variability in SBP, can be beneficial for improving functional out- comes.138
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage needing rapid blood pressure reduction, it is advantageous to meticulously adjust treatment to maintain consistent and stable blood pressure control, preventing spikes and significant fluctuations in systolic blood pressure, to enhance functional outcomes.

original: In patients with SIHD who have ≥1 coronary arteries that are not anatomically or function- ally significant (<70% diameter of non–left main coronary artery stenosis, FFR >0.80), coronary revascularization should not be performed with the primary or sole intent to improve survival.26,30 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with SIHD who have one or more coronary arteries that are neither anatomically nor functionally significant (less than 70% stenosis in non-left main coronary arteries, FFR greater than 0.80), coronary revascularization should not be conducted with the primary or sole purpose of enhancing survival.

original: In patients with HCM and hypertension, lifestyle modifications and medical therapy for hypertension are recommended,1 with preference for beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers in patients with obstructive HCM.
paraphrased: For patients with HCM and high blood pressure, it is advised to implement lifestyle changes and antihypertensive treatment, prioritizing beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers for those with obstructive HCM.

original: In patients with HF who have had a significant clinical change, or who have received GDMT and are being considered for invasive procedures or device therapy, repeat measurement of EF, degree of structural remodeling, and valvular function are useful to inform therapeutic interven- tions.4–7
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure who have experienced a notable clinical change or have been on guideline-directed medical therapy and are candidates for invasive procedures or device therapy, reassessing ejection fraction, structural remodeling extent, and valvular function is beneficial for guiding treatment decisions.

original: In patients with HCM, assessment for symptoms of sleep-disordered breathing is recommended, and, if present, referral to a sleep medicine specialist for evaluation and treatment is recommended.5–8
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is advised to evaluate for symptoms of sleep-disordered breathing, and if symptoms are detected, a referral to a sleep medicine specialist for further evaluation and treatment is advised.

original: In patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD appropriate for either CABG or PCI, revas- cularization is reasonable to lower the risk of cardiovascular events such as spontaneous MI, unplanned urgent revascularizations, or cardiac death.1-8
paraphrased: For patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD who are suitable candidates for CABG or PCI, revascularization is advisable to reduce the likelihood of cardiovascular events, including spontaneous MI, unplanned urgent revascularizations, or cardiac death.

original: In patients with IE who have a change in clinical signs or symptoms (eg, new murmur, embolism, persistent fever, HF, abscess, or atrioventricular heart block) and in patients at high risk of complications (eg, extensive infected tissue, large vegetation on initial echocardiogram, or staphylococcal, enterococcal, or fungal infections), TTE and/or TEE are recommended for reevaluation.24,31,41–46
paraphrased: For patients with infective endocarditis (IE) experiencing altered clinical signs or symptoms, such as a new murmur, embolism, ongoing fever, heart failure, abscess, or atrioventricular heart block, as well as those at high risk for complications, including extensive infected tissue, large vegetation on the initial echocardiogram, or infections caused by staphylococci, enterococci, or fungi, reevaluation with TTE and/or TEE is advised.

original: Patients with AF should receive comprehensive care addressing guideline-directed LRFM, AF symptoms, risk of stroke, and other associated medical conditions to reduce AF burden, progression, or consequences.1–3
paraphrased: Patients with atrial fibrillation should be provided with thorough care that targets guideline-recommended lifestyle and risk factor management, addresses AF symptoms, mitigates stroke risk, and treats other related medical issues to lessen the burden, progression, or impact of AF.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH in whom acute BP lowering is considered, initiating treatment within 2 hours of ICH onset and reaching target within 1 hour can be beneficial to reduce the risk of HE and improve func- tional outcome.139,140 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, starting blood pressure reduction within 2 hours of onset and achieving the target within 1 hour may help decrease the risk of HE and enhance functional outcomes.

original: In patients with refractory angina despite medical therapy and with significant coronary artery stenoses amenable to revascularization, revascularization is recommended to improve symptoms.1-6
paraphrased: For patients experiencing refractory angina that persists despite medical treatment and who have significant coronary artery stenoses suitable for revascularization, revascularization is advised to alleviate symptoms.

original: In patients for whom echocardiography is inadequate, alternative imaging (eg, cardiac magnetic resonance [CMR], cardiac computed tomography [CT], radionuclide imaging) is rec- ommended for assessment of LVEF.8–15
paraphrased: For patients where echocardiography is insufficient, it is advised to use alternative imaging methods such as cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR), cardiac computed tomography (CT), or radionuclide imaging to evaluate LVEF.

original: Patients with AF should be evaluated for their annual risk of thromboembolic events using a validated clinical risk score, such as CHA2DS2-VASc.1–4
paraphrased: Patients with atrial fibrillation should have their yearly risk of thromboembolic events assessed using a validated clinical risk score like CHA2DS2-VASc.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity presenting with SBP between 150 and 220 mm Hg, acute lower- ing of SBP to a target of 140 mm Hg with the goal of maintaining in the range of 130 to 150 mm Hg is safe and may be reasonable for improving functional outcomes.138,141–147
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage of mild to moderate severity with systolic blood pressure between 150 and 220 mm Hg, it is safe and potentially beneficial for functional outcomes to acutely reduce SBP to a target of 140 mm Hg, aiming to maintain it between 130 and 150 mm Hg.

original: In patients with HF or cardiomyopathy, CMR can be useful for diagnosis or manage- ment.16–23
paraphrased: For individuals with heart failure or cardiomyopathy, cardiac magnetic resonance imaging may aid in diagnosis or management.

original: In patients being considered for an early change to oral antibiotic therapy for the treatment of stable IE, a baseline TEE before switching to oral therapy and a repeat TEE
paraphrased: For patients evaluated for an early transition to oral antibiotics for stable IE treatment, perform a baseline TEE before the switch and repeat the TEE.

original: In patients undergoing valve surgery for IE, intraoperative TEE is recommended.47–50
paraphrased: For patients having valve surgery due to IE, it is advised to use intraoperative TEE.

original: In patients with angina but no anatomic or physiological criteria for revascularization, nei- ther CABG nor PCI should be performed.7,8
paraphrased: For patients with angina who lack anatomical or physiological indications for revascularization, both CABG and PCI are not recommended.

original: In patients with AF, use of clinical care pathways, such as nurse-led AF clinics, is reasonable to promote comprehensive, team-based care and to enhance adherence to evidence-based therapies for AF and associated conditions.4–6
paraphrased: For patients with AF, implementing clinical care pathways like nurse-led AF clinics is advisable to support thorough, team-oriented care and improve adherence to evidence-based treatments for AF and related conditions.

original: Patients with AF should be evaluated for factors that specifically indicate a higher risk of bleeding, such as previous bleeding and use of drugs that increase bleeding risk, in order to identify possible interven- tions to prevent bleeding on anticoagulation.5–7
paraphrased: Patients with AF need assessment for factors that elevate bleeding risk, like past bleeding incidents and medications that heighten bleeding risk, to identify potential interventions to prevent bleeding while on anticoagulation.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH presenting with large or severe ICH or those requir- ing surgical decompression, the safety and efficacy of intensive BP lowering are not well established.148
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH who have large or severe hemorrhages or need surgical decompression, the safety and effectiveness of aggressive BP reduction remain uncertain.

original: In patients with HF, an evaluation for possible ischemic heart disease can be useful to identify the cause and guide management.24–27
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, assessing for potential ischemic heart disease can be beneficial in determining the cause and directing treatment.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity presenting with SBP >150 mm Hg, acute lowering of SBP to <130 mm Hg is potentially harmful.146,149,150
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity with an SBP exceeding 150 mm Hg, rapidly reducing SBP to below 130 mm Hg may be detrimental.

original: In patients who require revascularization for significant left main CAD with high-complexity CAD, it is recommended to choose CABG over PCI to improve survival.1,2
paraphrased: For patients needing revascularization due to significant left main coronary artery disease with highly complex CAD, CABG is advised over PCI to enhance survival.

original: In patients with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia without a known source, TEE is reasonable to diagnose possible IE.11,36,52–56
paraphrased: For patients with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia of unknown origin, performing a TEE is advisable to identify potential IE.

original: In patients with HF and coronary artery disease (CAD) who are candidates for coronary revas- cularization, noninvasive stress imaging (stress echocardiography, single-photon emission CT [SPECT], CMR, or positron emission tomog- raphy [PET]) may be considered for detection of myocardial ischemia to help guide coronary revascularization.28–32
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure (HF) and coronary artery disease (CAD) who are eligible for coronary revascularization, noninvasive stress imaging techniques such as stress echocardiography, single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT), cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR), or positron emission tomography (PET) can be considered to identify myocardial ischemia and assist in guiding coronary revascularization decisions.

original: In patients with a prosthetic valve in the presence of persistent fever without bacteremia or a new murmur, a TEE is reasonable to aid in the diagnosis of IE.57–60
paraphrased: For patients with a prosthetic valve experiencing ongoing fever without bacteremia or a new heart murmur, it is reasonable to perform a TEE to assist in diagnosing IE.

original: In patients with anticoagulant-associated spontaneous ICH, anticoagulation should be discontinued immediately and rapid reversal of anticoagulation should be performed as soon as possible after diagnosis of spontaneous ICH to improve survival.162 VKAs
paraphrased: For patients experiencing anticoagulant-related spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), anticoagulation must be stopped right away, and anticoagulation reversal should be conducted promptly after diagnosing spontaneous ICH to enhance survival.

original: Patients with AF at intermediate annual risk of thromboembolic events by risk scores (eg, equiva- lent to CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1 in men or 2 in women), who remain uncertain about the benefit of anticoagulation, can benefit from consideration of factors that might modify their risk of stroke to help inform the decision.*
paraphrased: Patients with AF who have an intermediate yearly risk of thromboembolic events, as indicated by risk scores (such as a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1 for men or 2 for women), and are unsure about the advantages of anticoagulation, may find it helpful to evaluate additional factors that could alter their stroke risk to aid in decision-making.

original: In patients in whom the anatomy cannot be clearly delineated by echocardiography in the setting of suspected paravalvular infections, CT imaging is reasonable.37,61–68
paraphrased: For patients where echocardiography fails to clearly define the anatomy in suspected paravalvular infections, CT imaging is a reasonable option.

original: In patients who are deemed at high risk for stroke, bleeding risk scores should not be used in isolation to determine eligibility for oral anticoagulation but instead to identify and modify bleeding risk factors and to inform medical decision-making.8–10 *Factors may include AF burden or other features in Table 3.
paraphrased: For patients considered at high risk for stroke, bleeding risk scores should not solely dictate the eligibility for oral anticoagulation. Instead, they should be used to identify and adjust bleeding risk factors and guide clinical decisions, potentially considering factors like AF burden or other characteristics listed in Table 3.

original: In patients with diabetes and multivessel CAD with the involvement of the LAD, who are appropriate candidates for CABG, CABG (with a LIMA to the LAD) is recommended in pref- erence to PCI to reduce mortality and repeat revascularizations.1-8
paraphrased: For patients with diabetes and multivessel coronary artery disease involving the left anterior descending artery, who are suitable for coronary artery bypass grafting, it is advised to opt for CABG (using a left internal mammary artery graft to the LAD) over percutaneous coronary intervention to lower mortality and the need for repeat revascularizations.

original: In patients who require revascularization for multivessel CAD with complex or diffuse CAD (eg, SYNTAX score >33), it is reasonable to choose CABG over PCI to confer a survival advantage.2-5
paraphrased: For patients needing revascularization due to multivessel coronary artery disease with complex or widespread CAD (such as a SYNTAX score above 33), opting for CABG instead of PCI is advisable to enhance survival.

original: In patients with HF in the absence of: 1) clinical status change, 2) treatment interventions that might have had a significant effect on cardiac function, or 3) candidacy for invasive proce- dures or device therapy, routine repeat assess- ment of LV function is not indicated.
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, routine reassessment of left ventricular function is not warranted unless there is a change in clinical status, recent treatment interventions that could significantly impact cardiac function, or consideration for invasive procedures or device therapy.

original: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH and INR ≥2.0, 4-factor (4-F) prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is recommended in preference to fresh-frozen plasma (FFP) to achieve rapid correction of INR and limit HE.163
paraphrased: For patients experiencing VKA-related spontaneous ICH with an INR of 2.0 or higher, it is advised to use 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) over fresh-frozen plasma (FFP) to quickly correct INR and reduce HE.

original: In patients with HF, endomyocardial biopsy may be useful when a specific diagnosis is sus- pected that would influence therapy.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, an endomyocardial biopsy can be beneficial if a particular diagnosis is suspected that could alter treatment.

original: In patients with diabetes who have multivessel CAD amenable to PCI and an indication for revascularization and are poor candidates for surgery, PCI can be useful to reduce long-term ischemic outcomes.9,10
paraphrased: For diabetic patients with multivessel coronary artery disease who are suitable for PCI, require revascularization, and are not ideal surgical candidates, PCI may effectively lower long-term ischemic risks.

original: In patients diagnosed with AF who have an estimated annual risk of stroke or thromboembolic events ≥2%, selection of therapy to reduce the risk of stroke should be based on the risk of thromboembolism, regardless of whether the AF pattern is paroxysmal, persistent, long-standing persistent, or permanent.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with AF and an estimated annual stroke or thromboembolic event risk of 2% or higher, therapy to lower stroke risk should be chosen based on thromboembolism risk, irrespective of whether the AF is paroxysmal, persistent, long-standing persistent, or permanent.

original: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH, intravenous vitamin K should be adminis- tered directly after coagulation factor replace- ment (PCC or other) to prevent later increase in INR and subsequent HE.164,165
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH linked to VKA, intravenous vitamin K should be given immediately following coagulation factor replacement (such as PCC or alternatives) to avert a later rise in INR and subsequent HE.

original: In patients classified by Modified Duke Criteria as having “possible IE,” 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose PET/CT is reasonable as adjunct diagnostic imaging.69–71
paraphrased: For patients identified as "possible IE" according to the Modified Duke Criteria, using 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose PET/CT as supplementary diagnostic imaging is considered appropriate.

original: In patients with nosocomial S. aureus bacteremia with a known portal of entry from an extracardiac source, TEE might be considered to detect concomitant staphylococcal IE.22,53,54,72–74
paraphrased: For patients with hospital-acquired S. aureus bacteremia originating from a non-cardiac source, TEE may be considered to identify concurrent staphylococcal infective endocarditis.

original: In patients with AF at risk for stroke, reevaluation of the need for and choice of stroke risk reduction therapy at periodic intervals is recommended to reassess stroke and bleeding risk, net clinical benefit, and proper dosing.4,5
paraphrased: For patients with AF who are at risk of stroke, it is advised to periodically reassess the necessity and selection of stroke risk reduction therapy to evaluate stroke and bleeding risk, overall clinical benefit, and appropriate dosing.

original: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH with INR of 1.3 to 1.9, it may be reason- able to use PCC to achieve rapid correction of INR and limit HE.162,164 DOACs
paraphrased: For patients experiencing VKA-related spontaneous ICH with an INR between 1.3 and 1.9, using PCC to quickly correct the INR and reduce HE may be appropriate.

original: In patients with diabetes who have left main stenosis and low- or intermediate-complexity CAD in the rest of the coronary anatomy, PCI may be considered an alternative to CABG to reduce major adverse cardiovascular out- comes.5,11
paraphrased: For diabetic patients with left main stenosis and low- or intermediate-complexity coronary artery disease elsewhere, PCI can be an alternative to CABG to lower the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events.

original: In selected patients with HF with persistent or worsening symptoms, signs, diagnostic param- eters, and in whom hemodynamics are uncer- tain, invasive hemodynamic monitoring can be useful to guide management.
paraphrased: For certain patients with heart failure who continue to experience or have worsening symptoms, signs, and diagnostic indicators, and where hemodynamic status is unclear, invasive hemodynamic monitoring may be beneficial for guiding treatment.

original: In patients with HF, routine use of invasive hemodynamic monitoring is not recom- mended.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, invasive hemodynamic monitoring should not be routinely employed.

original: In patients with direct factor Xa inhibitor–asso- ciated spontaneous ICH, andexanet alfa is reasonable to reverse the anticoagulant effect of factor Xa inhibitors.166,167
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage linked to direct factor Xa inhibitors, using andexanet alfa to counteract the anticoagulant effects of these inhibitors is a reasonable option.

original: In patients with IE, appropriate antibiotic therapy should be initiated and continued after blood cultures are obtained, with guidance from antibiotic sensitivity data and the infectious disease experts on the MDT.1–7
paraphrased: For patients with IE, start and maintain suitable antibiotic treatment following blood culture collection, using antibiotic sensitivity results and advice from infectious disease specialists on the MDT.

original: For patients with AF and an estimated annual thromboembolic risk of ≥2% per year (eg, CHA2DS2-VASc score of ≥2 in men and ≥3 in women), anticoagulation is recommended to prevent stroke and systemic thromboembolism.1–7
paraphrased: Anticoagulation is advised for patients with atrial fibrillation who have an estimated annual thromboembolic risk of 2% or higher, such as those with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or more in men and 3 or more in women, to prevent stroke and systemic thromboembolism.

original: Patients with suspected or confirmed IE associated with drug use should be referred to addiction treatment for opioid substitution therapy.8–10
paraphrased: Patients with suspected or confirmed infective endocarditis linked to drug use should be directed to addiction treatment for opioid replacement therapy.

original: For patients undergoing routine evaluation of HF, endomyocardial biopsy should not be per- formed because of the risk of complications.5,6
paraphrased: Endomyocardial biopsy should be avoided in patients undergoing standard HF evaluation due to the potential for complications.

original: In patients with AF who do not have a history of moderate to severe rheumatic mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, and who are candidates for anticoagulation, DOACs are recommended over warfarin to reduce the risk of mortality, stroke, systemic embolism, and ICH.1–7
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation who are eligible for anticoagulation and do not have moderate to severe rheumatic mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are preferred over warfarin to lower the risk of death, stroke, systemic embolism, and intracranial hemorrhage.

original: In patients with dabigatran-associated spon- taneous ICH, idarucizumab is reasonable to reverse the anticoagulant effect of dabiga- tran.168
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage linked to dabigatran, using idarucizumab to counteract dabigatran's anticoagulant effect is advisable.

original: In patients with previous CABG and refractory angina on GDMT that is attributable to LAD disease, it is reasonable to choose CABG over PCI when an internal mammary artery (IMA) can be used as a conduit to the LAD.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with prior CABG and persistent angina despite GDMT due to LAD disease, opting for CABG instead of PCI is advisable if an internal mammary artery can be utilized as a conduit to the LAD.

original: In patients with IE and with evidence of cerebral embolism or stroke, regardless of the other indications for anticoagulation, it is reasonable to temporarily discontinue anticoagulation.11–24
paraphrased: For patients with IE who show signs of cerebral embolism or stroke, it is advisable to pause anticoagulation therapy temporarily, irrespective of any other reasons for its use.

original: For patients with AF and an estimated annual thromboembolic risk of ≥1% but <2% per year (equivalent to CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1 in men and 2 in women), anticoagulation is reasonable to prevent stroke and systemic thromboembolism.1,3
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation and an estimated annual thromboembolic risk between 1% and 2% (corresponding to a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1 for men and 2 for women), it is reasonable to use anticoagulation to prevent stroke and systemic thromboembolism.

original: In patients with previous CABG and complex CAD, it may be reasonable to choose CABG over PCI when an IMA can be used as a con- duit to the LAD.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with a history of CABG and complex CAD, opting for CABG instead of PCI might be advisable if an IMA can serve as a conduit to the LAD.

original: In patients with previous CABG with a patent LIMA to the LAD who need repeat revascu- larization, if PCI is feasible, it is reasonable to choose PCI over CABG.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with a prior CABG and a functioning LIMA to the LAD requiring additional revascularization, opting for PCI over CABG is advisable if PCI is a viable option.

original: In patients with direct factor Xa inhibitor– associated spontaneous ICH, a 4-F PCC or activated PCC (aPCC) may be considered to improve hemostasis.169–171
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage linked to direct factor Xa inhibitors, considering the use of a 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate or activated prothrombin complex concentrate may enhance hemostasis.

original: In patients with HF, assessment and documen- tation of NYHA functional classification are recommended to determine eligibility for treat- ments.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, it is advised to evaluate and record the NYHA functional classification to establish treatment eligibility.

original: In selected adult patients with NYHA class III HF and history of a HF hospitalization in the past year or elevated natriuretic peptide levels, on maximally tolerated stable doses of GDMT with optimal device therapy, the use- fulness of wireless monitoring of PA pressure by an implanted hemodynamic monitor to reduce the risk of subsequent HF hospitaliza- tions is uncertain.1–4 Value Statement: Uncertain Value (B-NR)
paraphrased: For certain adult patients with NYHA class III heart failure who have either been hospitalized for heart failure in the past year or have high natriuretic peptide levels, and are on the highest tolerable stable doses of guideline-directed medical therapy with optimal device therapy, the benefit of using an implanted hemodynamic monitor for wireless pulmonary artery pressure monitoring to lower the risk of future heart failure hospitalizations remains unclear.

original: In patients with AF without risk factors for stroke, aspirin monotherapy for prevention of thromboem- bolic events is of no benefit.10,11
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation who have no stroke risk factors, using aspirin alone does not help prevent thromboembolic events.

original: In patients with dabigatran- or factor Xa inhibi- tor–associated spontaneous ICH, when the DOAC agent was taken within the previous few hours, activated charcoal may be reason- able to prevent absorption of the DOAC.172–174
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage linked to dabigatran or factor Xa inhibitors, administering activated charcoal might be appropriate to inhibit DOAC absorption if the medication was ingested in the last few hours.

original: In selected ambulatory patients with HF, cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) is recommended to determine appropriateness of advanced treatments (eg, LVAD, heart transplant).4–8
paraphrased: For certain ambulatory patients with heart failure, it is advised to use cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) to assess the suitability for advanced therapies such as LVAD or heart transplantation.

original: In patients with multivessel CAD amenable to treatment with either PCI or CABG who are unable to access, tolerate, or adhere to DAPT for the appropriate duration of treatment, CABG is reasonable in preference to PCI.1-10
paraphrased: For patients with multivessel CAD who can be treated with either PCI or CABG but cannot access, tolerate, or adhere to DAPT for the necessary treatment duration, opting for CABG over PCI is advisable.

original: For patients with AF receiving DOACs, optimal man- agement of drug interactions is recommended for those receiving concomitant therapy with interacting drugs, especially CYP3A4 and/or p-glycoprotein inhibitors or inducers (Table 13).1–7
paraphrased: For patients with AF on DOACs, it is advised to carefully manage drug interactions, particularly when they are also taking drugs that interact, such as CYP3A4 and/or p-glycoprotein inhibitors or inducers.

original: In patients with left-sided IE caused by streptococcus, Enterococcus faecalis, S. aureus, or coagulase-negative staphylococci deemed stable by the MDT after initial intravenous antibiotics, a change to oral antibiotic therapy may be considered if TEE before the switch to oral therapy shows no paravalvular infection, if frequent and appropriate follow-up can be assured by the care team, and if a follow-up TEE can be performed 1 to 3 days before the completion of the antibiotic course.25
paraphrased: For patients with left-sided IE due to streptococcus, Enterococcus faecalis, S. aureus, or coagulase-negative staphylococci who are considered stable by the MDT after initial IV antibiotics, transitioning to oral antibiotics may be an option if a TEE prior to the switch confirms the absence of paravalvular infection, frequent and proper follow-up by the care team is ensured, and a follow-up TEE is conducted 1 to 3 days before completing the antibiotic regimen.

original: In ambulatory patients with HF, performing a CPET or 6-minute walk test is reasonable to assess functional capacity.4,5,9–16
paraphrased: For ambulatory patients with heart failure, it is reasonable to evaluate functional capacity using a CPET or a 6-minute walk test.

original: In patients receiving VKA anticoagulation at the time of IE diagnosis, temporary discontinuation of VKA anticoagulation may be considered.13,26–34
paraphrased: For patients on VKA anticoagulation when diagnosed with IE, it may be advisable to temporarily pause VKA anticoagulation.

original: In pregnant patients with STEMI not caused by spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD), it is reasonable to perform primary PCI as the preferred revascularization strategy.1,2
paraphrased: For pregnant patients experiencing STEMI not due to SCAD, primary PCI is a suitable choice for revascularization.

original: For patients with AF receiving warfarin,* a target INR between 2 and 3 is recommended, as well as optimal management of drug-drug interactions, consistency in vitamin K dietary intake, and routine INR monitoring to improve time in therapeutic range and to minimize risks of preventable thromboembolism or major bleed- ing.8–10
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation on warfarin, it is advised to maintain an INR target of 2 to 3, ensure effective management of drug interactions, maintain consistent vitamin K intake, and regularly monitor INR to enhance time within the therapeutic range and reduce the risk of preventable thromboembolism or significant bleeding.

original: In patients with dabigatran-associated sponta- neous ICH, when idarucizumab is not available, aPCC or PCCs may be considered to improve hemostasis.175,176
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage linked to dabigatran, if idarucizumab is unavailable, aPCC or PCCs can be considered to enhance hemostasis.

original: Patients with known VHD should not receive antibiotics before blood cultures are obtained for unexplained fever.22,35,36
paraphrased: Patients diagnosed with VHD should avoid taking antibiotics prior to obtaining blood cultures for an unexplained fever.

original: In patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH, when idarucizumab is not available, renal replacement therapy (RRT) may be considered to reduce dabigatran concentration.177 Heparins
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage linked to dabigatran, if idarucizumab is unavailable, renal replacement therapy can be considered to lower dabigatran levels.

original: Decisions about the timing of surgical intervention for IE should be made by a Heart Valve Team.1–6
paraphrased: The timing for surgical intervention in IE should be determined by a Heart Valve Team.

original: In pregnant patients with NSTE-ACS, an inva- sive strategy is reasonable if medical therapy is ineffective for the management of life- threatening complications.1,2
paraphrased: For pregnant patients experiencing NSTE-ACS, pursuing an invasive approach is appropriate when medical treatment fails to manage life-threatening complications.

original: In patients with stroke or TIA of undetermined cause, initial cardiac monitoring and, if needed, extended monitoring with an implantable loop recorder are reasonable to improve detection of AF.1 Table 13.  Continued Class VKA Direct Thrombin Inhibitor Factor Xa Inhibitor Name Warfarin Dabigatran Rivaroxaban Apixaban Edoxaban Appropriate use based on liver function (Child-Pugh score)† Child-Pugh A (mild) Not mentioned in the labeling No dose adjustment needed No dose adjustment needed No dose adjustment needed No dose adjustment needed Child-Pugh B (moderate) Use with caution Avoid use Use with caution Use with caution Child-Pugh C (severe) Avoid use Avoid use Avoid use Avoid use Information obtained from manufacturer package inserts.13,14,20–22 Adapted with permission from pgs. 28-31 of Kido et al.23 Copyright 2021 American College of
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a stroke or TIA with an unknown origin, it is advisable to begin with cardiac monitoring and, if necessary, proceed to extended monitoring using an implantable loop recorder to enhance the detection of AF.

original: In older adults, as in all patients, the treatment strategy for CAD should be based on an indi- vidual patient’s preferences, cognitive function, and life expectancy.1,2 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For older adults, similar to all patients, the approach to managing CAD should consider the individual's preferences, cognitive abilities, and anticipated lifespan.

original: In patients with unfractionated heparin (UFH)– associated spontaneous ICH, intravenous protamine is reasonable to reverse the antico- agulant effect of heparin.178
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) linked to unfractionated heparin (UFH), administering intravenous protamine is a reasonable approach to counteract the anticoagulant effects of heparin.

original: For patients with a device-detected atrial high-rate episode (AHRE) lasting ≥24 hours1 and with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk,2 it is reasonable to initiate oral anticoagulation3 within a SDM framework that considers episode duration and individual patient risk.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a device-detected atrial high-rate episode (AHRE) lasting 24 hours or more, and having a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or higher, or an equivalent stroke risk, it is appropriate to start oral anticoagulation within a shared decision-making framework that evaluates the episode's duration and the patient's individual risk.

original: In ambulatory patients with unexplained dys- pnea, CPET is reasonable to evaluate the cause of dyspnea.17,18
paraphrased: For outpatients experiencing unexplained shortness of breath, conducting a CPET is a sensible approach to determine the underlying cause.

original: In ambulatory or hospitalized patients with HF, validated multivariable risk scores can be useful to estimate subsequent risk of mortality.1–14
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure who are either outpatients or in the hospital, using validated multivariable risk scores can help predict future mortality risk.

original: In patients with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)–associated spontaneous ICH, intrave- nous protamine may be considered to partially reverse the anticoagulant effect of heparin.178
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) linked to low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), intravenous protamine can be considered to partially counteract the anticoagulant effects of heparin.

original: In patients with CKD undergoing contrast media injection for coronary angiography, measures should be taken to minimize the risk of contrast-induced acute kidney injury (AKI).1-3
paraphrased: For patients with CKD receiving contrast media for coronary angiography, steps should be implemented to reduce the likelihood of contrast-induced acute kidney injury (AKI).

original: In patients with IE who present with valve dysfunction resulting in symptoms of HF, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is indicated.7–19
paraphrased: For patients with IE experiencing valve dysfunction that leads to HF symptoms, it is recommended to perform early surgery during the initial hospital stay, prior to finishing the complete antibiotic treatment.

original: In patients with hypertension, blood pressure should be controlled in accordance with GDMT for hypertension to prevent symptomatic HF.1–9
paraphrased: For patients with hypertension, manage blood pressure following GDMT guidelines for hypertension to avert symptomatic heart failure.

original: For patients with a device-detected AHRE last- ing between 5 minutes and 24 hours and with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥3 or equivalent stroke risk,2 it may be reasonable to initiate anticoagulation within a SDM framework that considers episode duration and individual patient risk.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a device-detected AHRE lasting from 5 minutes to 24 hours and having a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 3 or higher, or an equivalent stroke risk, it might be appropriate to start anticoagulation within a shared decision-making framework that evaluates the duration of the episode and the patient's individual risk.

original: In patients with STEMI and CKD, coronary angiography and revascularization are recom- mended, with adequate measures to reduce the risk of AKI.
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI and CKD, it is advised to perform coronary angiography and revascularization while implementing appropriate strategies to minimize the risk of AKI.

original: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with aspirin and who require emer- gency neurosurgery, platelet transfusion might be considered to reduce postoperative bleed- ing and mortality.206
paraphrased: In patients with spontaneous ICH on aspirin therapy who need urgent neurosurgery, platelet transfusion may be considered to decrease postoperative bleeding and mortality.

original: In patients with left-sided IE caused by S. aureus, a fungal organism, or other highly resistant organisms, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is indicated.7,9,15,20–35
paraphrased: For patients with left-sided infective endocarditis due to S. aureus, a fungal pathogen, or other highly resistant organisms, early surgical intervention is recommended during the initial hospital stay and prior to completing the full antibiotic treatment.

original: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with antiplatelet agents, the effective- ness of desmopressin with or without platelet transfusions to reduce the expansion of the hematoma is uncertain.207–209
paraphrased: The effectiveness of desmopressin, alone or combined with platelet transfusions, in preventing hematoma expansion in patients with spontaneous ICH on antiplatelet therapy remains uncertain.

original: In patients with type 2 diabetes and either established CVD or at high cardiovascular risk, SGLT2i should be used to prevent hospitaliza- tions for HF.10–12
paraphrased: For patients with type 2 diabetes who have established cardiovascular disease or are at high risk for cardiovascular issues, SGLT2 inhibitors should be utilized to prevent heart failure-related hospitalizations.

original: Patients with a device-detected AHRE lasting <5 minutes and without another indication for oral anticoagulation should not receive oral anticoagulation.4,5
paraphrased: Oral anticoagulation should not be administered to patients who have a device-detected AHRE lasting less than 5 minutes and no other reason for anticoagulation.

original: In patients with IE complicated by heart block, annular or aortic abscess, or destructive penetrating lesions, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is indicated.7,9,36–44
paraphrased: For patients with IE who develop heart block, annular or aortic abscess, or destructive penetrating lesions, it is recommended to perform early surgery during the initial hospital stay and prior to finishing a complete course of antibiotics.

original: In the general population, healthy lifestyle hab- its such as regular physical activity, maintaining normal weight, healthy dietary patterns, and avoiding smoking are helpful to reduce future risk of HF.13–21
paraphrased: For the general population, engaging in regular exercise, keeping a normal weight, following a healthy diet, and refraining from smoking can help lower the future risk of heart failure.

original: In patients with AF, a moderate to high risk of stroke (CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2), and a contraindication (Table 14) to long-term oral anticoagulation due to a nonreversible cause, percutaneous LAAO (pLAAO) is reasonable.1–4
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation who have a moderate to high stroke risk (CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or more) and cannot undergo long-term oral anticoagulation due to an irreversible contraindication (refer to Table 14), considering percutaneous left atrial appendage occlusion (pLAAO) is appropriate.

original: In patients with IE and evidence of persistent infection as manifested by persistent bacteremia or fevers lasting >5 days after onset of appropriate antimicrobial therapy, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) for IE is indicated.7,9,15,25,26,45–48
paraphrased: For patients with IE who exhibit ongoing infection, such as persistent bacteremia or fevers persisting beyond 5 days after starting suitable antimicrobial treatment, early surgical intervention for IE is recommended during the initial hospital stay and prior to finishing the complete antibiotic course.

original: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with aspirin and not scheduled for emergency surgery, platelet transfusions are potentially harmful and should not be adminis- tered.210
paraphrased: In patients with spontaneous ICH who are on aspirin and not planned for urgent surgery, administering platelet transfusions may be detrimental and should be avoided.

original: In low-risk patients with NSTE-ACS and CKD, it is reasonable to weigh the risk of coronary angiography and revascularization against the potential benefit.
paraphrased: For low-risk patients with NSTE-ACS and CKD, it is advisable to consider the potential benefits of coronary angiography and revascularization in relation to their risks.

original: In high-risk patients with NSTE-ACS and CKD, it is reasonable to perform coronary angiography and revascularization, with ade- quate measures to reduce the risk of AKI.4,5
paraphrased: For patients at high risk with NSTE-ACS and CKD, conducting coronary angiography and revascularization is advisable, provided that appropriate precautions are taken to minimize the risk of AKI.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH (with or without the spot sign), the effectiveness of recombinant factor VIIa to improve functional outcome is unclear.218,219
paraphrased: The impact of recombinant factor VIIa on enhancing functional outcomes in patients with spontaneous ICH, regardless of the presence of the spot sign, remains uncertain.

original: For patients at risk of developing HF, natriuretic peptide biomarker–based screening followed by team-based care, including a cardiovascular specialist optimizing GDMT, can be useful to prevent the development of LV dysfunction (systolic or diastolic) or new-onset HF.22,23
paraphrased: Screening patients at risk for heart failure using natriuretic peptide biomarkers, followed by collaborative care with a cardiovascular specialist to optimize guideline-directed medical therapy, may help prevent the onset of left ventricular dysfunction (either systolic or diastolic) or new heart failure.

original: In all patients with definite endocarditis and an implanted cardiac electronic device, complete removal of the pacemaker or defibrillator systems, including all leads and the generator, is indicated.49–55
paraphrased: For patients diagnosed with confirmed endocarditis who have a cardiac electronic device implanted, it is recommended to entirely extract the pacemaker or defibrillator systems, encompassing all leads and the generator.

original: In patients with AF and a moderate to high risk of stroke and a high risk of major bleeding on oral anti- coagulation, pLAAO may be a reasonable alternative to oral anticoagulation based on patient preference, with careful consideration of procedural risk and with the understanding that the evidence for oral antico- agulation is more extensive.1–3,5,6
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation who have a moderate to high stroke risk and a significant risk of major bleeding from oral anticoagulants, percutaneous left atrial appendage occlusion (pLAAO) can be considered as an alternative to oral anticoagulation, taking into account patient preference, the procedural risks, and acknowledging that there is more comprehensive evidence supporting oral anticoagulation.

original: In asymptomatic patients with stable CAD and CKD, routine angiography and revasculariza- tion are not recommended if there is no com- pelling indication.6
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with stable coronary artery disease and chronic kidney disease, routine angiography and revascularization should be avoided unless there is a strong indication.

original: For patients with prosthetic valve endocarditis and relapsing infection (defined as recurrence of bacteremia after a complete course of appropriate antibiotics and subsequent negative blood culture results) without other identifiable source of infection, surgery is recommended.7
paraphrased: Surgery is advised for patients with prosthetic valve endocarditis experiencing recurrent infection, characterized by the return of bacteremia following a full course of suitable antibiotics and negative blood cultures, when no other infection source is identified.

original: In the general population, validated multivari- able risk scores can be useful to estimate sub- sequent risk of incident HF.24–26
paraphrased: Validated multivariable risk scores can be beneficial for predicting future risk of developing heart failure in the general population.

original: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery and LAA exclusion, a surgical technique resulting in absence of flow across the suture line and a stump of <1 cm as determined by intraoperative trans- esophageal echocardiography should be used.1,4,5
paraphrased: For patients with AF having cardiac surgery and LAA exclusion, employ a surgical method that ensures no flow across the suture line and a stump less than 1 cm, as verified by intraoperative transesophageal echocardiography.

original: In patients with non–left main or noncomplex CAD who are undergoing noncardiac sur- gery, routine coronary revascularization is not recommended solely to reduce perioperative cardiovascular events.1
paraphrased: For patients with non-left main or uncomplicated coronary artery disease undergoing noncardiac surgery, routine coronary revascularization is not advised solely for the purpose of decreasing perioperative cardiovascular events.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH (with or without the spot sign, black hole sign, or blend sign), the effectiveness of TXA to improve functional outcome is not well estab- lished.220–222
paraphrased: The efficacy of TXA in enhancing functional outcomes for patients with spontaneous ICH, regardless of the presence of the spot sign, black hole sign, or blend sign, remains uncertain.

original: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk, surgical LAA exclusion, in addition to continued anti- coagulation, is indicated to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation undergoing cardiac surgery who have a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or higher, or a similar stroke risk, it is recommended to perform surgical left atrial appendage exclusion alongside ongoing anticoagulation to lower the risk of stroke and systemic embolism.

original: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, ACEi should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortality.1–4
paraphrased: For patients with LVEF of 40% or less, ACE inhibitors are recommended to prevent symptomatic heart failure and lower mortality rates.

original: In patients with recurrent endocarditis and continued intravenous drug use, consultation with addiction medicine is recommended to discuss the long-term prognosis for the patient’s refraining from actions that risk reinfection before repeat surgical intervention is considered.56–60
paraphrased: For patients experiencing recurrent endocarditis who continue intravenous drug use, it is advised to consult with addiction medicine to evaluate the patient's long-term likelihood of avoiding behaviors that could lead to reinfection prior to considering repeat surgical intervention.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, provision of care in a specialized inpatient (eg, stroke) unit with a multidisciplinary team is recommended to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.231,232
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, it is advised to receive treatment in a specialized inpatient unit, such as a stroke unit, with a multidisciplinary team to enhance outcomes and lower mortality rates.

original: In patients with ventricular fibrillation, polymor- phic ventricular tachycardia (VT), or cardiac arrest, revascularization of significant CAD is recommended to improve survival.1-4
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ventricular fibrillation, polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, or cardiac arrest, it is advised to perform revascularization of significant coronary artery disease to enhance survival.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, provision of care at centers that can provide the full range of high-acuity care and expertise is recom- mended to improve outcomes.233
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, it is advised to receive treatment at facilities equipped to deliver comprehensive high-acuity care and specialized expertise to enhance outcomes.

original: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery with CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk, the benefit of surgical LAA exclusion in the absence of continued anticoagulation to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism is uncertain.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with AF who are having cardiac surgery and have a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or higher, or a similar risk of stroke, the advantage of surgically excluding the LAA without ongoing anticoagulation to lower the risk of stroke and systemic embolism remains unclear.

original: In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or ACS, statins should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and adverse cardiovascular events.5–9
paraphrased: For individuals with a past or recent history of myocardial infarction or acute coronary syndrome, statins are recommended to prevent symptomatic heart failure and negative cardiovascular outcomes.

original: In patients with CAD and suspected scar- mediated sustained monomorphic VT, revas- cularization is not recommended for the sole purpose of preventing recurrent VT.5-9
paraphrased: For patients with CAD and suspected scar-mediated sustained monomorphic VT, revascularization should not be performed solely to prevent recurrent VT.

original: In patients with AF receiving dabigatran who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with idarucizumab is recommended to rapidly reverse dabigatran’s anticoagulation effect.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation on dabigatran experiencing life-threatening bleeding, idarucizumab is advised to quickly counteract the anticoagulant effects of dabigatran.

original: In patients with a recent MI and LVEF ≤40% who are intolerant to ACEi, ARB should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortal- ity.10
paraphrased: For patients with a recent MI and LVEF of 40% or less who cannot tolerate ACE inhibitors, ARBs should be administered to prevent symptomatic heart failure and decrease mortality.

original: In patients with native left-sided valve endocarditis who exhibit mobile vegetations >10 mm in length (with or without clinical evidence of embolic phenomenon), early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) may be considered.20,61–63,67
paraphrased: For patients with native left-sided valve endocarditis and mobile vegetations exceeding 10 mm in length, early surgical intervention can be contemplated during the initial hospital stay and prior to finishing a complete course of antibiotics, regardless of the presence of clinical embolic events.

original: In patients with SCAD who have hemody- namic instability or ongoing ischemia despite conservative therapy, revascularization may be considered if feasible.1-5
paraphrased: For patients with SCAD experiencing hemodynamic instability or persistent ischemia despite conservative treatment, revascularization can be considered if it is possible.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and clini- cal hydrocephalus, transfer to centers with neurosurgical capabilities for definitive hydro- cephalus management (eg, EVD placement and monitoring) is recommended to reduce mortality.233,234
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage and clinical hydrocephalus, it is advised to transfer them to facilities with neurosurgical expertise for definitive hydrocephalus treatment, such as the placement and monitoring of an external ventricular drain, to decrease mortality.

original: In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and LVEF ≤40%, evidence-based beta blockers should be used to reduce mortality.11–13
paraphrased: For patients with a history of myocardial infarction or acute coronary syndrome and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40% or less, beta blockers supported by evidence should be administered to lower mortality rates.

original: Routine revascularization for SCAD should not be performed.1-5
paraphrased: Revascularization should not be routinely conducted for SCAD.

original: In patients with AF receiving dabigatran who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with activated prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is reason- able to reverse dabigatran’s anticoagulation effect if idarucizumab is unavailable.4,5
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation on dabigatran experiencing life-threatening bleeding, using activated prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is a suitable option to counteract the anticoagulation effect of dabigatran when idarucizumab is not accessible.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, care delivery that includes multidisciplinary teams trained in neurological assessment is recom- mended to improve outcomes.99,235,236
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, it is advised to involve multidisciplinary teams skilled in neurological evaluation to enhance outcomes.

original: In patients with IE and an indication for surgery who have suffered a stroke but have no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage, operation without delay may be considered.68–70
paraphrased: For patients with IE who require surgery and have experienced a stroke without signs of intracranial bleeding or significant neurological injury, immediate surgery may be an option.

original: In patients with IE who present with recurrent emboli and persistent vegetations despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is reasonable.53,61–66
paraphrased: For patients with IE experiencing repeated embolic events and ongoing vegetations despite suitable antibiotic treatment, it is advisable to consider early surgery during the initial hospital stay and prior to finishing the complete antibiotic regimen.

original: In hospitalized patients with spontaneous ICH who require hospital transfer but do not have adequate airway protection, cannot support adequate gas exchange, and/or do not have a stable hemodynamic profile, appropriate life-sustaining therapies should be initiated before transportation to prevent acute medical decompensation in transport.
paraphrased: For hospitalized patients with spontaneous ICH needing transfer who lack sufficient airway protection, cannot maintain adequate gas exchange, or have unstable hemodynamics, necessary life-sustaining treatments should be started prior to transport to avert acute medical deterioration during transit.

original: For patients with IE and major ischemic stroke with extensive neurological damage or intracranial hemorrhage, if the patient is hemodynamically stable, delaying valve surgery for at least 4 weeks may be considered.68,71
paraphrased: In patients with IE who have suffered a major ischemic stroke with significant neurological injury or intracranial bleeding, and are hemodynamically stable, it may be advisable to postpone valve surgery for a minimum of 4 weeks.

original: In patients with AF receiving warfarin who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (if available) in addition to intravenous vitamin K is recommended to rapidly achieve INR correction over fresh frozen plasma and intravenous vitamin K treatment.8–10
paraphrased: For patients with AF on warfarin experiencing life-threatening bleeding, it is advised to use 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (when accessible) along with intravenous vitamin K to quickly correct INR, rather than using fresh frozen plasma and intravenous vitamin K alone.

original: In patients who are at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT and have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, an ICD is recommended for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death (SCD) to reduce total mortality.14
paraphrased: For patients who are more than 40 days after an MI, have an LVEF of 30% or less, exhibit NYHA class I symptoms while on GDMT, and are expected to survive meaningfully for over a year, an ICD is advised for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death to lower overall mortality.

original: In patients with cardiac allograft vasculopathy and severe, proximal, discrete coronary lesions, revascularization with PCI is reasonable.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with cardiac allograft vasculopathy and significant, proximal, isolated coronary lesions, it is reasonable to consider revascularization through PCI.

original: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, beta blockers should be used to prevent symptomatic HF.12,13
paraphrased: For patients with an LVEF of 40% or less, beta blockers are recommended to prevent symptomatic heart failure.

original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, a radial approach is indicated in preference to a femoral approach to reduce the risk of death, vascular complications, or bleeding.1-4
paraphrased: For patients with ACS undergoing PCI, opting for a radial approach over a femoral one is recommended to lower the risk of mortality, vascular complications, or bleeding.

original: Women with suspected valve disease who are considering pregnancy should undergo a clinical evaluation and TTE before pregnancy.1–5
paraphrased: Women who may have valve disease and are planning to become pregnant should receive a clinical assessment and transthoracic echocardiography prior to conception.

original: In patients with AF who develop major gastrointestinal bleeding, resumption of oral anticoagulation therapy may be reasonable after correction of reversible causes of bleeding and reassessment of its long-term benefits and risks with a multidisciplinary team approach during SDM with patients.11,12 *B-NR LOE applies to data on apixaban or rivaroxaban. †C-LD LOE applies to data on edoxaban.
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation experiencing significant gastrointestinal bleeding, it might be appropriate to restart oral anticoagulation therapy after addressing reversible bleeding causes and evaluating the long-term benefits and risks with a multidisciplinary team during shared decision-making with the patient. *B-NR LOE pertains to apixaban or rivaroxaban data. †C-LD LOE pertains to edoxaban data.

original: In patients with LVEF <50%, thiazolidinediones should not be used because they increase the risk of HF, including hospitalizations.15
paraphrased: Thiazolidinediones should be avoided in patients with LVEF below 50% due to an increased risk of heart failure and related hospitalizations.

original: Women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) who are considering pregnancy should undergo pre-pregnancy counseling by a cardiologist with expertise in managing women with VHD during pregnancy.1–5
paraphrased: Women with advanced valve disease (Stages C and D) contemplating pregnancy should receive pre-pregnancy counseling from a cardiologist experienced in handling VHD in pregnant women.

original: In patients with AF and conditions associated with very high risk of thromboembolic events (>5%/year), such as rheumatic heart disease or a mechanical heart valve, early (1-2 weeks) resumption of antico- agulation after ICH is reasonable to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.1
