paraphrased: For patients with stable chronic HFrEF (LVEF ≤35%) classified as NYHA class II to III, who are on GDMT including a maximally tolerated dose of a beta blocker, and have a resting heart rate of ≥70 bpm while in sinus rhythm, ivabradine may help decrease the risk of HF hospitalizations and cardiovascular mortality.

original: In patients with AF and HF, rhythm control can be useful for improving symptoms and improving out- comes, such as mortality and hospitalizations for HF and ischemia.15–19
paraphrased: For patients with AF and HF, rhythm control may be beneficial in alleviating symptoms and enhancing outcomes, including reducing mortality and hospitalizations due to HF and ischemia.

original: In patients with symptomatic HFrEF despite GDMT (or who are unable to tolerate GDMT), digoxin might be considered to decrease hospi- talizations for HF.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with symptomatic HFrEF who do not respond to or cannot tolerate GDMT, digoxin may be considered to reduce HF-related hospitalizations.

original: The use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants with mechanical heart valves in pregnancy has not been assessed and is not recommended.30–32
paraphrased: Anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants are not advised for use with mechanical heart valves during pregnancy, as their effects have not been evaluated.

original: In patients with AF, rhythm-control strategies can be useful to reduce the likelihood of AF progression.20–27
paraphrased: For patients with AF, employing rhythm-control strategies may help decrease the risk of AF progression.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, the routine use of epiaortic ultrasound scanning can be useful to evaluate the presence, location, and severity of plaque in the ascending aorta to reduce the incidence of atheroembolic complications.1-10
paraphrased: For patients having CABG, regularly employing epiaortic ultrasound scanning can help assess the presence, location, and severity of plaque in the ascending aorta, thereby decreasing the risk of atheroembolic complications.

original: In patients undergoing valve surgery, aortic surgery, or other cardiac operations who have intermediate CAD, CABG may be reasonable with a goal of reducing ischemic events.5,7,10,12 Table 12.  Best Practices for the Use of Bypass Conduits in CABG Objectively assess palmar arch completeness and ulnar compensation before harvesting the radial artery. Use the arm with the best ulnar compensation for radial artery harvesting.
paraphrased: For patients having valve, aortic, or other heart surgeries with moderate coronary artery disease, CABG can be considered to decrease ischemic events. Objectively evaluate the completeness of the palmar arch and ulnar compensation prior to radial artery harvesting, and select the arm with superior ulnar compensation for this procedure.

original: For patients with spontaneous supratentorial ICH of <30-mL volume and IVH requiring EVD, the usefulness of minimally invasive IVH evacuation with neuroendoscopy plus EVD, with or without thrombolytic, to improve func- tional outcomes and reduce permanent shunt dependence is uncertain.419,420
paraphrased: The effectiveness of using minimally invasive neuroendoscopic IVH evacuation combined with EVD, with or without thrombolytics, to enhance functional outcomes and decrease the need for permanent shunts in patients with spontaneous supratentorial ICH of less than 30 mL and IVH requiring EVD remains uncertain.

original: In selected high-risk patients with HFrEF and recent worsening of HF already on GDMT, an oral soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator (vericiguat) may be considered to reduce HF hospitalization and cardiovascular death.1
paraphrased: For certain high-risk patients with HFrEF experiencing recent HF deterioration despite being on GDMT, considering an oral soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator like vericiguat could help decrease the risk of HF hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality.

original: In patients undergoing TAVI, 1) contrast- enhanced coronary CT angiography (in patients with a low pretest probability for CAD) or 2) an invasive coronary angiogram is recommended to assess coronary anatomy and guide revascularization.
paraphrased: For patients undergoing TAVI, it is advised to use either 1) contrast-enhanced coronary CT angiography for those with a low pretest probability of CAD, or 2) an invasive coronary angiogram to evaluate coronary anatomy and assist in planning revascularization.

original: For most patients with spontaneous supra- tentorial ICH of moderate or greater severity, the usefulness of craniotomy for hemorrhage evacuation to improve functional outcomes or mortality is uncertain.380,382,384,393,429–431
paraphrased: For the majority of patients experiencing spontaneous supratentorial intracerebral hemorrhage of moderate or greater severity, the benefit of craniotomy for hemorrhage removal in enhancing functional outcomes or reducing mortality remains unclear.

original: In patients with significant calcification of the aorta, the use of techniques to avoid aortic manipulation (off-pump techniques or beating heart) is reasonable to decrease the incidence of perioperative stroke when performed by experienced surgeons.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with notable aortic calcification, employing methods that minimize aortic handling, such as off-pump or beating heart techniques, is advisable to reduce the risk of perioperative stroke, provided they are executed by skilled surgeons.

original: In patients with AF where symptoms associated with AF are uncertain, a trial of rhythm control (eg, cardio- version or pharmacological therapy) may be useful to determine what if any symptoms are attributable to AF.28–32
paraphrased: For patients with AF who have unclear symptoms related to the condition, attempting rhythm control, such as cardioversion or medication, can help identify whether any symptoms are due to AF.

original: In patients with significant pulmonary disease, off-pump surgery may be reasonable to reduce perioperative risk when performed by experienced surgeons.2-6
paraphrased: For patients with severe lung disease, opting for off-pump surgery could be a sensible choice to lower perioperative risk if conducted by skilled surgeons.

original: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are deteriorating, craniotomy for hematoma evacu- ation might be considered as a lifesaving measure.382,384,429,432
paraphrased: For patients experiencing deterioration due to supratentorial ICH, considering craniotomy for hematoma removal could be a critical lifesaving intervention.

original: In patients undergoing TAVI with significant left main or proximal CAD with or without angina, revascularization by PCI before TAVI is reasonable.1,2
paraphrased: For patients receiving TAVI who have significant left main or proximal CAD, whether or not they experience angina, it is reasonable to perform PCI for revascularization prior to TAVI.

original: In patients with nonischemic DCM or ischemic heart disease at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤35% and NYHA class II or III symp- toms on chronic GDMT, who have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is recommended for primary pre- vention of SCD to reduce total mortality.1–9 Value Statement: High Value (A)
paraphrased: For patients with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy or ischemic heart disease who are at least 40 days post-myocardial infarction, have a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% or less, and exhibit NYHA class II or III symptoms while on long-term guideline-directed medical therapy, ICD therapy is advised for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death to lower overall mortality, provided they have a reasonable expectation of surviving more than one year.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, an intraopera- tive continuous insulin infusion should be initiated to maintain serum glucose level <180 mg/dL to reduce sternal wound infection.1-3
paraphrased: For patients having CABG, a continuous insulin infusion during surgery should be started to keep serum glucose levels below 180 mg/dL, thereby reducing the risk of sternal wound infection.

original: For patients with cerebellar ICH who are deteriorating neurologically, have brainstem compression and/or hydrocephalus from ventricular obstruction, or have cerebellar ICH volume ≥15 mL, immediate surgical removal of the hemorrhage with or without EVD is recom- mended in preference to medical management alone to reduce mortality.442–444
paraphrased: For patients experiencing neurological decline due to cerebellar ICH, who exhibit brainstem compression, hydrocephalus from blocked ventricles, or have a cerebellar ICH volume of 15 mL or more, prompt surgical evacuation of the hemorrhage, with or without EVD, is advised over solely medical treatment to decrease mortality.

original: In patients with AF, rhythm-control strategies may be useful to reduce the likelihood of development of dementia or worsening cardiac structural abnormali- ties.33–45
paraphrased: For patients with AF, employing rhythm-control strategies can help decrease the risk of dementia onset or the progression of cardiac structural abnormalities.

original: In patients with AF duration of ≥48 hours, a
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation lasting 48 hours or more, a

original: In patients at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT, who have reasonable expec- tation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is recommended for primary prevention of SCD to reduce total mortality.6
paraphrased: For patients who are over 40 days post-myocardial infarction, have a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30% or less, and exhibit NYHA class I symptoms while on guideline-directed medical therapy, ICD therapy is advised for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death to decrease overall mortality, provided they have a reasonable expectation of surviving more than one year.

original: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, left bundle branch block (LBBB) with a QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT is indicated to reduce total mortality, reduce hospi- talizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.16–21 Value Statement: High Value (B-NR)
paraphrased: CRT is recommended for patients with LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, left bundle branch block (LBBB) with a QRS duration of ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory IV symptoms on GDMT, to decrease overall mortality, lower hospitalization rates, and enhance symptoms and quality of life.

original: In patients with significant AS and significant CAD (luminal reduction >70% diameter, fractional flow reserve <0.8, instantaneous wave-free ratio <0.89) consisting of complex bifurcation left main and/or multivessel CAD with a SYNTAX (Synergy Between Percutaneous Coronary Intervention With Taxus and Cardiac Surgery) score >33, SAVR and CABG are reasonable and preferred over TAVI and PCI.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with severe aortic stenosis and significant coronary artery disease (defined by a luminal reduction greater than 70%, fractional flow reserve below 0.8, or instantaneous wave-free ratio under 0.89) involving complex bifurcation of the left main and/or multivessel disease with a SYNTAX score exceeding 33, surgical aortic valve replacement combined with coronary artery bypass grafting is advisable and favored over transcatheter aortic valve implantation and percutaneous coronary intervention.

original: In patients with symptoms of angina, objective evidence of ischemia, decreased LV systolic function, history of CAD, or coronary risk factors (including men >40 years of age and postmenopausal women), invasive coronary angiography is indicated before valve intervention.1–8
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting angina symptoms, objective signs of ischemia, reduced left ventricular systolic function, a history of coronary artery disease, or coronary risk factors (such as men over 40 and postmenopausal women), invasive coronary angiography should be performed prior to valve intervention.

original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR, invasive coronary angiography should be performed as part of the evaluation.9–11
paraphrased: For patients with chronic severe secondary MR, conducting invasive coronary angiography is recommended as part of the assessment.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, the use of continuous intravenous insulin to achieve and maintain an early postoperative blood glucose concentration of <180 mg/dL while avoid- ing hypoglycemia is indicated to reduce the incidence of adverse events, including deep sternal wound infection.3-6
paraphrased: For patients undergoing CABG, administering continuous intravenous insulin to maintain early postoperative blood glucose levels below 180 mg/dL, while preventing hypoglycemia, is recommended to decrease the risk of adverse events, such as deep sternal wound infections.

original: In patients with AF undergoing cardioversion, thera- peutic anticoagulation should be established before cardioversion and continued for at least 4 weeks afterwards without interruption to prevent thromboembolism.2–7
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation undergoing cardioversion, anticoagulation therapy must be initiated prior to the procedure and maintained for a minimum of 4 weeks post-cardioversion without any breaks to prevent thromboembolism.

original: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, a non-LBBB pattern with a QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory class IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT can be useful to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symp- toms and QOL.16–21,28–33
paraphrased: CRT may be beneficial for patients with LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, a non-LBBB pattern with a QRS duration of ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory class IV symptoms while on GDMT, as it can lower overall mortality, decrease hospitalizations, and enhance symptoms and quality of life.

original: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are in a coma, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have elevated ICP refractory to medical management, decompressive crani- ectomy with or without hematoma evacuation may be considered to reduce mortality.453–460
paraphrased: For patients with supratentorial ICH who are comatose, possess large hematomas causing substantial midline shift, or exhibit elevated ICP unresponsive to medical treatment, decompressive craniectomy, with or without hematoma removal, may be an option to lower mortality.

original: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are in a coma, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have elevated ICP refractory to medical management, effectiveness of decompressive craniectomy with or without hematoma evacuation to improve functional outcomes is uncertain.458–462
paraphrased: For patients with supratentorial ICH who are comatose, have substantial hematomas causing notable midline shift, or experience elevated ICP unresponsive to medical treatment, the benefit of decompressive craniectomy, with or without hematoma removal, in enhancing functional outcomes remains unclear.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, a comprehen- sive approach to reduce sternal wound infec- tion is recommended.7-14
paraphrased: For patients having CABG, it is advised to implement a thorough strategy to minimize sternal wound infections.

original: In patients with high-degree or complete heart block and LVEF of 36% to 50%, CRT is reasonable to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.34,35 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients experiencing high-degree or complete heart block with an LVEF between 36% and 50%, it is advisable to consider CRT to decrease overall mortality, lessen hospital admissions, and enhance symptoms and quality of life.

original: In patients with AF in whom cardioversion is deferred due to LAA thrombus detected on precardioversion imaging, therapeutic anticoagulation should be insti- tuted for at least 3 to 6 weeks, after which imaging should be repeated before cardioversion.1,8
paraphrased: For patients with AF where cardioversion is postponed because a thrombus in the LAA is found on precardioversion imaging, therapeutic anticoagulation should be administered for a minimum of 3 to 6 weeks, followed by repeat imaging prior to cardioversion.

original: In selected patients with a low to intermediate pretest probability of CAD, contrast-enhanced coronary CT angiography is reasonable to exclude the presence of significant obstructive CAD.12–18
paraphrased: For patients with a low to intermediate likelihood of CAD, it is appropriate to use contrast-enhanced coronary CT angiography to rule out significant obstructive CAD.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, administer- ing a baseline measure of overall hemorrhage severity is recommended as part of the initial evaluation to provide an overall measure of clinical severity.472–474
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH, it is advised to include a baseline assessment of hemorrhage severity in the initial evaluation to gauge the overall clinical severity.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, the usefulness of continuous intravenous insulin designed to achieve a target intraoperative blood glucose concentration <140 mg/dL is uncertain.4,15
paraphrased: For patients having CABG, the benefit of using continuous intravenous insulin to maintain an intraoperative blood glucose level below 140 mg/dL is unclear.

original: In patients with AF and previous LAAO who are not on anticoagulation, imaging evaluation to assess the adequacy of LAAO and exclude device-related throm- bosis before cardioversion may be reasonable.9–19
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation and a history of left atrial appendage occlusion not receiving anticoagulation, it may be appropriate to perform imaging to evaluate the effectiveness of the LAAO and rule out device-related thrombosis prior to cardioversion.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a baseline severity score might be reasonable to provide a general framework for communication with the patient and their caregivers.472,473
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, establishing an initial severity score could be useful as a general guide for discussions with the patient and their caregivers.

original: In patients undergoing CABG who are already taking daily aspirin preoperatively, it is recom- mended that they continue taking aspirin until the time of surgery to reduce ischemic events.1-7
paraphrased: For patients scheduled for CABG who are on a daily aspirin regimen before surgery, it is advised to maintain aspirin use up to the surgery date to minimize ischemic events.

original: In patients with AF and previous LAAO with residual leak, pericardioversion anticoagulation may be considered and continued thereafter.9–11,20
paraphrased: For patients with AF who have undergone LAAO and have a residual leak, anticoagulation before and after cardioversion can be considered.

original: In patients undergoing valve repair or replacement with significant proximal CAD (≥70% reduction in luminal diameter in major coronary arteries or ≥50% reduction in luminal diameter in the left main coronary artery and/or physiologically significance), CABG is reasonable for selective patients.19,20
paraphrased: For patients with significant proximal coronary artery disease—defined as a luminal diameter reduction of 70% or more in major coronary arteries, or 50% or more in the left main coronary artery, or physiologically significant—undergoing valve repair or replacement, coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) may be appropriate for certain individuals.

original: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, LBBB with a QRS duration of 120 to 149 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambu- latory IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT can be useful to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.16–21,28–33
paraphrased: For patients with an LVEF of 35% or less, sinus rhythm, LBBB with a QRS duration between 120 and 149 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory IV symptoms while on GDMT, CRT may be beneficial in lowering overall mortality, decreasing hospital admissions, and enhancing symptoms and quality of life.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a baseline severity score should not be used as the sole basis for forecasting individual prognosis or limiting life-sustaining treatment.475,476
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH, a baseline severity score should not be the only factor in predicting individual outcomes or deciding to withhold life-sustaining treatment.

original: In patients with AF and LVEF ≤35% on GDMT, CRT can be useful to reduce total mortality, improve symptoms and QOL, and increase LVEF, if: a) the patient requires ventricular pac- ing or otherwise meets CRT criteria and b) atrioventricular nodal ablation or pharmacologi- cal rate control will allow near 100% ventricu- lar pacing with CRT.16–21,28–33
paraphrased: For patients with AF and an LVEF of 35% or less who are on GDMT, CRT may be beneficial for decreasing overall mortality, alleviating symptoms, enhancing quality of life, and boosting LVEF, provided that: a) the patient needs ventricular pacing or fulfills CRT criteria, and b) atrioventricular nodal ablation or pharmacological rate control can achieve nearly 100% ventricular pacing with CRT.

original: In patients with VHD and AF for whom surgical intervention is planned, the potential symptomatic benefits and additional procedural risks of adjunctive arrhythmia surgery at the time of cardiac valvular surgery should be discussed with the patient.1–11
paraphrased: For patients with VHD and AF who are scheduled for surgery, it is important to discuss with them the possible symptomatic advantages and extra procedural risks of performing arrhythmia surgery alongside cardiac valvular surgery.

original: For symptomatic patients with paroxysmal or persistent AF who are undergoing valvular surgery, surgical pulmonary vein isolation or a maze procedure can be beneficial to reduce symptoms and prevent recurrent arrhythmias.1,2,12–15
paraphrased: For patients with symptoms of paroxysmal or persistent atrial fibrillation undergoing valve surgery, performing surgical pulmonary vein isolation or a maze procedure may help alleviate symptoms and prevent arrhythmia recurrence.

original: In patients with reported AF duration of <48 hours (not in the setting of cardiac surgery) and who are not on anticoagulation, precardioversion imaging to exclude intracardiac thrombus may be considered ins those who are at elevated thromboembolic risk (CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent).21,22
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation lasting less than 48 hours (excluding those post-cardiac surgery) who are not receiving anticoagulation, imaging before cardioversion to rule out intracardiac thrombus can be considered for those with a high thromboembolic risk (CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or higher, or similar).

original: In patients referred for urgent CABG, clopi- dogrel and ticagrelor should be discontinued for at least 24 hours before surgery to reduce major bleeding complications.8-11
paraphrased: For patients scheduled for urgent CABG, clopidogrel and ticagrelor must be stopped at least 24 hours prior to surgery to minimize the risk of major bleeding complications.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, discontinuation of short-acting glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors (eptifibatide and tirofiban) for 4 hours and abciximab for 12 hours before surgery is rec- ommended to reduce the risk of bleeding and transfusion.12-14
paraphrased: For patients scheduled for CABG, it is advised to stop short-acting glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors (eptifibatide and tirofiban) 4 hours prior and abciximab 12 hours before the procedure to minimize bleeding and the need for transfusions.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH who do not have preexisting documented requests for life- sustaining therapy limitations, aggressive care, including postponement of new DNAR orders or withdrawal of medical support until at least the second full day of hospitalization, is reasonable to decrease mortality and improve functional outcome.479–484
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH without prior documented limitations on life-sustaining treatments, it is reasonable to pursue intensive care, including delaying new DNAR orders or the withdrawal of medical support, until at least the second full day of hospitalization to reduce mortality and enhance functional outcomes.

original: For patients on GDMT who have LVEF ≤35% and are undergoing placement of a new or replacement device implantation with anticipated requirement for significant (>40%) ventricular pacing, CRT can be useful to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.16–21,28–33
paraphrased: For patients receiving GDMT with an LVEF of 35% or less who are having a new or replacement device implanted and are expected to need substantial ventricular pacing (over 40%), CRT may be beneficial in lowering overall mortality, decreasing hospital admissions, and enhancing symptoms and quality of life.

original: For patients with AF or atrial flutter who are undergoing valve surgery, LA appendage ligation/excision is reasonable to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.16–19
paraphrased: For individuals with atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter undergoing valve surgery, it is advisable to consider LA appendage ligation or excision to lower the risk of thromboembolic events.

original: In patients with genetic arrhythmogenic car- diomyopathy with high-risk features of sudden death, with EF ≤45%, implantation of ICD is reasonable to decrease sudden death.36,37
paraphrased: For patients with genetic arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy who have high-risk factors for sudden death and an EF of 45% or less, it is advisable to implant an ICD to reduce the risk of sudden death.

original: In patients with low thromboembolic risks (CHA2DS2-VASc 0-1 or equivalent) and AF duration of <12 hours, the benefit of precardioversion imaging or pericardioversion anticoagulation is uncertain given the low incidence of pericardioversion thromboembolic events in this population.21,22
paraphrased: For patients with low thromboembolic risk (CHA2DS2-VASc score of 0-1 or similar) and atrial fibrillation lasting less than 12 hours, the advantage of imaging before cardioversion or anticoagulation during cardioversion is unclear due to the low occurrence of thromboembolic events in this group.

original: In patients with hemodynamic instability attributable to AF, immediate electrical cardioversion should be performed to restore sinus rhythm.1
paraphrased: For patients experiencing hemodynamic instability due to AF, prompt electrical cardioversion is necessary to reestablish sinus rhythm.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH who are unable to fully participate in medical decision- making, use of a shared decision-making model between surrogates and physicians is reasonable to optimize the alignment of care with patient wishes and surrogate satisfac- tion.485
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH who cannot actively engage in medical decisions, it is advisable to employ a shared decision-making approach between surrogates and physicians to better align care with the patient's preferences and enhance surrogate satisfaction.

original: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, a non-LBBB pattern with QRS dura- tion of 120 to 149 ms, and NYHA class III or ambulatory class IV on GDMT, CRT may be considered to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.16–21,28–33
paraphrased: For patients with an LVEF of 35% or less, sinus rhythm, a non-LBBB pattern with a QRS duration between 120 and 149 ms, and who are classified as NYHA class III or ambulatory class IV while on GDMT, CRT can be considered to decrease overall mortality, lower hospitalization rates, and enhance symptoms and quality of life.

original: In patients undergoing LA surgical ablation of atrial arrhythmias and/or LA appendage ligation/excision, anticoagulation therapy is reasonable for at least 3 months after the procedure.20–22
paraphrased: For patients receiving LA surgical ablation for atrial arrhythmias and/or undergoing LA appendage ligation or excision, it is advisable to continue anticoagulation therapy for a minimum of 3 months post-procedure.

original: In patients undergoing elective CABG who receive P2Y12 receptor inhibitors before sur- gery, it is reasonable to discontinue clopidogrel for 5 days, ticagrelor for 3 days, and prasugrel for 7 days before CABG to reduce risk of major bleeding and blood product transfu- sion.8,9,11,15-23
paraphrased: For patients scheduled for elective CABG who are on P2Y12 receptor inhibitors, it is advisable to stop clopidogrel 5 days, ticagrelor 3 days, and prasugrel 7 days prior to surgery to minimize the risk of significant bleeding and the need for blood transfusions.

original: In patients undergoing elective CABG who are not already taking aspirin, the initiation of aspi- rin (100–300 mg daily) in the immediate pre- operative period (<24 hours before surgery) is not recommended.24,25
paraphrased: For patients scheduled for elective CABG who are not on aspirin, starting aspirin (100–300 mg daily) within 24 hours before surgery is not advised.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH who have DNAR status, limiting other medical and surgi- cal interventions, unless explicitly specified by the patient or surrogate, is associated with increased patient mortality.180,479,486,487
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH and DNAR status, restricting additional medical and surgical interventions, unless clearly directed by the patient or their surrogate, correlates with higher mortality rates.

original: In patients with AF who are hemodynamically stable, electrical cardioversion can be performed as initial rhythm-control strategy or after unsuccessful pharmacological cardioversion.2
paraphrased: For patients with AF who are hemodynamically stable, electrical cardioversion may be used as the first rhythm-control approach or following the failure of pharmacological cardioversion.

original: For patients without atrial arrhythmias who are undergoing valvular surgery, LA appendage occlusion/exclusion/amputation is potentially harmful.23
paraphrased: LA appendage occlusion, exclusion, or amputation may be detrimental for patients undergoing valvular surgery who do not have atrial arrhythmias.

original: For patients who have LVEF ≤30%, ischemic cause of HF, sinus rhythm, LBBB with a QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class I symp- toms on GDMT, CRT may be considered to reduce hospitalizations and improve symptoms and QOL.16–21,28–33
paraphrased: For patients with an LVEF of 30% or less, heart failure due to ischemia, sinus rhythm, LBBB with a QRS duration of 150 ms or more, and NYHA class I symptoms while on GDMT, CRT can be considered to decrease hospital admissions and enhance symptoms and quality of life.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, who do not have a contraindication to beta blockers, the administration of beta blockers before surgery can be beneficial to reduce the incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation.1-8
paraphrased: For patients scheduled for CABG without contraindications to beta blockers, administering these medications preoperatively may help decrease the occurrence of atrial fibrillation after surgery.

original: In patients with AF undergoing electrical cardiover- sion, energy delivery should be confirmed to be syn- chronized to the QRS to reduce the risk of inducing VF.3
paraphrased: For patients with AF undergoing electrical cardioversion, ensure that energy delivery is synchronized with the QRS complex to minimize the risk of triggering VF.

original: In patients with QRS duration <120 ms, CRT is not recommended.36–41
paraphrased: CRT is not advised for patients whose QRS duration is less than 120 ms.

original: In patients with clinically suspected moderate or greater degrees of valvular stenosis or regurgitation who are undergoing noncardiac surgery, preoperative echocardiography is recommended.
paraphrased: For patients with a clinical suspicion of moderate or more severe valvular stenosis or regurgitation undergoing noncardiac surgery, it is advised to perform a preoperative echocardiogram.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, multidisci- plinary rehabilitation, including regular team meetings and discharge planning, should be performed to improve functional outcome and reduce morbidity and mortality.231,232
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH, engaging in multidisciplinary rehabilitation that involves regular team meetings and discharge planning is recommended to enhance functional outcomes and decrease morbidity and mortality.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH with mild to moderate severity, early supported discharge is beneficial to increase the likelihood of patients living at home at 3 months.490
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity, early supported discharge enhances the probability of them residing at home after three months.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, preoperative amiodarone is reasonable to reduce the inci- dence of postoperative atrial fibrillation.9-11
paraphrased: For patients having CABG, administering amiodarone before surgery is advisable to lower the risk of atrial fibrillation after the operation.

original: For patients with AF undergoing elective electrical cardioversion, the use of biphasic energy of at least 200 J as initial energy can be beneficial to improve success of initial electrical shock.4,5
paraphrased: For patients with AF undergoing elective electrical cardioversion, starting with a biphasic energy of at least 200 J may enhance the success rate of the initial shock.

original: For patients with NYHA class I or II symptoms and non-LBBB pattern with QRS duration <150 ms, CRT is not recommended.16–21,28–33
paraphrased: CRT is not advised for patients exhibiting NYHA class I or II symptoms with a non-LBBB pattern and a QRS duration of less than 150 ms.

original: In patients who meet standard indications for intervention for VHD (replacement and repair) on the basis of symptoms and disease severity, intervention should be performed before elective noncardiac surgery to reduce perioperative risk if possible, depending on the urgency and risk of the noncardiac procedure.1
paraphrased: For patients eligible for VHD intervention (replacement and repair) due to symptoms and disease severity, the procedure should be conducted prior to elective noncardiac surgery to minimize perioperative risk, contingent on the urgency and risk associated with the noncardiac procedure.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, who do not have a contraindication to beta blockers, preoperative use of beta blockers may be effective in reducing in-hospital and 30-day mortality rates.12-18
paraphrased: For patients having CABG without contraindications to beta blockers, administering beta blockers before surgery may effectively lower mortality rates both in-hospital and at 30 days.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH with moder- ate severity, early rehabilitation beginning 24 to 48 hours after onset (including ADL train- ing, stretching, functional task training) may be considered to improve functional outcome and reduce mortality.491,492
paraphrased: For patients experiencing moderate spontaneous ICH, initiating rehabilitation, such as ADL training, stretching, and functional task exercises, within 24 to 48 hours of onset may be considered to enhance functional outcomes and decrease mortality.

original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of AS and normal LV systolic function, it is reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.1–3
paraphrased: For asymptomatic patients with moderate or more severe aortic stenosis and normal left ventricular systolic function, elective noncardiac surgery is considered reasonable.

original: For patients whose comorbidities or frailty limit survival with good functional capacity to <1 year, ICD and cardiac resynchronization therapy with defibrillation (CRT-D) are not indi- cated.1–9,16–21
paraphrased: ICD and cardiac resynchronization therapy with defibrillation (CRT-D) are not recommended for patients whose comorbidities or frailty restrict their survival with adequate functional capacity to less than one year.

original: In patients with AF undergoing elective cardiover- sion, with longer duration of AF or unsuccessful initial shock, optimization of electrode vector, use of higher energy, and pretreatment with antiarrhythmic drugs can facilitate success of electrical cardioversion.5–9
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation undergoing elective cardioversion, especially those with prolonged AF or an unsuccessful initial shock, adjusting the electrode placement, increasing the energy level, and using antiarrhythmic drugs beforehand can enhance the success rate of electrical cardioversion.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH without depression, fluoxetine therapy is not effective to enhance poststroke functional status.493–497
paraphrased: Fluoxetine treatment does not improve poststroke functional outcomes in patients with spontaneous ICH who do not have depression.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, the role of preop- erative beta blockers for the prevention of acute postoperative myocardial ischemia, stroke, AKI, or ventricular arrhythmia is uncertain.12-14,18
paraphrased: The effectiveness of preoperative beta blockers in preventing acute postoperative myocardial ischemia, stroke, acute kidney injury, or ventricular arrhythmia in patients undergoing CABG is unclear.

original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of rheumatic MS with less than severe pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery systolic pressure <50 mm Hg), it is reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.
paraphrased: For asymptomatic patients with moderate or more severe rheumatic mitral stenosis and pulmonary hypertension that is not severe (pulmonary artery systolic pressure under 50 mm Hg), elective noncardiac surgery is considered appropriate.

original: In patients with obesity and AF, use of manual pressure augmentation and/or further escalation of electrical energy may be beneficial to improve suc- cess of electrical cardioversion.10
paraphrased: For patients with obesity and atrial fibrillation, applying manual pressure or increasing the electrical energy may enhance the success rate of electrical cardioversion.

original: In selected patients with HF, reduced EF (EF ≤35%), and suitable coronary anatomy, surgical revascularization plus GDMT is beneficial to improve symptoms, cardiovascular hospitaliza- tions, and long-term all-cause mortality.1–8
paraphrased: For certain patients with heart failure, an ejection fraction of 35% or less, and appropriate coronary anatomy, combining surgical revascularization with guideline-directed medical therapy is advantageous for alleviating symptoms, reducing cardiovascular hospitalizations, and decreasing long-term all-cause mortality.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, very early and intense mobilization within the first 24 hours is associated with lower likelihood of good recovery.498,499
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, initiating very early and vigorous mobilization within the initial 24 hours is linked to a reduced chance of favorable recovery.

original: For patients with AF, pharmacological cardioversion is reasonable as an alternative to electrical cardiover- sion for those who are hemodynamically stable or in situations when electrical cardioversion is preferred but cannot be performed.1
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation, using medication to achieve cardioversion is a suitable alternative to electrical cardioversion for individuals who are hemodynamically stable or when electrical cardioversion is desired but not feasible.

original: In patients with HF, VHD should be managed in a multidisciplinary manner in accordance with clini- cal practice guidelines for VHD to prevent wors- ening of HF and adverse clinical outcomes.1–11
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, valvular heart disease should be addressed through a multidisciplinary approach following clinical practice guidelines for valvular heart disease to avert the progression of heart failure and negative clinical outcomes.

original: In selected patients undergoing PCI, shorter- duration DAPT (1–3 months) is reasonable, with subsequent transition to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy to reduce the risk of bleeding events.1-4
paraphrased: For certain patients receiving PCI, it is appropriate to consider a shorter DAPT course of 1–3 months, followed by switching to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy to minimize bleeding risk.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, aspirin (100–325 mg daily) should be initiated within 6 hours postoperatively and then continued indefinitely to reduce the occurrence of SVG closure and adverse cardiovascular events.1-7
paraphrased: For patients having CABG, start aspirin (100–325 mg daily) within 6 hours after surgery and maintain it indefinitely to lower the risk of SVG closure and negative cardiovascular outcomes.

original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of MR and normal LV systolic function with less than severe pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery systolic pressure <50 mm Hg), it is reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.4–7
paraphrased: For patients without symptoms who have moderate or greater mitral regurgitation and normal left ventricular systolic function, along with pulmonary artery systolic pressure under 50 mm Hg indicating less than severe pulmonary hypertension, elective noncardiac surgery is considered appropriate.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and mod- erate to severe depression, appropriate evidence-based treatments including psycho- therapy and pharmacotherapy are useful to reduce symptoms of depression.507,508
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH along with moderate to severe depression, utilizing evidence-based interventions such as psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy is beneficial for alleviating depressive symptoms.

original: For patients with AF, ibutilide2,3 is reasonable for pharmacological cardioversion for patients without depressed LV function (LVEF <40%).
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation, using ibutilide for pharmacological cardioversion is appropriate for those whose left ventricular function is not reduced (LVEF ≥40%).

original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of AR and normal LV systolic function, it is reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.8
paraphrased: For patients without symptoms who have moderate or more severe AR and normal LV systolic function, elective noncardiac surgery can be reasonably considered.

original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR and HFrEF, optimization of GDMT is recom- mended before any intervention for secondary MR related to LV dysfunction.3–5,12–14
paraphrased: For patients with chronic severe secondary MR and HFrEF, it is advised to optimize GDMT prior to any intervention addressing secondary MR due to LV dysfunction.

original: In selected patients undergoing CABG, DAPT with aspirin and ticagrelor or clopidogrel for 1 year may be reasonable to improve vein graft patency compared with aspirin alone.8-10
paraphrased: For certain patients receiving CABG, using DAPT with aspirin and ticagrelor or clopidogrel for one year might be advisable to enhance vein graft patency compared to using aspirin alone.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, administra- tion of depression and anxiety screening tools in the postacute period is recommended to identify patients with poststroke depression and anxiety.509
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, it is advised to use screening tools for depression and anxiety during the postacute phase to detect poststroke depression and anxiety.

original: In patients with HFmrEF, SGLT2i can be ben- eficial in decreasing HF hospitalizations and cardiovascular mortality.1
paraphrased: For patients with HFmrEF, SGLT2 inhibitors may help reduce hospital admissions due to heart failure and lower the risk of cardiovascular death.

original: In patients with SIHD and normal left ven- tricular function, the routine use of chronic oral beta blockers is not beneficial to reduce cardiovascular events after complete revascu- larization.1-6
paraphrased: For patients with SIHD and normal left ventricular function, chronic oral beta blockers do not provide a benefit in reducing cardiovascular events following complete revascularization.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, administra- tion of a cognitive screening tool in the post- acute period is useful to identify patients with cognitive impairment and dementia.510
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, employing a cognitive screening tool during the post-acute phase is beneficial for detecting cognitive impairment and dementia.

original: For patients with AF, intravenous amiodarone is rea- sonable for pharmacological cardioversion, although time to conversion is generally longer than with other agents (8-12 hours).4–8
paraphrased: Intravenous amiodarone is a suitable option for pharmacological cardioversion in patients with AF, though it typically takes longer to achieve conversion compared to other medications (8-12 hours).

original: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, aortic diameters should be mea- sured at reproducible anatomic landmarks perpendicular to axis of blood flow, and these measurement methods should be reported in a clear and consistent manner. In cases of asymmetric or oval contour, the longest diam- eter and its perpendicular diameter should be reported.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with confirmed or suspected aortic disease, measure aortic diameters at consistent anatomical landmarks perpendicular to the blood flow axis, and ensure these measurement techniques are clearly and consistently documented. If the contour is asymmetric or oval, report both the longest diameter and its perpendicular diameter.

original: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, episodic and cumulative ionizing radi- ation doses should be kept as low as feasible while maintaining diagnostic image quality.5-7
paraphrased: For patients with confirmed or potential aortic disease, ionizing radiation exposure should be minimized as much as possible without compromising the quality of diagnostic images.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and cogni- tive impairment, referral for cognitive therapy is reasonable to improve cognitive out- comes.511–515
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH and cognitive impairment, it is advisable to refer them for cognitive therapy to enhance cognitive outcomes.

original: For patients with recurrent AF occurring outside the setting of a hospital, the “pill-in-the-pocket” (PITP) approach with a single oral dose of flecainide9–11 or propafenone,10–14 with a concomitant atrioventricular nodal blocking agent,15 is reasonable for pharmaco- logical cardioversion if previously tested in a moni- tored setting.16–18
paraphrased: For patients experiencing recurrent atrial fibrillation outside of a hospital, using a single oral dose of flecainide or propafenone alongside an atrioventricular nodal blocking agent is a reasonable pharmacological cardioversion strategy, provided it has been previously tested in a monitored environment.

original: In patients after CABG, beta blockers are recommended and should be started as soon as possible to reduce the incidence or clinical sequelae of postoperative atrial fibrillation.1-7
paraphrased: For patients post-CABG, initiating beta blockers promptly is advised to decrease the occurrence or effects of postoperative atrial fibrillation.

original: Among patients with current or previous symp- tomatic HFmrEF (LVEF, 41%–49%), use of evidence-based beta blockers for HFrEF, ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, and MRAs may be considered to reduce the risk of HF hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality, particularly among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.2–9
paraphrased: For patients with current or past symptomatic HFmrEF (LVEF, 41%–49%), considering the use of evidence-based beta blockers for HFrEF, ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, and MRAs can help lower the risk of heart failure hospitalization and cardiovascular death, especially in those with LVEF at the lower range of this category.

original: For patients with AF, use of intravenous procainamide may be considered for pharmacological cardioversion when other intravenous agents are contraindicated or not preferred.19
paraphrased: Intravenous procainamide can be considered for pharmacological cardioversion in patients with AF when other intravenous medications are either contraindicated or not favored.

original: In patients with atrial fibrillation who are undergoing PCI and are taking oral anticoagu- lant therapy, it is recommended to discontinue aspirin treatment after 1 to 4 weeks while maintaining P2Y12 inhibitors in addition to a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant (rivaroxaban, dabigatran, apixaban, or edoxaban) or warfarin to reduce the risk of bleeding.1-7
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation undergoing PCI and on oral anticoagulant therapy, it is advised to stop aspirin after 1 to 4 weeks, while continuing P2Y12 inhibitors alongside a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant (such as rivaroxaban, dabigatran, apixaban, or edoxaban) or warfarin, to minimize bleeding risk.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and pre- existing or new mood disorders requiring pharmacotherapy, continuation or initiation of SSRIs after ICH can be beneficial for the treatment of mood disorders.508,516–518
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) who have existing or newly diagnosed mood disorders that need medication, starting or continuing SSRIs post-ICH may be advantageous for managing these mood disorders.

original: In patients with HFimpEF after treatment, GDMT should be continued to prevent relapse of HF and LV dysfunction, even in patients who may become asymptomatic.1
paraphrased: For patients with HFimpEF following treatment, it is important to maintain GDMT to avert the recurrence of HF and LV dysfunction, even if the patients become asymptomatic.

original: For patients with AF and no previous MI, or known or suspected significant structural heart disease, or ven- tricular scar or fibrosis, use of flecainide3–5 or propafe- none5–12 is reasonable for long-term maintenance of sinus rhythm.
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation who have no history of myocardial infarction, or have known or suspected significant structural heart disease, or ventricular scar or fibrosis, it is reasonable to use flecainide or propafenone for the long-term maintenance of sinus rhythm.

original: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, when performing CT or MR imaging, it is recommended that the root and ascending aortic diameters be measured from inner-edge to inner-edge, using an electrocardiographic- synchronized technique. If there are aortic wall abnormalities, such as atherosclerosis or discrete wall thickening (more common in the distal aorta), the outer-edge to outer-edge diameter should be reported (Table 4).
paraphrased: For patients with confirmed or suspected aortic disease undergoing CT or MR imaging, it is advised to measure the root and ascending aortic diameters from inner-edge to inner-edge using an ECG-synchronized method. In cases of aortic wall abnormalities like atherosclerosis or localized wall thickening, which are more prevalent in the distal aorta, the outer-edge to outer-edge diameter should be documented (refer to Table 4).

original: Patients with HFpEF and hypertension should have medication titrated to attain blood pres- sure targets in accordance with published clini- cal practice guidelines to prevent morbidity.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with HFpEF and hypertension, medications should be adjusted to achieve blood pressure goals as outlined in established clinical practice guidelines to reduce morbidity.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and cogni- tive impairment, treatment with cholinesterase inhibitors or memantine might be considered to improve cognitive outcomes.519–521
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage and cognitive deficits, considering the use of cholinesterase inhibitors or memantine may enhance cognitive outcomes.

original: For patients with AF without recent decompensated HF or severe LV dysfunction, use of dronedarone5,13–15 is reasonable for long-term maintenance of sinus rhythm.
paraphrased: For patients with AF who do not have recent decompensated heart failure or significant left ventricular dysfunction, it is appropriate to consider dronedarone for the long-term maintenance of sinus rhythm.

original: In patients with HFpEF, SGLT2i can be ben- eficial in decreasing HF hospitalizations and cardiovascular mortality.4
paraphrased: For patients with HFpEF, SGLT2i may help reduce hospital admissions due to heart failure and lower the risk of cardiovascular death.

original: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, the aortic root diameter should be recorded as maximum sinus to sinus mea- surement. In the setting of known asymmetry, multiple measurements should be reported, and both short- and long-axis images of the root should be obtained to avoid underestima- tion of the diameter.
paraphrased: For patients with confirmed or suspected aortic disease, the aortic root diameter should be documented as the largest sinus-to-sinus measurement. If asymmetry is present, several measurements should be provided, and images of the root in both short and long axes should be captured to prevent underestimating the diameter.

original: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, it is reasonable that a dilated root or ascending aorta be indexed to patient height or BSA in the report, to aid in clinical risk assessment.8-11
paraphrased: For patients with confirmed or suspected aortic disease, indexing a dilated root or ascending aorta to the patient's height or body surface area in the report is advisable to assist in clinical risk evaluation.

original: In patients with atrial fibrillation who are undergoing PCI, are taking oral anticoagu- lant therapy, and are treated with DAPT or a P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy, it is reasonable to choose a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant over warfarin to reduce the risk of bleeding.1,3,4
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation undergoing PCI and on oral anticoagulant therapy, who are also receiving DAPT or a P2Y12 inhibitor alone, opting for a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant instead of warfarin is advisable to lower bleeding risk.

original: In patients who have undergone revasculariza- tion, a comprehensive cardiac rehabilitation program (home based or center based) should be prescribed either before hospital discharge or during the first outpatient visit to reduce deaths and hospital readmissions and improve quality of life.1-4
paraphrased: For patients who have had revascularization, a thorough cardiac rehabilitation program, whether conducted at home or in a center, should be recommended either prior to hospital discharge or at the initial outpatient appointment to decrease mortality and hospital readmissions and enhance quality of life.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH in whom the risk for recurrent ICH may facilitate prognosti- cation or management decisions, it is reason- able to incorporate the following risk factors for ICH recurrence into decision-making: (a) lobar location of the initial ICH; (b) older age; (c) presence, number, and lobar location of microbleeds on MRI; (d) presence of dissemi- nated cortical superficial siderosis on MRI; (e) poorly controlled hypertension; (f) Asian or Black race; and (g) presence of apolipopro- tein E ε2 or ε4 alleles.562–571
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH where assessing the risk of recurrence could aid in prognosis or management, it is advisable to consider the following risk factors for ICH recurrence in decision-making: (a) initial ICH in a lobar location; (b) advanced age; (c) presence, quantity, and lobar location of microbleeds on MRI; (d) presence of disseminated cortical superficial siderosis on MRI; (e) uncontrolled hypertension; (f) Asian or Black ethnicity; and (g) presence of apolipoprotein E ε2 or ε4 alleles.

original: In patients with HFpEF, management of AF can be useful to improve symptoms.
paraphrased: For patients with HFpEF, addressing AF may be beneficial for symptom improvement.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, BP control is recommended to prevent hemorrhage recur- rence.563,581
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, managing blood pressure is advised to prevent the recurrence of bleeding.

original: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, when performing echocardiography, it is reasonable to measure the aorta from leading-edge to leading-edge, perpendicular to the axis of blood flow.
paraphrased: For patients with confirmed or suspected aortic disease, it is advisable to measure the aorta from leading-edge to leading-edge, perpendicular to the blood flow axis, during echocardiography.

original: Patients who have undergone revasculariza- tion should be educated about CVD risk factors and their modification to reduce car- diovascular events.5-7 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: Individuals who have received revascularization should be informed about cardiovascular disease risk factors and how to modify them to decrease the likelihood of cardiovascular events.

original: For patients with AF without significant baseline QT interval prolongation or uncorrected hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia, use of dofetilide1,5,16 5–7,10,17,18 is reasonable for long-term maintenance of sinus rhythm, with proper dose selection based on kidney function and close monitoring of the QT interval, serum potassium and magnesium concentrations, and kidney function.
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation who do not have significant baseline QT interval prolongation or untreated low potassium or magnesium levels, it is appropriate to use dofetilide for long-term sinus rhythm maintenance. This should involve selecting the dose according to renal function and closely monitoring the QT interval, as well as serum potassium, magnesium levels, and renal function.

original: For patients with acute aortic disease that requires urgent repair, a multidisciplinary team should determine the most suitable interven- tion.
paraphrased: For patients with acute aortic disease needing immediate repair, a multidisciplinary team should decide on the most appropriate intervention.

original: In selected patients with HFpEF, MRAs may be considered to decrease hospitalizations, par- ticularly among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.5–7
paraphrased: For certain patients with HFpEF, MRAs can be considered to reduce hospital admissions, especially in those with LVEF at the lower range of this category.

original: For patients with AF and normal LV function, use of low-dose amiodarone (100-200 mg/d) is rea- sonable for long-term maintenance of sinus rhy thm2,5,17–22 but, in view of its adverse effect pro- file,5,23,24 should be reserved for patients in whom other rhythm control strategies are ineffective, not preferred, or contraindicated.
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation and normal left ventricular function, it is appropriate to use low-dose amiodarone (100-200 mg/day) for long-term sinus rhythm maintenance. However, due to its side effect profile, it should be reserved for those who do not respond to, cannot tolerate, or have contraindications to other rhythm control methods.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is reason- able to lower BP to an SBP of 130 mm Hg and diastolic BP (DBP) of 80 mm Hg for long- term management to prevent hemorrhage recurrence.581,582
paraphrased: For long-term management in patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, it is advisable to reduce blood pressure to a systolic level of 130 mm Hg and a diastolic level of 80 mm Hg to prevent recurrence of hemorrhage.

original: In patients who use tobacco and have undergone coronary revascularization, a combination of behavioral interventions plus pharmacotherapy is recommended to maxi- mize cessation and reduce adverse cardiac events.1-3
paraphrased: For patients who smoke and have had coronary revascularization, it is advised to combine behavioral therapies with medication to optimize quitting and decrease negative cardiac outcomes.

original: In selected patients with HFpEF, the use of ARB may be considered to decrease hospital- izations, particularly among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.8,9
paraphrased: For certain patients with HFpEF, ARBs might be considered to reduce hospital admissions, especially for those with LVEF at the lower range of this category.

original: For patients with AF without significant baseline QT interval prolongation, hypokalemia, hypomag- nesemia, or bradycardia, use of sotalol5–7,10,17,18 may be considered for long-term maintenance of sinus rhythm, with proper dose selection based on kidney function and close monitoring of the QT interval, heart rate, serum potassium and magnesium con- centrations, and kidney function.
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation who do not have significant baseline QT interval prolongation, low potassium or magnesium levels, or slow heart rate, sotalol may be considered for long-term sinus rhythm maintenance. This should involve appropriate dosing according to renal function and careful monitoring of the QT interval, heart rate, and serum potassium and magnesium levels.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and condi- tions placing them at high risk of thromboem- bolic events, for example, a mechanical valve or LVAD, early resumption of anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic complications is reasonable.586,587
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage who are at elevated risk for thromboembolic events, such as those with a mechanical valve or LVAD, it is reasonable to restart anticoagulation early to prevent thromboembolic complications.

original: Patients with AF who are initiating, increasing the dose of, or reinitiating dofetilide therapy should be admitted for a minimum of 3 days to a facility that can provide continuous electrocardiographic monitoring, calculations of CrCl, and cardiac resuscitation, given the potential for proarrhythmia.1–7
paraphrased: Patients with atrial fibrillation starting, increasing, or resuming dofetilide treatment should be hospitalized for at least three days in a facility equipped for continuous ECG monitoring, CrCl assessment, and cardiac resuscitation due to the risk of proarrhythmia.

original: For patients who are asymptomatic with extensive aortic disease, or who may benefit from complex open and endovascular aortic repairs, or with multiple comorbidities for whom intervention is considered, referral to a high-volume center (performing at least 30-40 aortic procedures annually) with expe- rienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team is reasonable to optimize treatment outcomes.1-6
paraphrased: Referring asymptomatic patients with extensive aortic disease, those who could gain from complex open and endovascular aortic repairs, or individuals with multiple comorbidities requiring intervention to a high-volume center (conducting a minimum of 30-40 aortic procedures per year) with skilled surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team is advisable to enhance treatment outcomes.

original: In patients who use tobacco and have under- gone coronary revascularization, smoking ces- sation interventions are recommended during hospitalization and should include supportive follow-up for at least 1 month after discharge to facilitate tobacco cessation and reduce morbidity and mortality.4-6
paraphrased: For patients who use tobacco and have had coronary revascularization, it is advised to implement smoking cessation interventions during their hospital stay, with supportive follow-up for a minimum of one month post-discharge, to aid in quitting tobacco and decrease morbidity and mortality.

original: In selected patients with HFpEF, ARNi may be considered to decrease hospitalizations, par- ticularly among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.10,11
paraphrased: For certain patients with HFpEF, ARNi can be contemplated to reduce hospital admissions, especially in those whose LVEF is at the lower range of this category.

original: In patients with aortic disease, shared deci- sion-making is recommended when determin- ing the appropriate thresholds for intervention, deciding on the type of surgical repair, choos- ing between open surgical versus endovascu- lar approaches; and in medical management and surveillance.1-6
paraphrased: For patients with aortic disease, it is advised to engage in shared decision-making to establish suitable intervention thresholds, select the type of surgical repair, choose between open surgical and endovascular methods, and manage medical treatment and monitoring.

original: In patients who have undergone coronary revascularization who have symptoms of depression, anxiety, or stress, treatment with cognitive behavioral therapy, psychological counseling, and/or pharmacological interven- tions is beneficial to improve quality of life and cardiac outcomes.1-7
paraphrased: For patients who have had coronary revascularization and exhibit symptoms of depression, anxiety, or stress, utilizing cognitive behavioral therapy, psychological counseling, and/or medication is advantageous for enhancing quality of life and cardiac outcomes.

original: In patients with AF, it is reasonable to initiate sotalol therapy in a facility that can provide continuous electrocardiographic monitoring, calculations of CrCl, and cardiac resuscitation, given the potential for proarrhythmia and bradycardia.4,8–10
paraphrased: For patients with AF, starting sotalol treatment in a setting equipped for continuous ECG monitoring, CrCl assessment, and cardiac resuscitation is advisable due to the risks of proarrhythmia and bradycardia.

original: In patients with aortic disease who are contem- plating pregnancy or who are pregnant, shared decision-making is recommended when con- sidering the cardiovascular risks of pregnancy, the diameter thresholds for prophylactic aortic surgery, and the mode of delivery.
paraphrased: For patients with aortic disease who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant, it is advised to engage in shared decision-making regarding the cardiovascular risks associated with pregnancy, the size criteria for preventive aortic surgery, and the choice of delivery method.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH with an indi- cation for antiplatelet therapy, resumption of antiplatelet therapy may be reasonable for the prevention of thromboembolic events based on consideration of benefit and risk.588,589
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage who require antiplatelet therapy, restarting antiplatelet treatment could be considered to prevent thromboembolic events, taking into account the benefits and risks.

original: In patients with HFpEF, routine use of nitrates or phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors to increase activity or QOL is ineffective.12,13 *See Section 7.2, “Diuretics and Decongestion Strategies in Patients with HF,” and Section 10.2, “Management of Atrial Fibrillation (AF) in HF” for recom- mendations for use of diuretics and management of AF in HF. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with HFpEF, using nitrates or phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors routinely to enhance activity or quality of life is not effective. Refer to Section 7.2 for diuretic and decongestion strategies in HF patients, and Section 10.2 for managing atrial fibrillation in HF.

original: In patients who have undergone coronary revascularization, it may be reasonable to screen for depression and refer or treat when it is indicated to improve quality of life and recovery.8,9
paraphrased: For patients who have had coronary revascularization, screening for depression and providing referral or treatment when necessary can be beneficial for enhancing quality of life and recovery.

original: In patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (AF) and spontaneous ICH, the resumption of anti- coagulation to prevent thromboembolic events and reduce all-cause mortality may be consid- ered based on weighing benefit and risk.590–595
paraphrased: For patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (AF) who have experienced spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), restarting anticoagulation therapy to prevent thromboembolic events and lower all-cause mortality can be contemplated by evaluating the benefits against the risks.

original: Patients for whom there is a clinical suspi- cion for cardiac amyloidosis*1–5 should have screening for serum and urine monoclonal light chains with serum and urine immuno- fixation electrophoresis and serum free light chains.6
paraphrased: For patients with a clinical suspicion of cardiac amyloidosis, screening should include serum and urine monoclonal light chains using serum and urine immunofixation electrophoresis, along with serum free light chains.

original: With the goal of improving patient outcomes, it is recommended that cardiac surgery and PCI programs participate in state, regional, or national clinical data registries and receive periodic reports of their risk-adjusted out- comes as a quality assessment and improve- ment strategy.1-8
paraphrased: To enhance patient outcomes, it is advised that cardiac surgery and PCI programs engage in state, regional, or national clinical data registries and obtain regular reports on their risk-adjusted outcomes as a strategy for quality assessment and improvement.

original: In patients with AF and spontaneous ICH in whom the decision is made to restart antico- agulation, initiation of anticoagulation ≈7 to 8 weeks after ICH may be considered after weighing specific patient characteristics to optimize the balance of risks and benefits.596,597
paraphrased: For patients with AF who have experienced spontaneous ICH and are considered for resuming anticoagulation, starting anticoagulation approximately 7 to 8 weeks post-ICH can be contemplated after evaluating individual patient factors to optimize the risk-benefit balance.

original: In patients with AF who are initiating PITP dosing of flecainide and propafenone with concomitant atrioventricular nodal blocking drugs, it is reasonable to receive the first dose in a facility that can provide continuous electrocardiographic monitoring, given the potential for proarrhythmia.9–13
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation starting on PITP doses of flecainide and propafenone alongside atrioventricular nodal blocking agents, it is advisable to administer the initial dose in a setting equipped for continuous ECG monitoring due to the risk of proarrhythmia.

original: In patients with high clinical suspicion for car- diac amyloidosis, without evidence of serum or urine monoclonal light chains, bone scintigra- phy should be performed to confirm the pres- ence of transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis.7
paraphrased: For patients highly suspected of having cardiac amyloidosis and lacking serum or urine monoclonal light chains, bone scintigraphy is recommended to confirm transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis.

original: In patients with AF and spontaneous ICH deemed ineligible for anticoagulation, left atrial appendage closure may be considered to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.598–602
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation and spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage who cannot receive anticoagulation, left atrial appendage closure can be an option to lower the risk of thromboembolic events.

original: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection, obtaining a multigenerational family history of TAD, unex- plained sudden deaths, and peripheral and intracranial aneurysms is ­recommended.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with aortic root or ascending aortic aneurysms, or aortic dissection, it is advised to gather a multigenerational family history of thoracic aortic disease, unexplained sudden deaths, and peripheral or intracranial aneurysms.

original: In patients with symptomatic AF in whom anti- arrhythmic drugs have been ineffective, contra- indicated, not tolerated or not preferred, and continued rhythm control is desired, cath- eter ablation is useful to improve symptoms.1–10
paraphrased: For patients with symptomatic atrial fibrillation where anti-arrhythmic medications are ineffective, unsuitable, intolerable, or not favored, and ongoing rhythm control is needed, catheter ablation is beneficial for symptom improvement.

original: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection and risk factors for HTAD (Table 8, Figure 17), genetic testing to identify pathogenic/ likely pathogenic variants (ie, mutations) is ­recommended.4-6
paraphrased: For patients with aortic root or ascending aortic aneurysms, or aortic dissection who have risk factors for HTAD (refer to Table 8, Figure 17), it is advised to conduct genetic testing to detect pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants (mutations).

original: With the goal of improving patient outcomes, it is reasonable for cardiac surgery and PCI pro- grams to have a quality improvement program that routinely 1) reviews institutional quality programs and outcomes, 2) reviews individual operator outcomes, 3) provides peer review of difficult or complicated cases, and 4) performs random case reviews.9,10
paraphrased: To enhance patient outcomes, cardiac surgery and PCI programs should consider implementing a quality improvement initiative that regularly 1) evaluates institutional quality programs and outcomes, 2) assesses individual operator results, 3) conducts peer reviews of challenging or complex cases, and 4) carries out random case evaluations.

original: In patients with an established pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant in a gene predispos- ing to HTAD, it is recommended that genetic counseling be provided and the patient’s clini- cal management be informed by the specific gene and variant in the gene.7-9
paraphrased: For patients with a confirmed pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant in a gene associated with HTAD, genetic counseling should be offered, and clinical management should be guided by the specific gene and its variant.

original: In selected patients (generally younger with few comorbidities) with symptomatic parox- ysmal AF in whom rhythm control is desired, catheter ablation is useful as first-line therapy to improve symptoms and reduce progression to persistent AF.11–16
paraphrased: For certain patients, typically younger individuals with minimal comorbidities, who have symptomatic paroxysmal AF and require rhythm control, catheter ablation is beneficial as an initial treatment to alleviate symptoms and prevent progression to persistent AF.

original: Smaller volume cardiac surgery and PCI programs may consider affiliating with a high- volume center to improve patient care. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: Programs with lower volumes in cardiac surgery and PCI might enhance patient care by partnering with a high-volume center.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and an estab- lished indication for statin pharmacotherapy, the risks and benefits of statin therapy on ICH out- comes and recurrence relative to overall preven- tion of cardiovascular events are uncertain.605–609
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage who have a clear indication for statin use, the impact of statin therapy on ICH outcomes and recurrence, compared to its role in preventing cardiovascular events, remains unclear.

original: In patients for whom a diagnosis of transthyre- tin cardiac amyloidosis is made, genetic testing with TTR gene sequencing is recommended to differentiate hereditary variant from wild-type transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis.8 *LV wall thickness ≥14 mm in conjunction with fatigue, dyspnea, or edema, especially in the context of discordance between wall thickness on echocardiogram and QRS voltage on ECG, and in the context of aortic ste- nosis, HFpEF, carpal tunnel syndrome, spinal stenosis, and autonomic or sensory polyneuropathy.
paraphrased: For patients diagnosed with transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis, TTR gene sequencing is advised to distinguish between hereditary and wild-type forms. Consider this especially when left ventricular wall thickness is ≥14 mm along with symptoms like fatigue, dyspnea, or edema, particularly if there is a mismatch between echocardiogram wall thickness and QRS voltage on ECG, and in cases of aortic stenosis, HFpEF, carpal tunnel syndrome, spinal stenosis, or autonomic or sensory polyneuropathy.

original: In patients with symptomatic or clinically significant AFL, catheter ablation is useful for improving symptoms.17–19
paraphrased: Catheter ablation is beneficial for alleviating symptoms in patients with symptomatic or clinically significant AFL.17–19

original: In patients with TAD who have a pathogenic/ likely pathogenic variant, genetic testing of at- risk biological relatives (ie, cascade testing) is recommended.6,10,11 In family members who are found by genetic screening to have inherited the pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, aortic imaging with TTE (if aortic root and ascending aorta are adequately visualized, otherwise with CT or MRI) is recommended.4,5,12
paraphrased: For patients with TAD carrying a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant, it is advised to conduct genetic testing on at-risk biological relatives, known as cascade testing. If genetic screening reveals that family members have inherited the pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant, it is recommended to perform aortic imaging using TTE, provided the aortic root and ascending aorta are clearly visible; otherwise, CT or MRI should be used.

original: In select patients with wild-type or variant trans- thyretin cardiac amyloidosis and NYHA class I to III HF symptoms, transthyretin tetramer sta- bilizer therapy (tafamidis) is indicated to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.1 Value Statement: Low Value (B-NR)
paraphrased: For certain patients with wild-type or variant transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis experiencing NYHA class I to III heart failure symptoms, tafamidis, a transthyretin tetramer stabilizer, is recommended to decrease cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Value Statement: Low Value (B-NR)
