original: In patients with suspected ACS, a 12-lead ECG should be acquired and interpreted within 10 minutes of first medical contact (FMC)* to identify patients with STEMI.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with suspected ACS, a 12-lead ECG must be obtained and analyzed within 10 minutes of initial medical contact to detect those with STEMI.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, regular long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is potentially harmful because of the increased risk of ICH.610,611
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), the consistent long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) may be detrimental due to the heightened risk of ICH.

original: In patients who are undergoing ablation for AF, ablation of additional clinically significant supraventricular arrhythmias can be useful to reduce the likelihood of future arrhythmia.17,18,20–27
paraphrased: For patients receiving ablation for atrial fibrillation, targeting other clinically significant supraventricular arrhythmias during the procedure may help decrease the risk of future arrhythmias.

original: In patients with cardiac amyloidosis and AF, anticoagulation is reasonable to reduce the risk of stroke regardless of the CHA2DS2-VASc (congestive heart failure, hypertension, age ≥75 years, diabetes mellitus, stroke or transient ischemic attack [TIA], vascular disease, age 65 to 74 years, sex category) score.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with cardiac amyloidosis and atrial fibrillation, it is advisable to use anticoagulation to lower the risk of stroke, irrespective of the CHA2DS2-VASc score.

original: In a family with aortic root/ascending aor- tic aneurysms or aortic dissection, if the disease-causing variant is not identified with genetic testing, screening aortic imag- ing (as per recommendation 4) of at-risk biological relatives (ie, cascade testing) is ­recommended.13-15
paraphrased: For families with aortic root or ascending aortic aneurysms or dissection, if genetic testing does not reveal the causative variant, it is advised to conduct screening aortic imaging (following recommendation 4) for biological relatives at risk, known as cascade testing.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, lifestyle modification is reasonable to reduce BP.632
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage, it is advisable to modify lifestyle to lower blood pressure.

original: In patients with suspected ACS in which the initial ECG is nondiagnostic of STEMI, serial ECGs to detect potential ischemic changes should be performed, especially when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or the clinical condition deteriorates.†3,4 STEMI
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having ACS where the initial ECG does not diagnose STEMI, repeated ECGs should be conducted to identify possible ischemic changes, particularly if there is a strong clinical suspicion of ACS, ongoing symptoms, or worsening clinical condition.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, avoiding heavy alcohol consumption is reasonable to reduce hypertension and risk of ICH recurrence.633–635
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH, it is advisable to refrain from excessive alcohol intake to lower hypertension and the likelihood of ICH recurrence.

original: In patients (other than younger with few comorbidities) with symptomatic paroxysmal or persistent AF who are being managed with a rhythm-control strategy, catheter ablation as first-line therapy can be useful to improve symptoms.11–13,28 Cost Value Statement: Intermediate B-R
paraphrased: For patients with symptomatic paroxysmal or persistent atrial fibrillation, except younger individuals with minimal comorbidities, catheter ablation may be beneficial as an initial treatment in a rhythm-control approach to alleviate symptoms.

original: In patients with suspected STEMI, immediate emergency medical services (EMS) transport to a PCI-capable hospital for primary PCI (PPCI‡) is the recommended triage strategy, with an FMC–to-first-device time system goal of ≤90 minutes.5–7
paraphrased: For patients with suspected STEMI, the advised triage approach is prompt transport by emergency medical services to a hospital equipped for PCI, aiming for a system goal of ≤90 minutes from first medical contact to device deployment.

original: In patients with advanced HF, when consistent with the patient’s goals of care, timely refer- ral for HF specialty care is recommended to review HF management and assess suitability for advanced HF therapies (eg, LVAD, cardiac transplantation, palliative care, and palliative inotropes).1–6
paraphrased: For patients with advanced heart failure, it is advisable to promptly refer them to a heart failure specialist, in alignment with their care goals, to evaluate heart failure management and determine eligibility for advanced therapies such as LVAD, cardiac transplantation, palliative care, and palliative inotropes.

original: In patients with aortic root/ascending aor- tic aneurysms or aortic dissection, in the absence of either a known family history of TAD or pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, screening aortic imaging (as per recommen- dation 4) of first-degree relatives is recom- mended.13
paraphrased: For individuals with aortic root or ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection, and without a known family history of thoracic aortic disease or a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, it is advised to conduct screening aortic imaging of first-degree relatives, following recommendation 4.

original: For patients with advanced HF and hypona- tremia, the benefit of fluid restriction to reduce congestive symptoms is uncertain.1–4
paraphrased: The advantage of fluid restriction for alleviating congestive symptoms in patients with advanced heart failure and hyponatremia is unclear.

original: In selected* patients with asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic AF, catheter ablation may be useful for reducing progression of AF and its associated complications.31–39 *Younger patients with few comorbidities and a moderate to high burden of AF or persistent AF and AFL.
paraphrased: For certain patients with asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic atrial fibrillation, catheter ablation can be beneficial in decreasing the progression of AF and its related complications, particularly in younger individuals with minimal comorbidities and a moderate to high frequency of AF or persistent AF and AFL.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, lifestyle modification, including supervised training and counseling, may be reasonable to improve functional recovery.636,637 Patient and caregiver education
paraphrased: For patients experiencing spontaneous ICH, it may be beneficial to enhance functional recovery through lifestyle changes, such as guided exercise and counseling, along with education for both patients and caregivers.

original: In patients with suspected STEMI, early advance notification of the receiving PCI-capable hospital by EMS personnel and activation of the cardiac catheterization team is recommended to reduce time to reperfusion.1,8,9 *FMC indicates the time point when the patient is initially assessed by a health care professional who can obtain and interpret the ECG and deliver initial inter- ventions (eg, defibrillation). †Modified from the “2021 AHA/ACC/ASE/CHEST/SAEM/SCCT/SCMR Guideline for the Evaluation and Diagnosis of Chest Pain.”10 ‡PPCI refers to emergency PCI in the setting of STEMI to achieve reperfusion in patients without previous fibrinolytic treatment.
paraphrased: For patients with suspected STEMI, it is advised that EMS personnel promptly inform the PCI-capable hospital and activate the cardiac catheterization team to minimize reperfusion time.

original: In patients undergoing ablation for AF, PVI is recom- mended as the primary lesion set for all patients unless a different specific trigger is identified.1–7
paraphrased: For patients receiving ablation for atrial fibrillation, pulmonary vein isolation should be the initial lesion set for everyone, unless a distinct trigger is identified.

original: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nonsyndromic heritable thoracic aortic dis- ease (nsHTAD) and no identified genetic cause, determining the timing of surgical repair requires shared decision-making and is informed by known aortic diameters at the time of aortic dissection, TAA repair, or both in affected family members.1-4
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with aortic root or ascending aorta aneurysms due to nonsyndromic heritable thoracic aortic disease (nsHTAD) without a known genetic cause, the timing of surgical intervention should be decided collaboratively, guided by the aortic diameters observed during dissection or thoracic aortic aneurysm repair in family members.

original: In patients with advanced (stage D) HF refrac- tory to GDMT and device therapy who are eligible for and awaiting MCS or cardiac trans- plantation, continuous intravenous inotropic support is reasonable as “bridge therapy.”1–4
paraphrased: For patients with advanced stage D heart failure who do not respond to guideline-directed medical and device therapy and are candidates for mechanical circulatory support or heart transplantation, continuous intravenous inotropic therapy is a reasonable option as bridge therapy.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, psychoso- cial education for the caregiver can be ben- eficial to increase patients’ activity level and participation and/or quality of life.638
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH, providing psychosocial education to caregivers may help enhance the patients' activity levels, participation, and/or quality of life.

original: In patients with suspected ACS, acquisition and interpretation of an ECG within 10 minutes is recommended to help guide patient management.*1,2 Table 4.  Types of Acute Myocardial Infarction According to the Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction Type 1* Caused by acute coronary atherothrombosis, usually precipitated by atherosclerotic plaque disruption (rupture or erosion) and often associated with partial or complete vessel thrombosis. Type 2
paraphrased: For patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome (ACS), it is advised to obtain and interpret an ECG within 10 minutes to assist in directing patient care.

original: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nsHTAD and no identified genetic cause but no information on aortic diameters at the time of dissection or aneurysm repair in affected family members and who have no high-risk features for adverse aortic events (Table 9) it is recommended to repair the aorta when the maximal diameter reaches ≥5.0 cm.1
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals with aortic root or ascending aorta aneurysms associated with nsHTAD, lacking a genetic cause and without data on aortic diameters during dissection or repair in affected relatives, and who do not exhibit high-risk features for adverse aortic events (refer to Table 9), aortic repair is advised when the maximum diameter is ≥5.0 cm.

original: In patients undergoing ablation for AF, the value of other endpoints beyond PVI such as noninducibility and ablation of additional anatomic ablation targets (eg, posterior wall sites, low voltage areas, complex fractionated electrograms, rotors) is uncertain.8–18
paraphrased: For patients receiving ablation for atrial fibrillation, the significance of endpoints other than pulmonary vein isolation, such as achieving noninducibility and targeting additional anatomical sites (e.g., posterior wall, low voltage regions, complex fractionated electrograms, rotors), remains unclear.

original: In select patients with stage D HF, despite optimal GDMT and device therapy who are ineligible for either MCS or cardiac transplan- tation, continuous intravenous inotropic sup- port may be considered as palliative therapy for symptom control and improvement in func- tional status.5–7
paraphrased: For certain patients with stage D heart failure who do not qualify for mechanical circulatory support or heart transplantation, and have already received optimal guideline-directed medical and device therapy, continuous intravenous inotropic support can be considered as a palliative measure to manage symptoms and enhance functional status.

original: In patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nsHTAD and no identified genetic cause and a maximal aortic diameter of ≥4.5 cm, who have high-risk fea- tures for adverse aortic events (Table 9), or who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, aortic repair is reasonable when performed by experienced surgeons in a Mul- tidisciplinary Aortic Team.5
paraphrased: For patients with aortic root or ascending aorta aneurysms associated with nsHTAD, lacking a genetic cause, and having a maximal aortic diameter of 4.5 cm or greater, it is advisable to consider aortic repair if they exhibit high-risk features for adverse aortic events (see Table 9) or are undergoing cardiac surgery for other reasons, provided the procedure is conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, practical sup- port and training for the caregiver are reason- able to improve patients’ standing balance.639
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous ICH, providing practical support and training to the caregiver is advisable to enhance the patients' standing balance.

original: In patients with suspected ACS in whom the initial ECG is nondiagnostic, serial 12-lead ECGs should be performed to detect potential ischemic changes, especially when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or clinical condition deteriorates.*3
paraphrased: For patients with suspected ACS and an initial ECG that is inconclusive, repeated 12-lead ECGs are recommended to identify possible ischemic changes, particularly when there is a strong clinical suspicion of ACS, ongoing symptoms, or worsening clinical status.

original: For term and late preterm newborn infants ≥34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, delayed cord clamping (DCC) (≥30 seconds) can be beneficial when compared to early cord clamping (<30 seconds).
paraphrased: For newborns born at or after 34 weeks' gestation who do not need resuscitation, delaying cord clamping for at least 30 seconds may be advantageous compared to clamping before 30 seconds.

original: In patients with recurrent symptomatic AF after catheter ablation, repeat catheter ablation or antiarrhythmic drug therapy is useful to improve symptoms and freedom from AF.1–11
paraphrased: For patients experiencing recurrent symptomatic atrial fibrillation following catheter ablation, undergoing another catheter ablation or using antiarrhythmic medications is beneficial for alleviating symptoms and achieving freedom from atrial fibrillation.

original: In patients with suspected ACS, cTn should be measured as soon as possible, preferably using a high-sensitivity cTn (hs-cTn) assay.*4–7
paraphrased: For patients with suspected ACS, cTn should be assessed promptly, ideally with a high-sensitivity cTn (hs-cTn) test.

original: In patients with HF, long-term use of either continuous or intermittent intravenous inotropic agents, for reasons other than palliative care or as a bridge to advanced therapies, is potentially harmful.5,6,8–11
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure, prolonged administration of intravenous inotropic agents, whether continuous or intermittent, is potentially detrimental unless used for palliative care or as a transition to advanced treatments.

original: When considering primary prevention of ICH, it may be reasonable to incorporate any available MRI results demonstrating cerebral microbleed burden or cortical superficial sid- erosis to inform shared decision-making about stroke prevention treatment plans.25,564,644–648
paraphrased: For primary ICH prevention, it might be advisable to use MRI findings that show cerebral microbleeds or cortical superficial siderosis to guide collaborative decisions on stroke prevention strategies.

original: In some patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, short-term antiarrhythmic drug therapy after ablation can be useful to reduce early recur- rences of atrial arrhythmia and hospitalization.12–16
paraphrased: For certain patients who have had catheter ablation for AF, using antiarrhythmic drugs temporarily after the procedure may help decrease early atrial arrhythmia recurrences and the need for hospitalization.

original: For nonvigorous term and late preterm infants (35–42 weeks’ gestation), intact cord milking may be reasonable when compared to early cord clamping (<30 seconds).
paraphrased: For nonvigorous infants born at term or late preterm (35–42 weeks’ gestation), intact cord milking might be a reasonable alternative to early cord clamping (within 30 seconds).

original: In select patients with advanced HFrEF with NYHA class IV symptoms who are deemed to be dependent on continuous intravenous inotropes or temporary MCS, durable LVAD implantation is effective to improve functional status, QOL, and survival.1–18
paraphrased: For certain patients with advanced HFrEF exhibiting NYHA class IV symptoms and reliant on ongoing intravenous inotropes or temporary MCS, the implantation of a durable LVAD effectively enhances functional status, quality of life, and survival.

original: In adults with Marfan syndrome, after the initial TTE, a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is reasonable to confirm the aortic diameters and assess the remainder of the thoracic aorta. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For adults diagnosed with Marfan syndrome, following the initial transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), it is advisable to perform a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta to verify aortic measurements and evaluate the rest of the thoracic aorta.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, a TTE is recommended at the time of initial diagnosis, to determine the diameters of the aortic root and ascending aorta, and 6 months thereafter, to determine the rate of aortic growth; if the aortic diameters are stable, an annual surveillance TTE is recommended.1 If the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both are not adequately visualized on TTE, a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is recommended.2
paraphrased: For individuals diagnosed with Marfan syndrome, an initial TTE is advised to measure the aortic root and ascending aorta diameters, followed by another TTE in 6 months to assess aortic growth rate; if these diameters remain stable, an annual TTE is suggested. If TTE does not clearly visualize the aortic root or ascending aorta, a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta should be performed.

original: For patients with HCM or at risk for HCM, shared decision-making is recommended in developing a plan of care (including but not limited to decisions regarding genetic evaluation, activity, lifestyle, and therapy choices) that includes a full disclosure of the risks, benefits, and anticipated outcomes of all options, as well the opportunity for the patient to express their goals and concerns.4–9
paraphrased: For individuals diagnosed with or at risk for HCM, it is advised to engage in shared decision-making when formulating a care plan. This plan should encompass decisions about genetic testing, activity, lifestyle, and treatment options, ensuring a comprehensive discussion of the risks, benefits, and expected results of each choice, while also allowing the patient to communicate their objectives and concerns.

original: In patients on warfarin who are undergoing catheter ablation of AF, catheter ablation should be performed on uninterrupted therapeutic anticoagula- tion with a goal INR of 2.0 to 3.0.1
paraphrased: For patients receiving warfarin and undergoing catheter ablation for atrial fibrillation, the procedure should be conducted without interrupting therapeutic anticoagulation, aiming for an INR between 2.0 and 3.0.

original: In patients with suspected ACS with an initial hs-cTn or cTn that is nondiagnostic, the recommended time intervals for repeat measurements after the initial sample collection (time zero) are 1 to 2 hours for hs-cTn and 3 to 6 hours for conventional cTn assays.*8–12 *Adapted from the “2021 AHA/ACC/ASE/CHEST/SAEM/SCCT/SCMR Guideline for the Evaluation and Diagnosis of Chest Pain.”13
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having ACS with an initial nondiagnostic hs-cTn or cTn, it is advised to repeat hs-cTn measurements 1 to 2 hours after the initial sample (time zero) and conventional cTn assays 3 to 6 hours later.

original: For term and late preterm newborn infants ≥34 weeks’ gestation who do not require ­resuscitation, intact cord milking is not known to be beneficial when compared to DCC (≥30 seconds). Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: For newborns at or beyond 34 weeks' gestation who are full-term or late preterm and do not need resuscitation, intact cord milking has not been shown to offer advantages over delayed cord clamping of 30 seconds or more.

original: In select patients with advanced HFrEF who have NYHA class IV symptoms despite GDMT, durable MCS can be beneficial to improve symptoms, improve functional class, and reduce mortality.2,4,7,10,12–17,19 Value Statement: Uncertain Value (B-NR)
paraphrased: For certain patients with advanced HFrEF experiencing NYHA class IV symptoms despite GDMT, long-term MCS may be advantageous for alleviating symptoms, enhancing functional class, and decreasing mortality. Value Statement: Uncertain Value (B-NR)

original: Patients with cardiac arrest and STEMI who have been resuscitated should preferentially be transferred by EMS to a PPCI-capable center.1,2
paraphrased: Patients experiencing cardiac arrest and STEMI who have been revived should ideally be transported by EMS to a center equipped for PPCI.

original: In patients on a DOAC who are undergoing catheter ablation of AF, catheter ablation should be performed with either continuous or minimally interrupted oral anticoagulation.2–10
paraphrased: For patients taking a DOAC and undergoing catheter ablation for AF, the procedure should be conducted with either uninterrupted or minimally interrupted oral anticoagulation.

original: In patients with HCM in whom septal reduc- tion therapy (SRT) is indicated, the procedure should be performed at experienced centers (comprehensive or primary HCM centers) with demonstrated excellence in clinical out- comes for these procedures10–12 (Table 3 and
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who require septal reduction therapy (SRT), the procedure ought to be conducted at specialized centers (comprehensive or primary HCM centers) that have proven success in clinical outcomes for these procedures.

original: In patients with advanced HFrEF and hemody- namic compromise and shock, temporary MCS, including percutaneous and extracorporeal ventricular assist devices, are reasonable as a “bridge to recovery” or “bridge to decision.”25–29
paraphrased: For patients experiencing advanced HFrEF with hemodynamic instability and shock, it is reasonable to use temporary mechanical circulatory support, such as percutaneous and extracorporeal ventricular assist devices, as a "bridge to recovery" or "bridge to decision."

original: In patients with HCM, consultation with or referral to a comprehensive or primary HCM center is reasonable to aid in complex disease-related management decisions13–22 (Table 3).
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is advisable to seek consultation or referral to a specialized or primary HCM center to assist with intricate management decisions related to the disease.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome who have undergone aortic root replacement, surveil- lance imaging of the thoracic aorta by MRI (or CT) is recommended to evaluate for distal TAD, initially annually and then, if normal in diameter and unchanged after 2 years, every other year.3-6
paraphrased: For patients with Marfan syndrome who have had aortic root replacement, it is advised to perform surveillance imaging of the thoracic aorta using MRI or CT to assess for distal TAD. This should be done annually at first, and if the aorta remains normal in size and stable after two years, the imaging can be conducted every two years.

original: Patients who have been resuscitated after cardiac arrest and are noncomatose or who are comatose with favorable prognostic features and with evidence of STEMI, should undergo PPCI to improve survival.3–7
paraphrased: Patients resuscitated from cardiac arrest who are either noncomatose or comatose with positive prognostic indicators and show signs of STEMI should receive PPCI to enhance survival.

original: For preterm newborn infants between 28 and 34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation and in whom DCC cannot be performed, intact cord milking may be reasonable.
paraphrased: For preterm infants born between 28 and 34 weeks of gestation who do not need resuscitation and where delayed cord clamping is not possible, intact cord milking might be a suitable option.

original: For preterm newborn infants <34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, delaying cord clamping (≥30 seconds) can be beneficial when compared to early cord clamping (<30 seconds).
paraphrased: For preterm infants born before 34 weeks of gestation who do not need resuscitation, postponing cord clamping for at least 30 seconds may be advantageous compared to clamping it earlier than 30 seconds.

original: For selected patients with advanced HF despite GDMT, cardiac transplantation is indi- cated to improve survival and QOL.1–3 Value Statement: Intermediate Value (C-LD)
paraphrased: Cardiac transplantation is recommended for certain patients with advanced heart failure who do not respond to guideline-directed medical therapy, as it enhances survival and quality of life. Value Statement: Intermediate Value (C-LD)

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome who have undergone aortic root replacement, surveil- lance imaging every 3 to 5 years for potential AAA is reasonable.2,6
paraphrased: For patients with Marfan syndrome who have had aortic root replacement, it is advisable to perform surveillance imaging every 3 to 5 years to monitor for possible AAA.

original: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, oral anticoagulation should be continued for at least 3 months after the procedure with a longer duration determined by underlying risk.11
paraphrased: For patients who have had catheter ablation for AF, oral anticoagulation should be maintained for a minimum of 3 months post-procedure, with an extended duration based on their underlying risk.

original: In patients with suspected HCM, compre- hensive physical examination and complete medical and 3-generation family history is recommended as part of the initial diagnostic assessment23–28 (Table 5 and Table 6). Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For individuals suspected of having HCM, it is advised to conduct a thorough physical examination along with a detailed medical history and a family history spanning three generations as part of the initial diagnostic evaluation.

original: For preterm newborn infants <28 weeks’ gestation, intact cord milking is not recommended. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: Intact cord milking is not advised for preterm infants born before 28 weeks of gestation.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, treatment with either a beta blocker or an ARB, in maxi- mally tolerated doses (unless contraindicated), is recommended to reduce the rate of aortic dilation.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with Marfan syndrome, it is advised to use a beta blocker or an ARB at the highest tolerable doses (unless contraindicated) to slow the progression of aortic dilation.

original: In patients with cardiac arrest who are comatose, have unfavorable prognostic features, and evi- dence of STEMI, PPCI may be reasonable after individualized assessment.4,7
paraphrased: For comatose patients experiencing cardiac arrest with poor prognostic indicators and signs of STEMI, PPCI could be considered appropriate following a personalized evaluation.

original: In patients hospitalized with HF, severity of con- gestion and adequacy of perfusion should be assessed to guide triage and initial therapy.1–5
paraphrased: For patients admitted with heart failure, evaluate the extent of congestion and the sufficiency of perfusion to inform triage and initial treatment.

original: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, continuation of longer-term oral anticoagulation should be dictated according to the patients’ stroke risk (eg, CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2).11–17
paraphrased: For patients who have received catheter ablation for AF, the decision to maintain long-term oral anticoagulation should be based on their stroke risk, such as a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or higher.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, the use of both a beta blocker and an ARB, in maximally tolerated doses (unless contraindicated), is reasonable to reduce the rate of aortic dila- tion.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with Marfan syndrome, it is advisable to administer both a beta blocker and an ARB at the highest tolerable doses (unless contraindicated) to slow the progression of aortic dilation.

original: In patients with suspected HCM, a transtho- racic echocardiogram (TTE) is recommended in the initial evaluation.29–34
paraphrased: For the initial assessment of patients suspected to have HCM, a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is advised.

original: In patients hospitalized with HF, the common precipitating factors and the overall patient trajectory should be assessed to guide appro- priate therapy.5,6 Goals for Optimization and Continuation of GDMT
paraphrased: For patients admitted with heart failure, evaluate the usual triggers and the patient's overall progression to inform suitable treatment.

original: It can be beneficial to use a T-piece resuscitator instead of a self-inflating bag, with or without a positive end-expiratory pressure valve, for administering positive-pressure ventilation to newborn infants, particularly for preterm infants. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: Using a T-piece resuscitator may be advantageous over a self-inflating bag, whether or not it includes a positive end-expiratory pressure valve, for delivering positive-pressure ventilation to newborns, especially those born preterm.

original: In resuscitated patients who are comatose after cardiac arrest, electrically and hemodynamically stable, and without evidence of STEMI, immediate angiography is not recommended due to lack of benefit.8–14
paraphrased: For comatose patients who have been resuscitated following cardiac arrest, are electrically and hemodynamically stable, and show no signs of STEMI, immediate angiography is not advised as it offers no benefit.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aortic root diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is recommended.1-4
paraphrased: For individuals with Marfan syndrome whose aortic root measures 5.0 cm or larger, it is advised to perform surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta.

original: In patients with bradycardia requiring cardiac- implanted electronic devices who have normal atrioventricular conduction, device selection and pro- gramming strategies to maintain atrioventricular syn- chrony and minimize ventricular pacing should be used to reduce the incidence and progression of AF. 1–6
paraphrased: For patients with bradycardia who need cardiac-implanted electronic devices and have normal atrioventricular conduction, it is recommended to choose and program devices in a way that preserves atrioventricular synchrony and limits ventricular pacing to decrease the occurrence and progression of atrial fibrillation.

original: For patients with HCM who experience a change in clinical status or a new clinical event, repeat TTE is recommended.35,38,43–46
paraphrased: It is advised to perform a repeat TTE for patients with HCM who undergo a change in clinical condition or encounter a new clinical event.

original: In patients with ACS and confirmed hypoxia (oxygen saturation <90%), supplemental oxygen to increase oxygen saturations to ≥90% is recommended to improve myocardial oxygen supply and decrease anginal symptoms.1
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ACS with confirmed hypoxia (oxygen saturation below 90%), it is advised to administer supplemental oxygen to raise oxygen saturation levels to 90% or higher, enhancing myocardial oxygen supply and reducing anginal symptoms.

original: In selected patients with a pacemaker and symptomatic atrial tachyarrhythmias, antitachycar- dia atrial pacing and ventricular pacing minimiza- tion may be useful for reducing symptoms.7–13 (Continued ) Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For certain patients with a pacemaker experiencing symptomatic atrial tachyarrhythmias, utilizing antitachycardia atrial pacing and minimizing ventricular pacing can help alleviate symptoms.

original: It may be reasonable to use a supraglottic airway as the primary interface to administer PPV instead of a face mask for newborn infants delivered at ≥34 0/7 weeks’ gestation. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
paraphrased: Using a supraglottic airway as the main method for delivering positive pressure ventilation, rather than a face mask, might be appropriate for newborns born at or beyond 34 weeks of gestation.

original: For patients with HCM and resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient <50 mm Hg, a TTE with provocative maneuvers is recommended.47–50
paraphrased: For patients with HCM and a resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient of less than 50 mm Hg, it is advised to perform a TTE with provocative maneuvers.

original: For patients admitted with HF, treatment should address reversible factors, establish optimal volume status, and advance GDMT toward targets for outpatient therapy.6
paraphrased: In patients hospitalized with heart failure, care should focus on correcting reversible causes, achieving optimal fluid balance, and progressing guideline-directed medical therapy to outpatient targets.

original: In patients with ACS and oxygen saturations ≥90%, routine administration of supplemental oxygen is not recommended because it does not improve cardiovascular outcomes.2–4
paraphrased: For patients with ACS who have oxygen saturations of 90% or higher, routinely providing supplemental oxygen is not advised, as it does not enhance cardiovascular outcomes.

original: In patients with AF who require significant ventricular pacing, conduction system pacing may be useful to reduce progression of AF.14,15
paraphrased: For patients with AF needing substantial ventricular pacing, conduction system pacing can help mitigate AF progression.

original: In patients with aSAH, use of clinical scales (eg, the Hunt and Hess [HH] grade or World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies [WFNS] grade) is recom- mended to determine initial clinical sever- ity and predict outcome.28,29
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, it is advised to utilize clinical scales, such as the Hunt and Hess (HH) grade or the World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies (WFNS) grade, to assess initial clinical severity and forecast outcomes.

original: In patients with HFrEF requiring hospitalization, preexisting GDMT should be continued and optimized to improve outcomes, unless contra- indicated.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with HFrEF who need hospitalization, existing GDMT should be maintained and enhanced to improve outcomes, unless contraindicated.

original: For symptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is recommended for the detection and quantifi- cation of dynamic LVOTO.49–54
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who exhibit symptoms but lack a resting or inducible outflow tract gradient of ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is advised to detect and measure dynamic LVOTO.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, an aortic root diameter of ≥4.5 cm, and features associ- ated with an increased risk of aortic dissection (see Table 10), surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Mul- tidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,3,4
paraphrased: For patients with Marfan syndrome who have an aortic root diameter of 4.5 cm or greater and exhibit characteristics linked to a heightened risk of aortic dissection (refer to Table 10), it is advisable to consider surgical replacement of the aortic root and ascending aorta, provided it is conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and a maxi- mal cross-sectional aortic root area (cm2) to patient height (m) ratio of ≥10, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.5
paraphrased: For patients with Marfan syndrome, it is advisable to consider surgical replacement of the aortic root and ascending aorta when the ratio of maximal cross-sectional aortic root area (cm²) to patient height (m) is ≥10, provided the procedure is conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

original: In patients with high-grade aSAH, aneu- rysm treatment is reasonable, after careful discussion of likely prognosis with family members, to optimize patient outcome.28,30
paraphrased: For patients with high-grade aSAH, treating the aneurysm is advisable, following thorough discussions with family about the expected prognosis, to enhance the patient's outcome.

original: In patients with ACS, an initial oral loading dose of aspirin, followed by daily low-dose aspirin, is recommended to reduce death and MACE.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with ACS, it is advised to start with an oral loading dose of aspirin, then continue with a daily low-dose aspirin to decrease mortality and MACE.

original: In patients with AF, specialized atrial pacing algorithms designed to suppress AF are not useful for reducing the incidence or slowing the progression of AF.12,16–18
paraphrased: For patients with AF, atrial pacing algorithms specifically developed to prevent AF do not effectively decrease the occurrence or hinder the advancement of AF.

original: In patients experiencing mild decrease of renal function or asymptomatic reduction of blood pressure during HF hospitalization, diuresis and other GDMT should not routinely be discontin- ued.6–11
paraphrased: For patients with a slight decline in kidney function or an asymptomatic drop in blood pressure during heart failure hospitalization, diuretics and other guideline-directed medical therapies should generally be continued.

original: For patients with HCM undergoing surgical septal myectomy, intraoperative transesopha- geal echocardiogram (TEE) is recommended to assess mitral valve anatomy and function and adequacy of septal myectomy.55–58
paraphrased: In patients with HCM who are having surgical septal myectomy, it is advised to use intraoperative transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) to evaluate the mitral valve's structure and function, as well as the sufficiency of the septal myectomy.

original: In patients with ACS, an oral P2Y12 inhibitor should be administered in addition to aspirin to reduce MACE.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with ACS, a P2Y12 inhibitor taken orally should be given alongside aspirin to decrease MACE.

original: In patients with aSAH and advanced age, aneurysm treatment is reasonable, after care- ful discussion of prognosis with family mem- bers, to improve survival and outcome.31–33
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH who are elderly, it is advisable to consider aneurysm treatment, following a thorough discussion of prognosis with family members, to enhance survival and outcomes.

original: For patients with AF who are undergoing cardiac surgery, concomitant surgical ablation can be beneficial to reduce the risk of recurrent AF.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation undergoing heart surgery, performing surgical ablation at the same time may help lower the likelihood of AF recurrence.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aor- tic diameter approaching surgical threshold, who are candidates for valve-sparing root replacement (VSRR) and have a very low surgical risk, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta may be reasonable when performed by experienced surgeons in a Mul- tidisciplinary Aortic Team.2-4
paraphrased: For patients with Marfan syndrome whose aortic diameter is nearing the surgical threshold, and who are suitable for valve-sparing root replacement (VSRR) with minimal surgical risk, it may be appropriate to consider aortic root and ascending aorta replacement by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

original: In patients with HFrEF, GDMT should be initi- ated during hospitalization after clinical stability is achieved.2,3,5,12–18
paraphrased: For patients with HFrEF, GDMT ought to be started during their hospital stay once clinical stability is attained.

original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and a nondissected aneurysm of the aortic arch, descending thoracic aorta, or abdominal aorta of ≥5.0 cm, surgical intervention to replace the aneurysmal segment is ­reasonable.
paraphrased: For patients with Marfan syndrome who have a nondissected aneurysm measuring 5.0 cm or larger in the aortic arch, descending thoracic aorta, or abdominal aorta, it is advisable to surgically replace the affected segment.

original: In patients undergoing surgical ablation, anticoagulation therapy is reasonable for at least
paraphrased: For patients receiving surgical ablation, it is advisable to administer anticoagulation therapy for a minimum of

original: In patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack, prasugrel should not be adminis- tered because of worse net clinical outcomes.*†4 In-Hospital Management in Patients With NSTE-ACS
paraphrased: Prasugrel should not be given to patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack due to poorer overall clinical outcomes.

original: In patients with aSAH who do not improve after correction of modifiable conditions and are deemed unsalvageable because of evi- dence of irreversible neurological injury, treat- ment of the aneurysm is not beneficial.34,35
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH who show no improvement after addressing modifiable factors and are considered beyond recovery due to irreversible neurological damage, treating the aneurysm is not advantageous.

original: For patients with HCM undergoing alcohol septal ablation, TTE or intraoperative TEE with intracoronary ultrasound-enhancing contrast injection of the candidate’s septal perforator(s) is recommended.31,59–63
paraphrased: It is advised that patients with HCM undergoing alcohol septal ablation receive TTE or intraoperative TEE, along with intracoronary ultrasound-enhancing contrast injection into the candidate's septal perforator(s).

original: In patients with HFrEF, if discontinuation of GDMT is necessary during hospitalization, it should be reinitiated and further optimized as soon as possible.19–22
paraphrased: For patients with HFrEF, if GDMT must be stopped during a hospital stay, it should be restarted and further optimized at the earliest opportunity.

original: For patients with HCM who have undergone SRT, TTE within 3 to 6 months after the proce- dure is recommended to evaluate the proce- dural results.17,64–66
paraphrased: It is advised that patients with HCM who have had SRT undergo a TTE 3 to 6 months post-procedure to assess the outcomes.

original: In patients with acute onset of severe headache, prompt diagnostic workup and evaluation are recommended to diagnose/ exclude aSAH and minimize morbidity and mortality.43–46
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a sudden severe headache, immediate diagnostic assessment is advised to confirm or rule out aSAH and reduce the risk of complications and death.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor is recommended to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis.4–6
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, it is advised to use prasugrel or ticagrelor to decrease MACE and stent thrombosis.

original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a baseline TTE is recommended to determine the diameters of the aortic root and ascending aorta, and 6 months thereafter to determine the rate of aortic growth; if the aortic diam- eters are stable, annual surveillance TTE is recommended.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, an initial TTE is advised to assess the aortic root and ascending aorta diameters, followed by another TTE in 6 months to evaluate the aortic growth rate; if the diameters remain stable, a TTE should be conducted annually for monitoring.

original: For patients with symptomatic, persistent AF refractory to antiarrhythmic drug therapy, a hybrid epi- cardial and endocardial ablation might be reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent atrial arrhythmia.5–7 Recommendations for the Role of Pacemakers and ICDs for the Prevention and Treatment of AF (Continued ) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients experiencing symptomatic, persistent atrial fibrillation that does not respond to antiarrhythmic drugs, considering a combined epicardial and endocardial ablation could be a reasonable approach to lower the risk of recurrent atrial arrhythmias.

original: Patients with HF admitted with evidence of significant fluid overload should be promptly treated with intravenous loop diuretics to improve symptoms and reduce morbidity.1
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure who are admitted showing signs of substantial fluid overload, immediate treatment with intravenous loop diuretics is advised to alleviate symptoms and decrease morbidity.

original: Screening: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a TTE is recommended as part of initial family screening and periodic follow-up 31–33,35,36,61 (Figure 1, Table 6).
paraphrased: For initial family screening and regular follow-up in first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, a TTE is advised.

original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome and a dilated or dissected aorta and/or arterial branches at baseline, annual surveillance imaging of the affected aorta and arteries with MRI or CT is recommended.1
paraphrased: For patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome who have an enlarged or dissected aorta and/or arterial branches initially, it is advised to perform yearly imaging of the affected aorta and arteries using MRI or CT.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are managed without planned invasive evaluation, ticagrelor is recommended to reduce MACE.5,7
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS who are treated without a scheduled invasive assessment, ticagrelor is advised to lower MACE.

original: In patients with acute onset of severe head- ache who present >6 hours from symptom onset or who have a new neurological defi- cit, a noncontrast head CT and, if negative for aSAH, lumbar puncture (LP) should be performed to diagnose/exclude aSAH.47,48
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a sudden severe headache who arrive more than 6 hours after symptoms begin or exhibit a new neurological deficit, a noncontrast head CT should be conducted, followed by a lumbar puncture if the CT is negative, to diagnose or rule out aSAH.

original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a baseline MRI or CT from head to pelvis is recommended to evaluate the entire aorta and its branches for aneurysm, dissection, and tortuosity.1-4
paraphrased: For individuals with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, it is advised to perform an initial MRI or CT scan from head to pelvis to assess the entire aorta and its branches for aneurysms, dissections, and tortuosity.

original: For patients hospitalized with HF, therapy with diuretics and other guideline-directed medica- tions should be titrated with a goal to resolve clinical evidence of congestion to reduce symp- toms and rehospitalizations.1–6
paraphrased: In patients admitted with heart failure, adjust diuretics and other guideline-recommended treatments to eliminate signs of congestion, aiming to alleviate symptoms and decrease the likelihood of rehospitalization.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS, clopidogrel is recommended to reduce MACE when prasugrel or ticagrelor are unavailable, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.1
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS, clopidogrel is advised to lower MACE if prasugrel or ticagrelor are not available, not tolerated, or contraindicated.

original: In patients who present with a new diagnosis of HFrEF and AF, arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy should be suspected, and an early and aggressive approach to AF rhythm control is recommended.1,2
paraphrased: For patients newly diagnosed with HFrEF and AF, consider arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy and promptly pursue an assertive strategy for AF rhythm management.

original: Screening: In individuals who are genotype- positive or phenotype-negative, serial echocar- diography is recommended at periodic intervals depending on age (1 to 2 years in children and adolescents, 3 to 5 years in adults) and change in clinical status (Table 6; Figure 1).28,67,69–71
paraphrased: For those who have a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression, it is advised to perform serial echocardiography at regular intervals based on age—every 1 to 2 years for children and adolescents, and every 3 to 5 years for adults—or if there is a change in clinical status (refer to Table 6; Figure 1).

original: In patients with acute onset of severe head- ache who present <6 hours from symptom onset and without new neurological deficit, a noncontrast head CT performed on a high-quality scanner and interpreted by a board-certified neuroradiologist is reason- able to diagnose/exclude aSAH.49–53
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a sudden severe headache within 6 hours of symptom onset and without any new neurological deficits, it is appropriate to use a noncontrast head CT on a high-quality scanner, interpreted by a board-certified neuroradiologist, to diagnose or rule out aSAH.

original: For patients requiring diuretic treatment during hospitalization for HF, the discharge regimen should include a plan for adjustment of diuret- ics to decrease rehospitalizations.7
paraphrased: For patients needing diuretics while hospitalized for heart failure, the discharge plan should incorporate a strategy for adjusting diuretics to reduce the risk of rehospitalization.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS planned for an inva- sive strategy with timing of angiography antici- pated to be >24 hours, upstream treatment with clopidogrel or ticagrelor may be considered to reduce MACE.1,5,8 In-Hospital Management in Patients With STEMI
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS scheduled for an invasive strategy where angiography is expected to occur after 24 hours, initiating treatment with clopidogrel or ticagrelor beforehand may be considered to decrease MACE.

original: In appropriate patients with AF and HFrEF who are on GDMT, and with reasonable expectation of proce- dural benefit (Figure 24), catheter ablation is benefi- cial to improve symptoms, QOL, ventricular function, and cardiovascular outcomes.3–13
paraphrased: For suitable patients with AF and HFrEF receiving GDMT, and where procedural benefits are reasonably anticipated (Figure 24), catheter ablation is advantageous for enhancing symptoms, quality of life, ventricular function, and cardiovascular outcomes.

original: In patients with acute onset of severe headache without a new neurological deficit, application of the Ottawa SAH Rule may be reasonable to identify those at high risk for aSAH.45,54,55 Evaluation for cause of aSAH
paraphrased: For patients experiencing a sudden severe headache without any new neurological symptoms, it may be appropriate to use the Ottawa SAH Rule to determine those at high risk for aSAH.

original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome with- out dilation of the aorta distal to the aortic root or ascending aorta and without dilated or dissected arterial branches, surveillance imaging from chest to pelvis with MRI (or CT) every 2 years is reasonable, but imaging may be more frequent depending on family ­history.
paraphrased: For patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome who do not have dilation of the aorta beyond the aortic root or ascending aorta, and without dilated or dissected arterial branches, it is advisable to conduct surveillance imaging from the chest to the pelvis using MRI (or CT) every two years, although more frequent imaging may be warranted based on family history.

original: In appropriate patients with symptomatic AF and HFpEF with reasonable expectation of benefit, catheter ablation can be useful to improve symptoms and improve QOL.14,15
paraphrased: For suitable patients experiencing symptomatic AF and HFpEF, where a beneficial outcome is reasonably anticipated, catheter ablation may be beneficial for alleviating symptoms and enhancing quality of life.

original: For patients with HCM, TEE can be useful if TTE is inconclusive in clinical decision-making regarding medical therapy, and in situations such as planning for myectomy, exclusion of subaortic membrane or mitral regurgitation secondary to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve apparatus, or in the assessment of the feasibility of alcohol septal ablation.55–58
paraphrased: For individuals with HCM, TEE may be beneficial when TTE does not provide sufficient information for clinical decisions about medical treatment, and in cases like myectomy planning, ruling out subaortic membrane or mitral regurgitation due to structural issues with the mitral valve apparatus, or evaluating the suitability of alcohol septal ablation.

original: In patients with AF and HF, digoxin is reasonable for rate control, in combination with other rate-controlling agents or as monotherapy if other agents are not tolerated.16,17
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation and heart failure, using digoxin for rate control is appropriate, either alongside other rate-controlling medications or alone if other medications are not well-tolerated.

original: In patients hospitalized with HF when diuresis is inadequate to relieve symptoms and signs of congestion, it is reasonable to intensify the diuretic regimen using either: a. higher doses of intravenous loop diuretics.1,3); or b. addition of a second diuretic.3
paraphrased: For patients admitted with heart failure where diuresis fails to alleviate congestion symptoms and signs, it is appropriate to enhance the diuretic treatment by either: a. increasing the dosage of intravenous loop diuretics; or b. adding a second diuretic.

original: In patients with STEMI managed with PPCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor should be administered to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis.4,5,9,10
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI undergoing PPCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor should be given to decrease MACE and stent thrombosis.

original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome with- out dilation of the cerebral arteries on initial screening, periodic imaging surveillance for cerebral aneurysms with MRI or CT every 2 to
paraphrased: For patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome who do not show cerebral artery dilation on initial screening, regular imaging checks for cerebral aneurysms using MRI or CT should be conducted every 2 to

original: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnoses of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhanc- ing agent is reasonable particularly if other imaging modalities such as cardiovascular mag- netic resonance (CMR) are not readily available or contraindicated.72,73
paraphrased: For patients with HCM where the diagnosis of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or unusual hypertrophy patterns is uncertain on TTE, it is reasonable to use an intravenous ultrasound-enhancing agent, especially if other imaging methods like cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) are unavailable or contraindicated.

original: In patients with spontaneous SAH with high level of concern for aneurysmal source and a negative or inconclusive CT angiography (CTA), digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is indicated to diag- nose/exclude cerebral aneurysm(s).56–59
paraphrased: For patients with spontaneous SAH who are highly suspected of having an aneurysmal origin and have a negative or inconclusive CT angiography (CTA), digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is recommended to confirm or rule out cerebral aneurysms.

original: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exer- cise TTE is reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.43,48,49,51–54
paraphrased: For asymptomatic HCM patients without a resting or inducible outflow tract gradient of ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, it is reasonable to use exercise TTE to detect and measure dynamic LVOTO.

original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, treat- ment with a beta blocker or an ARB (unless contraindicated), or both, in maximally toler- ated doses, is reasonable.
paraphrased: For patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, it is advisable to administer a beta blocker or an ARB, or both, at the highest tolerable doses, unless contraindicated.

original: In patients who are admitted with decompen- sated HF, in the absence of systemic hypoten- sion, intravenous nitroglycerin or nitroprusside may be considered as an adjuvant to diuretic therapy for relief of dyspnea.1,2
paraphrased: For patients admitted with decompensated heart failure, and without systemic hypotension, intravenous nitroglycerin or nitroprusside can be used alongside diuretics to alleviate dyspnea.

original: In patients with AF and HF with rapid ventricular rates in whom beta blockers or calcium channel blockers are contraindicated or ineffective, intravenous amiodarone is reasonable for acute rate control.†18,19
paraphrased: For patients with AF and HF experiencing rapid ventricular rates, where beta blockers or calcium channel blockers are either unsuitable or ineffective, intravenous amiodarone is a reasonable option for acute rate control.

original: In patients with STEMI managed with PPCI, clopidogrel is recommended to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis when prasugrel or ticagrelor are unavailable, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.11
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI undergoing PPCI, clopidogrel is advised to decrease MACE and stent thrombosis if prasugrel or ticagrelor are not available, not tolerated, or contraindicated.

original: For patients suspected to have HCM in whom echocardiography is inconclusive, CMR imaging is indicated for diagnostic clarification.74–80
paraphrased: If echocardiography results are inconclusive in patients suspected of having HCM, CMR imaging is recommended for further diagnostic clarification.

original: In patients hospitalized with HF, prophylaxis for VTE is recommended to prevent venous throm- boembolic disease.1–3
paraphrased: For patients admitted with heart failure, it is advised to implement VTE prophylaxis to avert venous thromboembolic disease.

original: In patients with SAH from confirmed cerebral aneurysm(s), DSA can be useful to determine the optimal strategy for aneurysm intervention.60,61 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with SAH due to verified cerebral aneurysms, DSA may aid in identifying the best approach for aneurysm treatment.

original: In patients with STEMI managed with fibrinolytic therapy, clopidogrel should be administered concurrently to reduce death and MACE.2,3 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization”12 and the †”2023 AHA/ACC/ACCP/ASPC/NLA/PCNA Guideline for the Manage- ment of Patients With Chronic Coronary Disease.”13
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI who are treated with fibrinolytic therapy, clopidogrel should be given simultaneously to decrease mortality and major adverse cardiovascular events.

original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome and aortic dilation, the surgical threshold for prophylactic aortic root and ascending aortic replacement should be informed by the spe- cific genetic variant, aortic diameter, aortic growth rate, extra-aortic features, family his- tory, patient age and sex, and physician and patient preferences (Table 11).1-9
paraphrased: For patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome experiencing aortic dilation, the decision to proceed with prophylactic replacement of the aortic root and ascending aorta should be guided by the particular genetic variant, aortic size, rate of aortic enlargement, additional non-aortic characteristics, family history, age and sex of the patient, as well as the preferences of both the physician and patient (Table 11).1-9

original: In patients with cardiogenic shock, intravenous inotropic support should be used to maintain systemic perfusion and preserve end-organ performance.1–8
paraphrased: For patients experiencing cardiogenic shock, intravenous inotropic therapy is recommended to sustain systemic perfusion and protect end-organ function.

original: In patients with AF, HFrEF (LVEF <50%), and refractory rapid ventricular response who are not candidates for or in whom rhythm control has failed, AVNA and biventricular pacing therapy can be useful to improve symptoms, QOL, and EF.20–23
paraphrased: For patients with AF, HFrEF (LVEF <50%), and persistent rapid ventricular response who are unsuitable for rhythm control or have not benefited from it, AVNA combined with biventricular pacing therapy may be beneficial for enhancing symptoms, quality of life, and ejection fraction.

original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome attrib- utable to a pathogenic variant in TGFBR1, TGFBR2, or SMAD3, surgery to replace the intact aortic arch, descending aorta, or abdominal aorta at a diameter of ≥4.5 cm may be considered, with the specific genetic variant, patient age, aortic growth rate, family history, presence of high-risk features (Table 11), and surgical risk informing the decision.
paraphrased: For individuals with Loeys-Dietz syndrome due to a pathogenic variant in TGFBR1, TGFBR2, or SMAD3, surgical replacement of the intact aortic arch, descending aorta, or abdominal aorta may be considered when the diameter reaches 4.5 cm or more, taking into account the specific genetic variant, patient age, rate of aortic enlargement, family history, high-risk features (Table 11), and surgical risk.

original: Among patients with ACS undergoing PCI who have not received a P2Y12 inhibitor, intravenous cangrelor may be reasonable to reduce periprocedural ischemic events.*1–4 *Reproduced from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”5
paraphrased: For patients with ACS undergoing PCI who have not been administered a P2Y12 inhibitor, using intravenous cangrelor could be a reasonable option to decrease ischemic events during the procedure.

original: For patients with aSAH, timely transfer from hospitals with low case volume to higher-volume centers with multidisci- plinary neurointensive care services, com- prehensive stroke center capabilities, and experienced cerebrovascular surgeons/ neuroendovascular interventionalists is recommended to improve outcomes.67–77
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, it is advised to promptly transfer them from low-volume hospitals to high-volume centers that offer multidisciplinary neurointensive care, comprehensive stroke center facilities, and have skilled cerebrovascular surgeons or neuroendovascular specialists to enhance outcomes.

original: For patients with left ventricular hypertrophy in whom there is a suspicion of alternative diagnoses including infiltrative or storage disease as well as athlete’s heart, CMR imag- ing is useful74–80 (Figure 1).
paraphrased: CMR imaging is beneficial for patients with left ventricular hypertrophy when alternative diagnoses such as infiltrative or storage diseases and athlete's heart are suspected.

original: In patients with cardiogenic shock, temporary MCS is reasonable when end-organ function cannot be maintained by pharmacologic means to support cardiac function.9–17
paraphrased: For patients experiencing cardiogenic shock, it is appropriate to consider temporary mechanical circulatory support when medications alone are insufficient to sustain end-organ function.

original: In patients with Turner syndrome, TTE and cardiac MRI are recommended at the time of diagnosis to evaluate for BAV, aortic root and ascending aortic dilation, aortic coarctation, and other congenital heart defects.1-9
paraphrased: For individuals diagnosed with Turner syndrome, it is advised to perform TTE and cardiac MRI to assess for BAV, dilation of the aortic root and ascending aorta, aortic coarctation, and other congenital heart anomalies.

original: In patients with aSAH and unsecured aneurysm, frequent blood pressure (BP) monitoring and BP control with short- acting medication(s) is recommended to avoid severe hypotension, hypertension, and BP variability.
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH and an unsecured aneurysm, it is advised to regularly monitor blood pressure and manage it using short-acting medications to prevent severe hypotension, hypertension, and fluctuations in blood pressure.

original: For patients with aSAH, care should be provided in a dedicated neurocritical care unit by a multidisciplinary team.78–80 Table 3.  Ottawa SAH Rule For alert patients >15 y of age with new severe nontraumatic headache reaching maximum intensity within 1 h. Patients require additional investigation for SAH if they meet any of the following criteria:
paraphrased: Patients with aSAH should receive treatment in a specialized neurocritical care unit managed by a multidisciplinary team. For alert patients over 15 years old experiencing a new, severe, nontraumatic headache that peaks within an hour, further evaluation for SAH is necessary if any of the following criteria are met.

original: In patients with AF, HF, and implanted biventricular pacing therapy in whom an effective pacing percentage cannot be achieved with pharmacological therapy, AVNA can be beneficial to improve functional class,24,25 reduce the risk of ICD shock,26 and improve survival.24,25
paraphrased: For patients with AF, HF, and biventricular pacing devices who cannot attain an effective pacing percentage through medication, AVNA may help enhance functional class, decrease the likelihood of ICD shocks, and increase survival rates.

original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI with large thrombus burden, no-reflow, or slow flow, adjunctive use of an intravenous or intracoronary glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor is reasonable to improve procedural success and reduce infarct size.*,1,2
paraphrased: For patients with ACS undergoing PCI who have a significant thrombus burden, experience no-reflow, or have slow flow, it is advisable to use an intravenous or intracoronary glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor as an adjunct to enhance procedural success and minimize infarct size.

original: For patients with obstructive HCM in whom the anatomic mechanism of obstruction is inconclusive on echocardiography, CMR imag- ing is indicated to inform the selection and planning of SRT.88–92
paraphrased: For patients with obstructive HCM where echocardiography does not clearly define the anatomical cause of obstruction, CMR imaging is recommended to guide the choice and planning of SRT.

original: For patients with HCM who are not oth- erwise identified as high risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD), or in whom a decision to proceed with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal/family history, echocar- diography, and ambulatory electrocar- diographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for maximum left ven- tricular (LV) wall thickness, ejection frac- tion (EF), LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with late gadolinium enhancement.38,74–87
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who are not clearly at high risk for sudden cardiac death (SCD), or when the decision to implant an ICD is still uncertain after evaluating personal/family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory ECG monitoring, CMR imaging is useful to evaluate maximum left ventricular (LV) wall thickness, ejection fraction (EF), LV apical aneurysm, and the degree of myocardial fibrosis using late gadolinium enhancement.

original: In patients with cardiogenic shock, manage- ment by a multidisciplinary team experienced in shock is reasonable.17–22
paraphrased: For patients experiencing cardiogenic shock, it is advisable to have their care coordinated by a multidisciplinary team with expertise in shock management.

original: In patients with AF-induced cardiomyopathy who have recovered LV function, long-term surveillance can be beneficial to detect recurrent AF in view of the high risk of recurrence of arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy.27,28
paraphrased: For patients with cardiomyopathy caused by atrial fibrillation who have regained left ventricular function, ongoing monitoring can be advantageous to identify recurrent atrial fibrillation due to the high likelihood of arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy returning.

original: In patients with Turner syndrome who are ≥15 years old, the use of the ASI (ratio of aortic diameter [cm] to BSA [m2]) is recommended to define the degree of aortic dilation and assess the risk of aortic ­dissection.9,10,11
paraphrased: For patients aged 15 years or older with Turner syndrome, it is advised to use the ASI, which is the ratio of aortic diameter in centimeters to body surface area in square meters, to determine the extent of aortic dilation and evaluate the risk of aortic dissection.

original: In patients with ACS, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors should not be administered routinely due to lack of ischemic benefit and increased risk of bleeding.3–5 *Adapted from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”6
paraphrased: For patients with ACS, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors should not be used regularly, as they do not provide ischemic benefits and raise the risk of bleeding.

original: In patients presenting with cardiogenic shock, placement of a PA line may be considered to define hemodynamic subsets and appropriate management strategies.23–27
paraphrased: For patients with cardiogenic shock, considering the insertion of a PA line can help identify hemodynamic categories and guide suitable management approaches.

original: In patients with aSAH who are receiving anticoagulants, emergency anticoagula- tion reversal with appropriate reversal agents should be performed to prevent rebleeding.
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH on anticoagulants, urgent reversal of anticoagulation using suitable agents is necessary to avert rebleeding.

original: In patients with suspected AF-induced cardiomyopathy or refractory HF symptoms undergoing pharmacological rate-control therapy for AF, a stricter rate-control strategy (target heart rate <80 bpm at rest and <110 bpm during moderate exercise) may be reasonable.29–31
paraphrased: For patients with suspected AF-induced cardiomyopathy or persistent heart failure symptoms receiving medication for AF rate control, aiming for a stricter heart rate target of less than 80 bpm at rest and under 110 bpm during moderate activity may be appropriate.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS, intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) is useful to reduce ischemic events.†1–4
paraphrased: Intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) is beneficial in lowering ischemic events in patients with NSTE-ACS.

original: For patients with HCM, repeat contrast- enhanced CMR imaging on a periodic basis (every 3 to 5 years) for the purpose of SCD risk stratification may be considered to evaluate changes in late gadolinium enhancement and other morphologic changes, including EF, development of api- cal aneurysm, or LV wall thickness (Figure 1,
paraphrased: For individuals with HCM, it may be advisable to periodically perform contrast-enhanced CMR imaging every 3 to 5 years to assess SCD risk by evaluating alterations in late gadolinium enhancement and other morphological changes, such as EF, apical aneurysm formation, or LV wall thickness.

original: In patients with aSAH, routine use of anti- fibrinolytic therapy is not useful to improve functional outcome.85–87
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, regular administration of antifibrinolytic therapy does not enhance functional outcomes.

original: For patients who are not rapidly responding to initial shock measures, triage to centers that can provide temporary MCS may be consid- ered to optimize management.17–22
paraphrased: Patients who do not quickly respond to initial shock interventions may be referred to facilities capable of offering temporary mechanical circulatory support to enhance treatment.

original: In patients with AF and HFrEF who undergo AVNA, conduction system pacing of the His bundle or left bundle branch area may be reasonable as an alterna- tive to biventricular pacing to improve symptoms, QOL, and LV function.32–35
paraphrased: For patients with AF and HFrEF undergoing AVNA, pacing the His bundle or left bundle branch conduction system could be a viable alternative to biventricular pacing to enhance symptoms, quality of life, and left ventricular function.

original: In patients with Turner syndrome without risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 12), sur- veillance imaging with TTE or MRI to evalu- ate the aorta is recommended every 5 years in children and every 10 years in adults, as well as before planning a ­pregnancy.9,10,11
paraphrased: For patients with Turner syndrome who do not have risk factors for aortic dissection (refer to Table 12), it is advised to perform surveillance imaging of the aorta using TTE or MRI every 5 years in children and every 10 years in adults, in addition to prior to planning a pregnancy.

original: In adult patients with suspected HCM, cardiac CT may be considered for diagnosis if the echocardiogram is not diagnostic and CMR imaging is unavailable.34,93,94 Recommendations for Echocardiography (Continued) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For adult patients with suspected HCM, consider using cardiac CT for diagnosis if the echocardiogram results are inconclusive and CMR imaging cannot be accessed.

original: In patients with Turner syndrome and an ASI >2.3 cm/m2, surveillance imaging of the aorta is recommended at least ­annually.9 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For individuals with Turner syndrome and an ASI greater than 2.3 cm/m², it is advised to conduct aortic surveillance imaging at least once a year.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS in whom an early invasive approach is not anticipated, either enoxaparin or fondaparinux are recommended alternatives to UFH to reduce ischemic events.5–11 Anticoagulant Therapy in Patients Undergoing Coronary Revascularization
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS who are not expected to undergo an early invasive strategy, enoxaparin or fondaparinux are suggested as alternatives to UFH to decrease ischemic events.

original: For patients with aSAH, surgical or endovascular treatment of the ruptured aneurysm should be performed as early as feasible after presentation, preferably within 24 hours of onset, to improve outcome.40,98–104 Treatment goal
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, it is advised to conduct surgical or endovascular intervention on the ruptured aneurysm as soon as possible after presentation, ideally within 24 hours of onset, to enhance outcomes.

original: In patients with Turner syndrome and risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 12), surveil- lance aortic imaging at an interval depending on the aortic diameter, ASI, and aortic growth rate is recommended (­Figure 18).9
paraphrased: For patients with Turner syndrome who have risk factors for aortic dissection (refer to Table 12), it is advised to conduct surveillance aortic imaging at intervals based on the aortic diameter, ASI, and the rate of aortic growth (see Figure 18).

original: In patients with high-risk HF, particularly those with recurrent hospitalizations for HFrEF, refer- ral to multidisciplinary HF disease management programs is recommended to reduce the risk of hospitalization.1–4
paraphrased: For patients at high risk of heart failure, especially those frequently hospitalized for HFrEF, it is advised to refer them to multidisciplinary heart failure management programs to lower hospitalization risk.

original: In patients with an onset of unexplained AF before 30 years of age, electrophysiological study to evaluate and treat reentrant supraventricular tachyarrhythmias with a targeted ablation may be reasonable because of the high prevalence of reen- trant arrhythmias in this group.1–3
paraphrased: For patients experiencing unexplained atrial fibrillation before the age of 30, it may be appropriate to conduct an electrophysiological study to assess and address reentrant supraventricular tachyarrhythmias through targeted ablation, given the high incidence of reentrant arrhythmias in this population.

original: For patients with aSAH, complete oblit- eration of the ruptured aneurysm is indi- cated whenever feasible to reduce the risk of rebleeding and retreatment.105–107
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, achieving full obliteration of the ruptured aneurysm is recommended whenever possible to minimize the risk of rebleeding and the need for further treatment.

original: In patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is recommended in the initial evalu- ation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years)95–97 (Figure 1,
paraphrased: For individuals with HCM, it is advised to perform a 12-lead ECG during the initial assessment and regularly thereafter, every 1 to 2 years.

original: In patients with ACS undergoing coronary revascularization (CABG or PCI) in the same admission, parenteral anticoagulation should be continued until revascularization to reduce ischemic events.12,13 Anticoagulant Therapy to Support PCI in ACS (STEMI and NSTE-ACS)
paraphrased: For patients with ACS who are receiving coronary revascularization (either CABG or PCI) during the same hospital stay, parenteral anticoagulation should be maintained until the revascularization procedure is completed to minimize ischemic events.

original: In patents with an onset of AF before 45 years of age without obvious risk factors for AF, referral for genetic counseling, genetic testing for rare patho- genic variants, and surveillance for cardiomyopathy or arrhythmia syndromes may be reasonable.4,5
paraphrased: For patients who develop AF before the age of 45 without clear risk factors, it may be appropriate to consider genetic counseling, testing for rare pathogenic variants, and monitoring for cardiomyopathy or arrhythmia syndromes.
