original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, intravenous UFH is useful to reduce ischemic events.†
paraphrased: Intravenous UFH is beneficial for reducing ischemic events in patients with ACS who are undergoing PCI.

original: In patients hospitalized with worsening HF, patient-centered discharge instructions with a clear plan for transitional care should be pro- vided before hospital discharge.5,6
paraphrased: For patients admitted with deteriorating heart failure, it is essential to deliver personalized discharge instructions and a well-defined transitional care plan prior to their release from the hospital.

original: In patients with Turnery syndrome who are ≥15 years old and have an ASI of ≥2.5 cm/m2 plus risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 12), surgical intervention to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is reasonable.9,10
paraphrased: For patients aged 15 years or older with Turner syndrome and an ASI of 2.5 cm/m2 or greater, along with risk factors for aortic dissection (refer to Table 12), it is advisable to consider surgical replacement of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both.

original: In patients with HCM, 24- to 48-hour ambu- latory electrocardiographic monitoring is recommended in the initial evaluation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years) to identify patients who are at risk for SCD and guide management of arrhythmias (Figure 1).98–100
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is advised to conduct 24- to 48-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring during the initial assessment and periodically every 1 to 2 years to detect those at risk for SCD and to manage arrhythmias effectively.

original: For patients with aSAH in whom com- plete obliteration of the ruptured aneu- rysm by either clipping or primary coiling treatment is not feasible in the acute phase, partial obliteration to secure the rupture site and retreatment in a delayed fashion in those with functional recovery are reasonable to prevent rebleeding. Modality of treatment: general
paraphrased: In patients with aSAH where full obliteration of the ruptured aneurysm via clipping or primary coiling is not possible during the acute phase, partial obliteration to stabilize the rupture site followed by delayed retreatment in those who achieve functional recovery is a reasonable approach to prevent rebleeding. Treatment modality: general.

original: In patients hospitalized with worsening HF, participation in systems that allow benchmark- ing to performance measures is reasonable to increase use of evidence-based therapy, and to improve quality of care.7–10
paraphrased: For patients admitted with deteriorating heart failure, engaging in systems that enable performance measure benchmarking is advisable to enhance the application of evidence-based treatments and elevate care quality.

original: In athletes who develop AF, catheter ablation with PVI is a reasonable strategy for rhythm control because of its effectiveness and low risk of detrimental effect on exercise capacity.1,2
paraphrased: For athletes experiencing AF, employing catheter ablation with PVI is a sensible approach for rhythm management due to its efficacy and minimal impact on exercise capacity.

original: For patients with aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the posterior circulation that are amenable to coiling, coiling is indicated in preference to clipping to improve outcome.108–110
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH due to ruptured aneurysms in the posterior circulation that can be treated with coiling, coiling is recommended over clipping to enhance outcomes.

original: In patients with STEMI undergoing PCI, bivalirudin is useful as an alternative to UFH to reduce mortality and bleeding.†14–19
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI receiving PCI, bivalirudin serves as an effective substitute for UFH to lower mortality and bleeding.

original: In patients with a BAV, TTE is indicated to evaluate valve morphology and function, to evaluate the diameter of the aortic root and ascending aorta, and to evaluate for aortic coarctation and other associated cardiovascu- lar defects.1-4
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV, TTE is recommended to assess valve structure and performance, measure the aortic root and ascending aorta diameters, and check for aortic coarctation and other related cardiovascular anomalies.

original: In patients with AF and class III obesity (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2), DOACs are reasonable to choose over warfarin for stroke risk reduction.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation and class III obesity (BMI of 40 kg/m2 or higher), selecting DOACs instead of warfarin for reducing stroke risk is a reasonable option.

original: In patients with a BAV, CT or MRI of the tho- racic aorta is indicated when the diameter and morphology of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both cannot be assessed accurately or completely by TTE.1
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV, a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is recommended if the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both cannot be fully or accurately evaluated using TTE.

original: In patients with HCM who develop palpita- tions or lightheadedness, extended (>24 hours) electrocardiographic monitoring or event recording is recommended, which should not be considered diagnostic unless patients have had symptoms while being monitored.101
paraphrased: For patients with HCM experiencing palpitations or lightheadedness, it is advised to conduct extended electrocardiographic monitoring or event recording for more than 24 hours; however, this should only be deemed diagnostic if symptoms occur during the monitoring period.

original: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is recommended as a component of the screening algorithm95–97 (Figure 1, Table 6).
paraphrased: For screening first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, it is advised to include a 12-lead ECG as part of the evaluation process.

original: In patients being discharged after hospital- ization for worsening HF, an early follow-up, generally within 7 days of hospital discharge, is reasonable to optimize care and reduce rehos- pitalization.11,12
paraphrased: For patients discharged following hospitalization due to worsening heart failure, scheduling a follow-up appointment within 7 days is advisable to enhance care and minimize the risk of readmission.

original: In patients with AF who have undergone bariatric surgery, warfarin may be reasonable to choose over DOACs for stroke risk reduction in view of concerns about DOAC drug absorption.6,7 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation who have had bariatric surgery, opting for warfarin instead of direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) might be advisable for reducing stroke risk due to potential issues with DOAC absorption.

original: In patients with a BAV and either HTAD or phenotypic features concerning for Loeys- Dietz syndrome, a medical genetics evaluation is recommended.5,6
paraphrased: For patients with a bicuspid aortic valve and either hereditary thoracic aortic disease or characteristics suggestive of Loeys-Dietz syndrome, an evaluation by a medical geneticist is advised.

original: In patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, bivalirudin may be reasonable as an alternative to UFH to reduce bleeding.†16,20–23
paraphrased: For patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, using bivalirudin instead of UFH might be a suitable option to minimize bleeding.

original: In patients with HFrEF and iron deficiency with or without anemia, intravenous iron replace- ment is reasonable to improve functional status and QOL.1–4
paraphrased: For patients with HFrEF and iron deficiency, whether or not they have anemia, administering intravenous iron is advisable to enhance functional status and quality of life.

original: For patients with aSAH deemed salvageable and with depressed level of consciousness due to large intrapa- renchymal hematoma, emergency clot evacuation should be performed to reduce mortality.111,112
paraphrased: In patients with aSAH who are considered salvageable and have a decreased level of consciousness from a large intraparenchymal hematoma, urgent clot removal should be conducted to lower mortality.

original: In patients with HCM who have additional risk factors for atrial fibrillation (AF), such as left atrial dilatation, advanced age, and New York Heart Association (NYHA) class III to class IV heart failure (HF), and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambu- latory monitoring is reasonable to screen for AF as part of initial evaluation and peri- odic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years)102–106 (Figure 1).
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who possess additional atrial fibrillation (AF) risk factors like left atrial enlargement, older age, and NYHA class III or IV heart failure (HF), and who qualify for anticoagulation, it is advisable to conduct extended ambulatory monitoring to detect AF during the initial assessment and at regular intervals (every 1 to 2 years).

original: Patients with AF with rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF), and hemodynamic instability should be treated with electrical cardioversion.1,2
paraphrased: For patients experiencing AF with rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF) and hemodynamic instability, electrical cardioversion is recommended.

original: In patients with ACS, intravenous enoxaparin may be considered as an alternative to UFH at the time of PCI to reduce ischemic events.‡7,8,24–26
paraphrased: For patients with ACS, intravenous enoxaparin can be an option instead of UFH during PCI to decrease ischemic events.

original: For patients with aSAH, the ruptured aneu- rysm should be evaluated by specialist(s) with endovascular and surgical expertise to determine the relative risks and benefits of surgical or endovascular treatment accord- ing to patient and aneurysm characteristics.
paraphrased: Patients with aSAH should have their ruptured aneurysm assessed by specialists skilled in both endovascular and surgical techniques to weigh the risks and benefits of each treatment option based on the characteristics of the patient and the aneurysm.

original: In patients with HF and anemia, erythropoietin- stimulating agents should not be used to improve morbidity and mortality.5,6 Management of Hypertension
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure and anemia, erythropoietin-stimulating agents should not be utilized to enhance morbidity and mortality outcomes.

original: In patients with ACS, fondaparinux should not be used to support PCI because of the risk of catheter thrombosis.5,27 STEMI: Anticoagulant Therapy Treated With Fibrinolytic Therapy
paraphrased: For patients with ACS, fondaparinux is not recommended for PCI support due to the potential for catheter thrombosis.

original: In adult patients with HCM without risk factors for AF and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring may be considered to assess for asymptomatic paroxysmal AF as part of initial evaluation and periodic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years).102–106
paraphrased: For adult patients with HCM who lack AF risk factors and qualify for anticoagulation, it may be advisable to use extended ambulatory monitoring to detect asymptomatic paroxysmal AF during the initial assessment and at regular intervals (every 1 to 2 years).

original: In patients with HFrEF and hypertension, uptitration of GDMT to the maximally tolerated target dose is recommended.7,8 Management of Sleep Disorders
paraphrased: For patients with HFrEF and high blood pressure, it is advised to increase GDMT to the highest dose that is well-tolerated.

original: For patients with AF with rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF), catheter ablation of accessory pathways (APs) is recommended.3–7
paraphrased: Catheter ablation of accessory pathways is advised for patients with atrial fibrillation exhibiting rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF).

original: For patients >70 years of age with aSAH, the superiority of coiling or clipping to improve outcome is not well established.113,114
paraphrased: For patients older than 70 with aSAH, it is unclear whether coiling or clipping offers better outcomes.

original: In patients with a BAV and a dilated aortic root or ascending aorta, screening of all first- degree relatives by TTE is recommended to evaluate for the presence of a BAV, dilation of the aortic root and ascending aorta, or both; if the diameter and morphology of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both cannot be assessed accurately or completely by TTE, a cardiac-gated CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is indicated.7
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV and an enlarged aortic root or ascending aorta, it is advised to screen all first-degree relatives using TTE to check for a BAV, aortic root dilation, ascending aorta dilation, or both; if TTE does not provide a precise or complete assessment of the aortic root or ascending aorta's diameter and morphology, a cardiac-gated CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta should be performed.

original: For patients with HCM who are candidates for SRT and for whom there is uncertainty regarding the presence or severity of LVOTO on nonin- vasive imaging studies, invasive hemodynamic assessment with cardiac catheterization is recommended.45,107–109
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who are eligible for SRT and where noninvasive imaging does not clearly determine the presence or severity of LVOTO, it is advised to perform invasive hemodynamic evaluation using cardiac catheterization.

original: In patients with a BAV, screening of all first- degree relatives by TTE is reasonable to evaluate for the presence of a BAV, dilation of the aortic root and ascending aorta, or both.7-10
paraphrased: For individuals with a BAV, it is advisable to screen all first-degree relatives using TTE to assess for a BAV, aortic root dilation, ascending aorta dilation, or both.

original: In patients with AF with rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF) and hemodynamic stability, pharmacological cardioversion with intravenous ibutilide or intravenous procainamide is recommended as an alternative to elective cardioversion.1,8,9
paraphrased: For patients with AF exhibiting rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF) who are hemodynamically stable, intravenous ibutilide or procainamide is advised for pharmacological cardioversion as an alternative to elective cardioversion.

original: In patients with HF and suspicion of sleep-dis- ordered breathing, a formal sleep assessment is reasonable to confirm the diagnosis and differentiate between obstructive and central sleep apnea.9,10
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure and suspected sleep-disordered breathing, conducting a formal sleep evaluation is advisable to verify the diagnosis and distinguish between obstructive and central sleep apnea.

original: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy, parenteral anticoagulation should be continued for the duration of the hospital stay (maximum of 8 days) or until revascularization is performed to reduce ischemic events.9,10,27–29
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI receiving fibrinolytic therapy, continue parenteral anticoagulation throughout the hospital stay (up to 8 days) or until revascularization occurs to minimize ischemic events.

original: For patients <40 years of age with aSAH, clipping of the ruptured aneurysm might be considered the preferred mode of treatment to improve durability of the treatment and outcome.113,115 Modality of treatment: for aneurysms equally suitable for clipping and coiling
paraphrased: For patients under 40 with aSAH, clipping the ruptured aneurysm may be favored to enhance treatment durability and outcomes, especially when both clipping and coiling are viable options.

original: In patients with HCM with symptoms or evidence of myocardial ischemia, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is recommended.110
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who exhibit symptoms or signs of myocardial ischemia, it is advised to perform coronary angiography, either via CT or invasive methods.

original: In adults with congenital heart disease and AF, it is recommended to evaluate for and treat precipitating factors and reversible causes of AF, recognizing that residual hemodynamic sequelae may contribute to the occurrence of the arrhythmia.1,2
paraphrased: For adults with congenital heart disease and atrial fibrillation, it is advised to assess and address any triggering factors and reversible causes of the arrhythmia, while acknowledging that lingering hemodynamic effects may play a role in its development.

original: For patients with good-grade aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the anterior circulation equally suitable for both primary coiling and clipping, primary coiling is recommended in preference to clipping to improve 1-year functional outcome.110,116
paraphrased: For patients with good-grade aSAH due to ruptured aneurysms in the anterior circulation who are equally candidates for both primary coiling and clipping, primary coiling is advised over clipping to enhance functional outcomes at one year.

original: In patients with a BAV who have undergone previous aortic valve repair or replacement and have a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aortic, or both of ≥4.0 cm, lifelong surveillance imaging of the aortic root and ascending aorta by TTE, CT, or MRI is recom- mended at an interval dependent on aortic diameter and rate of growth.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV who have had prior aortic valve repair or replacement and possess an aortic root or ascending aorta diameter of 4.0 cm or more, continuous lifelong imaging surveillance of these areas using TTE, CT, or MRI is advised, with the frequency determined by the aortic diameter and growth rate.

original: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy who are not intended to undergo an invasive approach, enoxaparin is the recommended anticoagulant to reduce ischemic events.9,10,28,29
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI receiving fibrinolytic therapy and not scheduled for an invasive procedure, enoxaparin is advised as the anticoagulant to decrease ischemic events.

original: In patients with HF and obstructive sleep apnea, continuous positive airway pressure may be reasonable to improve sleep quality and decrease daytime sleepiness.9,11–13
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure and obstructive sleep apnea, using continuous positive airway pressure might be appropriate to enhance sleep quality and reduce daytime drowsiness.

original: In patients with HCM who are at risk of coro- nary atherosclerosis, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is recommended before surgi- cal myectomy.111
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who may develop coronary atherosclerosis, it is advised to perform coronary angiography (either CT or invasive) prior to surgical myectomy.

original: For patients with good-grade aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the anterior circulation equally suitable for both primary coiling and clipping, both treat- ment options are reasonable to achieve favorable long-term outcome.108,109,117 Endovascular adjuncts
paraphrased: For patients with good-grade aSAH due to ruptured aneurysms in the anterior circulation who are equally candidates for primary coiling or clipping, either treatment option is appropriate for achieving a favorable long-term outcome.

original: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy who are not intended to undergo an inva- sive approach, fondaparinux is a recommended alternative to reduce ischemic events.27,30 *At the time of diagnosis and prior to invasive coronary angiography if planned. †Adapted or ‡modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”31
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI receiving fibrinolytic therapy who are not planned for an invasive strategy, fondaparinux is advised as an alternative to decrease ischemic events.

original: In adults with AF and moderate or complex congeni- tal heart disease, electrophysiological procedures should be performed by operators with expertise in ACHD procedures and in collaboration with an ACHD cardiologist, ideally in specialized centers, when available.3–5
paraphrased: For adults with atrial fibrillation and moderate or complex congenital heart disease, electrophysiological procedures should be conducted by specialists experienced in ACHD procedures, in partnership with an ACHD cardiologist, preferably at specialized centers when possible.

original: In patients with a BAV and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both of ≥4.0 cm, lifelong surveillance imaging of the aortic root and ascending aorta by TTE, CT, or MRI is recommended at an interval dependent on aortic diameter and rate of growth.4,5
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV and an aortic root or ascending aorta diameter of 4.0 cm or more, it is advised to conduct lifelong surveillance imaging of these areas using TTE, CT, or MRI, with the frequency determined by the aortic diameter and growth rate.

original: In patients with NYHA class II to IV HFrEF and central sleep apnea, adaptive servo-ventilation causes harm.11,12 Management of Diabetes
paraphrased: Adaptive servo-ventilation is harmful for patients with NYHA class II to IV HFrEF who have central sleep apnea.

original: In patients with ACS, high-intensity statin therapy is recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.*1–4
paraphrased: For patients with ACS, it is advised to use high-intensity statin therapy to lower the risk of MACE.

original: For patients with aSAH from ruptured wide-neck aneurysms not amenable to surgical clipping or primary coiling, endo- vascular treatment with stent-assisted coiling or flow diverters is reasonable to reduce the risk of rebleed.118,119
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH due to ruptured wide-neck aneurysms that cannot be treated with surgical clipping or primary coiling, endovascular treatment using stent-assisted coiling or flow diverters is a reasonable option to lower the risk of rebleeding.

original: In patients with HF and type 2 diabetes, the use of SGLT2i is recommended for the man- agement of hyperglycemia and to reduce HF- related morbidity and mortality.14–17
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure and type 2 diabetes, SGLT2 inhibitors are advised to manage high blood sugar and decrease heart failure-related morbidity and mortality.

original: In adults with congenital heart disease and symp- tomatic or hemodynamically significant paroxysmal or persistent AF, an initial strategy of rhythm control is recommended regardless of lesion severity as AF in this population is often poorly tolerated.6
paraphrased: For adults with congenital heart disease experiencing symptomatic or hemodynamically significant paroxysmal or persistent atrial fibrillation, it is advised to initially pursue rhythm control, irrespective of the lesion's severity, as AF is frequently poorly tolerated in this group.

original: For symptomatic patients with HCM who do not have resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is recommended for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.50,112
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who exhibit symptoms but lack a resting or inducible outflow tract gradient of ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is advised to identify and measure dynamic LVOTO.

original: For patients with aSAH from ruptured fusiform/blister aneurysms, the use of flow diverters is reasonable to reduce mortality.120,121
paraphrased: Using flow diverters for patients with aSAH due to ruptured fusiform or blister aneurysms is a reasonable approach to decrease mortality.

original: In patients with a BAV and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both of ≥5.5 cm, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is recom- mended.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV and an aortic root or ascending aorta measuring 5.5 cm or larger, it is advised to perform surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both.

original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite guideline-directed management and therapy), cardiopulmonary exercise stress testing should be performed to quantify the degree of functional limi- tation and aid in selection of patients for heart trans- plantation or mechanical circulatory support.113,114
paraphrased: For patients with nonobstructive HCM experiencing severe heart failure (classified as NYHA class III or IV despite receiving guideline-directed treatment), cardiopulmonary exercise stress testing is recommended to assess functional limitations and assist in determining eligibility for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.

original: In patients with ACS who are already on maximally tolerated statin therapy with low- density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), adding a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent is recommended to further reduce the risk of MACE.†5–7
paraphrased: For patients with ACS on the highest tolerated dose of statins and LDL-C levels of 70 mg/dL (1.8 mmol/L) or higher, it is advised to add a nonstatin lipid-lowering medication to further decrease the risk of MACE.

original: In patients with a BAV and a cross-­sectional aortic root or ascending aortic area (cm2) to height (m) ratio of ≥10 cm2/m, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is reasonable, when performed by expe- rienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV and a ratio of aortic root or ascending aortic area (cm²) to height (m) of ≥10 cm²/m, it is advisable to consider surgical replacement of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, when conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

original: In symptomatic patients with simple congenital heart disease with antiarrhythmic drug–refractory AF, it is reasonable to choose ablation over long-term antiar- rhythmic therapies.4,7
paraphrased: For patients with simple congenital heart disease who have symptomatic AF that does not respond to antiarrhythmic drugs, opting for ablation instead of prolonged antiarrhythmic treatment is a reasonable approach.

original: In patients with HCM, exercise stress testing is reasonable to determine functional capacity and to provide prognostic information as part of initial evaluation.113,114
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is appropriate to conduct exercise stress testing to assess functional capacity and offer prognostic insights during the initial evaluation.

original: Patients with chronic HF with permanent-per- sistent-paroxysmal AF and a CHA2DS2-VASc score of ≥2 (for men) and ≥3 (for women) should receive chronic anticoagulant therapy.1–5
paraphrased: Individuals with chronic heart failure and permanent, persistent, or paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, who have a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or higher for men and 3 or higher for women, should be prescribed long-term anticoagulant treatment.

original: In patients with a BAV, a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of 5.0 cm to 5.4 cm, and an additional risk factor for aortic dissec- tion (Table 14), surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,5
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV, an aortic root or ascending aorta measuring 5.0 cm to 5.4 cm, and an extra risk factor for aortic dissection (refer to Table 14), it is advisable to consider surgical replacement of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, provided it is conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

original: For patients with aSAH from ruptured saccular aneurysms amenable to either primary coiling or clipping, stents or flow diverters should not be used to avoid higher risk of complications.122,123 Recommendations for Surgical and Endovascular Methods for Treatment of Ruptured Cerebral Aneurysms (Continued) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH due to ruptured saccular aneurysms that can be treated with either primary coiling or clipping, the use of stents or flow diverters is discouraged to prevent increased complication risks.

original: In patients with ACS who are statin intolerant, nonstatin lipid-lowering therapy is recommended to lower LDL-C and reduce the risk of MACE.8–10
paraphrased: For patients with ACS who cannot tolerate statins, it is advised to use nonstatin lipid-lowering treatments to decrease LDL-C levels and minimize the risk of MACE.

original: For patients with chronic HF with permanent- persistent-paroxysmal AF, DOAC is recom- mended over warfarin in eligible patients.2–10
paraphrased: In patients with chronic heart failure and permanent, persistent, or paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, a DOAC is advised over warfarin for those who qualify.

original: In adults with congenital heart disease with AF undergoing PVI, it may be reasonable to include an ablative strategy in the right atrium directed at reentrant arrhythmia secondary to atriotomy scars and the CTI.8,9
paraphrased: For adults with congenital heart disease and AF undergoing PVI, considering an ablative approach targeting reentrant arrhythmias in the right atrium due to atriotomy scars and the CTI may be appropriate.

original: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is reasonable for the detection and quantifi- cation of dynamic LVOTO.49,51–54,115
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who show no symptoms and lack a resting or inducible outflow tract gradient of 50 mm Hg or more on standard TTE, it is reasonable to use exercise TTE to detect and measure dynamic LVOTO.

original: In patients with a BAV who are undergoing surgical aortic valve repair or replacement, and who have a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of ≥4.5 cm, concomitant replacement of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,6
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV undergoing surgical repair or replacement of the aortic valve, it is advisable to also replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both if the diameter is ≥4.5 cm, provided the procedure is conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

original: In patients with ACS who are already on maximally tolerated statin therapy with LDL-C 55 to 69 mg/dL (≥1.4 to <1.8 mmol/L), adding a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent is reasonable to reduce the risk of MACE.*5–7,11–13
paraphrased: For patients with ACS on the highest tolerated statin dose and LDL-C levels between 55 and 69 mg/dL (≥1.4 to <1.8 mmol/L), it is advisable to add a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent to decrease the risk of MACE.

original: For patients with HF and symptoms caused by AF, AF ablation is reasonable to improve symp- toms and QOL.11–14
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure experiencing symptoms due to atrial fibrillation, it is reasonable to consider AF ablation to enhance symptoms and quality of life.

original: In patients with aSAH, the intraoperative use of mannitol or hypertonic saline can be effective in reducing ICP and cerebral edema.135,136
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, administering mannitol or hypertonic saline during surgery may effectively lower ICP and decrease cerebral edema.

original: In patients with obstructive HCM, who are being considered for SRT, and in whom functional capac- ity or symptom status is uncertain, exercise stress testing may be reasonable (Figure 1).
paraphrased: For patients with obstructive HCM being evaluated for SRT, where there is uncertainty about functional capacity or symptom status, it may be appropriate to consider exercise stress testing (Figure 1).

original: In patients with ACS, the concurrent initiation of ezetimibe in combination with maximally tolerated statin may be considered to reduce the risk of MACE.5 *Modified or †adapted from the “2023 AHA/ACC/ACCP/ASPC/NLA/PCNA Guideline for the Management of Patients With Chronic Coronary Disease.”14
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ACS, starting ezetimibe alongside the highest tolerated dose of statin can be contemplated to lower the risk of MACE.

original: In patients with a BAV, a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of 5.0 cm to 5.4 cm, no other risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 14), and at low surgical risk, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both may be reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,2,5
paraphrased: For patients with a BAV, where the aortic root or ascending aorta measures between 5.0 cm and 5.4 cm, lacks additional aortic dissection risk factors (refer to Table 14), and presents low surgical risk, it may be appropriate to consider surgical replacement of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, provided it is conducted by skilled surgeons within a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

original: In patients with aSAH, anesthetic goals should include minimizing postprocedural pain, nausea, and vomiting.137–140
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, the anesthetic objectives should focus on reducing pain, nausea, and vomiting after the procedure.

original: In adults with AF and moderate or severe forms of congenital heart disease, particularly those with low-flow states such as Fontan circulation, blind- ending cardiac chambers, and cyanosis, it may be reasonable to treat with anticoagulation independent of conventional risk score to reduce risk of thromboembolic events.10
paraphrased: For adults with atrial fibrillation and moderate to severe congenital heart disease, especially those experiencing low-flow conditions like Fontan circulation, blind-ending cardiac chambers, and cyanosis, anticoagulation treatment may be justified regardless of traditional risk scores to lower the risk of thromboembolic events.

original: In patients with HCM in whom functional capacity or symptom status is uncertain, exercise stress test- ing may be considered every 2 to 3 years (Figure 1).
paraphrased: For patients with HCM where there is uncertainty about their functional capacity or symptom status, conducting an exercise stress test every 2 to 3 years may be advisable (Figure 1).

original: In men who are ≥65 years of age who have ever smoked, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is recommended.1
paraphrased: For men aged 65 and older with a history of smoking, it is advised to undergo ultrasound screening to detect AAA.

original: In patients undergoing cardiac surgery who are at high risk for postoperative AF, it is reasonable to administer short-term prophylactic beta blockers or amiodarone to reduce the incidence of postoperative AF.1–5
paraphrased: For patients at high risk of postoperative atrial fibrillation following cardiac surgery, short-term use of prophylactic beta blockers or amiodarone is advisable to decrease the occurrence of postoperative AF.

original: In patients with ACS without contraindications, early (<24 hours) initiation of oral beta-blocker therapy is recommended to reduce risk of reinfarction and ventricular arrhythmias.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with ACS who have no contraindications, it is advised to start oral beta-blocker therapy within 24 hours to lower the risk of reinfarction and ventricular arrhythmias.

original: In patients undergoing CABG, aortic valve, or ascend- ing aortic aneurysm operations, it is reasonable to perform concomitant posterior left pericardiotomy to reduce the incidence of postoperative AF.6,7
paraphrased: For patients having CABG, aortic valve, or ascending aortic aneurysm surgeries, performing a simultaneous posterior left pericardiotomy is advisable to lower the risk of postoperative atrial fibrillation.

original: In patients with aSAH, prevention of intraoperative hyperglycemia and hypogly- cemia during aneurysm surgery is reason- able to improve outcomes.141–147
paraphrased: For patients undergoing aneurysm surgery for aSAH, it is advisable to prevent both hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia during the operation to enhance outcomes.

original: For patients with AF and LVEF ≤50%, if a rhythm control strategy fails or is not desired, and ventricular rates remain rapid despite medi- cal therapy, atrioventricular nodal ablation with implantation of a CRT device is reasonable.15–22
paraphrased: For patients with AF and LVEF ≤50%, if rhythm control is unsuccessful or not preferred, and ventricular rates remain high despite medication, it is reasonable to consider atrioventricular nodal ablation with CRT device implantation.

original: In men or women who are ≥65 years of age and who are first-degree relatives of patients with AAA, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is recommended.2,3
paraphrased: For individuals aged 65 or older who have a first-degree relative with AAA, it is advised to undergo ultrasound screening to detect AAA.

original: For patients with chronic HF and permanent- persistent-paroxysmal AF, chronic anticoagulant therapy is reasonable for men and women with- out additional risk factors.23–26
paraphrased: For individuals with chronic heart failure and permanent, persistent, or paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, it is appropriate to consider long-term anticoagulant therapy for both men and women who do not have other risk factors.

original: In patients with aSAH and an unsecured ruptured aneurysm, frequent intraopera- tive BP monitoring and BP control are reasonable to prevent ischemia and rerupture.148–153
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH and an unsecured ruptured aneurysm, it is advisable to frequently monitor and manage blood pressure intraoperatively to prevent ischemia and rerupture.

original: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is recommended as part of the initial assessment.23,25–28,117,118
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is advised to assess familial inheritance by obtaining a family history spanning three generations as part of the initial evaluation.

original: In vulnerable patient populations at risk for health disparities, HF risk assessments and multidisciplinary management strategies should target both known risks for CVD and social determinants of health, as a means toward elimination of disparate HF outcomes.1–6
paraphrased: For patient groups susceptible to health disparities, HF risk evaluations and multidisciplinary management approaches should address both established CVD risks and social determinants of health to eliminate unequal HF outcomes.

original: In high-risk patients with ACS (LVEF ≤40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or STEMI with anterior location), an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.1–6
paraphrased: For patients at high risk of ACS, such as those with an LVEF of 40% or less, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or anterior STEMI, it is recommended to prescribe an oral ACE inhibitor or ARB to lower the risk of all-cause mortality and major adverse cardiovascular events.

original: In hemodynamically stable cardiac surgery patients with postoperative AF, rate-control (target heart rate, <100 bpm) and/or rhythm-control medications are recommended as initial therapy, with the choice of strategy according to patient symptoms, hemody- namic consequences of the arrhythmia, and physician preference.5,6
paraphrased: For cardiac surgery patients who are hemodynamically stable and develop postoperative atrial fibrillation, it is advised to start with rate-control (aiming for a heart rate below 100 bpm) and/or rhythm-control medications, with the choice of approach based on the patient's symptoms, the hemodynamic impact of the arrhythmia, and the physician's judgment.

original: In patients with aSAH, intraoperative neuromonitoring may be reasonable to guide anesthetic and operative management.154–159
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, using intraoperative neuromonitoring can be a sensible approach to direct anesthetic and surgical management.

original: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is bene- ficial to elucidate the genetic basis to facilitate the identification of family members at risk for developing HCM (cascade testing).119–122
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, genetic testing is advantageous to clarify the genetic cause and aid in identifying family members who may be at risk of developing HCM through cascade testing.

original: In patients with ACS and LVEF ≤40%, and with HF symptoms and/or diabetes mellitus, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.7
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ACS with an LVEF of 40% or less, who also have heart failure symptoms and/or diabetes mellitus, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist is recommended to lower the risk of all-cause mortality and major adverse cardiovascular events.

original: In patients who develop poorly tolerated AF after cardiac surgery, direct current cardioversion in com- bination with antiarrhythmic drug therapy is recom- mended, with consideration of imaging to rule out left appendage thrombus before cardioversion in those patients in whom AF has been present >48 hours and who have not been on anticoagulation.5,6
paraphrased: For patients experiencing poorly tolerated atrial fibrillation following cardiac surgery, it is advised to use direct current cardioversion alongside antiarrhythmic medication. Prior to cardioversion, consider imaging to exclude a left atrial appendage thrombus in patients with atrial fibrillation lasting over 48 hours who have not received anticoagulation therapy.

original: Evidence of health disparities should be moni- tored and addressed at the clinical practice and the health care system levels.7–13 *This section crosslinks to Section 7.1.1, “Stage C Nonpharmacological In- terventions and Self-Care Support in HF,” where screening and interventions for social determinants of health are now addressed.
paraphrased: Health disparities should be tracked and tackled within clinical practices and the broader healthcare system. This connects to Section 7.1.1, "Stage C Nonpharmacological Interventions and Self-Care Support in HF," which now includes screening and interventions for social determinants of health.

original: In patients with an atypical clinical presentation of HCM or when another genetic condition is suspected to be the cause, a work-up includ- ing genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy (“HCM phenocopies”) is recommended.123–125
paraphrased: For patients exhibiting unusual clinical signs of HCM or when a different genetic disorder is suspected as the underlying cause, it is advised to conduct an evaluation that includes genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy, known as "HCM phenocopies."

original: In men or women <65 years of age and who have multiple risk factors (Table 15) or a first-degree relative with AAA, ultrasound screening for AAA may be considered.5,6
paraphrased: For individuals under 65 years old with several risk factors (refer to Table 15) or a first-degree relative with an AAA, ultrasound screening for AAA can be considered.

original: In patients with ACS who are not considered high risk, an oral ACEi or an ARB is reasonable to reduce MACE.4
paraphrased: For patients with ACS who are not deemed high risk, it is reasonable to use an oral ACEi or ARB to lower the risk of MACE.

original: In patients who develop cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy or HF, a multidisciplinary discussion involving the patient about the risk- benefit ratio of cancer therapy interruption, dis- continuation, or continuation is recommended to improve management.1,2
paraphrased: For patients experiencing cardiomyopathy or heart failure due to cancer treatment, it is advised to engage in a multidisciplinary discussion with the patient to evaluate the risks and benefits of pausing, stopping, or continuing cancer therapy to enhance management.

original: In patients with aSAH and an uncontrolled intraoperative aneurysmal rupture, adenosine may be considered to facilitate aneurysm clip placement by inducing cardiac standstill and temporary profound pause.160,161
paraphrased: For patients experiencing an uncontrolled intraoperative aneurysmal rupture during aSAH, adenosine can be used to induce cardiac standstill and a temporary profound pause, aiding in the placement of an aneurysm clip.

original: In asymptomatic men or women >75 years who have had a negative initial ultrasound screen, repeat screening for detection of AAA is not recommended.1
paraphrased: For asymptomatic individuals over 75 years old with a negative initial ultrasound screening, further screening for AAA is not advised.

original: In women who are ≥65 years of age who have ever smoked, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is reasonable.4,5
paraphrased: For women aged 65 and older with a history of smoking, it is advisable to conduct an ultrasound screening to detect AAA.

original: In patients who develop postoperative AF after cardiac surgery, it is reasonable to administer anti- coagulation when deemed safe in regard to surgical bleeding for 60 days after surgery unless complica- tions develop and to reevaluate the need for longer term anticoagulation at that time.5,7
paraphrased: For patients experiencing postoperative atrial fibrillation following cardiac surgery, it is advisable to provide anticoagulation therapy for 60 days post-surgery, provided it is safe concerning surgical bleeding, and reassess the necessity for extended anticoagulation if complications arise.

original: In patients with good-grade aSAH, the routine use of induced mild hypothermia during aneurysm surgery is not benefi- cial.147,162–168
paraphrased: For patients with good-grade aSAH, routinely applying induced mild hypothermia during aneurysm surgery does not provide benefits.

original: All communities should create and maintain regional systems of STEMI care that coordinate prehospital and hospital-based STEMI care processes with the goal of reducing total ischemic time and improving survival in patients with STEMI.1–6
paraphrased: Every community ought to establish and sustain regional STEMI care systems that integrate prehospital and hospital-based care procedures, aiming to minimize total ischemic time and enhance survival rates in STEMI patients.

original: In patients with HCM who choose to undergo genetic testing, pre- and posttest genetic coun- seling by an expert in the genetics of cardio- vascular disease is recommended so that risks, benefits, results, and their clinical significance can be reviewed and discussed with the patient in a shared decision-making process.23–25,117
paraphrased: For patients with HCM opting for genetic testing, it is advised that they receive genetic counseling from a cardiovascular genetics specialist both before and after the test, to ensure that the risks, benefits, results, and their clinical implications are thoroughly reviewed and discussed with the patient in a collaborative decision-making process.

original: In patients with TAA and an average systolic BP (SBP) of ≥130 mm Hg or an average diastolic BP (DBP) of ≥80 mm Hg, the use of antihypertensive medications is recommended to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with TAA whose average systolic blood pressure is 130 mm Hg or higher, or average diastolic blood pressure is 80 mm Hg or higher, it is advised to use antihypertensive drugs to lower the risk of cardiovascular events.

original: In asymptomatic patients with cancer therapy– related cardiomyopathy (EF <50%), ARB, ACEi, and beta blockers are reasonable to prevent progression to HF and improve cardiac function.2–4
paraphrased: For asymptomatic patients with cardiomyopathy due to cancer treatment (EF <50%), using ARBs, ACE inhibitors, and beta blockers is advisable to prevent heart failure progression and enhance cardiac function.

original: When performing genetic testing in an HCM proband, the initial tier of genes tested should include genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.*119,122,127,128 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: In an HCM proband undergoing genetic testing, the first set of genes examined should consist of those with robust evidence of being causative for HCM.

original: In patients who develop AF after cardiac surgery and who are treated with rate-control strategy, at 30- to 60-day follow-up it is reasonable to perform rhythm assessment and, if AF does not revert to sinus rhythm spontaneously, consider cardioversion after an adequate duration of anticoagulation.5,6 *A LOE applies to the data on beta blockers. †B-R LOE applies to the data on nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing AF post-cardiac surgery and managed with a rate-control approach, it is advisable to evaluate rhythm at a 30- to 60-day follow-up. If AF persists and does not spontaneously revert to sinus rhythm, cardioversion should be considered following sufficient anticoagulation. *A LOE pertains to beta blocker data. †B-R LOE pertains to nondihydropyridine calcium channel blocker data.

original: In patients with STEMI presenting <12 hours after symptom onset, PPCI should be performed with a goal of FMC to device activation of ≤90 minutes, or ≤120 minutes in patients requiring hospital transfer, to improve survival.1–7
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI who present within 12 hours of symptom onset, PPCI should be conducted aiming for FMC to device activation within 90 minutes, or within 120 minutes if hospital transfer is needed, to enhance survival.

original: Patients with AF who are identified in the setting of acute medical illness or surgery should be coun- seled about the significant risk of recurrent AF after the acute illness is resolved.1–6
paraphrased: Patients diagnosed with AF during an acute medical condition or surgery should be informed about the high likelihood of AF recurrence once the acute condition has subsided.

original: In patients with aSAH who require mechanical ventilation for >24 hours, implementation of a standardized ICU care bundle is recommended to reduce the duration of mechanical ventilation and hospital-acquired pneumonia.177,178 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH needing mechanical ventilation for more than 24 hours, it is advised to apply a standardized ICU care bundle to decrease the length of mechanical ventilation and the incidence of hospital-acquired pneumonia.

original: In patients with cardiovascular risk factors or known cardiac disease being considered for potentially cardiotoxic anticancer therapies, pretherapy evaluation of cardiac function is rea- sonable to establish baseline cardiac function and guide the choice of cancer therapy.2,5–16
paraphrased: For patients with cardiovascular risk factors or existing heart disease who are candidates for potentially cardiotoxic cancer treatments, it is advisable to assess cardiac function before starting therapy to establish a baseline and inform treatment decisions.

original: In patients with TAA, regardless of cause and in the absence of contraindications, use of beta blockers to achieve target BP goals is reasonable.1,4,5
paraphrased: For patients with TAA, irrespective of the underlying cause and if there are no contraindications, it is advisable to use beta blockers to reach target blood pressure levels.

original: In patients with ACS and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, emergency revascularization of the culprit vessel by PCI or CABG is indicated to improve survival, irrespective of time from symptom onset.8–11
paraphrased: For patients experiencing ACS with cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, urgent revascularization of the culprit vessel through PCI or CABG is recommended to enhance survival, regardless of the time elapsed since symptom onset.

original: In patients with cardiovascular risk factors or known cardiac disease receiving potentially cardiotoxic anticancer therapies, monitoring of cardiac function is reasonable for the early iden- tification of drug-induced cardiomyopathy.2,4,6,8
paraphrased: For patients with cardiovascular risk factors or existing heart disease undergoing potentially cardiotoxic cancer treatments, it is advisable to monitor cardiac function to detect drug-induced cardiomyopathy early.

original: In patients with AF who are identified in the setting of acute medical illness or surgery, outpatient follow- up for thromboembolic risk stratification and decision-making on OAC initiation or continuation, as well as AF surveillance, can be beneficial given a high risk of AF recurrence.4–9
paraphrased: For patients with AF detected during acute medical conditions or surgery, it can be advantageous to conduct outpatient follow-up for assessing thromboembolic risk and deciding on the initiation or continuation of OAC, as well as monitoring AF, due to a high likelihood of AF recurrence.

original: In patients with aSAH who develop severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and life-threatening hypoxemia, rescue maneuvers such as prone position- ing and alveolar recruitment maneuvers with ICP monitoring may be reasonable to improve oxygenation.179–182 Intravascular volume and electrolyte management
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH experiencing severe ARDS and critical hypoxemia, it may be appropriate to use rescue strategies like prone positioning and alveolar recruitment maneuvers while monitoring ICP to enhance oxygenation.

original: In patients with TAA, regardless of etiology and in the absence of contraindications, ARB therapy is a reasonable adjunct to beta- blocker therapy to achieve target BP goals.6
paraphrased: For patients with TAA, irrespective of the cause and if no contraindications exist, adding ARB therapy to beta-blocker treatment is a sensible approach to reach target blood pressure goals.

original: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, both clinical screening (ECG and 2D echocar- diogram) and cascade genetic testing (when a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant has been identified in the proband) should be offered.23,67,123,130–132
paraphrased: For first-degree relatives of individuals with HCM, it is recommended to provide both clinical evaluations (including ECG and 2D echocardiogram) and cascade genetic testing if a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant is detected in the proband.

original: In patients with aSAH, close monitor- ing and goal-directed treatment of volume status are reasonable to maintain euvolemia.183–185
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, it is advisable to closely monitor and manage volume status to ensure euvolemia.

original: In families where a sudden unexplained death has occurred with a postmortem diagnosis of HCM, postmortem genetic testing is benefi- cial to facilitate cascade genetic testing and clinical screening in first-degree relatives.133,134
paraphrased: In cases where a sudden unexplained death has been attributed to HCM after an autopsy, conducting genetic testing postmortem is advantageous for enabling cascade genetic testing and clinical screening in first-degree relatives.

original: In patients with STEMI presenting 12 to 24 hours after symptom onset, PPCI is reasonable to improve clinical outcomes.*12–15
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI who present 12 to 24 hours after symptoms begin, it is reasonable to perform PPCI to enhance clinical outcomes.

original: In patients at risk of cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy, initiation of beta blockers and ACEi/ARB for the primary prevention of drug-induced cardiomyopathy is of uncertain benefit.17–28
paraphrased: For patients at risk of cardiomyopathy due to cancer treatment, starting beta blockers and ACE inhibitors or ARBs for primary prevention of drug-induced cardiomyopathy has an uncertain benefit.

original: In patients with TAA and imaging or clinical evidence of atherosclerosis, statin therapy at moderate or high intensity is ­reasonable.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with TAA who show imaging or clinical signs of atherosclerosis, it is appropriate to consider moderate or high-intensity statin therapy.

original: In patients with aSAH, use of mineralocor- ticoids is reasonable to treat natriuresis and hyponatremia.186,187
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, administering mineralocorticoids is a sensible approach to manage natriuresis and hyponatremia.

original: In patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing, serial reevaluation of the variant(s) identified is recommended to assess for variant reclassification, which may impact diagnosis and cascade genetic testing in family members.135–137 (Figure 1 and Figure 2)
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who have had genetic testing, it is advised to periodically reassess the identified variant(s) to determine if reclassification is necessary, as this could affect diagnosis and genetic testing of family members.

original: In patients with STEMI presenting >24 hours after symptom onset with the presence of ongoing ischemia or life-threatening arrhythmia, PPCI is reasonable to improve clinical outcomes.†12,14
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI who present more than 24 hours after symptoms begin and have ongoing ischemia or life-threatening arrhythmias, performing PPCI can be a reasonable approach to enhance clinical outcomes.

original: In patients with hyperthyroidism and AF who have an elevated risk of stroke based on a standard clinical risk score, anticoagulation is recommended until thyroid function has returned to normal and sinus rhythm can be maintained.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with hyperthyroidism and atrial fibrillation who have a high stroke risk according to a standard clinical risk assessment, anticoagulation is advised until thyroid function normalizes and sinus rhythm is stable.

original: In patients with AF who are identified in the setting of critical illness due to sepsis, the benefits of anticoagulation during critical illness for stroke pre- vention are uncertain.10,11
paraphrased: For patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) experiencing critical illness from sepsis, the advantages of using anticoagulation to prevent stroke during this period are unclear.

original: In patients being considered for potentially car- diotoxic therapies, serial measurement of car- diac troponin might be reasonable for further risk stratification.29–32
paraphrased: For patients who may undergo therapies with potential cardiotoxic effects, it could be appropriate to measure cardiac troponin levels serially to aid in further risk assessment.

original: In affected families with HCM, preconception and prenatal reproductive and genetic counsel- ing should be offered.23–25,117
paraphrased: For families impacted by HCM, it is advised to provide reproductive and genetic counseling before conception and during pregnancy.

original: In patients who are stable with STEMI who have a totally occluded infarct-related artery >24 hours after symptom onset and are without evidence of ongoing ischemia, acute severe HF, or life-threatening arrhythmia, PPCI should not be performed due to lack of benefit.†16,17 *Reproduced or †modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”18
paraphrased: For patients with stable STEMI and a completely blocked infarct-related artery more than 24 hours after symptoms begin, who show no signs of ongoing ischemia, acute severe heart failure, or life-threatening arrhythmias, performing PPCI is not recommended as it offers no benefit.

original: In patients with aSAH, induction of hyper- volemia is potentially harmful because of the association with excess morbid- ity.188–190 Other
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, inducing hypervolemia may be detrimental due to its link with increased morbidity.

original: In patients with TAA who have no evidence of atherosclerosis, the use of statin therapy may be considered.3-6
paraphrased: Statin therapy can be considered for patients with TAA who show no signs of atherosclerosis.

original: In patients with TAA who smoke cigarettes, smoking cessation efforts are recommended.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with TAA who are cigarette smokers, it is advised to pursue smoking cessation.

original: In patients with AF and COPD, it is reasonable to use cardioselective beta blockers for rate control of AF, especially where other indications exist (eg, MI and HF).1–3
paraphrased: For patients with AF and COPD, using cardioselective beta blockers for AF rate control is advisable, particularly when there are additional indications such as MI and HF.

original: In patients with HCM, the usefulness of genetic testing in the assessment of risk of SCD is uncertain.121,137–139
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, the value of genetic testing in evaluating the risk of SCD remains unclear.

original: In women with a history of HF or cardiomyopathy, including previous peripartum cardiomyopathy, patient-centered counseling regarding contra- ception and the risks of cardiovascular deteriora- tion during pregnancy should be provided.1–8
paraphrased: For women with a history of heart failure or cardiomyopathy, including past peripartum cardiomyopathy, it is important to offer counseling focused on the patient regarding contraception and the potential for cardiovascular decline during pregnancy.

original: In patients with aSAH whose ruptured aneurysm has been secured, pharmaco- logical or mechanical venous thromboem- bolism (VTE) prophylaxis is recommended to reduce the risk for VTE.191–193
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH who have had their ruptured aneurysm stabilized, it is advised to use pharmacological or mechanical VTE prophylaxis to lower the risk of VTE.

original: In patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) with pulmonary vascular disease and AF or AFL, a rhythm-control strategy is reasonable to improve functional status and potentially prolong survival.4–12
paraphrased: For patients with pulmonary hypertension and vascular disease who have AF or AFL, employing a rhythm-control strategy is advisable to enhance functional status and possibly extend survival.

original: In patients with atherosclerotic TAA and con- comitant aortic atheroma or PAU, the use of low-dose aspirin is reasonable, unless contra- indicated.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with atherosclerotic TAA and accompanying aortic atheroma or PAU, it is advisable to use low-dose aspirin, provided there are no contraindications.

original: In women with acute HF caused by peripartum cardiomyopathy and LVEF <30%, anticoagula- tion may be reasonable at diagnosis, until 6 to 8 weeks postpartum, although the efficacy and safety are uncertain.9–12
paraphrased: For women experiencing acute heart failure due to peripartum cardiomyopathy with an LVEF below 30%, initiating anticoagulation from diagnosis until 6 to 8 weeks after childbirth might be considered, despite uncertain efficacy and safety.

original: In patients with STEMI in whom PCI is not feasible or successful, with a large area of myocardium at risk, emergency or urgent CABG surgery can be effective to improve clinical outcomes.*1,2 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”3
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI where PCI cannot be performed or has failed, and there is a significant myocardial area at risk, emergency or urgent CABG surgery may be beneficial in enhancing clinical outcomes.

original: In patients with HCM who harbor a variant of uncertain significance, the usefulness of clinical genetic testing of phenotype-negative relatives for the purpose of variant reclassifi- cation is uncertain.28,70,118,119
paraphrased: For patients with HCM possessing a variant of uncertain significance, the benefit of conducting clinical genetic testing on relatives without the phenotype to aid in variant reclassification remains unclear.

original: In patients with STEMI and an estimated time from FMC to device activation of ≤120 minutes or those with a contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy, transfer to a PCI-capable hospital for PPCI is recommended to reduce MACE.1–3
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI with an estimated FMC to device activation time of 120 minutes or less, or those who cannot undergo fibrinolytic therapy, it is advised to transfer them to a PCI-capable hospital for PPCI to lower the risk of MACE.

original: In women with HF or cardiomyopathy who are pregnant or currently planning for pregnancy, ACEi, ARB, ARNi, MRA, SGLT2i, ivabradine, and vericiguat should not be administered because of significant risks of fetal harm.13–15
paraphrased: For women with heart failure or cardiomyopathy who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant, the use of ACE inhibitors, ARBs, ARNis, MRAs, SGLT2 inhibitors, ivabradine, and vericiguat is contraindicated due to the substantial risk of fetal harm.

original: In patients with aSAH, effective glycemic control, strict hyperglycemia management, and avoidance of hypoglycemia are rea- sonable to improve outcome.141,142,194,195
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, it is advisable to maintain effective glycemic control, rigorously manage hyperglycemia, and prevent hypoglycemia to enhance outcomes.

original: In pregnant patients with AF, DCCV is safe to the patient and fetus and should be performed in the same manner as in patients who are not pregnant.1
paraphrased: For pregnant patients with atrial fibrillation, direct current cardioversion is safe for both the mother and the fetus and should be conducted similarly to how it is done in non-pregnant patients.

original: In patients with AAA and an average SBP of ≥130 mm Hg, or an average DBP of ≥80 mm Hg, the use of antihypertensive medication is recommended to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with an AAA and an average SBP of 130 mm Hg or higher, or an average DBP of 80 mm Hg or higher, it is advised to use antihypertensive drugs to lower the risk of cardiovascular events.

original: For patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing and were found to have no pathogenic variants (ie, harbor only benign/ likely benign variants), cascade genetic testing of the family is not useful.118–121
paraphrased: Cascade genetic testing of the family is not beneficial for patients with HCM who have had genetic testing and only possess benign or likely benign variants, with no pathogenic variants detected.

original: In patients with AAA and evidence of aortic atherosclerosis, statin therapy at moderate or high intensity is recommended.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with AAA and signs of aortic atherosclerosis, it is advised to administer statin therapy at a moderate or high intensity.

original: In patients with STEMI and symptom onset of <12 hours and anticipated delay to PPCI >120 minutes from FMC, fibrinolytic therapy should be administered in patients without contraindication to reduce MACE.4–10 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI with symptoms beginning less than 12 hours ago and an expected delay to PPCI exceeding 120 minutes from FMC, fibrinolytic therapy should be given to those without contraindications to decrease MACE.

original: Performance measures based on professionally developed clinical practice guidelines should be used with the goal of improving quality of care for patients with HF.1–7
paraphrased: Performance metrics derived from expert-formulated clinical practice guidelines should aim to enhance the quality of care for patients with heart failure.

original: In pregnant individuals with structurally normal hearts and hemodynamically stable AF, pharmacological cardioversion with agents with history of safe use in pregnancy, such as intravenous procainamide, may be considered.1,2
paraphrased: For pregnant patients with normal heart structure and stable hemodynamics experiencing AF, it is advisable to consider pharmacological cardioversion using drugs known to be safe during pregnancy, such as intravenous procainamide.

original: Ongoing clinical screening is not indicated in genotype-negative relatives in families with genotype-positive HCM, unless the disease- causing variant is downgraded to variant of uncertain significance, likely benign, or benign variant during follow-up.15,135,140,142,143 *Strong evidence HCM genes include, at the time of this publication,
paraphrased: Routine clinical screening is unnecessary for genotype-negative family members in families with genotype-positive HCM, unless the pathogenic variant is reclassified as a variant of uncertain significance, likely benign, or benign during follow-up.

original: In patients with aSAH with fever refractory to antipyretic medications, the effective- ness of therapeutic temperature manage- ment (TTM) during the acute phase of aSAH is uncertain.196–198
paraphrased: For patients experiencing aSAH with fever that does not respond to antipyretic drugs, the effectiveness of therapeutic temperature management (TTM) in the acute phase of aSAH remains unclear.

original: Participation in quality improvement programs, including patient registries that provide bench- mark feedback on nationally endorsed, clinical practice guideline–based quality and perfor- mance measures can be beneficial in improving the quality of care for patients with HF.1,2,5,6
paraphrased: Engaging in quality improvement initiatives, such as patient registries that offer benchmark feedback on nationally recognized clinical practice guideline-based quality and performance metrics, can enhance the care quality for patients with heart failure.

original: In patients with AAA but no evidence of atherosclerosis, statin therapy may be ­considered.4,5
paraphrased: For patients with AAA who do not show signs of atherosclerosis, considering statin therapy is an option.

original: In patients with STEMI and symptom onset of 12 to 24 hours, transfer to a PCI-capable hospital for PPCI is reasonable to reduce infarct size and MACE.11,12
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI with symptoms beginning 12 to 24 hours prior, it is advisable to transfer them to a hospital equipped for PCI to decrease infarct size and major adverse cardiac events.

original: In patients with aSAH, use of evidence- based protocols and order sets is recom- mended to improve standardization of care.243–250
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, it is advised to utilize evidence-based protocols and order sets to enhance the consistency of care.

original: In patients with aSAH, frequent neuro- logical assessment with a neurological assessment tool such as the GCS or National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is recommended to monitor DCI and other secondary complica- tions.246,251–254
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, it is advised to regularly perform neurological evaluations using tools like the GCS or NIHSS to track DCI and other secondary complications.

original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assessment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are recommended at periodic intervals depending on age (every 1 to 2 years in chil- dren and adolescents, and every 3 to 5 years in adults) and change in clinical status.28,67,69–71 (Figure 1 and Figure 2, Table 6)
paraphrased: For those with a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression of HCM, it is advised to conduct regular clinical evaluations, electrocardiograms, and cardiac imaging at intervals based on age—every 1 to 2 years for children and adolescents, and every 3 to 5 years for adults—or if there is a change in clinical status.

original: In patients with only ST-segment depres- sion, except when true posterior STEMI is suspected, fibrinolytic therapy should not be administered due to risk of hemorrhagic stroke and major noncerebral bleeding.13
paraphrased: Fibrinolytic therapy should be avoided in patients presenting solely with ST-segment depression, unless a true posterior STEMI is suspected, due to the risk of hemorrhagic stroke and significant noncerebral bleeding.

original: In pregnant individuals with persistent AF, rate-control agents with a record of safety in pregnancy, such as beta blockers (eg, propranolol or metoprolol) and digoxin, either alone or in combination with beta blockers, are reasonable as first-line agents.1,2
paraphrased: For pregnant patients with persistent AF, it is reasonable to use rate-control medications known to be safe during pregnancy, such as beta blockers (e.g., propranolol or metoprolol) and digoxin, either alone or combined with beta blockers, as first-line treatments.

original: In patients with AAA who smoke cigarettes, smoking cessation efforts are recom- mended.1-4
paraphrased: For patients with AAA who are cigarette smokers, it is advised to undertake smoking cessation efforts.

original: For all patients with HF, palliative and supportive care—including high-quality communication, conveyance of prognosis, clarifying goals of care, shared decision-making, symptom man- agement, and caregiver support—should be provided to improve QOL and relieve suffering.1
paraphrased: For every patient with heart failure, palliative and supportive care should be offered to enhance quality of life and alleviate suffering, encompassing effective communication, prognosis discussion, care goals clarification, collaborative decision-making, symptom management, and caregiver support.

original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phe- notype-negative for HCM, participation in com- petitive athletics of any intensity is reasonable.132
paraphrased: For those with a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression of HCM, engaging in competitive sports at any level is considered reasonable.

original: In patients with STEMI, transfer to a PCI-capable center immediately after fibrinolytic therapy is recommended.1–5
paraphrased: For patients experiencing STEMI, it is advised to promptly transfer them to a center equipped for PCI following fibrinolytic treatment.

original: In patients with aSAH, frequent vital sign and neurological monitoring is recommended for detection of neu- rological change and prevention of secondary cerebral insults and poor outcomes.244,246,250,255–257 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, it is advised to regularly monitor vital signs and neurological status to identify neurological changes and prevent secondary cerebral injuries and adverse outcomes.

original: Pregnant individuals with AF and elevated risk of stroke may be considered for anticoagulation with the recognition that no anticoagulation strategy is completely safe for both the mother and fetus, and an SDM discussion should take place regarding risks to both mother and fetus (Table 28).3
paraphrased: For pregnant patients with atrial fibrillation and a high stroke risk, anticoagulation can be considered, acknowledging that no strategy is entirely risk-free for mother and fetus; a shared decision-making discussion about potential risks to both should occur (Table 28).3

original: In pregnant individuals with AF and without structural heart disease, antiarrhythmic agents with history of safe use in pregnancy (eg, flecainide and sotalol) are reasonable for maintenance of sinus rhythm.1,2
paraphrased: For pregnant individuals with atrial fibrillation and no structural heart disease, it is reasonable to use antiarrhythmic drugs like flecainide and sotalol, which have a history of safe use during pregnancy, to maintain sinus rhythm.

original: In patients with AAA with concomitant ather- oma and/or PAU, the use of low-dose aspirin may be considered, unless contraindicated.1
paraphrased: For patients with AAA who also have atheroma and/or PAU, low-dose aspirin can be considered, provided there are no contraindications.

original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, ICD is not recom- mended for primary prevention.28,69–71,132,145
paraphrased: For those with a positive genotype but no phenotypic expression of HCM, an ICD is not advised for primary prevention.

original: For patients with HF being considered for, or treated with, life-extending therapies, the option for discontinuation should be anticipated and dis- cussed through the continuum of care, including at the time of initiation, and reassessed with changing medical conditions and shifting goals of care.2,3
paraphrased: For patients with heart failure who are being evaluated for or receiving life-prolonging treatments, the possibility of stopping these therapies should be anticipated and addressed throughout their care, starting at the initiation phase and re-evaluated as medical conditions and care objectives evolve.

original: In patients with aSAH, a validated dysphagia screening protocol should be implemented before initiation of oral intake to reduce the incidence of pneumo- nia.244,246,258–261
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, a proven dysphagia screening protocol must be conducted prior to starting oral intake to decrease the risk of pneumonia.

original: In patients with STEMI with suspected failed reperfusion after fibrinolytic therapy, immediate angiography with rescue PCI is recommended to reduce the risk of death or recurrent MI.*6–9
paraphrased: For patients with STEMI who are suspected to have unsuccessful reperfusion following fibrinolytic therapy, it is advised to perform immediate angiography with rescue PCI to lower the risk of mortality or recurrent myocardial infarction.

original: For patients with HF—particularly stage D HF patients being evaluated for advanced therapies, patients requiring inotropic support or temporary mechanical support, patients experiencing uncontrolled symptoms, major medical decisions, or multimorbidity, frailty, and cognitive impairment—specialist palliative care consultation can be useful to improve QOL and relieve suffering.4–6 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: Specialist palliative care consultation may be beneficial for patients with heart failure, especially those in stage D being considered for advanced treatments, those needing inotropic or temporary mechanical support, those with uncontrolled symptoms, facing significant medical decisions, or dealing with multimorbidity, frailty, and cognitive impairment, to enhance quality of life and alleviate suffering.

original: In patients with aSAH, specialized nursing stroke competencies and certification can be effective to positively affect outcomes, timeliness of care, and adherence to stroke protocols.248,262–264
paraphrased: For patients with aSAH, having nurses with specialized stroke skills and certification can effectively improve outcomes, ensure timely care, and maintain adherence to stroke protocols.

original: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrino- lytic therapy, early angiography between 2 and 24 hours with the intent to perform PCI is recommended to reduce the rates of death or MI.*1–5,10,11 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”12
