paraphrased: For patients with claudication that limits function and are candidates for revascularization, the potential improvements in quality of life, walking ability, and overall function should be balanced against the intervention's risks, longevity, and the possibility of needing additional procedures.

original: In pregnant women with HCM, cardioversion for new or recurrent AF, particularly if symp- tomatic, is reasonable.302,313
paraphrased: For pregnant women with HCM, performing cardioversion for new or recurrent AF, especially if symptomatic, is advisable.

original: In patients with AAA treated with EVAR and abnormal findings (Table 21) on any surveil- lance duplex ultrasound, additional cross-sec- tional imaging with CT or MRI is reasonable.9
paraphrased: For patients with AAA who have undergone EVAR and exhibit abnormal results on any surveillance duplex ultrasound (refer to Table 21), it is reasonable to obtain further cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI.

original: We recommend sedation for severe agitation from sympathomimetic poisoning.
paraphrased: Sedation is advised for managing severe agitation caused by sympathomimetic poisoning.

original: In patients with AAA treated with complex EVAR, a modified surveillance imaging plan that combines cross-sectional imaging and duplex ultrasound of target vessels is reason- able.10,11
paraphrased: For patients undergoing complex EVAR for AAA, it is reasonable to implement a revised imaging surveillance strategy that integrates cross-sectional imaging with duplex ultrasound of the target vessels.

original: In pregnant women with HCM, general or epidural anesthesia is reasonable, with precautions to avoid hypotension.310
paraphrased: For pregnant women with HCM, it is advisable to use general or epidural anesthesia while taking measures to prevent hypotension.

original: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, previous testing when available should be considered and incorporated into CDPs.20-24
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with a suspicion of ACS, any prior test results should be evaluated and integrated into CDPs.

original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and an inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), revascularization is a reasonable treatment option to improve walking function and QOL.7–14
paraphrased: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, revascularization is a suitable option to enhance walking ability and quality of life.

original: For patients with acute chest pain, a normal ECG, and symptoms suggestive of ACS that began at least 3 hours before ED arrival, a single hs-cTn concentration that is below the limit of detection on initial measurement (time zero) is reasonable to exclude myocardial injury.13,25-29
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with a normal ECG and symptoms indicative of ACS that started at least 3 hours prior to arriving at the ED, it is reasonable to rule out myocardial injury if a single hs-cTn level measured at time zero is below the detection limit.

original: We recommend rapid external cooling for life- threatening hyperthermia from sympathomimetic poisoning.
paraphrased: We advise prompt external cooling for severe hyperthermia caused by sympathomimetic toxicity.

original: Vasodilators, such as phentolamine and/or nitrates, are reasonable for coronary vasospasm from sympathomimetic poisoning.
paraphrased: Phentolamine and/or nitrates, as vasodilators, are appropriate for treating coronary vasospasm caused by sympathomimetic poisoning.

original: Patients with acute chest pain and a 30-day risk of death or MACE <1% should be designated as low risk.1-11
paraphrased: Patients experiencing acute chest pain with a 30-day mortality or major adverse cardiac event risk of less than 1% should be classified as low risk.

original: In patients with AAA who have undergone open repair, surveillance imaging with CT or MRI of the abdominopelvic aorta within 1 year postoperatively and then every 5 years there- after is reasonable.5,6
paraphrased: For patients with AAA who have had open repair, it is advisable to perform surveillance imaging of the abdominopelvic aorta using CT or MRI within the first year after surgery and subsequently every five years.

original: In patients with claudication who have had an adequate clinical response to GDMT (including structured exercise), revascularization is not recommended. Revascularization for Claudication: Aortoiliac Disease and Femoro- popliteal Disease (Excluding Common Femoral Artery Disease)
paraphrased: For patients experiencing claudication who have responded well to guideline-directed medical therapy, including structured exercise, revascularization is not advised for aortoiliac and femoropopliteal diseases, excluding common femoral artery disease.

original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant aortoiliac or femoropopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), endovascular revascularization is effective to improve walking performance and QOL.7–28
paraphrased: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant aortoiliac or femoropopliteal disease who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, endovascular revascularization effectively enhances walking ability and quality of life.

original: In patients with a suspected AAS, CT is rec- ommended for initial diagnostic imaging, given its wide availability, accuracy, and speed, as well as the extent of anatomic detail it pro- vides.1-5
paraphrased: For patients suspected of having an AAS, it is advised to use CT for the initial diagnostic imaging due to its broad accessibility, precision, rapid results, and the detailed anatomical information it offers.

original: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are deemed low-risk (<1% 30-day risk of death or MACE), it is reasonable to discharge home without admission or urgent cardiac testing.12-16
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with suspected ACS and assessed as low-risk (less than 1% 30-day risk of death or MACE), it is appropriate to discharge them home without hospital admission or immediate cardiac testing.

original: In pregnant women with HCM, fetal echocar- diography may be considered for diagnosis of fetal HCM in the context of prenatal counseling. 6.4. Comorbidities Table 9 addresses lifestyle considerations for patients with HCM. Recommendations for Patients With Comorbidities Referenced studies that support the recommendations are summarized in Online Data Supplement 21. COR LOE Recommendations
paraphrased: For pregnant women with HCM, fetal echocardiography can be considered to diagnose fetal HCM as part of prenatal counseling.

original: In pregnant women with HCM, it is reason- able to perform serial echocardiography, par- ticularly during the second or third trimester when hemodynamic load is highest, or if clini- cal symptoms develop.309
paraphrased: For pregnant women with HCM, conducting regular echocardiograms is advisable, especially in the second or third trimester when the hemodynamic load peaks, or if clinical symptoms arise.

original: In patients with a suspected AAS, TEE and MRI are reasonable alternatives for initial diagnostic imaging.1-6
paraphrased: For patients with a suspected AAS, TEE and MRI are suitable options for initial diagnostic imaging.

original: In patients with HCM, adherence to the guidelines on the prevention of atheroscle- rotic cardiovascular disease is recommended to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.294
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is advised to follow the guidelines for preventing atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease to lower the risk of cardiovascular events.

original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant aortoiliac or femoropopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), surgical revascularization is reasonable if perioperative risk is acceptable and technical factors suggest advantages over endovascular approaches.29–31 Revascularization for Claudication: Common Femoral Artery Disease
paraphrased: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant aortoiliac or femoropopliteal disease who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, surgical revascularization is a reasonable option if the perioperative risk is acceptable and technical considerations favor it over endovascular methods.

original: Mechanical circulatory support, such as intra- aortic balloon pump or VA-ECMO, is reasonable for cardiogenic shock from sympathomimetic poi- soning refractory to other treatment measures.
paraphrased: For cardiogenic shock due to sympathomimetic poisoning that does not respond to other treatments, using mechanical circulatory support like an intra-aortic balloon pump or VA-ECMO is a reasonable option.

original: Prolonged use of physical restraint without sedation is potentially harmful. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: Extended application of physical restraint without sedation may be detrimental.

original: In patients presenting to the hospital with AAS, prompt treatment with anti-impulse therapy with invasive monitoring of BP with an arterial line in an ICU setting is recommended as initial treatment to decrease aortic wall stress.1-5
paraphrased: For patients admitted with AAS, it is advised to initiate anti-impulse therapy and closely monitor blood pressure using an arterial line in an ICU to reduce stress on the aortic wall.

original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant common femoral artery disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), surgical endarterectomy is reasonable, especially if endovascular approaches adversely affect profunda femoris artery pathways.32,33
paraphrased: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication and significant hemodynamic impairment of the common femoral artery who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, surgical endarterectomy is a reasonable option, particularly if endovascular methods negatively impact the profunda femoris artery pathways.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, management in an observation unit is reasonable to shorten length of stay and lower cost relative to an inpatient admission.1-7
paraphrased: For patients with acute chest pain who are at intermediate risk, it is reasonable to manage them in an observation unit to reduce both the duration of their stay and the associated costs compared to inpatient admission.

original: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss294 and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.314–316
paraphrased: For patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, it is advised to provide counseling and implement comprehensive lifestyle changes to achieve and sustain weight loss, which may also reduce the risk of LVOTO, HF, and AF.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, TTE is recommended as a rapid, bedside test to establish baseline ventricular and valvular function, evaluate for wall motion abnormalities, and to assess for pericardial effusion.
paraphrased: For patients with acute chest pain at intermediate risk, a TTE is advised as a quick, bedside examination to determine baseline ventricular and valvular function, check for wall motion abnormalities, and detect pericardial effusion.

original: It is reasonable to use VA-ECMO for persistent cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest due to poison- ing that is not responsive to maximal treatment measures.
paraphrased: VA-ECMO may be appropriately utilized for ongoing cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest resulting from poisoning when maximal treatment efforts fail to yield a response.

original: Patients with AAS should be treated to an SBP <120 mm Hg or to lowest BP that main- tains adequate end-organ perfusion, as well as to a target heart rate of 60 to 80 bpm.3,6
paraphrased: For patients with AAS, aim to achieve a systolic blood pressure below 120 mm Hg or the lowest level that ensures sufficient end-organ perfusion, and maintain a heart rate between 60 and 80 bpm.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD eligible for diagnostic testing after a negative or inconclusive evaluation for ACS, CCTA is useful for exclusion of atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.1-11
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk with acute chest pain and no history of CAD, who are suitable for diagnostic testing following a negative or inconclusive ACS assessment, CCTA is beneficial for ruling out atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.

original: It is reasonable to use VA-ECMO for persistent dysrhythmias due to poisoning when other treat- ment measures fail.
paraphrased: VA-ECMO can be considered for persistent dysrhythmias caused by poisoning when other treatments are ineffective.

original: In patients with HCM and hypertension, lifestyle modifications and medical therapy for hypertension are recommended294 with preference for beta blockers and non-dihydro- pyridine calcium channel blockers in patients with obstructive HCM.310,316–319
paraphrased: For patients with HCM and high blood pressure, it is advised to implement lifestyle changes and use antihypertensive medication, prioritizing beta blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers for those with obstructive HCM.

original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant common femoral artery disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), endovascular approaches may be considered in those at high risk for surgical revascularization and/or if anatomical factors are favorable (ie, no adverse effect on profunda femoris artery pathways).33–40 Revascularization for Claudication: Infrapopliteal Disease
paraphrased: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant disease of the common femoral artery who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, endovascular methods can be considered if they are at high surgical risk and/or if anatomical conditions are suitable, such as no negative impact on the profunda femoris artery pathways.

original: In patients with AAS, initial management should include intravenous beta blockers, except in patients with contraindications.2,5,7
paraphrased: For patients with AAS, intravenous beta blockers should be administered initially, unless contraindications are present.

original: In patients with HCM, assessment for symptoms of sleep disordered breathing is recommended and, if present, referral to a sleep medicine specialist for evaluation and treatment.320–323 ACC/AHA JOINT COMMITTEE MEMBERS
paraphrased: For patients with HCM, it is advised to evaluate for symptoms of sleep disordered breathing, and if detected, to refer them to a sleep medicine specialist for further assessment and management.

original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and isolated hemodynamically significant infrapopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), the effectiveness of endovascular revascularization is unknown.41
paraphrased: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication due to isolated hemodynamically significant infrapopliteal disease who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, the efficacy of endovascular revascularization remains uncertain.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, moderate-severe ischemia on current or prior (≤1 year) stress testing, and no known CAD established by prior anatomic testing,
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk experiencing acute chest pain, who show moderate to severe ischemia on recent or past (within 1 year) stress tests, and have no previously identified CAD from anatomical testing,

original: The effectiveness of VA-ECMO for poisoned patients with cardiovascular collapse from causes other than cardiogenic shock has not been estab- lished. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: The efficacy of VA-ECMO in treating poisoned patients experiencing cardiovascular collapse due to non-cardiogenic shock remains unproven.

original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and isolated hemodynamically significant infrapop- liteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), the effectiveness of surgical revascularization is unknown.42
paraphrased: For patients experiencing functionally limiting claudication due to isolated hemodynamically significant infrapopliteal disease who do not adequately respond to GDMT, including structured exercise, the efficacy of surgical revascularization remains uncertain.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain with evidence of previous mildly abnormal stress test results (≤1 year), CCTA is reasonable for diagnosing obstructive CAD.12,13 Stress Testing
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk experiencing acute chest pain and having mildly abnormal stress test results from within the past year, CCTA is a suitable option for diagnosing obstructive CAD.

original: In patients with AAS, initial management should include intravenous vasodilators if the BP is not well controlled after initiation of intravenous beta-blocker therapy.8
paraphrased: For patients with AAS, if blood pressure remains uncontrolled following the start of intravenous beta-blockers, intravenous vasodilators should be included in the initial treatment.

original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, stress positron emission tomography/single photon emission CT myocardial perfusion imaging (PET/ SPECT MPI), cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging, or stress echocardiography is recommended to detect the presence and extent of myocardial ischemia, estimate risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), and guide therapeutic decision-making.*1–23
paraphrased: For patients with CCD experiencing persistent changes in symptoms or functional capacity despite GDMT, it is advised to use stress PET/SPECT MPI, CMR imaging, or stress echocardiography to identify myocardial ischemia, assess the risk of MACE, and inform treatment decisions.

original: Patients with AAS should be treated with pain control, as needed, to help with hemodynamic management.
paraphrased: For patients with AAS, administer pain relief as necessary to assist in managing hemodynamics.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD who are eligible for cardiac testing, either exercise ECG, stress echocardiography, stress PET/SPECT MPI, or stress CMR is useful for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.1,4,10,14-36 Sequential or Add-on Diagnostic Testing
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk with acute chest pain and no history of coronary artery disease who qualify for cardiac evaluation, exercise ECG, stress echocardiography, stress PET/SPECT MPI, or stress CMR can effectively diagnose myocardial ischemia.

original: In patients who are undergoing surgical revascu- larization for functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant femoropopliteal disease, bypass to the popliteal artery with autogenous vein is recommended in preference to prosthetic graft material.1–5
paraphrased: For patients receiving surgical revascularization due to functionally limiting claudication and significant femoropopliteal disease, it is advised to use an autogenous vein for bypass to the popliteal artery rather than a prosthetic graft.

original: In patients with CLTI, a multispecialty care team should evaluate and provide comprehensive care with goals of complete wound healing, minimizing tissue loss, and preservation of ambulatory status.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI, a multidisciplinary team should assess and deliver holistic care aimed at achieving full wound healing, reducing tissue loss, and maintaining the ability to walk.

original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, invasive coronary angiography (ICA) is recommended for guiding therapeutic decision-making with the goal of improving anginal symptoms.*24–28
paraphrased: For patients with CCD who experience persistent changes in symptoms or functional capacity despite GDMT, it is advised to perform invasive coronary angiography (ICA) to guide treatment decisions aimed at alleviating anginal symptoms.*24–28

original: In patients with AAS, it is recommended to treat with long-term beta blockers (unless contraindicated) to control heart rate and BP to reduce late aortic-related adverse events.1-7 Additional antihypertensive agents (particu- larly ARBs and ACEIs) should be added, as necessary, to adequately control BP.
paraphrased: For patients with AAS, long-term beta blocker therapy is advised to manage heart rate and blood pressure, thereby minimizing late aortic-related complications, unless contraindicated. Additional antihypertensive medications, especially ARBs and ACEIs, should be included as needed to ensure proper blood pressure control.

original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, when selected for rest/stress nuclear MPI, PET is reasonable in preference to SPECT, if available, to improve diagnostic accuracy and decrease the rate of nondiagnostic test results.*29
paraphrased: For patients with CCD experiencing persistent changes in symptoms or functional capacity despite GDMT, choosing PET over SPECT for rest/stress nuclear MPI is advisable, if accessible, to enhance diagnostic precision and reduce nondiagnostic outcomes.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, with a coronary artery stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle coronary artery on CCTA, FFR-CT can be useful for the diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia and to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.37-43
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk who experience acute chest pain and have no history of coronary artery disease, and who show a 40% to 90% stenosis in a proximal or middle coronary artery on CCTA, FFR-CT may aid in diagnosing vessel-specific ischemia and assist in determining the need for coronary revascularization.

original: In patients with CLTI, surgical, endovascular, or hybrid revascularization techniques are recommended, when feasible, to minimize tissue loss, heal wounds, relieve pain, and preserve a functional limb.1–14
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI, it is advised to use surgical, endovascular, or hybrid revascularization methods, if possible, to reduce tissue loss, promote wound healing, alleviate pain, and maintain limb functionality.

original: In patients presenting with suspected or con- firmed acute type A aortic dissection, emer- gency surgical consultation and evaluation and immediate surgical intervention is recom- mended because of the high risk of associated life-threatening complications.1,2
paraphrased: For patients with suspected or confirmed acute type A aortic dissection, it is advised to seek emergency surgical consultation and evaluation, followed by prompt surgical intervention, due to the high risk of life-threatening complications.

original: In patients with CLTI, an evaluation for revasculariza- tion options by a multispecialty care team is recom- mended before amputation (Table 15). Revascularization Strategy for CLTI
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI, it is advised to assess revascularization options with a multispecialty care team prior to considering amputation (Table 15).

original: In patients presenting with acute type A aortic dissection, who are stable enough for transfer, transfer from a low- to a high- volume aortic center is reasonable to improve survival.3,4
paraphrased: For patients with acute type A aortic dissection who are stable for transport, it is advisable to move them from a low-volume to a high-volume aortic center to enhance survival chances.

original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, exercise treadmill testing can be useful to determine whether the symptoms are consistent with angina pectoris, assess the severity of symptoms, evaluate functional capacity, and guide management.*26,30–32
paraphrased: For patients with CCD experiencing persistent changes in symptoms or functional capacity despite GDMT, exercise treadmill testing may be beneficial to ascertain if the symptoms align with angina pectoris, to evaluate symptom severity, assess functional capacity, and inform management strategies.*26,30–32

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, as well as an inconclusive prior stress test, CCTA can be useful for excluding the presence of atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk who experience acute chest pain, have no history of CAD, and have had an inconclusive stress test, CCTA is beneficial for ruling out atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.

original: In patients undergoing surgical revascularization for CLTI, bypass to the popliteal or infrapopliteal arteries (ie, tibial, pedal) should be constructed with autog- enous vein if available.14–20
paraphrased: For patients having surgical revascularization for CLTI, an autogenous vein should be used for bypass to the popliteal or infrapopliteal arteries (such as tibial or pedal) if it is available.

original: In patients with CCD undergoing stress PET MPI or stress CMR imaging, the addition of myocardial blood flow reserve (MBFR) can be useful to improve diagnostic accuracy and enhance risk stratification.*18–23
paraphrased: For patients with CCD who are having stress PET MPI or stress CMR imaging, incorporating myocardial blood flow reserve (MBFR) can be beneficial for increasing diagnostic precision and improving risk assessment.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, with an inconclusive CCTA, stress imaging (with echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI, or CMR) can be useful for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk who experience acute chest pain without a history of CAD and have an inconclusive CCTA, stress imaging using echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI, or CMR may aid in diagnosing myocardial ischemia.

original: In patients presenting with nonhemorrhagic stroke complicating acute type A aortic dis- section, surgical intervention is reasonable over medical therapy to reduce mortality and improve neurologic outcomes.5,6
paraphrased: For patients with nonhemorrhagic stroke due to acute type A aortic dissection, opting for surgical treatment rather than medical management is advisable to lower mortality and enhance neurological outcomes.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection presenting with renal, mesenteric, or lower extremity malperfusion, it is recommended to proceed to immediate operative repair of the ascending aorta.1,2
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute type A aortic dissection with renal, mesenteric, or lower extremity malperfusion, immediate surgical repair of the ascending aorta is advised.

original: In patients with CLTI due to infrainguinal disease, anatomy, available conduit, patient comorbidities, and patient preferences should be considered in selecting the optimal first revascularization strategy (surgical bypass or endovascular revascularization) (Table 16).3,13
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI caused by infrainguinal disease, the choice of the best initial revascularization approach—either surgical bypass or endovascular revascularization—should take into account the anatomy, available conduit, patient comorbidities, and patient preferences.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain who have known CAD and present with new onset or worsening symptoms, GDMT should be optimized before additional cardiac testing is performed.1,2 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk experiencing acute chest pain with existing CAD and new or worsening symptoms, GDMT should be maximized prior to conducting further cardiac evaluations.

original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, and who have had previous coronary revascularization, coronary CT angiography (CCTA) is reasonable to evaluate bypass graft or stent patency (for stents ≥3 mm).*33–37 *Modified from the 2021 AHA/ACC/Multisociety Guideline for the Evaluation and Diagnosis of Chest Pain.38
paraphrased: For patients with CCD experiencing persistent changes in symptoms or functional capacity despite GDMT, and who have undergone coronary revascularization, it is reasonable to use coronary CT angiography (CCTA) to assess the patency of bypass grafts or stents (for stents ≥3 mm).*33–37 *Adapted from the 2021 AHA/ACC/Multisociety Guideline for the Evaluation and Diagnosis of Chest Pain.38

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain who have worsening frequency of symptoms with significant left main, proximal left anterior descending stenosis, or multivessel CAD on prior anatomic testing or history of prior coronary revascularization, ICA is recommended.3-8
paraphrased: For intermediate-risk patients experiencing acute chest pain with increasing symptom frequency and significant stenosis in the left main, proximal left anterior descending artery, or multivessel coronary artery disease as shown in previous anatomic tests or with a history of coronary revascularization, ICA is advised.

original: In patients with CCD, it is recommended that risk stratification incorporate all available information, including noninvasive, invasive, or both cardiovascular diagnostic testing results or use validated risk scores to classify patients as low (<1%), intermediate (1%-3%), or high (>3%) yearly risk for cardiovascular death or nonfatal MI.1–4 Relationship to Treatment
paraphrased: For patients with CCD, it is advised to use all accessible data, whether from noninvasive, invasive, or both types of cardiovascular diagnostic tests, or to apply validated risk scores to categorize patients into low (<1%), intermediate (1%-3%), or high (>3%) annual risk for cardiovascular death or nonfatal MI.

original: In patients with CLTI who are candidates for surgical bypass and endovascular revascularization, ultrasound mapping of the great saphenous vein is recom- mended.3,13
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI eligible for both surgical bypass and endovascular revascularization, it is advised to perform ultrasound mapping of the great saphenous vein.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection presenting with clinically significant mesen- teric (celiac, SMA) malperfusion, either imme- diate operative repair of the ascending aorta or immediate mesenteric revascularization via endovascular or open surgical intervention by those with this expertise before ascending aortic repair is reasonable.3-6
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute type A aortic dissection with significant mesenteric malperfusion (celiac, SMA), it is reasonable to either proceed with immediate surgical repair of the ascending aorta or perform immediate mesenteric revascularization through endovascular or open surgery by specialists before addressing the ascending aorta.

original: In patients with CCD, optimization of GDMT is recommended to reduce MACE.*5–7
paraphrased: For patients with CCD, it is advised to optimize GDMT to decrease MACE.*5–7

original: In patients with CLTI for whom a surgical approach is selected and a suitable autogenous vein is unavailable, alternative conduits such as prosthetic or cadaveric grafts can be effective for bypass to the popliteal and tibial arteries.21–26
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI who are chosen for surgery and lack an appropriate autogenous vein, prosthetic or cadaveric grafts may serve as effective alternatives for bypassing the popliteal and tibial arteries.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and known nonobstructive CAD, CCTA can be useful to determine progression of atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.9-11
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk who experience acute chest pain and have known nonobstructive coronary artery disease, CCTA may be beneficial in assessing the advancement of atherosclerotic plaque and the presence of obstructive coronary artery disease.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection and a partially dissected aortic root but no significant aortic valve leaflet pathology, aortic valve resuspension is recommended over valve replacement.1-5
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute type A aortic dissection with a partially dissected aortic root and no major issues with the aortic valve leaflets, it is advised to perform aortic valve resuspension instead of valve replacement.

original: In patients with CLTI and nonhealing wounds or gangrene, revascularization in a manner that achieves in-line blood flow or maximizes perfusion to the wound bed can be beneficial.27–33
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI and nonhealing wounds or gangrene, performing revascularization to ensure direct blood flow or enhance perfusion to the wound area can be advantageous.

original: In patients with CCD with newly reduced LV systolic function, clinical heart failure, or both, ICA is recommended to assess coronary anatomy and guide potential revascularization.8,9
paraphrased: For patients with CCD who have newly decreased LV systolic function, clinical heart failure, or both, ICA is advised to evaluate coronary anatomy and direct possible revascularization.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and coronary artery stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle segment on CCTA, FFR-CT is reasonable for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia and to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.12-17
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk who present with acute chest pain and have coronary artery stenosis ranging from 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle segment as seen on CCTA, using FFR-CT is a reasonable approach to diagnose vessel-specific ischemia and assist in determining the need for coronary revascularization.

original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and known CAD who have new onset or worsening symptoms, stress imaging (PET/ SPECT MPI, CMR, or stress echocardiography) is reasonable.18-21
paraphrased: For patients at intermediate risk with acute chest pain and established coronary artery disease experiencing new or worsening symptoms, it is appropriate to consider stress imaging such as PET/SPECT MPI, CMR, or stress echocardiography.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection who have extensive destruction of the aortic root, a root aneurysm, or a known genetic aor- tic disorder, aortic root replacement is recom- mended with a mechanical or biological valved conduit.6-9
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute type A aortic dissection with significant damage to the aortic root, presence of a root aneurysm, or an identified genetic aortic condition, it is advised to perform aortic root replacement using either a mechanical or biological valved conduit.

original: In patients with CCD, ICA for risk stratification is not routinely recommended in patients without LV systolic dysfunction, heart failure, stable chest pain refractory to GDMT, and/or noninvasive testing sug- gestive of significant (>50%) left main disease.5–7,10,11 *Modified from the 2021 AHA/ACC/Multisociety Guideline for the Evaluation and Diagnosis of Chest Pain.12
paraphrased: For patients with CCD, ICA for risk assessment is generally not advised unless they have LV systolic dysfunction, heart failure, stable chest pain unresponsive to GDMT, or noninvasive tests indicating significant (>50%) left main disease.

original: In patients with CLTI with ischemic rest pain (ie, with- out nonhealing wounds or gangrene) attributable to multilevel arterial disease, a revascularization strategy addressing inflow disease first is reasonable.34,35
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI experiencing ischemic rest pain without nonhealing wounds or gangrene due to multilevel arterial disease, it is reasonable to first pursue a revascularization approach targeting inflow disease.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissec- tion undergoing aortic repair, an open distal anastomosis is recommended to improve survival and increase false-lumen thrombosis rates.12-15
paraphrased: For patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing aortic repair, performing an open distal anastomosis is advised to enhance survival and raise the rates of false-lumen thrombosis.

original: Patients with CLTI and diabetic foot ulcers should receive pressure offloading, when possible, to promote tissue growth and wound healing.1–9
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI and diabetic foot ulcers, pressure offloading should be implemented, if feasible, to enhance tissue regeneration and wound healing.

original: In patients with CCD, clinical follow-up at least annually is recommended to assess for symptoms,1–12 change in functional status, adherence to and adequacy of lifestyle and medical interventions,13–15 and monitoring for complications of CCD and its treatments.16–18
paraphrased: For patients with CCD, it is advised to conduct clinical evaluations at least once a year to monitor symptoms, changes in functional status, compliance with and effectiveness of lifestyle and medical treatments, and to check for complications related to CCD and its therapies.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissec- tion without an intimal tear in the arch or a significant arch aneurysm, hemiarch repair is recommended over more extensive arch replacement.16-18
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute type A aortic dissection without an intimal tear in the arch or a notable arch aneurysm, hemiarch repair is advised instead of a more extensive arch replacement.

original: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who have new ischemic changes on electrocardiography, troponin- confirmed acute myocardial injury, new- onset left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction <40%), newly diagnosed moderate-severe ischemia on stress testing, hemodynamic instability, and/or a high clinical decision pathway (CDP) risk score should be designated as high risk for short-term MACE.1-3
paraphrased: Patients experiencing acute chest pain with suspected ACS should be considered at high risk for short-term MACE if they exhibit new ischemic changes on ECG, troponin-confirmed acute myocardial injury, new-onset left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction below 40%), newly diagnosed moderate to severe ischemia on stress testing, hemodynamic instability, and/or a high risk score on the clinical decision pathway (CDP).

original: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are designated as high risk, ICA is recommended.4-7
paraphrased: For individuals experiencing acute chest pain with suspected ACS and classified as high risk, ICA is advised.

original: In patients with CCD, use of a validated CCD-specific patient-reported health status measure may be reasonable to assess symptoms, functional status, and QOL.19–23
paraphrased: For patients with CCD, employing a validated patient-reported health status tool specific to CCD can be a reasonable approach to evaluate symptoms, functional status, and quality of life.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissec- tion and a dissection flap extending through the arch into the descending thoracic aorta, an extended aortic repair with antegrade stenting of the proximal descending thoracic aorta may be considered to treat malperfu- sion and reduce late distal aortic complica- tions.19,20 Perfusion and Cannulation Strategies
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute type A aortic dissection with a dissection flap reaching from the arch into the descending thoracic aorta, considering an extended aortic repair that includes antegrade stenting of the proximal descending thoracic aorta may help address malperfusion and decrease the risk of future distal aortic complications.

original: For high-risk patients with acute chest pain who are troponin positive in whom obstructive CAD has been excluded by CCTA or ICA, CMR or echocardiography can be effective in establishing alternative diagnoses.8-12
paraphrased: For high-risk patients experiencing acute chest pain with positive troponin levels, where obstructive CAD has been ruled out by CCTA or ICA, CMR or echocardiography may be useful in identifying other diagnoses.

original: Patients with PAD and previous diabetic foot ulcers should be referred for customized footwear that accommodates, protects, and fits the shape of their feet.10–12
paraphrased: Patients with PAD and a history of diabetic foot ulcers should be directed to obtain personalized footwear that conforms to, safeguards, and fits their foot shape.

original: In patients with CCD, a multidisciplinary team- based approach is recommended to improve health outcomes, facilitate modification of ASCVD risk factors, and improve health service utilization.*1–13 *Modified from the 2019 ACC/AHA Guideline on the Primary Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease.14
paraphrased: For patients with CCD, it is advised to employ a multidisciplinary team approach to enhance health outcomes, aid in adjusting ASCVD risk factors, and optimize the use of health services.

original: In patients with prior CABG surgery presenting with acute chest pain who do not have ACS, performing stress imaging is effective to evaluate for myocardial ischemia or CCTA for graft stenosis or occlusion.1-7
paraphrased: For patients with a history of CABG surgery experiencing acute chest pain without ACS, stress imaging is useful to assess myocardial ischemia, or CCTA can be used to check for graft stenosis or occlusion.

original: Patients with CLTI and foot ulcers who do not have diabetes may be considered for pressure offloading to promote tissue growth and wound healing.
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI and foot ulcers without diabetes, pressure offloading can be considered to enhance tissue regeneration and wound healing.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing surgical repair, axillary cannula- tion, when feasible, is reasonable over femoral cannulation to reduce the risk of stroke or retrograde malperfusion.21,22
paraphrased: For patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing surgery, opting for axillary cannulation instead of femoral cannulation is advisable, when possible, to lower the risk of stroke or retrograde malperfusion.

original: In patients with CLTI, prompt management of foot infection with antibiotics, debridement, and other surgical management is recommended.1–5
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI, it is advised to quickly address foot infections using antibiotics, debridement, and other surgical interventions.

original: Patients with CCD should receive ongoing individualized education on symptom management, lifestyle changes, and SDOH risk factors to improve knowledge and facilitate behavior change.1
paraphrased: Individuals with CCD should be continuously educated on managing symptoms, modifying lifestyle, and understanding SDOH risk factors to enhance their knowledge and promote behavioral changes.

original: Patients with CCD should receive ongoing individualized education on medication adherence to improve knowledge and facilitate behavior change.2–4
paraphrased: Patients with CCD should be continuously educated on a personal basis about adhering to their medication regimen to enhance understanding and promote behavioral modifications.

original: In patients with prior CABG surgery presenting with acute chest pain, who do not have ACS8-14 or who have an indeterminate/nondiagnostic stress test, ICA is useful.8
paraphrased: For patients with a history of CABG surgery experiencing acute chest pain, who neither have ACS8-14 nor a conclusive stress test, ICA is beneficial.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dis- section undergoing surgical repair who require circulatory arrest, cerebral perfusion is reasonable to improve neurologic out- comes.23-25
paraphrased: For patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing surgery that necessitates circulatory arrest, using cerebral perfusion is advisable to enhance neurological outcomes.

original: In patients with CLTI with nonhealing wounds, wound care should be provided to optimize the wound-healing environment after revascularization with the goal of complete wound healing.6–10
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI and nonhealing wounds, it is essential to deliver wound care to enhance the healing environment following revascularization, aiming for full wound closure.

original: In patients who experience acute unremitting chest pain while undergoing dialysis, transfer by EMS to an acute care setting is recommended.1-5
paraphrased: For patients undergoing dialysis who have persistent acute chest pain, it is advised to transport them via EMS to an acute care facility.

original: In patients with acute type A aortic dis- section undergoing surgical repair, direct aortic26,27 or innominate artery28 cannula- tion with imaging guidance is reasonable as an alternative to femoral or axillary ­cannulation.29-31
paraphrased: For patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing surgery, it is reasonable to consider direct cannulation of the aorta or innominate artery with imaging guidance as an alternative to femoral or axillary cannulation.

original: Patients with CCD and their clinicians should engage in shared decision-making particularly when evidence is unclear on the optimal diagnostic or treatment strategy, or when a significant risk or benefit tradeoff exists.1–3
paraphrased: Clinicians and patients with CCD should participate in shared decision-making, especially when the best diagnostic or treatment approach is uncertain or when there are notable risk-benefit considerations.

original: In all patients with uncomplicated acute type B aortic dissection, medical therapy is recommended as the initial management strategy.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with uncomplicated acute type B aortic dissection, it is advised to begin treatment with medical management.

original: In patients with CLTI with nonhealing diabetic foot ulcers, hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be considered to assist in wound healing after revascularization.11–14
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI who have diabetic foot ulcers that are not healing, hyperbaric oxygen therapy can be contemplated as an aid for wound healing following revascularization.

original: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, it is reasonable to consider cocaine and methamphetamine use as a cause of their symptoms.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with sudden chest pain, evaluating the possibility of cocaine and methamphetamine use as a cause of their symptoms is advisable.

original: In patients with CLTI for whom revascularization is not an option and a lack of outflow to the foot is observed, the usefulness of prostanoids is uncertain.1–3
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI who cannot undergo revascularization and exhibit inadequate blood flow to the foot, the effectiveness of prostanoids remains unclear.

original: For patients with CCD and angina on GDMT who are engaged in shared decision-making regarding revascularization, a validated decision aid may be considered to improve patient understanding and knowledge about treatment options.4
paraphrased: For patients with CCD and angina on GDMT involved in shared decision-making about revascularization, using a validated decision aid can be considered to enhance their understanding and knowledge of treatment options.

original: In patients with acute type B aortic dissection and rupture or other complications (Table 27), intervention is recommended.4-6
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute type B aortic dissection accompanied by rupture or other complications (refer to Table 27), it is advised to proceed with intervention.

original: In patients with CCD, routine assessment by clinicians and the care team for SDOH is recom- mended to inform patient-centered treatment deci- sions and lifestyle change recommendations.*1–8 *Modified from the 2019 ACC/AHA Guideline on the Primary Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease.9
paraphrased: For individuals with CCD, it is advised that clinicians and the care team regularly evaluate SDOH to guide personalized treatment choices and lifestyle change suggestions.

original: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are deemed low risk by a CDP, patient decision aids are beneficial to improve understanding and effectively facilitate risk communication.1,2
paraphrased: For individuals experiencing acute chest pain with suspected ACS and classified as low risk by a CDP, using patient decision aids enhances comprehension and aids in effective risk communication.

original: In patients with uncomplicated acute type B aortic dissection who have high-risk anatomic features (Table 28), endovascular manage- ment may be considered.8,9
paraphrased: For patients with uncomplicated acute type B aortic dissection and high-risk anatomical characteristics (refer to Table 28), endovascular treatment can be considered.

original: In patients with CLTI for whom revascularization is not an option, arterial intermittent pneumatic compression devices may be considered to augment wound healing or ameliorate ischemic rest pain.4–7
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI who cannot undergo revascularization, using arterial intermittent pneumatic compression devices might be an option to enhance wound healing or reduce ischemic rest pain.

original: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are deemed intermediate risk by a CDP, shared decision-making between the clinician and patient regarding the need for admission, for observation, discharge, or further evaluation in an outpatient setting is recommended for improving patient understanding and reducing low-value testing.1,2
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute chest pain with suspected ACS classified as intermediate risk by a CDP, it is advised to engage in shared decision-making between the clinician and patient about whether to admit for observation, discharge, or pursue further evaluation in an outpatient setting, to enhance patient comprehension and minimize unnecessary testing.

original: In patients with CCD, a diet emphasizing vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, whole grains, and lean protein is recommended to reduce the risk of CVD events.*1–4
paraphrased: For patients with CCD, it is advised to follow a diet rich in vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, whole grains, and lean proteins to lower the risk of CVD events.

original: In patients with CLTI for whom arterial revascularization is not an option and a lack of outflow to the foot is observed, venous arterialization may be considered for limb preservation.8–12
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI who cannot undergo arterial revascularization and have no outflow to the foot, venous arterialization might be an option for preserving the limb.

original: In patients with complicated (Table 29) acute type A or type B aortic IMH, urgent repair is recommended.1-3
paraphrased: For patients with complicated acute type A or type B aortic IMH, immediate repair is advised.

original: In patients with acute chest pain in whom other potentially life-threatening nonischemic cardiac conditions are suspected (eg, aortic pathology, pericardial effusion, endocarditis), TTE is recommended for diagnosis.
paraphrased: For patients experiencing acute chest pain where other serious nonischemic cardiac conditions are suspected, such as aortic abnormalities, pericardial effusion, or endocarditis, it is advised to use TTE for diagnostic purposes.

original: In patients with uncomplicated acute type A IMH, prompt open surgical repair is recom- mended.1,4-6
paraphrased: For patients with uncomplicated acute type A IMH, immediate open surgical repair is advised.

original: In patients with CLTI who require amputation, evaluation should be performed by a multispecialty care team (Table 15) to assess for the most distal level of amputation that facilitates healing and provides maximal functional ability.1–6
paraphrased: For patients with CLTI needing amputation, a multispecialty care team should evaluate to determine the most distal amputation level that promotes healing and maximizes functional capacity.

original: In patients with CCD, reducing the percentage of calories from saturated fat (<6% of total calories) and replacing with dietary monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fat, complex carbohydrates, and dietary fiber can be beneficial to reduce the risk of CVD events.*1–6
paraphrased: For individuals with CCD, lowering saturated fat intake to less than 6% of total calories and substituting it with monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats, complex carbohydrates, and dietary fiber may help decrease the risk of CVD events.
